content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Let me preface this by saying I only recommend this game if you are invested in the trilogy's story, because it does end the trilogy and the story did have it's moments.  But as an overall game, it gets a C+ in comparison to Arkham City's A+ in my books.This review is not about the ineptitude and failure to deliver a good port, or how the game runs.  Because for me the game ran perfectly fine.  I have a system that could run it at 60fps just fine.  I was one of the lucky ones.Therefore I waited until I completed the game, and this will be a review of the actual game itself, and will contain spoilers.  For Knight and for Arkham City, maybe a little for Asylum, because I have to make this comparison.If you were to ask me which of the Arkham games was the best.  Far and away it would be City.  Knight in comparison feels, lazy, and the Batmobile segments feel forced, far too often do you use the Batmobile for miniscule things, like Riddler tasks.  Why would the Riddler design a underground racetrack for the Batmobile?  His entire premise is about Riddles.So why you ask is City a better game.  Well.  The Boss Battles.  Not only did City make you "Feel" like the Batman, it made some of it's most distinguished villains feel memorable.  Bane in Asylum was a good, classic, Nintendo era style boss fight.  Dodge him a few times, nail him in the back with Batarangs, take him on and rip his hoses out.  Freeze in City is by far one of the better boss fights I've ever played in a game.  I've never fought a boss that would actually block off a method of taking him on after you used it before.  Solomon Grundy in City, much like Bane from Asylum, was a big brute you had to dodge a lot and actually fight.  Even Ra's Al Ghul himself in City, or Clayface in City.  Were far and away, better than any boss you will fight in Arkham Knight.This is why City is the better game.  Compare those fights in City to what you get in Knight.  Your first fight with the Arkham Knight is in a bloody tank.  He doesn't even fight you himself, he sits in a tank.  Yes, this is the first use of the Batmobile gimmick.  You continue to play along, man, doesn't seem to be many bosses in this game... oh wait heres the Second Encounter with the Arkham Knight.  Guess what?  He's in a bigger ♥♥♥♥ing bloody tank that can drill underground, which you run from in the Batmobile gimmick 3 more times.  Awesome, done with that.  Time to rescue Gordon.  Heres out first encounter with the Red Hood, unmasked lazily Jason Todd is the Arkham Knight, woo way to throw a twist in there Rocksteady.  Red Hood isn't even a boss, he's 4 glorified Predator rooms linked together to defeat him... thats it.  Thats the last you'll see of the Red Hood till the end of the game.  What a boss fight.  So The Arkham Knight/Red Hood is gone, so who takes over for him? Good old Deathstroke, but don't worry, you won't get to actually fight Deathstroke. They recycle the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Tank encounter you had with the Knight the first time for this lazily thought out "Boss Battle".  And I'm not even going to spoiler tag this, I'm going to spell it out for you clearly, THERE IS NO FINAL BOSS BATTLE IN THIS GAME.  You never fight Crane.  You go to him for the final moment of the game,  You do actually fight the "Fear Toxin" and Lock away Joker in your head but there is literally no satisfying boss fight in this game.  At all.I wanted to like Knight, and I enjoyed my time in Gotham City doing all of the various tasks.  But even those Tasks.  Where you capture the other big name villains in the game like Two-Face, Penguin, Firefly, Pyg, Riddler, Deathstroke.  Not a single one of them, in any shape or form, has a memorable boss fight.  They are bullet points at the end of a task list.  You finish 100% of the tasks in their chain and you capture them pretty much effortlessly.  This is absolutely disappointing and lazy.  They are Supervillains.  They are Batman's most lethal and ruthless adversaries.  And they turned them into fetch tasks.There where other things missing from this game.  These 2 bothered me the most.  The Duel Stealth Takedown option is gone.  Replaced with the Fear Takedown.  Thats great, I can Chain Takedown 5 guys (At max'd skill)... but I have to do it loud.  So if I sneak up on two guys who don't notice me, can I stealth takedown them?  Nope, I can Fear takedown them, loudly.... Why did Batman forget how to stealth takedown two guys?  Why was it necessary for him to forget how to do one essential Batman thing to learn how to do another?  That is ridiculous.  The other major thing missing from the game is the ability to freeroam as the other characters like you could in City after completeing the story.  Or any Predator/Wave room challenges with the other characters in the game.  Nightwing, Robin, Red Hood, Harley, Azrael, Catwoman... all Playable during the game at some point, or in the case of Harley and Red Hood DLC, but I can't take them for a spin anywhere else?  Come on Rocksteady.My advice to you is, if you want to play a Batman game, go back and play Arkham City.  Play a Batman game done right.  I love Rocksteady and I respect the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of what they did for Batman in the video game universe and the fact they tried to up the scale each and every game.  But the lack of anything memorable in Knight will forever be a stain on this series.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This is a disastrous launch, stay the hell away from this game until they patch it properly, even though i wouldn't bet on it.I'm running this on a oc'd 2600k@4.5Ghz and oc'd 970 @1080p with the latest drivers from nvidia. First of all, the framerate is capped at 30(!) fps. Great job devs, especially for a 2015 game. You can unlock it via the .ini file though, so let's ingnore this for now.I am launching the game again ready to enjoy glorious 60 fps gameplay...NOT! Even with all the gameworks crap turned off, i am getting dips to sub 30's while driving, gliding and various other situations making it pretty much unplayable at times. The graphics quality doesn't justify such terrible performance, i can't even imagine how the game runs on lower spec systems. Trying to tune the settings does little to no difference at all. Gpu usage in afterburner is unstable during gameplay from 40% to 80% which indicates the game is poorly coded and cant ulitilize gpus properly. Before you say my cpu is bottleneching my gpu, there are guys in the forums with latest oc'd intel cpus and TitanX facing the same issues.Rocksteady already admitted here http://community.wbgames.com/t5/Support-for-PC/PC-Performance-issues-we-hear-you/m-p/571341#U571341 that they tossed the pc version of the game to an "external PC development partner" so you can understand how much they appreciate us.Update 25/6: Well, apparently WarnerBros halted sales of the game until it is fixed. You can thank steam's new refund policy for that because i highly doubt they would do such a move with the old, no-refund system. I want to be positive that we will get the pc version that we deserve but I still advice everyone who is eligible to get a refund and wait until the game's new release. If it works properly, you can just buy it again. If it's not, you can tell them to f*ck off and move on. Don't forget, WB is in full damage control mode right now so we don't really know what to expect from them. Or when.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Bias: I am a dinosaur. But I wish to be as great as BatmanDespite the initial issues with the PC release, I decided to wait until the improvements were made.This installation of the Batman series was a great ending to the story.I really  enjoyed the new editions to the game : BatMobile and Combo Fighting. Both additions were enjoyable. I will say, if the combo fighting was integrated into other games by the developer (like in LOTR: Shadow of Mordor) it would be a great addition in future games.I enjoyed the story. Combined some different aspects I have read in the comics without spoiling the villain and who the Arkham Knight, I thought it was an interesting addition the the Batman Video Game Universe. The game dark and gritty environment made me feel I was in Gotham. It was also enjoyable to see Gotham city itself. From lower parts of the city to from the height from Wayne Tower to LexCorp.I will also add, I enjoyed this game to the point that I even completed all the riddler\'s riddles (I did not do this in AA, AC, or AO)One complaint, I will say is the repetitive nature of some missions (but that was the same in the other members of the series). Another was how much focus on Bat Mobile Missions. I initially enjoyed these, but further into the game, I found them to be quite annoying and bother some.I would give this game a 9/10. I would also rank it in the series second. Arkham Asylum > Arkham Knight > Arkham City > Arkham Origins. Those people would disagree with me. I did enjoy this story more then Arkham City.

												30 fps cap, horrible glitches, bad performance on enthusiast builds, don't waste your money on this piece of crapEdited 7/29.I have finished playing the game, and, technical issues aside, I still don't recommend it.The story is good, although I'm not a huge fan of the ending, but the whole gameplay is really bad. This port was poorly done. Controls are weird (Press 1 ten times to use a batmobile weapon, press alt+1 for a takedown, press Unasigned for combo batarang), they didn't even bother. I have a mouse with programable keys, so I could use those, but it should come to that. The batmobile is pretty cool at first, but it becomes a burden as you need it for almost everything you do. Drones was their response to the whole "Batman doens't kill" discussion, but you now have to battle wave after wave of drones, even in some boss battles that should have been the highlights of the game.Arkham City took Arkham Assylum and made it better, but Arkham Knight just couldn't do the same. Let's hope there's some cool DLC coming when they re-launch it in September...

												Heard about the horrible PC launch and skipped it. My system couldn't handle it anyway.But my Radeon 7870 2GB died. Bought GTX 1070 8GB. Then summer sale came up. Read the "recent reviews" that the game was already in a much better condition, so I bought it. After all my graphic card can now handle it.I'm still playing it, but so far only 8 hours now,  I didn't find any technical issues at all. All graphic settings max in 1080p, including all those nVidia specific settings (but use FXAA only), the game runs smoothly. The lowest fps I got was 56fps and it was very very very rarely. Read that 970 could handle it very well, too.So far I like the gameplay, the story (darkest in the series) and really enjoyed it. If you're a Batman fan, or just a action-adventure third person gamer fan, you should get this.Basically it's Arkham City plus Batmobile and with lots and lots of new features and improvements here and there. I understand that Batmobile is a little bit overused. Some even mock "Be the Batmobile" should be used instead of "Be the Batman". But overall, it's still a great game. One that shouldn't be missed if you have the system to handle it.Plus :Good story (so far)Great gameplayAmazing graphicsHell..it's Batman from RockSteadyMinus:A somewhat too much batmobile gameplay (but still okay for me)Inefficent use of VRAM PS. I read that it still doesn't play well with a few AMD cards, so do some research first if you own AMD cards. Or you can just buy it, try it in your AMD cards, and refund it if it doesn't work well.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												I love this game. It's far from perfect, but it's a great game nonetheless. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it, especially to fans of the previous games.Pros:-You are the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman-You get to drive the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batmobile-You can hang people upside down from gargoyles-Good story with a wide cast of villains-Great ending to the series-Amazing voice acting, as always-Lots of references that comic book fans will appreciate-The game looks fantastic, even on the lowest settings-Gotham itself is extremely detailed-Way less Riddler stuff than in Arkham City (City had 440, this only has 243)-Tons of extra content, including side missions, collectibles, challenge maps, and New Game PlusCons:-Many people still experience serious performance issues-Combat is a bit of a step back from Arkham City-Batmobile is heavily overused in gameplay-Only a couple of real boss fights, and they aren't very creative or interesting-All Riddler collectibles/challenges are required to get the full endingWhile it isn't as good as Arkham City, and there's more Batmobile than I would have liked, it's still a fantastic game and I would definitely recommend getting it if you enjoyed the previous games.As for performance, I was able to run the game at the lowest setting at 1360x768 and get a consistent 60fps. I didn't encounter any issues aside from the occasional lag spike, but as far as I can tell many people still have problems running the game. For reference, here are my specs:Intel Core i7-4770 (3.4GHz)Nvidia GeForce GTX 760 Ti8GB RAMWindows 10

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I honestly don’t know if I should recommend this. Was it entertaining? Yes, but mostly because it felt like playing Arkham City again. It’s another Batman game: better than the average action title, but nowhere near as good as its predecessors. Arkham Knight gets so much wrong. Firstly, the story is really two stories that have no business intersecting one another. The game kicks off with Scarecrow threatening to release a cloud of fear toxin over Gotham. Scarecrow could have been an amazing antagonist. Imagine the entire city transformed into a gallery of Batman’s worst nightmares: a surreal hell-scape that would have fit perfectly with the game’s Halloween setting. But all Scarecrow does is say, “You’ll lose, Batman” on TV screens. The fear gas does less than it did in Arkham Asylum. 80% of the story focuses on the new Arkham Knight villain. (If you can’t figure out who the Knight is in the first hour, you should probably question your knowledge of Batman. Yet, somehow Batman himself is perplexed the entire game.) The Arkham Knight leads the story in a terrible direction that feels more like exploring a dystopian cyberpunk world than playing as Batman. He fills Gotham with tanks, drones, and soldiers – far removed from supervillains and detective work. Batman spends most of his time in the Batmobile (also a tank). It’s overused to the point of nauseam. I hate the Batmobile. I hate its slippery controls, how slowly it moves, and how long and tedious its combat feels. Not to mention it kills people. The game tries to gloss over it by giving the tank “dummy” rounds and creating a ridiculous shock field that only zaps enemies when you run them over. But they are absolutely dying, especially when you ram into cars until they’re mangled soup cans. The first game in the series offered Batman a handful of gadgets, but designed the world around using them. Arkham Knight gives him dozens of gadgets and doesn’t have any level design at all. Every patch of Gotham looks like every other patch. It’s ugly, monotone, and lacks any recognizable landmarks. Even the combat feels bloated. Enemies are specialized to such an extent that beating them becomes a chore. Big enemies, electric enemies, ninja enemies, electric ninja enemies, enemies with shields, enemies with electric shields, enemies who heal other enemies and make them electric, enemies with guns, enemies with bigger guns, enemies that require beat-downs, enemies that require shocks, enemies that require the Batarang, enemies with quick-time events. It becomes so ridiculous, the game provides tutorials until the last hour of play. Everything is supersized until you’re gliding from one waypoint to another in a gigantic, empty world. When the story does get some room to breathe, it’s amazing. Some of the villains are even creepy. But they’re treated as afterthoughts. And don’t get me started on the DLC. I really wanted to play as Harley Quinn. In fact, for three games, all I’ve wanted to do is play as Harley Quinn. Know how long her missions are? 20 minutes. I’m betting some players will rush through them in ten. I paid real money for 20 minutes of gameplay? She has THREE fights in her entire story! The other DLC missions are just as bad. Batgirl’s is glitchy and short; no one cares about Red Hood, and all the characters are just dumbed-down versions of Batman. Do not waste your money on the DLC. Oh, and as a final note, yes, the game is finally playable. Barely. My GTX 900 series card runs it at about 40 frames-per-second. It eats up a staggering amount of processing power – so much that my computer will lag for five minutes after closing the program. It’s the worst-optimized game I’ve ever played. Nothing about Arkham Knight compares to its predecessors. Only buy it if you’re really desperate for some Batman action.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I am not in the habit of overreacting or exaggerating, so try to take what I write as literally:- Settings are VERY limited. As in some of the worst I have seen in a while.- I have to run with "low" textures, because I only have 2GB RAM on my GPU. Textures still often pop and take a couple of seconds to load, which is distracting to say the least and still they look terrible. A chimney I looked at reminded me of Battlefield 2, which is now 10 years old.- The framerate is horrible. With settings all the way down, and the game looking worse than Arkham City, which is 4 years old, I still only get a framerate of around 40 in the benchmark. of course that is locked to 30 FPS in game so that doesn't matter, am I right?- 30 FPS does not look good when you are gliding across the low textured rooftops with depth of field and motion blur forced on, because you can't disable them in the settings. I took to the .INI and configured a couple of things: I disabled motion blur, ambient occlusion, bloom and capped the framerate at 60. I then started the game for real:- FPS 45-80 which is playable for me, I am not a demanding man. Unfortunately some things just didn't load properly:- When in detective mode, no enemies, or people generally, were rendered. So I could see the analysis of people I couldn't see. And upon deactivation of detective mode for a second, they were still invisible, and then they popped in, rendering through 3 sets of textures in half a second.- When in combat, there were no markers above the enemies when they were about to strike, no indicators of when to block. I was playing on 'normal' difficulty, and I am pretty sure they are supposed to be there, altough not entirely certain.- I changed the keyboard controls to fit my usual Arkham setup, but the notices ingame did not really update. It kept telling me to press 'R' to eject from the Batmobile, but all it did was look behind the car. Through pressing random buttons I found that I needed to press 'E'. So that's kind of useless.At this point I have nothing more to add. I have been waiting for this title since the release of Arkham CIty, and I think I deserve a properly working title for all this waiting, and for paying that amount of money. I will just have to wait a month or six and hope they are able to fix this pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Let me start by saying this review has nothing to do with the actual technical issues faced by somany PC players. Enough has been said about that. With that said:So I buy Arkham Knight - I must admit fantastic game and i can run it ok by reducing the settings. I have a season pass too. Yay! Oh but theres issues with the PC version? So they pull it from the store. Fair enough. Months go by. I wait patiently for them to get going again so i can get some DLC and continue to enjoy the game. That time has come, except apparently my season pass only unlocks about 3 pieces of DLC, non of the new mini campaigns no new batmobiles, and not most of the skins. So can i get this straight WB, i assume my season pass covered the 'season' where you stopped releasing DLC and i am now expected to pay for it ON TOP of my season pass? I am furious! I will never buy a WB game again (and to be fair, I've really enjoyed their recent ones, Arkham Knight included) due to these shoddy business practices, and cannot reccomend that anyone else does. Please people, dont encourage them.edit - Thought I'd throw an edit to be fair to WB; They have fixed the season pass issue. Yay!! However I can't help but notice that although WB have now stated that for Windows 10 machines they recommend a minimum of 12GB RAM, they have not updated the min/recommended sys requirements on the store page. Despite the fact that, with Microsoft ramming Win10 down everyones throats, more and more people will be finding this issue out the hard way. I can only assume it's because if they were honest it would almost certainly stop a large percentage of steam users buying the game and if we know one thing, it's that WB loves that money.  So, unfortunately, one issue is fixed but many more remain. And shoddy business practice is still rampant. I still cannot reccomend this game and my views on future WB games remain unchanged.edit 2: More shoddy business practices, just when i thought it couldnt get worse. The 'offer' they have made as COMPENSATION (although i imagine most affected already own most if not all of the Arkham games) is being used as a marketing technique to get more people to buy this broken game. They're advertising it on the store page as a Special Offer. Why not label it what it is. Poor compensation to the schmucks who bought the game. I must admit though, i was pleased to see that they are offering refunds. So one step forward, two steps back i guess.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Arkham Knight is the final game in the Arkham trilogy that started with Arkham Asylum. There's a lot to love about Arkham Knight and a lot to dislike. The devs polished a lot of the minute to minute gameplay really well. Batman's animations are much smoother, running and zipping from rooftops feels better than ever, the graphics are really pretty and so on. The things I'd expect from a sequel. The parts I really dislike though are the things Rocksteady tried to innovate with.For the first time they included the Batmobile as part of gameplay. However this to me feels like the biggest misstep Rocksteady made. The batmobile is equipped with guns and controls like a tank. And you routinely jump into it to shoot at other tanks. It feels like a window into a different game Rocksteady was more interested in developing. You go from a relatively down to Earth experience where you use your fists to dispatch criminals in alleyways, to jumping into a sci-fi tank and destroying hundreds of other tanks with automatic missle launchers. I keep expecting a boss fight with Metal Gear REX whenever I enter it. I wish they didn't include the Batmobile and I especially wish it wasn't in the game so often.They also added multiple elements to the combat and stealth mechanics I dislike. For instance, you can now take out multiple enemies in succession with "fear takedowns". This feels gimmicky and unnecessary. They also included new enemy types. The worst one by far are medics who can revive enemies. This ruins how you would normally play the predator segments. Instead of encouraging you to watch a room carefully, waiting for enemies to become separated and avoiding being seen. You're now encouraged to take out enemies really quickly. I always felt much more anxious during these segments which used to be my favorite part of the series.It's really a shame that this game went one step forward two steps back. Since there was clearly a huge amount of work that went into making it. But as it stands, and ignoring the infrequent framedrops Arkham Knight feels unpolished. I think Rocksteady was too focused on making the game much larger than the previous entries in the series. When they should've focused on making a tighter and memorable experience. As it stands, the parts of the game I remember are the parts I wanted to avoid.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												I must say that this game has really taken me by surprise. I understand that it had a rough launch, but they have really done a great job gettin' the game back on its feet. I have had no issues of any technical degree what so ever, since I launched it the first time. It runs smoothly with everything on max graphic settings with a steady 60 fps. So far, the story is good. I would say that the other stories in the previous games had more to offer. The big difference is that some of the first games, like Arkham asylum, had a very linear story, which resulted in them spending more time on main story. I am not saying that it's a bad thing, but it shows that they have focused on a lot more different elements. Arkham knight is a big open world, with a lot of challenges and side missions to complete. The key element to this game, is of course the batmobile that you can use as much as you wish, to drive around the beautiful city. The combat has evolved nicely through the series, with a lot more environment integration. Batman is as awesome as ever, with all his gadgets and suits, that becomes bigger and better as you would expect of the bat!All around the game is really nice, and has a lot to offer. If you are big fan of batman you will of course love all the little easter eggs and references to the universe, with some of the dlc's addin' even more to it. Price is not too bad, for what you are gettin' but i'm sure that it will go on sale soon, with the summer sale coming. Now get out there! A long night awaits!

												*Note: This relates to Batman: Arkham Knight as it stands on the day of it's release for PC.*After editing .ini files to get this shoddy PC port to even function, I've managed to sink a couple of hours into the storyline of Arkham Knight. But I'm not going to talk about the story, the mechanics or even the gameplay. As I said, I had to edit .ini files to get the game to *function.* As it stands, upon release, this game suffers from a locked framerate of 30, memory leaks, crashes, dropping frames, severe stuttering, *THE GAME DELETING ITSELF* and quite a few other severe problems. These issues are effecting the majority of people who purchased the PC version of this game to some degree or another, even on computers that are more than powerful enough to handle the Arkham Knight system requirements. It's effecting Nvidia and AMD users.The port of this game is atrocious. It's barely playable at best and unplayable at worst. People shouldn't be unknowingly paying for unfinished, broken products. Hopefully a patch will be released soon to deal with these issues. In the mean time, we are out of luck. "Enjoy your AAA video game title, crafted with love and care and held together with duct tape and prayers."

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												With great anticipation I unpacked my PC copy for Batman: Arkham Knight, however, the reign of my excitement was cut short by the quality of this product. To describe this product as substandard and bad would almost be to promote those terms to the level of respectability. To describe the PC portation as a piece of crap would be to run the risk of a discourse that would never again rise above the excremental. In short: It is one gigantic clusterf**k. There may be people among you that ask me to give WB Games the benefit of a doubt and that they might not have known the state their game was in but that would suggest a complete loss of oversight and control which is just not realistic. I wish WB Games would have taken the same approach as with the Special Edition that was ultimately delayed because of quality issues. The fact that they haven’t leaves a bitter taste in the mouth of the PC community – appearance, apparently, is more important than a working software. The more we’re faced with such subpar programming the more I warm up to the idea that there should be a governing body; an equivalent to the NHTSA, NTSB or FDA.I bet the executives over at Rocksteady, the name behind Batman: Arkham Knight, are fuming. See, Rocksteady wasn’t responsible for the PC port of this game but another third party was put in charge (various sources speak of Iron Galaxy) – yet, Rocksteady has all the bad press and is busy doing damage control; I feel for you guys! Maybe you should send some flowers to whoever signed off on this travesty. I wonder how you can sign off on a 5-disc physical copy of a videogame that installs exactly 7.7 GB and makes you download the remaining 26.1 GB from the internet – WHAT WERE YOU THINKING?! Whoever waved this through should have his decision power relegated to answer questions like whether you’d like fries with that burger.How can you ship a game that has a framerate lock at 30?! Sadly, the problems won’t stop there – besides being slow and prone to stutter and locking up which topples the game over the brink of unplay-ability, you’re likely to suffer from audio glitches and then there is the god-awful Denuvo DRM, it’s as if there has been no lessons learned from Lords of the Fallen. Legitimate players are stifled and get hurt the most with those laughable protection attempts to fend off Pirates sailing the seven ISPs. I get that you want the community to purchase your games and you want to be compensated for your work – every gamer that actually cares for videogames understands that. The problem is that by treating everyone like a potential criminal and pumping out defective software you’ll lose your customer base, you’ll lose them by not taking them seriously and frankly you deserve it. Arkham Knight is the absolute worst PC port I’ve ever seen. The only way to fix this is to have a fresh go at it, preferably not by the same company that is responsible for the initial portation but someone capable and competent. Instead I’m afraid we’ll just see a myriad of patches and nobody owning the mistakes that were made.UPDATE: WB has pulled the game and suspended sales and already the masses are singing praise - the poor delusional souls. Commending WB to ‘a brave step’ or ‘the right thing’ is silly and wrong and is a perfect reflection of what’s wrong with gaming nowadays. You mustn’t sell defective goods, pulling it from sales is the normal thing to do and should therefore be acknowledged and met a with a slight nod but certainly not with exultation and cheer.Many of us seem to have become so used to shoddy programming that we expect problems when we purchase a game, some even go as far as trying to gloss over game-breaking bugs. This will never bring about a change in behavior from the publisher, they’ll just expect us to bend over and ‘get on with it’ and worse, many are buying in to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, the broken promises and cheap tricks – it’s like they have the attention span of a gnat. The fact is: This game should have NEVER been greenlit for PC release.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I was one of the lucky, hated few for whom, on release, the game worked well for. It had a few bugs but nothing terrible for me. At that time I would have given it an average to low review as it lacked polish and whilst playable it clearly had some major issues. Since purchase -as I was fool enough to pick up the season pass with it- I  have been forced by the publisher to sit on my thumbs for months as they forcibly stopped me from accessing the DLC I paid for while they pulled the game which as a one off was a bitter pill but I suppose I could look forwards to them bringing it all out with a shiny. polished, "as it should have been" version of the game.Finally yesterday they re-released the game.....Now the game crashes every 120 seconds in the batmobile, and around every 8 minutes on foot. The same graphical bugs, low post processing quality and missing features (I'm looking at you fancy rain effects) are still there/missing after 4 months of "fixing". I am still effectively barred from accessing the dlc content I paid for months ago because now in essence the game for me is non-functional.I am Extremely disappointed and feel let down by the whole debacle as such despite my best intentions I can personally only rate this game based on my experiences with it's playability which for me has lessened to the point that it is now unplayable.I won't give it a straight 0/10 because some people might be able to get it to run, like I was when it first was released months ago.3/10 seems only fair to me. Franchise's legacy has been utterly ruined - for me at least.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Great game; story and gameplay wise so far but the lack of AMD optimisation cripples performance, I'm using an R9 285 2GB on low textures and the game's fps lie between 21 and 30 and on average 27, note that there is a 30 fps cap in the actual game but not the game benchmark. Why is the game so Nvidia biased?I also pre-purchased the game (not from steam) before the game's minimum requirements were increased shortly before release date. I am using the updated graphics driver as well.The game is quite fun though when its running smoothly, albeit uncommon, the batmobile is bloody awesome and it looks like there is so much to do.Edit 1: There is a workaround for the 30 fps cap now. The game also runs terribly on Nvidea cards too.Edit 2: I've set the max fps to 60 with the workaround and the game feels and runs better than before, the framerate no longer dips below 25 (except from extreme stuttering), I run the game mostly at 58-61 fps (keep in mind that my card is below the NEW altered minimum requirements that was posted shortly before the game's release and it runs at this framerate) however there are still many cases of stuttering and tearing occurs quite a lot.Something I mentioned in the comments:I said Nvidia biased because 2GB is the min for an Nvidea card whereas its is 3GB for an AMD card, also the HD 7950 3GB is a better performing card in most instances than the GTX 660 2GB.Sidenote: I'm pretty sure the 7950 outperforms the 660 on Arkham City.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This game is really mediocre . I'll try to be as synthetic as i can.Positive aspects :- The main story and  PERFECT ending were properly designed- The Batmobile addition and the improved combat system- The melee combat system is even more fluid and challenging- No loadings when entering/leaving buildings - Flying and diving were polished to the extreme perfection- Gotham City is awesomeNEGATIVE ones ( spoilers included ) :1 - pointless upgrade system  :You'll have to spend several points in order to be able to unlock abilities,forcing you to wait a ♥♥♥♥♥ON of time before getting some of those 8-points abilities that are quite often meaningless, like the super-hyper batmobile's ejection system.2 - some upgrades ARE STUPIDLY OVERPOWERED :Clear example : you'll meet 2 new enemy types : medics and camouflaged soldiers. Don't worry,your jammer rifle will thwart their abilities,neutralizing them immediately.NIO,JUST NO. A NEW ENEMY SHOULD RESULT IN AN IMPROVED THREAT / AND INCREASED GAME DIFFICULTY AND VARIETY. This is not the case at all,especially in New Game +.3 - Lack of boss fights and overall boss stupidity :You won't have boss fights. Forget about Bane,Coppehead,Deathstroke,Deadshot,Mr FREEZE.They're FFF GONE FOREVER. This is...stupid. Now. The Joker is dead,right? THEN ♥♥♥♥ING REPLACE HIS DEATH PROPERLY! New epic boss fights are totally absent,except for the Riddler's wresting match. ( "--__-- ).Wanna have a laugh? Riddler vs Batmam is like "Loki vs Hulk in Avegers 1". 'Nuff said. SPOILER : Loki gets brutalized.4 - Bosses Stupidity :HOLY CUPCAKES. The Arkham Knight should be the ultimate enemy but instead...he's a clueless moron running with his drilling♥♥♥♥♥♥♥machine into underground explosives?!. He should also have been a melee combat expert...BUT NO! A FIRST CLASS CAMPING WUSS,like Mr.Mundy from Team Fortress 2 ! - Deathstroke : he'll replace the Arkam Knight right after you'll defeat him. The worst thing about it is that....you'll have to defeat Deathstroke in the same way that you've defeated the KNIGHT! HOLY MACKERELS! Deathstroke's fight was epic in Batman Origins...but here you'll just have to play hide-and-seek-and-rocket-him as well with 100+ tanks. ROCKSTEADY...you could have shown some creativity! Lazyness at the 100th power.5 - The Batmobile :The Batmobile addon could have been useful...the problem is that...IT'S NOT.Compared to the grappling hook flying...this car is as fast and handy as a shopping cart driven by a drunken sailor in the morning. ( Yes,obvious reference to the Irish Lovers' song here )Also,in order to solve many Riddler's challenges you'll need this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ vehicle. Good luck.6 - SIDE QUESTS :This is where the game fails the most . They're utterly repetitive and BADLY designed,clearly showing how lazy they were building them .Just to show :1) Man-Bat case : i thought "wow a cool new enemy to fight;super senses,super agility,the ability to fly,to produce supersonic echoes.." THE HARSH REALITY : DO A PIGGYBACK RIDE TO SUCK HIS DAMN BLOOD. Please. What a wasted opportunity.2) Firefly's case : forget the epic fight scenes in Origins,say welcome to a batmobile pursuit. "--__--3) Dr.Pyg Case : all those ♥♥♥♥tards killed by him have the 3 body clues in the same 3 areas all the ♥♥♥♥ing time. Some more variety in finding those clues would have been great. But no : scan epidermic level,muscular level and skeleton. You're done. The boss fight? The butcher from Wanted. You're done.4) Hush : a forced scene with Morgan Freeman,ops. Lucius Fox. 3 minutes and Hush is butt♥♥♥♥ed,again.7 - DLCs and overlall additional contentHarlet Quinn DLC was a llama's spit in the eye long 5 minutes.Literally. Asking for a 40€ season pass before the game came out on PC was awful,dreadful and un-ethic.Batgirl's DLC lasts 45 minutes and doesn't show anything new from the base game.8 - PC PortI have a great Gaming PC and the game itself goes on 30fps on ultra-Nvidia-tailored optimization. Not more. Checking you game files integrity WILL DELETE CHUNCKS OF YOUR GAME. The game itself will crash  at least 3-4 times during your gameplay and WILL USE MORE THAN 3 GB of your memory when it's running.9 - Challenges :They're pretty easy,except for the Batmobile's ones. Prepare to rage.10 - Enemies' total awareness and common sense :The devs said : " During Stealth rooms enemies will counter you,adapting their tactics in order to outmatch you. "  F-A-L-S-E.REALITY : they will learn ( was about time after 3 games,i'd say) after you wipe out the 30-40% of them; even if they learn,they're still too slow to react properly. Stealth is easy . Too easy. No matter if they added the heavy patrol guard,the drone controller and the medics. They still aren't a serious threat.11 - FEAR TAKEDOWS :Holy cupcakes. The hardest thing to do in steath is do deal with several enemies at the same time. This new skill will delete the problem,allowing you to pretty much obliterate any real issue you could have in those clueless rooms filled with scaredy cats enemies.To sum up :This game could have been better AND IT HAD TO BE. Devs were just too lazy on not optimizing the game,not improving side quests and NOT MAKING THE GAME HARDER. A wasted chance to make the last Batman game unforgettable.Verdict  : 4 / 10

number of helpful: 38 of 43 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Still terrible. It seems the pc version of this game will never truly be fixed. If you're running a top-of-the-line system, you might find this playable (although that's not a guarantee) but otherwise you should stay away for performance reasons alone. Even if you get things running smoothly, it's still not a very good game. The story is...fine. Incredibly predictable, but fine. If you've read even a few issues of Batman published within the last decade you're going to know exactly who the Arkham Knight is the moment you meet him. There's also just way too much going on. In addition to the core story missions, there is a glut of repeatable side missions that focus on different members of Batman's Rouges Gallery. The problem is that once you've played one kind of these missions, there's no reason to play any more of them except for completion's sake. All the penguin missions are identical, as are all the Two Face missions, as are all the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Riddler Races, etc, etc. Which brings me to the biggest problem in this game, one you doubtlessly know about, the batmobile. It sucks. It's completely antithetical to what the rest of the game tries to offer, and it's forced upon you again and again. Why would anyone who enjoys the satisfying, rhythm-based combat or the puzzle-like, predator sections want to play Missile Command with tanks? It's boring and feels like a tax you're obliged to pay to access any of the fun stuff. It's also weirdly tied to the Arkham Knight, so it makes me resent his inclusion in the game even more. Wanna go fight Scarecrow's goons? Too bad, you gotta make it through 5 waves of Arkham Knight tank-faff first. What's more, by being so watered-down the fun stuff isn't even that fun any more. The combat is pretty much the same that it's always been (although the few sections you get to team up with another member of the bat family, wherein you may execute cool team takedowns, are pretty fun), and there are so few predator sections (which were my favorite part of the series) that the game doesn't feel like it has room to experiment much with them. Don't even get me started on the Riddler garbage (too late!). In Asylum, the Riddler stuff was essentially a bunch of fun extras that led to a really cool secret. City was a bit more ambitious but it was all fairly do-able. In Arkham Knight there are over 240 of those ♥♥♥♥ers, not to mention awful races where you'll blow up the batmobile umpteen times trying to memorize patterns in a lethal (yet somehow hideously dull) car-based version of Simon Says. And they use this♥♥♥♥♥♥to gate the real ending of the game. That's right, if you want the conclusion to this pile of dross you're going to have to sift through a whole lot of it. In summary, Arkham Knight is a mess. Even without the technical issues, it's still an overstuffed game where all the good bits are suffocated under the sagging, bloated flesh of bad mechanics and repetitive design. Please don't buy it.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I will have this review split into 2 sections. One on the game itself and the other on the current state of the PC versions.So the final part in the Batman Arkham series and I can honestly say its an amazing way to end a very loved series. The game is a true love letter to anybody that is familar with the Dark Knight and has some references from some of his most memorable moments in history.Gameplay: This Arkham game has the most in depth combat system with everything you've known from the previous games and adds a lot more. To be honest it has gotten more difficult since it has more enemy varieties that keeps you on your toes to not mess up your combo. Same goes for the stealth sections which adds more features so you can experiment how you can take down your enemies. The Batmobile has be a mixed bag for everybody, IMO its fun. For the first few missions the Batmobile does feel like its been shoved in there especially the Riddler challenges but its still fun to use and you can also upgrade it. Whats new with the AR challenges is they include challenges for the Batmobile which can be racing tracks or combat and they aren't as good as the rest of the challenges IMO. The open-world aspect of the game has the most collectibles and side missions than the previous games. Story: Being the final part in the Arkham series, the story is amazing and has a really good and honestly a sad ending... But the story is told really well and references some of Batman's greatest moments from his comic books and is shown off very well. After like 20% through the main story you will come across a bit of a shocking twist with someone making a comeback... which I won't spoil! I would say this has the best story out of the whole series, just passing Arkham City and you will be amazed by the ending.Conclusion: Batman Arkham Knight is a great ending to one of the best video game series of all time and your a big fan of anything related to Batman you will have an amazing experience with this game. Combat is a lot of fun as well as the Batmobile which may be different for a some people but regardless I had an amazing time with this game.Rating: 9/10Now I will talk about the most controversial topic about this game... the PC port issues which I'm sure you all have heard about.When this game came out last year it was dubbed one of the worst PC ports of all time and they were right about that. The game would crash, capped at 30 FPS, broken textures, etc... So right now I can safely say that this game is fixed... but only if you have a 4GB graphics card. As I look at some videos everyone is saying the game runs fine as long as you have a lot of video memory on your GPU and if you have less than 4GB you probably won't have a great time. But for me running the game on 2x 980 Ti the game ran very good, it had some stuttering but 90% of the time it ran smooth and 90 FPS and didn't crash once for me. So take these notes as a warning before you purchase this game to see if your system will run the game well!

number of helpful: 51 of 65 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												While no doubt a controversial PC release, most, if not all, of the technical issues this game launched with have been well ironed out at this point. And outside of that I'd dare to say that Arkham Knight, while maybe not as exciting as previous titles in the series, is a great game. As far as gameplay goes, the freeflow combat system is still an incredibly fun and satisfying gameplay system to battle with, and the predator encounters are still tense and engaging. But both of these systems lack the shine they once had when the series first began all those years ago due to general franchise fatigue. But I can't imagine any way to make any real groundbreaking improvments on either front. The introduction of a playable batmobile seems to have been an attempt to battle this fatigue, and in some respects it succeeds. I found it exhilarating to race through the streets, chasing down enemies and completing races. But while they are fun at the start, on the whole the tank battles sections are not varied or complex enough to be very engaging. There is also an extremely dissappointing absence of interesting boss fights, which the series has lauded for in past titles. Almost every boss encounter is a slight variation of either the freeflow, predator, or tank battles systems. The legendary setting of Gotham City has also never been more detailed and full of life though. And not only in any other game, but also any other medium. It is an absolute blast to glide around Gotham and appreciate all the care and detail that was put into its construction. But the lack of complex interior environments is a dissapointment.The game's story is maybe its most impressive feat, and is anchored by a miriad of outstanding performances. The pacing is outstanding with each story beat being followed by an even better one. It has such an incredibly strong start, which it confidently builds on until the very end. Never before has there been such an enthralling narrative that successfully delves into Batman's mental and emotional psyche. But with that being said, my biggest complaint (in terms of both the story and entire game) is that many iconic Batman villians are given a bit of the short stick in their side missions. Characters that have dense wonderful stories in the comics; like Hush, Deacon Blackfire, and Ra's al Ghul; are quickly and unceremoniously rushed out the door in an obvious attempt to ties up all the series' loose ends. And while I consider this a true travesty, I'll still confidently say that Batman Arkham Knight is a great game.

Posted: September 7, 2015
First contact: well, this is a disaster.Preordered the game, then one month later I bought a GTX 980 to meet the "ULTRA" requirements, and got another copy of the game. Then the game released, and I found myself with 2 copies of the same crap.The game ran incredibly bad, no matter the options I changed, but I kept playing, even with the unbelievable framedrops, because I love Batman. I couldn't stop myself from playing just from my sheer love of the Arkham saga. At least until... near the end of the main story, during a cinematic, the game completely crashed on me, while using 6GB of RAM. I finally decided to stop and wait for a patch before making a review.Fast forward to September, the first interim patch is released.Does the game run better? Yes, it does. Are there still framedrops? There are, specially with the batmobile (they drop even below 30). Can you run the game on max with everything on? No. Interactive fog makes the fps drop below 40, no matter how much I lower the other options like texture quality, shadows, etc. Do I meet the ultra requirements? I do. Will I preorder another game from WB or Rocksteady? Never.I love the story, the new moves, the voice acting, all of it, but... they took months to improve the performance of a game that was released in a sorry state (and failed to meet the August patch release schedule), and still can't make it work properly for a PC that meets the ultra specs. Way to end the franchise. Congratulations, Rocksteady and Warner.28th of October patch arrived, and nothing changed from September.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
One more night in the whole of Gotham City. From the first 5 minutes you can tell this is a different Arkham game. It's bigger in scope, yet the story is more personal. Characters are at their best or worst and Batman seems to oscillate between the two. Fighting is same old Arkham one, however it's been improved with new precise and brutal move-sets.  In predator mode you can take advantage of enemies fears and take up to 5 in 5 epic moves. For the first time, the batmobile is available, as a means to destroy buildings while driving or take out an army of drones. While it was designed to blend into game's events, sometimes it feels like the game blends into the Batmobile. The challenge room is equipped with multiple players, some of them even being villains from the main game, all of them having different combat styles and the maps that are available are consistent. If one wants more, there's plenty of DLCs to satisfy even the biggest appetite. With all it's features, the logical conclusion would be to call Arkham Knight the best game out of Rocksteady's Trilogy. Yet there's something more to talk about....This time around, Joker's dead but lives on through the people who he traumatized. Scarecrow and the new Arkham Knight are bent on taking down Batman for good, not as a man but as a legend. The other villains either decide to ignore Batman, not being a threat much longer or just want their piece of him while they can(Riddler is even more deranged).  With  new moves, tech and an unexpected game-changer, Batman finds himself attacked on different levels, putting up a good fight and yet he keeps sliding downhill. All characters and elements have a sense of finality in them. It's obvious they're all going for a change and it all depends on what happens with the legend of the Dark Knight. 


Extremists deal in Black and White 
A Screenshot of Batman™: Arkham Knight
By: F4rseeR




The new villain, Arkham Knight, isn't as "new" as someone who reads comics might expect. He knows everything he needs to know about Batman in order to be a serious threat to him and his allies. Out of all villains, he's the one that hits Batman where it hurts most. But when he's taking the mask off, he's the villain that needs a hug. Scarecrow, despite looking more menacing and undergoing a more fatalist mission, is just as vulnerable as before. Truth be told, it's the villains in the side-quests that are more fleshed out and add to the Gotham dynamic. The Batmobile is as awesome as it looks, going fast though destructible environments and having a battle-mode which has it's own upgrades. However, the times it's used can be tiresome and provided you won't enjoy as much as other can kill the mood to play this game, as there are some challenging sections in the main storyline that consists of taking the Batmobile into battle. Through some points in the storyline and some side-quests there's some detective work included, which is handled somewhat better than Arkham Origins and sadly, there's not enough of that. Aside from seeing Riddler's machinations everywhere in the city, there's a militia that can be taken down through several ways, cleaning down the areas resulting in a safer Gotham City. 


Gotham in its livelyhood 
A Screenshot of Batman™: Arkham Knight
By: F4rseeR




A nice feature this game also has is the photo-mode, which ensured that the screenshot section of the community hub looks as good if not better than the artwork section. Being able to edit the light and exposure, change camera angles, depth of field, having some graphic assets and filters good enough to inspire graphic designers is an invitation to capture certain events or places in Gotham the way you see it or view&capture it through different angles. It can be just as thrilling as being the photographer in a photo-shoot.  A lengthy campaign, plenty of side-quests that are a must-do, new game plus and the challenge rooms, which involve the biggest number of characters in the Arkham series + some racetracks for the Batmobiles, which has different skins: indulging in all of that made me stick around for almost 70 hours, the most I've spent in a Batman game and almost any game, as I'm a guy on a tight schedule. It's a high class game in every department. Performance issues are a thing of the past for most players. Previous games made you feel like you're Batman. This one makes you feel like you're more than that.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												You may notice at the top of the page that the Overall Reviews are Mixed but the recent reviews are Overwhelminhly Positive. At first, I thought this was a joke the internet was playing, like how the Cory in the House DS game has a 9.5 user score on Metacritic, but then I read some of the reviews and some forum posts and saw that people are saying the game is playable now. So, I picked this game up cheap (the game's reputation has lowered its price on third party stores) and I played it. Let me tell you, it was definitely worth it. Is the game playable? Yes. Is it well optimized now? Oh God no. There was a lot of stuttering when I first loaded up the game, or when I go to new areas in the open world. But, I'm a patient man so I was able to deal with it. It should be noted that I have a 4 year old card so some of the higher end GPUs will probably have better performances. Other than that, the only other bugs I encountered were small texture bugs. I never experienced any game breaking bugs. Now on to the actual game. How is it? Well, my recommendation should tell you that I very much enjoyed the game. I think it's the best in the series (which is not an opinion shared by many). I felt the story was extremely well done. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that the other Arkham games were really focused on the plot and the supervillians that Batman goes up against, but this game really explores Batman himself as a character. Again, some people were a bit disappointed by the story, especially with the reveal of the Arkham Knight, but I was fine with it. I was never a die-hard Batman comic book fan so I don't share the same point of view as those people. The gameplay is where the game really shines. I loved everything about it. Even the Batmobile. I had a lot of fun driving around Gotham. At first, the driving controls felt really wonky, but once I got used to it, it felt really great. Now the tank mode. A lot of people hated it, but I found it very enjoyable. You can probably notice a trend here...How about the ground combat? They improved nearly everything from AC. No longer can you "spam Y to win". They have added many new enemies into the game, such as electricty covered enemies and medics, that require you to change up your tactics. There is also a "Fear Takedown" ability that allows you to take out multiple enemies in one go without the enemy being able to react, which helps makes Predator Mode faster and more enjoyable. Finally, when travelling around the city, it is mostly unchanged, but they did buff the grapple boost since the city is MUCH bigger this time around. This game is a great conclusion to the trilogy. The story is very well done (but the ending was a bit weak), the presentation is godly (well, when everything is working properly), the gameplay is the best it has ever been, and the music OH THE MUSIC. The PC version is playable now and you can get it for cheap during a Steam Sale or on a third party site. If you are a fan of the Arkham series, you should get this game. If you are new, play AC first, then come to this.

Despite all the negative publicity at launch, Batman Arkham Knight is a solid entry in the Arkham series that deserves a second look. [8/10]The Good:the most beautiful Gotham City created in gaming so far;built-in VRAM usage prediction tool to help tweaking the game's graphical options;good story plot (though at one point the plot armor seems to be thicker than average);Robin's fans will like this game.The Bad:some graphical features are nVidia exclusive.  One of them lags;built-in antialiasing support makes the rain blurry.  For best effect, use DSR;game still suffer occasional (but rare) glitches, like Batman falling through floor;lots of DLC, but only one is worth playing and contributes to the story;Batmobile.  While a refreshing experience on its own, developers appear to over-emphasize its existence in the game.The Ugly:you have to finish all Riddler's challenges to watch the full ending.Bottom line:The Pro's outweight the Con's.  Give it a try when it's on sales.

content:
Posted: February 16
												Batman: Arkham Knight offers high production values, a huge Gotham to explore, and a return of the hard-hitting, gadget-centric combat that Arkham fans love. The story, however, focuses too much on the pathetic Arkham Knight, a paper-thin character whose menace is all empty gestures. Add in poorly designed boss battles, and a forced collect-a-thon in order to see the full ending of the game, and Arkham Knight earns its mixed reputation. Recommended for franchise fans, but be prepared to like and dislike it in equal measure.Total size on my hard drive (with all DLC): 55.4 GB  (yes, fifty-five point four gigabytes)+ The graphics are stunning. Even if you have to play with the settings on low as I did, Arkham Knight is one of the most visually appealing games I’ve ever seen. Facial animations are equally impressive.+ Some awe-inspiring set-pieces and alterations to the landscape that happen as the game progresses. Can’t say more without spoiling it.+ Gotham is amazingly detailed. Dust, neon lights, crumbling brick and shiny steel. Simply fantastic.+ Most of the voice-acting regulars return, led by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill.+ Most of the major villains make an appearance, and some get interesting send-offs (Mr. Freeze was my favorite). Some even get a shot at redemption.+ Scarecrow’s toxin. It’s used very creatively. Can’t say more without spoiling the story.+ Mob combat is as awesome as ever. This is the fully-powered version of Batman who has access to all of his gadgets.+ Incredible variety and thoughtful design in the Predator Encounters (where Batman has to sneak around a room, taking out guards one-by-one).+ The team-up mechanic that allows for switching from Batman to a partner and back works well. It was very cool to go on missions with Robin, Nightwing or Catwoman.+ A lot of care and attention clearly went into the challenge maps. There are a lot to choose from.+ Lots of skins. Want Batman to dress up in the classic 1989 outfit (with the car to match)? Or perhaps the Batman Beyond outfit? He can. There are many more, as well as some alternate skins for Robin, Nightwing, and yes, Catwoman.+/- Too much Arkham Knight, not enough Scarecrow. +/- I was expecting Scarecrow to sound the way he did in Arkham Asylum. He doesn’t. He hits the same tones as Hugo Strange (nothing against the Strange voice). And why did Rocksteady re-cast the voice of Barbara Gordon / Oracle? The new voice (Ashley Greene) is all right, but I missed Kimberly Brooks.+/- The soundtrack lacks the heroic feel of the Arkham City and Arkham Origins soundtracks, but is absolutely beautiful in the calm / slow / sad sections.+/- The Arkham games have always had complicated control schemes. Arkham Knight takes the complexity to a new level. That’s good news for franchise veterans, bad news for newbies.+/- Optimization. After a disastrous launch on PC that was plagued with bugs, Arkham Knight ran well enough on my low-end gaming system (Core i5-4590 + 2GB R7 260X). 


YouTube™ Video: Batman: Arkham Knight - Batmobile Frame-rate test (R7 260X) (900p) 

			Views: 70		

			Just me running around Gotham doing random stuff. I am using software-based capture (Fraps), so my frames-per-second is about 10fps higher when not recording.		

*Update April 2016* I got a new graphics card, an RX 470, and made another gameplay video.


YouTube™ Video: Arkham Knight - Gameplay (RX 470) (MAX Settings) 

			Views: 32		

			Resolution: 1920x1080 Recorded with Fraps. Batman: Arkham Knight was created by Rocksteady and Warner Bros. System specs: OS: Windows 7 x64 Ultimate CPU Intel Core i5-4590 Motherboard Asrock H97M...		

- You’ve heard there’s too much Batmobile. Well, there’s too much Batmobile. Sometimes it feels more like a Saints Row 3 tank rampage than Batman. Sad part is, Rocksteady was clearly so proud of their work on the Batmobile that they tried to incorporate it into as many parts of the game as possible.- You have to collect all 200+ Riddler trophies to unlock the complete ending. At least it’s not DLC, but still, this is bull.- The Arkham Knight is one of the weakest, most pathetic antagonists in a Batman game. His unmasking has no tension. And you actually have to fight him as a boss three times: twice in the Batmobile (awful), and once in a predator encounter (decent, but not a real boss battle). There’s much I could say about the Arkham Knight, but all of it would spoil the game in a BIG way. He is simply an awful character. - Bosses in general are disappointing. After the epic boss battles provided by Arkham Origins (admittedly by a different studio), this is a massive disappointment. For instance, even if you hated Deathstroke’s boss battle in Arkham Origins as a collection of QTEs, at least he and Batman fought mano y mano. The Deathstroke boss battle in Arkham Knight is – DRUMROLL – another tank battle. That’s right,  the greatest hand-to-hand combatants in the Batverse fight with tanks. Rocksteady’s lack of inspiration (or will?) to craft interesting boss battles was never more apparent than in Arkham Knight.- Have a controller nearby. Some of mini-games are incredibly frustrating with a mouse + keyboard.- Combat targeting is poor. “I’ll just use the bat-grapple to whip that gun out of his hands… No, not that guy, THAT guy!” Also some occasional input delay.- Much harder to achieve a smooth, continuous combo. Combat now REQUIRES the use of awkward key combinations to put together a successful string of attacks. And the whole "climb up the riot shield" for an over-head attack is as wonky as ever; Batman is as likely to flip over the target as he is to do an aerial attack. Add in the poor targeting mentioned above, and combat can become very frustrating to even experienced users.- A large part of the story hinges on Batman suffering from the after-effects of being infected with Joker’s blood in Arkham City. But… Batman found the cure for that, didn’t he? Apparently that wasn’t really a cure. Rocksteady just couldn’t make a Batman game without the Joker. The Batman Arkham games are some of my favorites, and while I enjoyed my time in Arkham Knight, I’m incredibly frustrated by the fact that it gets as many things wrong as it gets right. A good game as it stands, and if you’re just looking for more Batman, this game will satisfy. But Arkham Knight had the potential to be a “game for the ages” instead of “just another Batman game.” Rocksteady clearly loves the Batman universe, but it’s time for them to move on (and from their own statements, this will indeed be their last Batman game). Thanks for the memories, Rocksteady.

content:
Posted: February 2
												If you've played  and enjoyed previous games in the series, it seems obvious you'd enjoy Arkham Knight. Since the PC performance issues have been mainly ironed out, Arkham Knight has become a worthy addition to the series. Combat: 8/10Pros: -Same tight combat as the previous Arkham games-New enemies-New characters and items to experiment with-New combo abilitiesCons:-Combat can become stale by the end of the game, especially if you've put a lot of hours into the previous entries in the series-Combat challenges start to feel grindy after a whileStealth: 8/10Pros: -Same stealth as the previous games-New, larger areas to perform stealth missions in -New abilities to terrorize and take out enemies-Stealth challenges have interesting (if occasionally very difficult) bonus challengesCons:-Some of the non-Batman characters can make stealth tedious because they lack a majority of his abilities (which could be a pro if you like those kind of challenges)The World: 7/10Pros:-A new map to explore (refreshing if you were frustrated by the tedium between City and Origins)-More Batman lore to come across-The Batmobile is fun...for a time-Lots of sidequests and collectibles (could be a con if that causes you anxiety as a dedicated completionist)-More villains to interact with than any other Arkham gameCons:-The Riddler sidequest in particular can become very tedious.-The Batmobile becomes tedious after a while. I tended to traverse the world as Batman, especially after the Batmobile is awkwardly made compulsory in a few big sidequests. -[SPOILERS] The final Deathstroke sidequest in particular feels like a copy pasted version of a main story boss. Especially insulting considering the Deathstroke fight in Origins. -Some of the sidequests attempt to wrap up loose ends from previous games in a messy, unsatisfying way. The Story: 7/10Pros: -A conclusion to the Arkham story-Returning characters and villains are a treatCons:-Some of the plot twists aren't surprising-Scarecrow feels overshadowed by the Arkham Knight, much like Hugo Strange and Ra'as al Ghul in City. Performance:Pros:-It's been fixed significantly since launch-Mostly consistent 60 fpsCons:-FPS drops in busy areas-The cape seems to cause some issues with particle effectsMy PC: Nvidia GTX 9708 GB RAMIntel i5 4960K @ 3.50 GHz

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												I can't honestly recommend this game. It's not a bad game - far from it. It's very well put together. The graphics are beautiful, the controls are polished, and the overall production is top notch. If wanted a prettier Arkham game with all the dials turned to 11, this is it.Plot wise, it's a bland mish-mash of multiple graphic novels -- I won't mention them here as not to spoil it, but somehow, Arkham Knight manages to muddle them together into something resembling a plot. There's a lot of other Batman references/characters inserted into the game, too, which also winds up being a confused mess. You'll complete a major plot point only to have Alfred pop up and tell you that the Riddler/Manbat/Two Face/Azrael/Mad Hatter (who for all intents and purposes is a better dressed Riddler)/Flying fire boy are up to no good and need to be taken care of. Gameplay-wise.... Batmobile, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batmobile. You spend about a third of the game inside of it, and it's not bad... but after a few missions it simply stops being fun and becomes another chore for you to finish before you can get to the good parts. Grappling through the city, fighting mooks, and sneaking around are where the series shines, and replacing that gameplay with 'just ok' tank/driving sections was a poor design decision. Combat is the same old Arkham Combat, complete with the annoying shield/knife/electrified enemies. Things get interesting when you get to play as other characters, but opportunities to do so are rare and are over far too soon. If you loved Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, and you really want more of the same thing, Knight is a good bet. There's a lot for fans of the character and the game series in here. Otherwise, it's just a mix villians  and random missions loosely held together by a muddled plot and really hurt by repetitive and boring vehicle combat.

content:
Posted: February 10
A bad reception.People give Arkham Knight allot of♥♥♥♥♥♥ And I understand this because I know Arkham Knight had possibly one of the worst launches of all time, Rocksteady out-sourced the PC port of this game to a cheap and half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Chinese company who had no passion for the game and only cared about meeting the crteria of being able to launch the game on a PC so they could make their pay-check.As Shigeru Miyamoto said: "A delayed game is eventually good, but a rushed game is forever bad."This was the reason for Arkham Knights not-so-welcoming reception on launch, on PC anyway. And why it's still considered a bad game by most.But since it's launch people have neglected Rocksteady's dedication to this game. They didn't leave it in a broken state and cut their losses like many other triple A developers would have (Ubisoft is a perfect example). They worked effortlessly to make this game a true ending to the acclaimed Arkham series, and they have, the game runs perfectly on PC now after many patches since launch, and the DLC they've produced for the game adds many hours worth the couple dollars you spend on it.The DLC debacle.While the DLC was also surrounded by controversy and was very poorly reviewed for being incredibly overpriced at the time of its release, that is certainly not the case anymore. The only complaint about the DLC was the cost - so Rocksteady halfed the cost of the season pass and made the many individual items dirt cheap, while I don't care about $1 cosmetics I do care about the many story packs that were added as DLC, allowing you to play as a whole array of characters including villians such as Red Hood. The DLC wasn't a bad thing - it was just way too expensive when it was introduced and Rocksteady asked allot for very little for a long time, but this is not the case anymore.The Batmobile.When you go through the reviews for this game despite allot of them being negative you will only really find 1 common complaint: the Batmobile was too forced into the game and main story. And I agree, it was too forced into the game, hell the insanly built up boss fight for Deadshot was a tank fight we'd done 3 times before that you can finish in less than a minute with a fully upgraded batmobile, this really annoyed me esspecially after how awesome previous encounters with deadshot were in the other Arkham games. But don't let this fool you into thinking the batmobile is a horrible addition to the game - because the batmobile is next level awesome. It was just way too forced into the story.Give it one more chance to win you over.The game is quite cheap now and the DLC is basically a steal, if you're willing to goto third party websites you can pickup this game for about $5. Come on, for $5 you can just try it, it's the price of a cup of coffee for what might be the best arkham experience you might have; at the very least a great Batman experience.

number of helpful: 32 of 37 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Cannot recommend this game after the botched launch and failure to patch. The game has now been 're-released', tagging all prior reviews as 'pre-release' in an attempt to invalidate negative reviews (The game was around ~40% positive at 're-release', which is almost unheard of), despite the fact that the game was very much released and only pulled after public outcry.Many of the performance issues have NOT been fixed as promised. There is a fairly serious memory leak, and their 'fix' was to tell users 'we’ve found that having at least 12GB of system RAM on a PC allows the game to operate without paging and provides a smoother gameplay experience.' (Windows 10), or 'If you encounter this, simply re-launching the game will resolve the issue.' (Windows 7). Other FPS issues, such as severe rain/batmobile slowdown as well as very clear object pop-in, are still present.WB has issued an 'apology' in the form of free past-Arkham games, but most of the people affected, who bought the game at original launch, or pre-purchased, already own these prior games, as they are fans of the series. It seems more of a simple promotional tool to pull in more new buyers (The 'apology' free pack is for anyone who buys the game for the next couple weeks, in addition to the past), rather than actually compensating those who were affected. New buyers actually get all the same content as pre-purchasers and original launch buyers, while also benefitting from a $10 reduced price.Performance aside, if you're lucky and have the game run well on your machine (it seems to be left to chance whether the game works well or not on any system, high or low end) the game itself is actually very well done and fun. Most of the characters, with the exception of the main antagonist (whose identity is made painfully obvious WELL before the reveal), are written and voiced well, and the different side objectives are mostly fun. The combat is fluid, as you'd expect coming from any of the past games. However, it doesn't add too many new elements. The one big new 'feature' is the batmobile, which should be a fun addition, but is shoehorned into any situation the writers could think of, and turns out to be very boring to use.EDIT: Oh, forgot to mention. One of the optional boss battles, with the Riddler, is locked behind obtaining ***every riddler trophy in the game***. Basically, you do his side questline, which was actually pretty enjoyable, win, and he says 'well, you haven't won until you do ALL my challenges, peace!' and runs away. As someone that likes doing side missions and completing side-arcs, this really bugs me. I'm not willing to run around for hours and hours doing boring little puzzles and 100% the game just to get to a new peice of content/arc closure. I gave up and just watched it on Youtube.===================================================================All in all, with the performance issues, horribly handled launch, poor community support and self-serving 'apology', I can't recommend this game at anywhere near $50. Even if you buy it with a good rig, it seems to be a 50-50 shot whether or not you'll have performance issues that hinder your play. The actual gameplay and story is fun though, so it may be worth taking a risk (or 'demoing' it to test performance, then buying) once it goes on sale for $10-$15.

number of helpful: 45 of 59 people (76%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Performance:Date: November 15th, 2015 (After the game was "fixed")i7 3820GTX 660 ti16 GB DDR3 ram7200 rpm HDDEverything set to off/low except anisotropic filtering x16. Getting 25-35 fps average. I know my 660 ti isn't top notch, but I can still run most games on high just fine. So this is disappointingly low performance for such a big AAA game. *Edit: December 30th, 2015 - Another patch has been released and I bought myself an SSD. Mostly solid 30-40 fps, but inside the GCPD its more like 28 because there is so much stuff in there post game. And I get the occasional dip to 28 when there is a lot of destruction going on when I'm in the batmobile. I think my SSD has more to do with the framerate bump than the latest patch though as I've read of others getting big framerate boosts when using an SSD on this game. Its playable now, but only after I bought an SSD, and even on the lowest settings its still a very pretty game. Still going to keep my review as a "No" recommendation because its still very poor performance from such a big budget game. They spent more time making dlc then they did fixing their broken game. Do not support this game.=========Story:About the Arkham Knight character being "an entirely new character". That is a lie. Its an old character. False advertising.Thomas Wayne narrated a trailer. He is not in the game in any form. Just an FYI in case you got your hopes up about hearing more from him.If they had just done the "Arkham Knight" like he was in the comics, the story would have been decent IMO. Not trilogy ending worthy, but decent. But because the marketing flat out lied about Arkham Knight being a new character it completely ruined the reveal and the buildup to the reveal for me. The buildup for the reveal is kinda weak as well, if they had set it up earlier in Asylum or City or even Origins, then it would have worked a hell of a lot better as a trilogy ending. I still would have known what was coming, but at least it would have been set up better.=========Gameplay:The batmobile starts out pretty neat, but the game forces you to tank fight in it WAY too much, especially in the latter half of the game. And not only that but the tank combat rarely ever changes, the minor additions to the combat do nothing to change it up and it becomes a chore every time you hear someone on the comm say tanks incoming. Some of the puzzles where you have to work with your remote controlled batmobile are neat, but then the game forces you to use the batmobile for a majority of the puzzles and it gets tiresome.Predator takedowns (I think thats what they were called) are awesome to look at, but somewhat exploitable if you're half decent at stealth takedowns. And once you upgrade it you can pretty much clear an entire area without even trying. Low risk, high reward gameplay. =========TL:DRIf you can ignore the performance issues, accept a rehashed story, and slog through all the tank combat, then you'll find an average Batman Arkham game. If it ran perfectly I'd probably give it a 7/10.But because it runs so poorly I give it a 4/10
