number of helpful: 37 of 46 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I wish I could be the batman on release date. Brand New Nvidia 960 w/ new drivers3.2 ghz i5 CPU16 gb of RamBasically way past minimum and mostly past recomended and I could only play past the poison ivy part and introduction to batmobile combat before getting tired of the constant stuttering and inability to even watch cutscenes because it freezes all of the time. Rocksteady better be releasing that patch in a couple of days.This isn't to say the game is bad, but if I can't play the game at all then obviously it has issues that need to be fixed before it gets the review it deserves rather than the one it getsEdit: Still no luck to getting it running smoothly. Been told that the pre-load files may have had something wrong and am currently redownloading. Only problem is for some reason I am only getting around 200 kb/s right now on steam while downloading from other sources is just fine (3 mb/s)2nd and possibly final edit until optimization patch comes out: I am now able to play with everything on the lowest settings and it still suffers from frame rate drops, small amounts of stuttering and audio desyncs during conversations and cut scenes. Other than these known issue it is a very good game. The story and side missions come rather naturally in most cases and the riddler is back to actually giving some riddles rather than small puzzles. The story is great so far with something that throws me completely off guard often. I loved Arkham City and Asylum and this game by far takes the cake for me. I will recommend this game only after the optimization fixes.The heat coming from my computer when playing this game right now also causes my room to become unbearably hot.And the latest issue is randomly the game will seem to alt-tab and whenever I try to re enter it crashes. Only happened twice now within the 7 hour time frame that I have been playing. Minor nuisance since the game autosaves a lot.Honestly it has been too long without another update and the first one still hasn't fixed the terrible preformance.Pros:The game itself is very fun. The batmobile is a great part of the game that helps with puzzles and overall is just a fun way to get around the city. Combat has been expanded with new enemies and the ability to pick up and use weapons. The one thing that will never make sense is why Batman must go out of his way to show boat when he picks up a weapon. He stands there for an extra 3 seconds flipping a bat instead of hitting people with it. The main story was amazing with a twist around the corner everywhere. Cons:Except for the Arkham Knight. That was the worst identity and was obvious who it was from the start (If you are a big Batman fan). Side quests are boring and repetitive. Looking around a alrge city for dead people was fun. Chasing Firefly in the batmobile each and every time was repetetive. Chasing cars for a while and following them to a stash was boring. Finding a mysterious creature and curing it was boring. They were all practically the same. Remember in Arkham City when the bosses were fun too? You don't get that in this game. Come to think of it, there wasn't actually any bosses. The Arkham Knight should have been a great boss fight, but it wasn't at all. It seems like every boss fight in this game either comes down to chasing them all over the place and taking them down or dealing with a bunch of adds and henchmen without actually fighting the boss.Batmobile combat is less than stellar. Shoot unmanned tanks and shoot more tnaks. There are tanks everywhere. Often times it will be 50 to 1 and you have to take them all. Often times I am frustrated by the batmobile combat because there is so much♥♥♥♥♥♥to watch out for and just isn't fun.Ultimately I wanted to like this game. I just can't when the entire game feels like Rocksteady didn't make it except for the story. Along with the fact that it still has not really had any fixes to issues like the stuttering framerate. Yes the game runs. But it also crashes and stutters every now and then.I can not reccomend this game at full price even if they fixed every single optimisation issue. The game is just missing fun bosses, new gadgets, and the only thing really holding the game up is the story.If you really want the game just wait for the GOTY edition at like 20 dollars. IF it gets GOTY I guess

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Update October 29:The game has been updated. For me, it runs well, though I have a fairly powerful PC.For what it's worth, I enjoy "Arkham Knight". Under different circumstances, I'd recommend it.However, I do not feel adequately compensated for WB's ruining the launch of a game I paid full price for, and took days off to play. Giving me free games I already own, and adding console features that should have been included anyway does not feel fair to me.WB's behavior was immoral, and close to criminal. I can not in good conscience make this a positive review until I feel they actually understand what they did wrong, and repay their fans accordingly.To the employees at Rocksteady, you worked hard on a game for several years, and it shows in the result. I'm sorry that upper-management bungled your work at the last minute.Original:I'll delete this negative review when the game runs. But seriously Warner Bros. I have a good Nvidia graphics card, yet this game still looks and runs like garbage on low settings. Yes, I updated my drivers. No, I'm not going to dig into the system files of a game I paid full price for. Like Assassins Creed Unity, this port has been released a month before it was ready.  I'm posting this negative review to make a point:Don't release an unfinished game. I wouldn't have been mad if this game came out one month later than the console ports. But if you tell me a game releases on a certain day, I expect it to work on that day.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												I've preordered both the base game as well as the season pass long before release. I've had some performance issues, but I really enjoyed the base game content. The DLC isn't really worth it so far (the story packs are nice short "clips" to play through and the Batgirl DLC is quite enjoyable, but other stuff is just skins or challenges, stuff I don't care).So far, I'd really recommend the base game. It has its issues, but it's a very nice end to the Arkham Trilogy (or Quadtrilogy if you want), especially considering the very great open world feel without the fear of missing anything significant before beating the game.So far I even declined on using that possibility to get a full refund on the game. I didn't consider it fair, considering I've had fun for nearly 50 hours (and still haven't solved all Riddler challenges). However, today I noticed this game popping up yet again under Steam's "Popular New Releases". I check in and what do I see?ALL REVIEWS WRITTEN POST-LAUNCH (BUT BEFORE 17th NOVEMBER AS OF RIGHT NOW) ARE TAGGED AS "PRE-RELEASE" BY THE PUBLISHER. THIS IS *NOT* HELPFUL.I could understand them marking old reviews from before the October (or was it early November?) re-release as "pre-release". It's dodgy, but still fair considering they took it off the market, etc.However, I don't see why they should have the right to claim reviews written yesterday, clearly POST-RELEASE as pre-release just to try to lessen their significance.Don't blame the devs, they've delivered a great game, but what the publisher is doing here is more than dodgy. I guess this also marks my last WB Games game for a long while, because this is nothing I want to support in any way or form.Update end of 2016: It took me a while to play through all DLC – and I still haven't finished the Mad Hatter one – but overall I can now definitely say that the DLC is not worth your money. If you're a real completionist, maybe during a sale, but overall none of them is significant in any way. "Story DLCs" all consist of a hand full of rooms (at most) and up to three or four fights or encounters. As amazing as the base game is (apart from that repetitive boss fight), so disappointing are the DLCs.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												So here is an update. After getting really bad performance using a 780ti sli rig, i decided to disable sli and try benchmark the game with a single card which got me much better performance then the two. after editing the ini file I managed to hit 60 fps on max settings apart from gameworks (yay) However this is where the problems started coming in. As i loaded up the story, I started gliding around and noticed huge fps drops and stuttering. I lowered the settings bit by bit to the point where i was set to the lowest settings but was still getting stutters. In combat I got 50 - 60 fps which is great but too bad it isn't consistant throughout. I really was looking forward to playing this game for a long time but the drops are making this game unplayable right now, really disappointed but hopefully patches come at CDPR speed

content:
Posted: January 23
												Fantastic game.  I would say this is my personal favorite in the series for several reasons.  I'll keep this as spoiler free as possible just on a side note.  #1 The combat is the most polished in the series with extra things being added like environment takedowns.  #2 It is the most difficult game in the series combat wise and puzzle wise.  #3 the batmobile is a great addition even though it's a bit slow.  #4 The cinematics/psychological exploration of Bruce Wayne's mind of the game are the best in the series from my perspective.  #5 They added more obsure and interesting villians from the comics.  #6 Finally, this doesn't really apply to a comparison with Asylum, but of the open world Batman games this one felt more coherent, meaning a lot of stuff didn't feel as fetch quest like with the obvious exception of Riddler and one or two of the other side quests like City and Origins felt (meaning I actually was interested in every part of most of the side quests, not just the end).  However, I can say people may not like the lack of proper boss fights in this game.  They still exist, but they are not as prominent as any of the other games (ie Poison Ivy (Arkham Asylym) and Mr. Freeze (Arkham City)).  Overall, the most complete and best open world Batman game.

Yes, finally batman can fully realize his dream of joining the army and blasting those isis ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to smithereens with his batmotank. Thank you rocksteady, for taking arkham city, jacking up the system requirements without making visual improvements, taking out all the fun, and charging $30 for a season pass. content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Against my better judgement I preordered the game because the previous titles in the series all worked very well at launch. What can I say, it's kind of a letdown. I've played for an hour so far and the game itself is probably good.  The combat is fun as always and in contrast to a lot of other people I find the whole Batmobile gameplay quiet appealing so far.That being said, the performance and optimization of this game is a huge bummer.Arguably I don't have the best rig there is, but while I can play The Witcher 3 on high settings without any problems, Arkham Knight's performance is just awful.There are constant fps drops which really disturb the flow of the game and lowering the graphics settings doesn't really do that much, despite making the game look much worse than Arkham Asylum. On top of that, there aren't even that many settings to begin with ingame. You actually have to meddle with an .ini file to change things like Motion Blur or Depth of Field, settings that SHOULD be easily accessable through the menu.YES, you can change these options (which for some people will crash the game on startup, so good luck with that, I guess), BUT this still doesn't excuse the lack of a proper ingame menu to change them. It's Dying Light all over again. So let's hope there will soon be some patches to the performance as well as to the possibilities of configuration. In it's current state, the game is, at least for me, not fun to play.Another point of criticism is the magnificently intransparent DLC policy coming with this game. I preordered it and according to my vendor's advertisement I SHOULD have the Harley Quinn DLC....well...like many others I don't, and nobody really seems to know why. What I read on forums went from it being Gamestop exclusive to having been pulled by Rocksteady from the preorder last minute and now being avaiable through the Season Pass, which would quiet frankly be beyond devious.So all in all, it is a pretty messed up launch and I strongly recommend AGAINST buying it at this point, at least not for full price. I actually got it cheaper and I still am rather annoyed.

number of helpful: 143 of 227 people (63%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Batman Arkham Knight is an action-adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Brothers, coming out on PS4, Xbox One and PC in June 2015.  The game is run using the Unreal Engine 3. The PC release of Arkham Knight brought plenty of controversy and issues.  The technical issues on the PC release almost forced Warner Brothers to suspend sales on the game in order for them to address the issues people were having. The game was re-released on Steam in October 2015 after a few patches in order to solve the technical issues.  Sadly people still reported problems with the game forcing Warner Brothers to offer full refunds on the game regardless of whether you met the regular criteria or not.  To this day, the developers are still working on technical issues which people are having. Before I start my review, I would like to point out that I played this game on a mechanical hard drive, with one nVidia 970 (my second one is being RMA’ed right now!), playing at 1080p with graphics turned on and the majority of the nVidia graphics options turned on as well.  On launch of the title, Warner Brothers recommended that the game be installed on a solid state drive, so as you read the review, please bear all of the above in mind. Game play in Arkham Knight is again, the same as its predecessors; this shouldn’t be taken as a negative thing though, as the game play is absolutely stellar. The combat system is as fluid and easy to grasp as ever, with some new and interesting combos and special take downs being introduced, such as double take downs when you are working with a partner on some missions.  Some new gadgets have been introduced, a remote controlled batarang which can scan the area for information, and a voice synthesiser, that mimics other character’s voices; this gives you plenty of different ways to use such as ordering enemies around and opening voice controlled locked doors. The major new game play mechanic that has been added in Arkham Knight is the Batmobile.  You are able to summon the Batmobile to your location when you are on foot or gliding in the air. The Batmobile has two different mods that can easily be used at any time: Pursuit and Battle. Pursuit is the regular movement mode with little on offer in terms of firepower, as you are traveling from A to B. Battle mod turns your Batmobile into a death machine; as you utilise all of the weapon systems on board. The Batmobile can be upgraded using the points you are rewarded with for levelling up as well. Graphically, I was really impressed with how the game looked. The high resolution textures and rain effects are all stunning.  All of the characters look almost life like, and you can really appreciate this when you get close up shots on their faces; so much detail has gone into the modelling and texturing, to the point where you can see the blackheads on the Joker’s face! All of the game’s animations are done very well too; the Arkham combat system has a very fluid feel to it, so they need to be spot on or else it would just look out of place. The plot within Arkham Knight is probably my favourite of the series so far. It is the last episode in the Arkham series, so takes place after origins, Asylum and City. I have not read the comic book series so I missed out on a lot of the plot in between the games but the game does do a good job of trying to fill in the gaps.  Arkham Knight introduces a few new main characters to the fold if you haven’t read the comic books too, such as Robin, and a more starring role for Barbara Gordon. With plenty of the other regulars returning, such as Cat-Woman and Alfred. You will encounter plenty of the super villains, Scarecrow, Penguin, Two-Face, Riddler, Poison Ivy, Harley Quin, and of course, the Joker. One new villain, Arkham Knight also has a starring role and has an important storyline plot attached to him as well. Difficulty can be scaled depending on how hard you set the game. I felt the medium setting to be just enough challenge without hitting the brick wall. None of the boss battles in Arkham Knight are just generic fist fights, each of them uses a unique mechanic which adds some variety to the game. As with its predecessors’ the open world aspect of the game does a very good job of filling in lots of “blank space” with plenty of side missions and collectables to find. Most Wanted missions, Riddler's Revenge, collectables and AR challenges makes the optional part of the game full to the brim with content. You are also able to unlock different endings to the game by completing the side missions as well, giving you more incentive to continue playing after finishing. I have been playing for about twenty five hours so far, this has allowed me to finish a handful of side missions and the main story in the game. I will definitely be dropping a few more hours into completing the rest of the most wanted missions in order to unlock the alternative endings, but I can’t see myself wanting to collect the hundreds of Riddler items again after my fiasco with the past two games with them! Now, onto the technical issues.  As I said above, I am using a single nVidia 970 and the game was installed on a mechanical hard drive. The majority of the time the game was running around 57-60 fps. There are moments where the frame rate will drop to 30 for no good reason. I can understand if it drops on more graphically intensive scenes or when there is a lot happening, but it can sometimes happen when you are in a building with very little going on. Maybe this would have been different if I was using SLI, but even then, it has been reported the SLI makes no difference to the performance. Taking all of this into consideration it seems I was on the lucky side and the pure power in my machine seemed to pull it through to an acceptable playable state.My conclusion of Batman Arkham Knight may come as a controversial one, but like all of my reviews it is my honest and truthful opinion. I am going to highly recommend Arkham Knight. The game play and interesting compelling story make it a definite worthwhile play through.  I would only recommend this game to people who have a bit of meat in their rig to play it though, unless you are willing to sacrifice some of the graphical fidelity, please bear in mind all of what I noted in the technical issues section of the review and make your judgement on purchasing the game on that if you are on the fence. The game’s retail price on Steam is £34,99, I would also recommend that you don’t purchase it for that price, either get it from another source (definitely not GEE 2 AAAA hint hint hint hint) or wait for one of Steam’s sales as this game will go on sale for less than £20, and more than likely even more now.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Neither Warner Bros., Rocksteady, or Iron Galaxy Studios deserve your money for this half attempted port which released with tons of issues. Took months to fix and the entire time nothing was done to make things right with the PC community, just thanks for being patient in a situation where players had no choice but to either hang tight or get a refund.Go watch some Youtube videos of people playing the game to get the best it has to offer without any of the pain as Rocksteady loses their way by overpromising and discovering just how hard it is to deliver on those promises. Get ready to experience the Bat-tank, a wannabe Batmobile that plays more like it belongs in Armored Core than a Batman game and will leave you wondering how on Earth Batman avoids killing people while running them over in a two ton vehicle doing 90 mph. Watch as characters are marginalized to pointless side missions which feel like a reason to implement some weird puzzle mechanic or to merely make things so easy there isn't even a challenge anymore. Watch in awe as Rocksteady disregards their own story timeline and simply throws characters in where they don't belong because they already built that character model so who cares if we got the wrong Robin? Prepare yourself to be underwhelmed by every piece of DLC content that is not only overpriced but underdeveloped as skins look worse than they did last generation, new characters can't be used in free roam mode, and story content that leaves you scratching your head as to when any of this is supposed to take place.This is how they did it. This is how they killed the Batman.Good job Warner Bros., Rocksteady, and Iron Galaxy Studios for taking what should have been a surefire hit and doing nearly everything possible short of coming to my home and punching me in the gut right after I booted the game up to ensure this was a miserable experience. Save yourself even those couple of bucks you're thinking of spending on this because it's already heavily discounted because they lost a ton of money on this port. There are far better games to play than this and far better developers who will actually deliver a functioning game when promised without compromising their vision to make sure the console version is working and the graphics are as pretty as possible with gameplay coming second. There are times where even the voice actors are phoning it in because they could tell how ridiculous this was. Spoiler alert this game contains the most unconvincing death scene ever that leaves you wondering when a 12 year old took over writing duties and why the cast seems more interested in delivering as few words or emotion as possible before moving on like it never happened.

content:
Posted: March 18
												It's been a long journey with Batman. I've been playing Arkham games since november and I gotta say I had great times while playing those games. Wish they never ended but all good things come to an end, right? Arkham Knight is a great game in almost every way. They've improved combat A LOT since Arkham City, added new moves, gadgets, mechanics etc. Animations, movement, everything have been improved. I remember the first time when it came out. People were complaining about the optimization but it seems like it's been fixed now. Although they added Batmobile and improved everything, it seems like they've restrained some good things like boss fights. There are boss fights but most of them are tank battles. I remember only two boss battles that we had to fight with fists. Waste of an amazing combat system if you ask me. About the city... well... we still don't have whole Gotham to explore, instead we have three huge islands which is enough if you ask me. Apart from all of those amazing features, most thing I liked about the game was Red Hood. Buy the DLC, mod the game, and kill those filthy criminals. Like I said, it's a great game in almost every way. If you think your PC can handle it, buy it and enjoy!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
 This review is updated and based off the version after the September 3ed patch So while this game has had a hard first few months, it finally got its patch. With this new patch, preformance was increased, the 30 fps cap is now an optional setting in graphics tab, and stuttering is minimum if you set settings to ones that match your PC build (but still consistant). Now to the breakdown.Gameplay+The characters, enemies and allies, are very well designed and voiced+This Batman game adds many new mechanics listed below   +Batmobile/vehicle's make for awesome gameplay   +New enemies, from Medics that revive enemies to brutes weilding Miniguns    +New abilites, such as the Fear Takedown and Counter-throw   +Have a helper during combat, for new items/abilities and duel takedowns+The map is large, filled with enemies and interesting side-quest+The AI is more adaptive with the Militia, such as radio checkins, seeing into and grenading vents, and drones+Selecting side-quest is a breeze with the new mission select wheel+The game is just amazingly beutiful-The game seems to lag more during batmobile chases, prefer to roam by glide to reduce lag-The game still lags a lot, and stuttering still occures-As far as I've seen so far, you cannot switch characters (i.e. Robin, Nightwing) outside of their missions, making them one-time characters, making their unique weapon-loadout pointless-PC controls are terrible, either adapt or use a consol controller PC adapter like I use-Some side-quest are very short, and makes me wishing they would make them longerStory (Warning, May Contain Slight Spoilers+The story was decently long, and interesting+Scarecrow and the Arkham Knight made great main-enemies+The Arkham Knight is a well-design character, personality and preformance wise+Has a good few twist in the story-One detective-mode crimescene in the entire main story, and a few mini-detective-mode crimescene's in sidequest. Wtf WB Games? They were one of the funnest parts!!!-Has a pretty obvious twist if you're a fan of Batman, knowing the comicbooks OverallThe game was very enjoyable to play overall. However, one feature that I really enjoyed from previous Arkham games, the Detective Crime scanes were lacking, very disappointed by this. The Batmobile made a heavy impact on the game, in both quest and campaign, making up for lack of detective work. This is, what I believe, to be a great ending to the Batman: Arkham series, however with WB games taking its sweet time releasing the patch, I feel like the PC version is dead and unrevivable.EDIT: With the refund option now avalible for everyone, no matter the hours played, I would recommend to refund the game for PC. While I do not recommend the game for PC, I do recommend the game for console if avalible.

number of helpful: 20 of 20 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												TLDR; 7/10 game running at a 3/10 performance. Game runs poorly, actual story is okay but ruined in the last hour, extra collectables were a chore and not worth the time and effort. Buy GOTY edition for cheap but the game still isn't good enough on PC. I will update this review with future patches.Please note, I have played Arkham Asylum and City both to 100% on PC/xbox 360. I have also played origins but did not 100% the main. This review will not contain any spoilers. I played at 1080 resolution at around 60/45fps with very occasional dips lower, with the lowest settings for everything. I have an i7 4770k, 16gb RAM and a GTX 770 and I played this on windows 8. I played the game on a SSD so loading times might be considerably better for me than the files on a HDD. When I played the game, I had the interim patch but from what I understand, the full release hasn't changed much. Also, I played the game with a wired xbox 360 controller on a 1080 TV on hard mode. Your experience may differ based on your hardware and software. Also I will not be including a full dlc review in this. Performance/appearance:Batman Arkham knight ran poorly on my machine. There was issues concerning large frame rate drops about (20-30 fps decrease), textures not loading for a few seconds, micro stuttering and large loading times. The performance is unacceptably bad for a game in 2015 with a major publisher backing the studio. The patches have improved the performance however, it is still not good enough for most gamers. You shouldn't be required to have a SSD, over 8 GB RAM and a 760+ for a performance this bad. I suspect more patches will be added in the future to improve the performance so if you want an update of the performance based on my parts in the future then send me a mail and I will see if things have improved. Batmobile sections were the biggest offenders of reducing the frame rate however the frame rate dropped at random during other portions of the game.I will say, the game was nice to look at with some cool destructions physics, lighting effects some excellent rain effects. If you are using an nvidia card the nvidia gameworks options look nice but they completely crippled my frame rate to around 22-18 fps. I'm not sure what the effect will be on an AMD card but I imagine it will probably make things even worse for your experience. Gameplay:Gameplay is broken up into a few different sections. These include combat, stealth, free roam, driving the batmobile and small detective section. These mechanics are used in part with the side missions and the main campaign. If you have played any of the Arkham games you know how the combat is and the free roaming however there has been minor changes which did make a difference to my experience with the game.Combat was much less precise than in Asylum or City. I found myself hitting enemies who I was not aiming for more than a few times which lead to some unfair deaths. My partner and a friend played the PS4 version and we found the same issue with their experience too. Some of the new enemies aloud for healing and revival which combined with existing enemies, meant combat lasted far too long in some sections. However, as a Batman veteran, the game was a nice challenge with the combat and it was nice for hard mode to actually feel like it was hard at times. Stealth is for the most part unchanged. You distract enemies, you knock them out, you pick them up one by one and you which if you have played any of the previous games you know the song and dance. There are some minor changes but they don't change too much bar getting the fear multi takedown ability which makes many of the stealth sections much easier. In response, enemies have new gadgets and tech but it is given at a nice difficulty curve. Freeroaming was probably the least changed mechanic but the most improved. The grappling hook has received a much welcomed boost in strength and you can go much further and faster than in previous games. I did have some issues with the frame rate during some of the very fast flight sections however they were not too frequent. The only down side to freely roaming the city is some sections will require you to use the batmobile. Which leads me to my next point. The batmobile was the worst bit of the game and unfortunately you have to spend a lot of time in it. As I mentioned in my performance paragraph, I found the frame rate was at its worst during these sections with the frame rate dropping significantly when driving very quickly. The batmobile is also used in stealth section in some ridiculous ways and many times during the game when i didn't know what to do, the solution as using the batmobile in some silly way. I get that this is a game and I should suspend my disbelief but I also didn't have much fun during these sections due to the dull tank controls, low frame rate and at the rate I had to use it. Detective mode has probably been one of the smallest but most significant changes for Arkham Knight. The main detective vision has been seriously nerfed giving less detail on objects, being blocked more often in stealth sections, not available in the batmobile and having a lower viewer distance. For most of the game this isn't an issue, however I will explain why it is an issue with the side missions. There are some decent side missions but some of the supervillains were pretty lame and their side missions were tedious with the same mission repeated several times. If you aren't going to try and get all the riddles then move onto my story section. If you have played any of the previous games then you will know about the riddler mission which involves collecting question mark tokens and taking pictures of question marks and small hints of characters from the batman universe. As I mentioned in detective mode, the vision mode has been hugely nerfed and now riddler clues are not highlighted at all. This means you are almost forced to go find all the riddler informants and constantly check you map which can be a chore at best and a miserable slog at worse. Story:As I mentioned, I won't be spoiling the game. I felt the Arkham Knight was a little underwhelming but it was to be expected. I would recommend avoiding IMDB pages and looking up voice actors if you don't want to know who the Arkham Knight. However, the identity was pretty obvious about 50% through the story. Parts of the best bits of the story are literally there to develop the reveal or the Arkham Knight and was some brilliant depictions of some of the iconic sections of the batman lore. There was a complaint I had that one of the best bits of the game and some of the story arcs of one of the characters was made completely pointlessly in the last reveal. This was a disappointment to me as it was one of the best bits of the game and probably the single most shocking part in any of the Arkham games.  Overall, the story was the only thing keeping me going and I found once I was done with the story, the fun I had with the game was diminished and I was getting impatient with the side missions. If you are compelled to collect everything like I was then go for it but if I were to do it for a first time again, finish all the side missions except the riddler and then watch the true ending on YouTube. Please let me know if I have missed anything and I can update my review to reflect my opinion on the sections I have missed.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I waited patiently for four months for Rocksteady and Warner Bros. to put this game back on Steam and fix it properly. I bought it when it was first up for sale, and the game ran very poorly for me, yet I wanted to know where the story went so I struggled through all the lag and stuttering and horrible textures to play through it to the end of the main story. I only own a PC and not any consoles so that was the only choice available to me to play through the game. I was really excited to play the sequel to Arkham Asylum and City, two games that I really enjoyed, and I am a huge Batman fan. I read all the comic books, and I watch all the movies and cartoons, so I was always going to play through this game, awful port or not.Now I will admit I don't have the best and most up to date computer in the world, but I find it more than adequate to play through pretty much any other game I might try to throw at it. I've enjoyed playing The Witcher 3, GTA V, MGS V and countless other great games on it this year with perfectly acceptable settings and stable performance. But somehow this game just won't quite run nicely for me, even after the update from a month or two ago, which did improve things for me and make the game run a fair bit better, it's still not quite right. The framerate jumps up and down like a yo-yo, from around 55fps to 25fps, constantly shifting. I'd prefer the game to run at a consistent 60fps but I honestly don't mind a framerate in the 30 range, but only if it's stable and consistent, but it is not in this game no matter what settings I put it on. It's kind of like watching a movie and somebody is constantly pressing the fast forward and pause button. The textures, which I have to play on 'low' as I have a 2gb VRAM card, have improved from the awful state of release, but I still see occasional objects that just look like a blurry mess. There's also still issues with dialogue going out of sync on cut scenes.What annoys me here is that this is a game running on Unreal Engine 3, a game engine that has been around for over a decade and developers really have no excuse for not being able to develop stable and well optimised games on it at this stage. I understand that it is a 'heavily modified' version of Unreal Engine 3, but it really shouldn't matter. And it most certainly should not be an engine that requires amazing hardware to handle a game developed on it. I believe Bioshock Infinite runs on UE3 and I run that game at like a stable 80fps with everything on max settings, different type of game admittedly, but really there is no excuse.Normally at this point I would say that graphics don't really matter, and it is gameplay, story and replayability that’s important. I would dearly like to say that about this game, but I just can't quite say that. I did enjoy many things about this game, it is basically the same as Asylum and City but with some cool new moves put in which work from the FEAR suit. I do love the design in this game. The way Batman's suit looks is seriously cool, and Gotham City is beautifully detailed and huge in scope. The new thing in this one is the Batmobile, I know a lot of people hate it, but I actually rather enjoyed it, but it is certainly overused. I particularly don't like it when you are literally driving the batmobile inside buildings to solve environmental puzzles. I get it, you've got this cool new thing, and you want to show it off, but there is no need to try and force it in to nearly every part of the game. I did like the story of this game, I particularly like the references to The Killing Joke, and how they brought back a certain character. Many of the moments in the story were very emotionally charged in a way that the previous games lacked. What is a shame is that the game lacks the great boss battles that the previous games were so memorable for. Scarecrow as the main villain I found particularly disappointing. I've always found him interesting as a psychological manipulative villain, but all the stuff about him in this game just basically comes to nothing. There's also another villain in this game whose story is a bit odd, without wanting to spoil anything all I can really say is that it's just kind of lame the way they try to hide something which is very obvious to any Batman fan. They could have just done his story a lot better, and it could have been amazing, but as it is, it's just kind of a messed up opportunity.I cannot give this game a thumbs up and I do not recommend it. It is not completely unplayable to me, and as described the game has a lot of commendable things. If you are a fan of the series and have to play it, then yeah get it, but do be aware that for a lot of people it is still unplayable. If you can get it on another system or are able to wait then don't get it now on Steam. Don't expect this game to ever be properly fixed. Warner Bros./Rocksteady have been saying for months about all the stuff they are going to do to fix it, but still haven't done all the stuff they said they would. They seem more concerned about getting the DLC up. Their idea of compensation is almost laughable, not that I ever wanted free stuff from them, I wanted a working game. But the way they treat their customers is disrespectful, and ultimately that is why I have to give this game a thumbs down.Edit: well the game now runs quite well for me, with some tweaking. If I lock the framerate to 30fps to get a pretty consistent stutter free experience that looks quite nice. It's not perfect though by any means and 30fps is far from ideal, but I can live with it for now. My thumbs down still stays though I'm afraid. It took too long for them to even put a graphics menu in with a fully featured set of options, and the attitude from Warner Bros just was not what I would call good customer service. Even with the game working alright for me, it's still a bit of a let down compared to the previous games in terms of story and gameplay. I can't help but wonder what I'd think of this game had it been released in the state it is at now. But I'll never know the answer to that unfortunately.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Rating: 8.5/10Overview: Open World Action Adventure The Good:+ One of the best looking open world games I have ever played. + This game handles one of my bigger criticisms I had with the previous games, the open world feels a lot more alive; cop cars chase criminals, military and thugs patrol the streets, etc. + I love the story and how many of the characters make a return and the roles they play. A fantastic way to finish the series. + The batmobile looks and plays incredibly well. The ability to call the car at a moment’s notice, seeing it drive through the streets as it turns right before you and then jump in and drive off without missing a second feels awesome.   +Solid sense of progression and upgrades. Gaining experience unlocks more powerful combat moves and gadgets. + AR challenge maps further the replay value giving you extra challenges. You can play as many different characters+ Riddler trophies makes a return. Many of these collectables have a little puzzle associated with them making them fun to collect if you are into that sort of thing. + Great voice acting and sound + New Game Plus- Upgrades carry over. The Average:+/- Given the calibre of this game I was a bit disappointed with the graphical and gameplay options. +/- Side quests that deal with villains are fun, however other side quests suffer with open world syndrome, i.e they start to feel repetitive over time. You can only disable so many road mines, military checkpoints, save so many fireman before you start getting tired of it. +/- The game is heavily designed around using the batmobile. Many objectives have you using the batmobile whether for driving or combat. If you don’t like the controls or using the car in general you may be disappointed with a lot of the missions. +/- Combat remains mostly the same. You can strike, counter, dodge, use gadgets and do a variety of special moves all while trying to maintain the combo meter.  The new addition is that you can now fight with a partner and do a special takedown moves. There are also a few new enemies to keep things fresh. The developers decided to make changes to the camera, timing and some changes to certain move sets which lead to a more frustrating experience. +/- This game features a ton of DLC, yet most of them never felt substantial. Most of the arkham episodes can easily be beaten in under 30 minutes and most of them play out exactly the same.  The Bad:- This is not a well optimised PC game.  This game is one of the worst pc ports in recent memory and even after many problems were fixed the game still struggles to play sometimes. You need a system above minimum requirements to play this game at a somewhat decent performance.  Conclusion:I love Rocksteady Batman games, they are some of my favorite games and if this is Rocksteady’s final Batman game then they should be very proud of their efforts. Though I love the game, the formula is starting to wear thin for me. If you played Arkham City and even Origins this game offers little surprise, you’ve done it all before except this time you have the batmobile.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
If you overlook disasterous release of Batman™: Arkham Knight it's a well elaborated game with amazing graphics.Arkham Knight brings large rigorous open world, Batmobile and with it the whole new system of drone fights. Speaking about Batmobile for one thing it's sad when drone fights become annoying when the game forces you to crush an army of them for hundered times over and over. On the other hand driving Batmobile through Gotham streets or on one of many race tracks the game offers is pretty enjoyable. It was for the first time I found Arkham challenges entertaining. Predator mode is terrific as always, including more features than before, new types of enemies and also gadgets. This is what developers did really great work with. However what I think is not done with great care or I could say was sloppily made is the story. Many think the story is the best part of the Arkham series, but in this title its predictable, rapidly escalating and not going too far. Best part of it are cutscenes which are joy to behold.Altogether I recommend this one if you have played previous titles.7.5 /10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
EDIT #2 as of 6/24, afternoonIt seems like they've patched the Batmobile wrecking the framerate. This is a pretty huge improvement, since large portions of the game require you to use it. There's still a lot of motion blur (unsure if that's frames related or what) when moving the camera, and a couple moments of frame drop every now and again. Overall the experience is definitely improving, and the optimization issues are not impeding my progress in the game.EDIT #1 as of 6/23, late afternoonI was told about this thread, which has been very helpful with regards to stabilizing the framerate. Shoutout to Derp or whatever your name is for going over all the gamefiles and figuring this out. I also downloaded the "game-ready" drivers which apparently came out yesterday, you can read more about it here[www.geforce.com]. With all of that, the game is definitely playable but certainly not amazing. Still getting frame drops from rotating the cam and driving the Batmobile, but it has yet to go into slideshow mode again. If the remaining frame drops are eliminated and the devs fix up the game so nobody has to root around in the game files, I'll consider switching this review to "recommended". As of now, I wouldn't recommend the current experience to consumers (especially not at full price)My original reviewas of 6/23, early afternoonI'm leaving this up in full so people get an idea of what the game was like on release:Nearly unplayable in its current state. At first I thought the framedrops only occurred during cutscenes, until the combat started and the game became a slideshow randomly. God forbid you get in the Batmobile- for whatever reason that thing absolutely MURDERS the framerate.The rest of the game seems to look good, the combat seems snappy and responsive, and the gadgets all seem to function just as well as the other games in this series... I just can't play it when I'm faced with constant fluctuations between 14 and 25 FPS. I can barely make out what's happening on-screen and I feel like I'm going to get motion sickness or something. Yes, I've heard of the .ini file you can edit to unlock the 30FPS cap but all other reports seem to say the performance somehow gets even worse when you do that.I'm totally willing to re-write this review if Rocksteady shows they actually care about finishing the job. As of now, they've released an unfinished, unoptimized game that is not fun to play and I cannot say anything other than this- stay far, far away.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												You do not have the graphical capability to fully enjoy this game. Whatever you think, your graphics card is most likely not powerful enough to support this game. That's all there is to it.Against all warnings from friends, I pre-ordered this game along with the season pass to play it on launch date, like I've done with all of the Arkham series games. This is the first time however that I decided to get the game on PC, the last times were always on PS3. But since this game is next generation, I could not justify buying a PS4 just to play it, I instead decided to use my PC, which, while a year old at this point, is still very powerful, I can play most new games with the highest settings (Mad Max and Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain work smooth as butter with maxed out settings). This was not the case with Batman Arkham Knight on June 26.While I was one of the lucky ones to be able to play the game at all, throughout my playthrough I had only 2 crashes which came at two unrelated random points. But otherwise, I could play the game and I was willing to overlook most problems, chalking it off as it'll get patched in the coming weeks, I mean it's not uncommon. My nVidia GeForce Experience optimal settings recommended that I minimalise all settings, which to me was shocking, how needy could the game be? So I ignored it and wanted to experience how bad it can get. And oh man, it got bad. The framerate could not handle anything and would often drop down to 1.Throughout my gameplay I eventually had a system going where whenever I was out as Batman, I would set my texture quality to medium, shadow quality to low and level of detail on high, but whenever I was in the Batmobile and there was any kind of action, I had to drop the texture quality and level of detail back to low and back again whenever there were any kinds of cutscenes going on so I could enjoy the experience even slightly. But even then, I played the game and defended it, because in the end, when it all comes down to it, it's NOT a bad game.I enjoyed the Batmobile sequences more the more I learned how to handle the controls and the innovations in combat when you're controlling Batman were definitely the best so far. The parts of Gotham you get the explore (and it's not the whole city, just 3 parts of it) are big, but not overwhelmingly so, because the Batmobile makes pretty fast to traverse around. The usual controls were a bit changed however which did confuse me throughout the game, but it's nothing too damaging to the overall experience. I had fun, enjoyed the story which I will not spoil, but I'm pretty sure everyone knows at this point, and managed to complete my normal playthrough to 100%. I decided to leave the New Game+ mode for whenever the game gets patched and I can play it with optimum settings.So if I liked the game, why the negative review? Simple. This port is atrocious compared to the console ports. The PC port was a simple afterthought and was handled by another developer, not Rocksteady. So when push came to shove in releasing the game, all the innovations that Rocksteady made, were not translated properly and the game sufferred. As most of you know, it was so bad that WB had to take the game off Steam so that they could develop a patch. For 3 months. It is now October and the patch was released. Can people play this game now? Yes. Did they fix some major issues? According to them, they have. Have they really? No, the game still functions the same as it did before for me. I can still only play the game with minimum settings.Honestly, I think the only way they could have fixed it would have been if they reworked the graphics engine for the game and I seriously doubt they want to do that at this point. WB PR solution to this is to give out all the previous Arkham games out for free to the buyers who've waited for 3 months and not returned the game back in the first week. I already have all the Arkham games. I think most fans do. They're the ones that made us want to buy this sequel. Plus, the games have been on every other sale for around 5 euros each, so I'm pretty sure everyone has them. I personally am not getting anything out of being patient and supportive from all this time. From my perspective, they've done nothing to improve my experience.So no, don't buy this game. Not on PC. Wait a couple of years. Let it drop in price, naturally upgrade your computer with time, let them patch it over and over and only then you'll have a good enough reason to play it.Or go play it on the consoles now, it works perfectly fine there.

number of helpful: 86 of 136 people (63%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												The forth game in the Arkham series (and the third developed by Rocksteady) is one that is in serious danger of collapsing under the weight of franchise fatigue. Early impressions are that it’s business as usual – A dark, brooding, po-faced adventure where you play a man who dresses as a bat while driving a funny bat themed car. Never is this bizarre tonal contradiction more acute than when you are afflicted with fear gas – after dealing with the terrifying nightmarish journey through your conflicted subconscious you return to reality and you’re still a man dressed as a bat.Let’s discuss the creaking, oiled leather clad elephant in the room before going any further – the PC port. On a 980ti at 1080p, with almost everything set to it’s highest I managed a mostly stable 60FPS on foot, and an uneven but playable framerate when driving. Turning on enhanced fog and debris brought the framerate crashing down, which puts it on par with most Nvidia specific features in games (hot garbage). So not fantastic, but a far cry from the car crash that the game was at launch.Let’s also discuss the smaller, leotard wearing acrobat elephant in the room – the batmobile. This is the big selling point of the game, and it’s clear a lot of work has gone into this. The developers are obviously very proud of their creation, and it takes any excuse to pan leeringly over it’s admittedly impressive bodywork, focussing on it’s plates and gears and seemingly extraneous transforming knick-knacks. You’ll be using it a lot whether you like it or not. Virtually every section of the game has a mandatory car section wedged in there, and it is almost entirely to the games detriment. Driving around Gotham is fun in short bursts, though in all honesty grappling and gliding is both faster and typically more entertaining, as well as granting you a superior vantage point to spot the game’s generous helping of side quests.Really, the bulk of Arkham Knight’s problems rest with the tank. You seem to spend half the game circle strafing enemy drones, and the tank combat never gets any more complex or entertaining. From the first battle, you’ve seen everything the tank has to offer. That half of the boss battles are also tank based just adds insult to injury – there’s nothing here that even approaches the creativity of the Freeze battle in City, a high point among a series rich in excellent set pieces.The tank also stretches even videogame credulity to breaking point – ploughing into a thug at high speed jolts him (totally non lethally yo) out of the way, and hitting a person with a cannon capable of shredding steel seems to cause nothing more serious than unconsciousness (and presumably the odd shattered pelvis). That’s to say nothing of the unsettling realisation that I’m playing a millionaire using my wealth to hunt the poor and dispossessed – admittedly a problem that has plagued any modern day interpretation of Batman, but it’s at its most crass here.It’s when the game is most like it’s predecessors that it’s at it’s best – the early portions of the game with Scarecrow are narrow and focussed, and the batmobile still novel enough to be entertaining. The trifecta of stealth, punching and puzzle solving is still engaging (though beginning to sag under the weight of feature creep), and the whole game is so polished you can see your chiselled, scowling face in it. Voice acting is impeccable as ever, though outside of the welcome return of Scarecrow the rogue’s gallery is limp – it was inevitable that by the third game we’d be resorting to repetition or second stringers (with the titular Arkham Knight himself being mostly an extended bum note).The side quests, featuring more colourful B-Listers (including a welcome appearance by Man Bat) are almost universally more entertaining than the main story – the extended Riddler sidequest inparticular is a high point, though quite how race circuits feature into his battle of wits is not particularly clear. The challenges are however varied and often require you to at least partially engage your brain, more than can be said for the rest of the game. Sadly, some of the other sidequests are Ubisoft tier busywork – including the interminable Riddler trophy ticklist, an exercise in mind numbing masochism which is gallingly required for the true ending.While this is a review of nothing but complaining, it’s worth noting that Arkham Knight is not a BAD game, not really – just one that is inferior to the games that preceded it, learning all the wrong lessons. Everything new falls flat, and when it sticks to what it knows it can’t help but feel a bit tired. I really need that middle ground rating curiously absent from steam, as this has got 3/5 written all over it – it feels like a cop out to say “If you want more Batman, you’ll enjoy this” but that’s really what it comes down to – more of the same, except the new parts that are a bit rubbish.

												WOW, MIGHT BE THE WORST PC PORT THIS YEAR.MY PC SPECSI7 4790kMsi gtx970 (2)16gb of ramcorsair ax860 power supplycrucial m500 960gb ssdFirst off they don't let you change the frame rate past 30 in game, in my opinion because they new no machine could run this game in any setting over that because of such HORRIBLE OPTIMIZATION!!!!!!!!!!Then they make an sli profile that I personally see worse results then with one gtx 970.I would have prefered if they made this game well optimized and not have a day one horrible sli profileI tried runnig the game on LOW SETTINGS with ALL NVIDIA GAMEWORKS FEATURES OFF and still dip under 30 fps on the regular.THERE SHOULD BE NO GAME THAT REQUIRES A GAMING RIG THIS POWERFULL TO RUN BELOW 60FPS ON 1080P ON HIGH SETTINGS LET ALONE ON LOWLONG STORY SHORT - if you like playing games in 1080p at 60fps THIS IS NOT THE GAME FOR YOU!!!luckily for anyone who bought this game you can get refunds now. I got it free when I bought my second gtx970 and I'm still upset about this, so I can only imagine how♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I would be if I pre ordered this game (which I don't  pre-order games anymore, ever since assasins creed 3)Hopefully the community can come up in arms and force the developer to fix this joke of a port by requesting a refund in mass numbers.I came into this franchise back when Arkham city came out, My first preorder (for ps3) which I loved at the time, then played arkham Origins which ran decently, but had game breaking parts early on (luckily it was patched and works pretty good now) Best case scenerio the developer show's that they actually CARE ABOUT THE PC PORT and will make a patch as soon as possible.If you haven't bought this game yet consider yourself lucky and wait until a patch comes out to make this game playable at respectable frame rates.EDITED:I still can't 100% or even 50% recomend this game, unless you have a 980ti and up, or a g sync monitor, but since the last reviewI changed the max fps from 144 to 60turned off sli profileand I'm now able to run the game around 45 to 60 fps for 80% of the time with the occasional dips to 30 Which doesn't sound great, but IF YOU HAVE A G SYNC MONITOR, and don't mind playing it in mostly low settings, the gameplay is refreshed enough with a story so far that is my favorite of all the last arkham games "gameplay wise", I personally do like the car mode and tank mode addition.PLEASE MAKE THIS GAME RUN BETTER DEV'S hopefully they patch this wtihin the week so people can enjoy this game on pc

												(Writing this late cause my old computer wasnt able to run it)Wow! I must say as a massive fan of Batman and the Arkham games (Apart from Origins) this is the true epitome of Batman lore. Nothing comes close as it pays homage to so many great characters, In detail I havent seen before! Nothing immerses me as much as a video game does, This is one of the reasons Batman: Arkham Knight is so great (and why I love video games so much :) ). Exploring Gotham is a treat gliding or driving the Batmobile, Announcements pop up from all over and the game constantly engages you to search all around the city. Each Villian has there own feel and interesting story to go with. There are many twists in the game which im sure would have more effect on me if i didnt already know what was going to happen ;) (Massive Batman nerd here), But the way they're revealed is great and enjoyable. The combat is great as always maybe a bit stale now, But this is the final batman game so its been well used and not overdone.There is so much i want to talk about, but it is hard to without spoiling the story and i hate when reviewers do that. I will just say this is the greatest portrayal of the Batman Universe to date and would recommend it to anyone even remotely interested in Batman, i know theres alot of fans out there but still... im really bad at ending this so im just gonna say GO BUY BATMANSSSSSS!!!!

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
Batman: Arkham Knight is not a perfect game, but it has come a long way since launch. You can play it now, most issues have been fixed.I didn't play the game at launch because of all the problems regarding the PC port and I must say that the waiting has paid off with this title. One year later, after numerous patches, the game has fixed most of the performance issues and bugs. Best graphics in a Batman game so far deliver a breathtaking Gotham City that you get to explore at good frame rates. However, I noticed some frame drops in the Batmobile and I see that a lot of people are complaining about the same problem. In 50h of gameplay it crashed once for me, but I was very satisfied with the overall performance.The story is awesome and as far as I can tell you should play Arkham Origins, Arkham Asylum and Arkham City in this order if you want to fully understand and enjoy it. Skip Blackgate - that game is bad. Without going into very much detail: you'll get to fight against most adversaries from the Batman universe and sometimes your assistans will join to help. The Batmobile is a big part of the game and integrates vehicle combat as a new gameplay element. Most of the time you will use it as a tank to destroy drones and it gets repetitive, but sometimes you'll also need it to pass certain puzzles or transport captured villains to your headquarters: the GCPD building.Combat on foot is similar to the previous games - part melee encounters, part stealth sectors where enemies have fire weapons. A new  takedown system and gadgets have been added to Batman's repertoire.Gotham City is your stage once again, but this time you'll encounter more elements from the open-world genre. These come in the form of various optional missions such as liberating towers, taking out drones or disarming land mines. You can treat them as time fillers or new opportunities to test your moves and gadgets. On the other hand, the villain optional missions are more fun and make a better part of the story with mini-boss battles and cut-scenes at the end. All optional missions reward the player with Wayne Tech points needed for upgrading your suit, gadgets and Batmobile. Conclusion: A true sequel to previous Batman games that could have been the perfect ending for the series if it didn't suffer from minor technical problems. Still, worth playing for the amazing graphics, great atmoshpere and story.

												I upgraded my PC to a rx 480 and wanted to play a graphics intensive game to test it out. Lo and behold, bamham arkham knight, sequel to 2 of my favorite games, is on sale. I was wrong. I boot up the game, excitedly crank up every single setting to the highest it can go and begin the game. I am immediately greeted with long and noticeable hiccups and dips. Alright then, I think, maybe I'm overestimating my new card. So I lower every single setting to the lowest it could go and see how it runs again. To my surprise, I still ran like absolute garbage, like they actively tried to make their game run as bad as possible. I want to play this, I do, but I literally cannot play this game. I'm not one of those guys who can only play a game in solid 60 fps, but what I'm getting is legitimately unplayable. It's like I'm playing this on a tablet. This is a batman game, so If you miraculously run this game well, then you'll probably like the gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Mandatory complaint about one of the game's many issues:Personally I did not experience any kind of crashes so I consider myself lucky in this department, I have seen and read of other's experiences with this. The only thing I experienced throughout the game was the drop in frame rates especially in instances where the batmobile showed up, cinematics, or entering a new zone. Hell even turning around really fast sometimes caused this. It's awful, it's bad, fix please.PC specs:i7 3770 @ 3.48 GB RAMgtx 660Win 8Actual game review:Despite all this I was able to complete the game to avoid the internet spoiling any major goodies this game had to offer. Overall I was pretty happy with the game. The story was great. The batmobile was really fun to drive and unlike many games that allow you to drive a vehicle the batmobile is unstopabble, you're not gonna get stopped by a bench, or a tree, or even a pillar. Boss fights is where I felt this game kind of dropped the ball, I know Arkham Origins is usually ridiculed by the fan base but they handled boss fights quite well, in fact all of the arkham series games did, but Arkham Knight kind of dropped the ball here. Your boss fights will consist more of fighting mobs or you in the batmobile. I definitely enjoyed the side missions this time around and the riddler's race tracks.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I'm so glad they finally fixed this. Now I can pay to get all the DLC of the console version while it still runs like garbage on my computer despite meeting the minimum specs and cranking every setting through the floor. I'm not saying I expect every game in a franchise, especially one spanning multiple years, to have the same requirements, but on minimum it looks like garbage compared to the previous Arkham games... and somehow runs worse. I would almost be impressed if I hadn't wasted money on this. On the bright side, the latest patch improved performance from sub 15 frames per second average to sub 17 frames per second average, an improvement of not nearly enough %.UPDATE:As of November, the game is still shamefully broken, but at least there's more DLC support. In solidarity with idiots who purchased before knowing how broken the game is, the minimum specifications still reflect some fantasy port we didn't get so anyone who browses the store page will not know that apparently they need 12GB of RAM to get the game to run on Windows 10, because how to program. But at least the November DLC is supported with the new patches.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												0/10 won't even start can't get past the first scene in-game hell the game even crashes at times during benchmark joke of a game avoid like plauge, its atrocious how they even released the game in this state i woulnd't recommend buying it until its dirt cheap a year or so later coz its ♥♥♥♥ing hillarious how the devs treat us.EDIT - Tried it after the major patches and after the game was purchasable on steam again still the same issue unresolved, can safely say biggest AAA ♥♥♥♥up of 2015EDIT 2 (June 2016 edit) - so somehow i managed to get past the first screen and play the game still its buggy and broken af fps drops are constant no matter what settings you try and horrible optimized still and devs said they can never fix it.It is a technical hell and probably the worst AAA ♥♥♥♥up but i am going to write everything apart from the tech issues below coz its not worth talking at this about how broken this game is.so is the game any good tech issues aside yes it is, if you have a console id strongly suggest you buy it there since those versions are no where near as broken and glitchy like the PC version is, i love this game and this is evident by me putting 40+ hours into the game even though i faced all sorts of tech issues out of which frequent crashing was rampant still i got past those coz the game is brilliant and rocksteady delivers once again, the voice over actors are amazing and authentic the story is pretty decent, overall the main story plus all side missions of which there are plenty can take 50 hours to complete (i did not complete the riddle mission apart from that completed all the remaining 12 sides along with main, no dlcs were played), there are AR missions which are plenty and you can sink another 10-12 hrs in those, the batmobile feels and handles very good but can be a problem to handle with keyboard somethings, the controls are somewhat changed not too much still could have been better and if you feel comfy with a controller i suggest you play with that, the audio is once again spot on the game never feels dull due to these audio queues which always keeps the mood going, the level design and level of detail is astonishing for an open game world, the combat is slightly improved by adding fear takedowns and by batman picking up and throwing objects along with fighting with a baseball bat now, the environmental takedowns are probably the ones which really make you feel like a badass and the new gadgets are really fun to use and how the interact with the environment really mixes things up.tl;dr - i still cant recommend it coz the glaring technical issues which will never be fixed but if you owe a console i highly suggest you grab it there and if you want you can try out the PC version yourself different people have different issues with the game by main issue was crashing and constant fps drops along with freezing but it varies from people to people.

number of helpful: 28 of 38 people (74%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												When Batman Arkham Knight first came out on PC it was a complete disaster; I like many other PC gamers was very annoyed at how poorly it ran and how frequently it crashed; however I was on the lucky side of the stick and was able to complete the game. On October 28th the Interim Patch was finally released (as well as all the DLC up until that point); the game also went back on sale and things from here started to look up - the game ran much better and there were a lot more options available for PC users such as framerate cap, Anisotropic Filtering, higher quality textures, shadows and lighting. Since Oct 28th the game received an update every month (up until the point I'm writing this review) that would have performance fixes, stability improvements and included DLC that was being released monthly in the Season Pass.Batman Arkham Knight runs a lot better than it did on day one; provided you meet the system requirements you should have no issues running the game. Just make sure you have the latest drivers.I haven't focused much on the gameplay/story side because there are thousands of other reviews out there - I will say this; if you're going to get this game you need the Season Pass; the extra DLC, AR challenges, Story Packs and Skins really adds necessary depth to the game. I am quite happy changing this review from a negative to a positive - I would also imagine most negative reviews are pre Oct 28th. I'm not endorsing the state the game was originally released in but the fact is it runs a lot smoother; if you are still holding off buying the game just go and get it.While it may not be the epic finale we deserved it's still a great game any 'Arkham' fan should pick-up.P.S. I can guarantee people will rate this down because even 7 months later it's still the cool thing to hate on this game.

number of helpful: 22 of 28 people (79%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												Let me start by saying that I'm a huge fan of Arkham Asylum and City. They're among my favorite games (City being my all time favorite). So naturally I was very excited for this game. I had full faith in Rocksteady after their previous works but unfortunately, they ♥♥♥♥ed up. Arkham Knight is one of the most disappointing games I've ever played. You probably already know how horrible the port is, so I'm not going to talk about that. I'll focus on the game itself. Let's start with the story. I personally didn't like it. I found it cliche and boring. There is not a single memorable moment in the entire campaign. It is unbelievably cliche. Same with villains. Scarecrow was awesome in Asylum. Here, he is a joke. He doesn't do anything, just talks about fear. Arkham Knight is even worse. He is very boring and weak. He calls you a coward but hides behind an army of drones. His 'boss battles' are terrible. His identity is ridiculously obvious. If you have the slightest comic book knowledge you'll immediately know who he is and if not don't worry, game tells you who he is way before it is actually revealed. Also SPOILER ALERT I'm really sick of these people's obsession with Joker. I get it he's a good villain but he doesn't need to be the main villain in all Batman games. Oh yeah, you thought this was about Arkham Knight? Nope! Joker is the main villain again. ♥♥♥♥ you Rocksteady.Gameplay is also kinda messed up. Many people claim it's the best in the series but it's not. It has a few nice improvements and it has much more depth but it lacks the smoothness that made Asylum and City so great. Input drops, attacking an armored enemy instead of the normal enemy right next to him, losing combo for no reason are only some of these problems. The new environmental takedowns look cool but they are unreliable. Sometimes they cause you to drop your combo for no reason. Same with picking weapons from ground. The detection on these thing was so bad, I stopped using them after a while. Also the camera during combat felt a little more zoomed in than previous games and it often caused me to lose my combo. I also hated the new big enemies. They're essentially the armored enemies from City but they're so hard to distinguish in the heat of combat. In City, they wore red vests so you'd immediately spot them. Here, they look like regular enemies but just bigger. Fear takedown is also a new addition, it looks cool but its implementation is awful. Forget about relying on that thing. Anytime I wanted to use a fear takedown in a tight spot Batman just punched air and got me killed.Of course the big new thing in this game is the batmobile. It's fun for a bit but it's way overused. You use it to get around, solve puzzles, fight tanks. Game forces it on you so much. You can't take two steps without it and I'm sorry but that's just stupid. Just like Riddler race tracks. I mean, just think about it. Riddler creating race tracks for batmobile. Nice one Rocksteady.Arkham City had great side missions. Admittedly, they were a little repetitive. What I mean is, they mostly consisted of doing the same thing 3-4 times. Arkham Knight takes this to a ridiculous level. Almost every side mission in the game has you doing the same thing time after time again. Specially those god damn Militia missions. They're just a cheap way to increase the game's length in my opinion.Remember challenge maps? They're gone. They are replaced with AR challenges and these suck. You cannot play as other characters in them and they have awful blue walls around them. So disappointing. There is only one fun AR challenge and you don't even play as Batman in that one. More than half of these damn things are for batmobile. We get it Rocksteady. You're really proud of that damn tank. Stop shoving it to our faces.If you've made it this far you probably noticed I suck at long reviews and I agree with you. So I'll stop here. Batman Arkham Knight is a terrible port, it has a boring, cliche story, good but not good enough combat, way too much batmobile, the worst villains of the series, awful side missions (a couple exceptions) and a very disappointing ending. Way to end your legacy Rocksteady.

number of helpful: 18 of 21 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Underneath the issues and poor performance is a game I'd really like to enjoy. Underneath all the bugs, is a game I'd love to experience at its best. Underneath the missing graphical effects is a game I'd love to see in it's true form. But that is not Arkham Knight PC version. Arkham Knight on PC is one of the worst ports I have ever come across. I honestly did not think a game could be as horrible as AC Unity. But I am proven wrong. The game's mechanics seem very nice so far even though I am very early into the game and it's story. But the constant FPS drops and overall stuttering is a HUGE turn off to play this game to begin with. The lack of graphical settings to choose from is pathetic. The fact that the game is locked to 30 FPS and can only be disabled by editing an ini file is rediculous. I have seen many people trying to help each other out by giving out tips on editing the ini file to increase performance. Which is nice to see I'll say that. It's not often I see the gaming community trying to help each other out.But a AAA title should NOT and I repeat NOT be released like this to the consumers. It is utterly disgusting that players themselves have to actually take time to edit ini files to try squeeze out as much performance as they can even though they meet the recommended requirements or are even far above them. I've seen some people call others "entitled" and to "relax it's just a game" as well as "if you don't like it, get a refund" among other more nasty comments. Thats entirely besides the point and honestly, the people dishing out those comments need to wake up and realize that releases like this are just a big no. You wouldn't want to buy a physical product and have it barely work would you? "Oh it's just a TV, it's ok that it stutters and that the screen goes black every 5 seconds" I doubt you people would be fine with that would you?The point is that a AAA publisher and developer should not be releasing something like this to their consumers. Paying $60/+ for something that runs like pure garbage is just unacceptable. And WB deserves every bit of hate they get for it. They knew very well what the PC version was like. And they still released it. The story so far to me seems to be interesting enough. But I still feel like it's going to be difficult to enjoy it due to all of the issues present in the game. This game could have been an amazing PC release. But due to WB's lack of care and poor choices on the PC Port. I honestly cannot recommend this game to anybody. Unless it's bugs and performance issues are resolved, this game is something I would stay away from. It is not worth the money and honestly, I think WB is going to have to do a lot to make up for this. While I did not pre order the game. I was tempted to buy it shortly after it's release. And so I did. But I see now that it was a mistake. I hope that some big shiny pure patches come soon and fix all of these issues. Otherwise I will not be buying another game from WB ever again.
