Some people claim new drivers helped or turning off gameworks, but I have no nvidia features active and I am on the latest drivers so neither is the problem. The game is just broken. I can play for 20-40 minutes between crashes. This is the ONLY game with this problem. All other games work flawlessly. I will wait for future patches before starting a New Game+.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Re-release Review:With the game's re-release, I went and tested it again for half hour to see any changes. There's still frame drops when summoning the Batmobile and drifting with it. This is with 1080 and all maxed with the following specs: i7, GTX970, 16GB RAM, SSD (OS, Steam, and AK in SSD), with all drivers updated. In short, it didn't feel like there were any changes at all - way below 60fps and occassional dips to single digits when summoning the/drifting with the Batmobile. For me, this means the Excavator encounter, chasing something/someone, and fighting myriad drones are still going to be sh*t. There are still texture streaming changes that if there are a lot of things going on or you quickly look at an area with lots of textures and details, the texture streaming is not always fluid and seamless - you still notice some textures load slowly.There are reports that gliding slows it downs too (aka framedrops), although I didn't experience it. There are still the gliding bug/glitch where you will do a nosedive, even if you didn't initiate it - I still experience that from time to time.Some people couldn't start the game, which could be something about users changing game files, according to WB official statements. The solution is to delete the changed files and then verify cache, so the files that were deleted are regenerated, using the latest version of said files.Some reports the game takes a while to start, which could be affecting mostly those running the game in mechanical drives (non-SSD), which is still bad - the game shouldn't be too taxing that mechanical drives become a problem. If I'm already experiencing slowdowns and (sometimes) texture streaming issues with the game in my SSD, I'm certain it's going to be worse if I put it in one of my mechanical drives with 7.2k RPM.The re-release/patch notes did not identify any gamebreaking bugs that were fixed, such as the locked door trap bug, or the drone bug. Also, it seems that to run the game without paging, you need 12GB.Verdict: still Not Recommended. 6/10As stated, they barely fix anything, as far as optimizing it further and fixing known bugs and glitches. It seems that they prioritized getting the DLCs and the re-release ready.However, they intend to make amends for those who waited for a game that's still far from "optimal". They intend to give those affected with the entire Arkham library, along with a community challenge map pack exclusive to the PC version for a while (supposedly about a week) before it becomes multiplat, and some Arkham games-themed TF2 junk.Here's the problem with that:- What if you already own all Arkham games? Are you just f*cked? Will they even let you choose another WB game?- What if you don't like any other Arkham game? Can't you choose some other WB game? Can't you get a Season Pass of any WB game instead?- Another challenge map pack? A story pack would've been better than another challenge map pack, or character/Batmobile skins pack (there's a lot of that sh*t already), or another race track pack.- If you don't play and don't intend to play TF2, the last giveaway is useless.BAK with Interim and Windows 10:It seems that switching to Windows 10 made it slightly worse. Now I'm playing 30-45fps on average, 10fps on the low end - 2fps being the lowest. Maybe I should not have switched to Windows 10...03 September 2015 Interim Patch: Well, the interim patch came out and it slightly fixed the frame drops and crashes. At least for me, it doesn't crash anymore, but it still drops to 10fps or less when certain things happen. And yes, it's usually when I summon the Batmobile, or driving it. Gamebreaking bugs, from what I read in the AK forums, are still not fixed. The big gain from the patch is the inclusion of the high res textures, fixed rain effects (still some issue with it, revolving around saving and loading the game), fixed smoke/fog (still some issues with it, such as reduced duration and interactivity issues), and inclusion of other settings to tweak graphics. Film grain and chromatic aberration can be toggled now, which is good. It's still not optimized enough, and that's with the game in an SSD. I broke my "one rule" of not putting any game with Denuvo sh*t in my SSD. As mentioned, there are still frame drops.Also, some people are still unable to run it or unable to run it as expected (maxed out everything at 4k on some machines with SLI and multiple "monster" GPUs). But this review is about my experience with the game.My verdict: still Not Recommended.The game, as stated, still needs further optimization. But if you meet at least in between the minimum and the recommended specs, and don't mind that the game is far from the expected "perfection" that some were hoping it would be (like me) and don't max everything, then you can buy it if you want and it will be playable. If you're all about "I WANT TO MAX EVERYTHING, TO THE MAX!" and have monster rigs, then don't buy it yet, as those with monster rigs are still facing issues.There's also some issues with DLC. For now, DLC is still inaccessible, if you bought the Season Pass. You also can't buy the Season Pass yet, or any individual DLCs. Some DLC content are short. The Batgirl and Robin DLC, if you're a seasoned veteran and know what you're doing, you can finish it in under 1 hour - that's short. The Harley Quinn and Red Hood DLCs are extremely short that you can finish each in under 10 minutes - you can finish Red Hood's DLC in under 5. The "Challenge Maps" aren't the traditional challenge maps that you can customize, like pick a character that will play in that map or pick modifiers/handicaps. The racing tracks, I never really like - if you're into racing, then go get that DLC. The bulk of the Season Pass is skins.  EDIT:Re-release info: Still not recommended. 6/10 Interim patch info, with Windows 10: Still not recommended. 6/10Pre-interim patch info: Added 2 gamebreaking bugs found (so far), a possible gamebreaking bug (the Minus key not working), and lowered score from 4-5/10 to 1/10. Not recommended

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I'm sad to say this but I am changing my stance on this game. I'm not one of the individuals that had any issues with the game. I did experience some random freezing and some random total system reboots. Still unsure what caused them. I've gotten to the *yawns* Riddler questions phase where you have to find the riddles to get the full ending and just lost interest in the game. I tried to stay an avid supporter of it, and if WB had changed their stance on the DLCs which are like 15 to 60 mins of game play to complete with the Harley Quinn and from what was reported to be the case with Batgirl, I'd be likely still supporting it. However, the PC doesn't get any DLCs until it gets fixed... This game has became one of the biggest let downs I've ever had in any game I've played or even modded. It has its issues, running at 3 monitor 1080p, its very low FPS isn't all that great. Running single monitor, is a let down too cause most action seems to happen off screen. Sadly, there is another issue with this game that nothing will be able to fix. The leaderboard for Steam use of this game, is not infalable. I mean literally you can get every star for every AR challenge without breaking much of a sweat by... cheating. Its a single player game, so cheating isn't that bad... but if you're playing with friends and trying to best each other, it can get to be unfair to the others. This isn't really all that bad, but... it happens.Also, one last thing. The story line isn't as immersive as it should be. However, if you think you can get by without using excessively the batmobile/bat-tank... You're likely missing most of the game's content.UPDATE: August 6...Well, looks like it may be August 31 before an update happens, but at this rate, I'm likely to not replay this game ever again. I mean having completed everything but the Riddler's challenges, its pointless to go back and do everything over again in my book.

number of helpful: 21 of 31 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Let me start with the fact that I am a massive Batman fan.  I've read many many comics, watched the various TV shows, cartoons, and movies, and have played all of the games.  I've played the games primarily on the PC.  This game's story is pretty good, and without giving spoilers fans of the Dark Knight will likely pick up hints of who and what the main story is based on.  Gameplay is about the same as the previous incarnations, with the addition of the Batmobile (which is so fun to drive around in and blow crap up that I've spent hours just tooling about the city.)Rocksteady has managed to make Gotham feel large with a unique feel for the various districts and islands.  You spend much of the game going from place to place, with numerous side quests and missions to complete if you so desire.  The scope of the game feels bigger than the previous titles.That being said, the game is incredibly unstable.  Every single time I launch the game I have to go into a configuration xml file and change a field to fix the constant resizing issue.  I'm playing on a top of the line system with a 980 and I still get hiccups at 720p.  That's right, even with the settings reduced I still get major stuttering at random times.  I can live with that, but it's annoying.What I can't live with, however, is the fact that the game lost my saves.  I cannot get the damn thing to load my saves (All I get in the slot where it usually says "X percent complete" is a message that says "This save data was created using a newer version of the game. Please install all relevant updates to continue using this save data."  I'm on the final fight of the game.I've invested more than 30 hours doing all of the side missions, main quest, etc and now I have lost everything.  I'm incredibly upset by this.  Unfortunately I've passed the return period otherwise I would return this piece of crap.tl;dr wait for the updates - don't bother beta testing for WB

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
 Update on the re-release patch (28/10/2015). Still as broken as it ever was, windows 7 + 8gb ram = memory leak after less than 5 minutes in the batmobile, a bit longer on foot/gliding. Game can easily be completely unplayable on your system due to a memory leak and there is not a thing you can do about it, even the dev team gave up on fixing this issue. Just for reference, my PC runs AC Unity at a constant 30 fps with all settings set to high, so it's definitely strong enough to run this game, hell, it runs fine for 1 minute, it's just that this game's memory management doesn't function properly. I reinstalled it 5 times on my PC with various gpu drivers, and all kinds of pagefile scenarios I could think of, it just doesn't work properly on my machine (I guess after having great luck with running AC Unity and Watch_Dogs - this one runs at above 50fps most of the time on high settings, my luck with bad PC ports had run out) - to save yourself a headache, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC!!! Don't reward sloppy PC devs with your hard earned money, please.  The rest of my review was written on release date (the actual release date) and editing it even slightly would probably just p!ss me the eff off, so I'll leave it like this, unless the game actually becomes playable at some point. If you're one of those people who thought Origins was a bad Arkham game, has Rocksteady got a surprise for you.So yeah, let's make an UE3 game look like it's using Cryengine 3, but let's definitely not buy a Cryengine license, cause money yo!If you have a card with 2gb of vram (if you have less, look the other way, the game will not run at all), be prepared to lower the settings to the bare minimum (that's right! all 3 settings, all of the 3 settings that are 3... THREE... 3... 3... 3, not 2, definitely not 4, but 3), lower the resolution below 1080p and expect huge fps dips and chugging and even complete pauses in gameplay (0 fps). This is always present in the driving sections, and often while gliding across the map or diving to take out an enemy.Can't turn off blur, depth of field, dynamic lights or shadows, film grain, chromatic aberration, you can just make your game look super blurry by lowering the textures, and have all these wonderful frame dropping filters on, to make your eyes bleed a bit more.Let's say a thing or two about the gameplay (after all I suffered through this game for 20+ hours so far) - It's a mix between the good old Arkham Asylum/City laser precise and very responsive combat, and some of the worst predator encounters I have experienced in an Arkham game, the enemy placement is a mess, there are too many enemies in every predator encounter I came across, and they decreased the number of ceiling grappling points drastically, so often you're in underground shafts or making those 2 ceiling grappling points work somehow.The story "SO FAR" is not great, I'm not enjoying it regardless of the frame rate. The Riddler challenges with the batmobile are either a puzzle or a race against the clock, the races are just horrible and tedious, puzzles are decent but not great, all in all the Riddler side quests are not that good. The open city batmobile sections themselves are totally unneeded, and battling the tanks while you're in the car feels like a mediocre Playstation 2 Japanese giant robot game, it's just tedious and dumb.I have to say though that the car does come in handy and is used in really interesting ways at times, but that's only in scripted main story moments.Voice acting and music are of course top notch, not a single complaint there.Catwoman looks hot!Oh yeah, you can unlock the 30fps cap imposed by Hitle... I mean by the devs, by editing an .ini file, but what's the point really? :)I'll update/rewrite the review and maybe even change the rating if I feel the game is actually worth buying when (more probably "IF") they fix this mess.So, unless you have an nvidia gtx 900 series card or a titan, I suggest you stay away from this game for now.edit: They actually increased the game's price by 5 euros. XDedit 2: and now you can't even purchase it from steam, because it's so damn unfinished.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Warner Brother's handling of this game has been so poor it's driven me to write my first Steam review ever - and a grossly negative one at that. Performance of this game has improved since it's initial "release" in June, but so minutely that one could describe the change as from "complete and utter dogshit" to "wow, this is a pretty awful port". The mere fact that WB tried to pawn off the unpolished turd that was Batman: Arkham Knight in June was tantamount to spitting in PC gamers' faces. In my mind any attempts by WB to rectify this have been a knee-jerk reaction to the huge backlash at the games release, and the coinciding then-recent advent of Steam refunds. Now here we are at the end of October, with a still barely playable, ugly, crashing game. To put the brown icing on top of the poop cake, at the time of this review Season Passes are not even properly working, rendering a multitude of gamers unable to access content they have rightfully (over)paid for. The cynic in me who has seen WB's past transgressions wonders if it's some attempt to squeeze money out of unaware consumers by letting them "accidently" but DLC after already purchasing the Season Pass, in one last attempt to juice the PC gaming community for money until "post-patch" reviews are all out and everyone realizes this game is still a turd-sandwhich.Do not buy this game. Do not support Warner Brothers. I regret every moment of not refunding my initial purchase of Batman: Arkham Knight back in June, hoping against hope that WB and Rocksteady would pull through and deliver the game they promised us in good time.I do not recommend Batman: Arkham Knight

												Hi guys! I think I should tell you straight-up: Arkham Knight is a FANTASTIC video game. If you don't mind 30 FPS and have an Xbox One or Playstation 4, I highly recommend you get it on those platforms! Unfortunately, you're reading this review on the Steam digital distribution service for personal computers, which I assume means you're gathering info on what the game would be like if you bought it from Steam. The answer to that is: It's dogshit!During the long hiatus where it was unavailable for purchase, Arkham Knight received one patch that addressed bugs and performance towards the end of September, and that was it. While improvements were made, the game's performance is still quite poor, and many of the errors that plagued launch haven't been fully fixed! Rain effects still don't work the way they do on consoles! As those of us in "the biz" like to say: Man, what a crock!The patch that accompanied the relaunch added support for the game's DLC, and that's it! No improvements to the base game whatsoever.If you install this game on an SSD, and have 16 GB of RAM and a high-end i7 and like a 980 Ti, great news! You can actually enjoy this PC game! But those of us who haven't upgraded our PC in the last two weeks are kinda screwed. If you are reading this review in the year 2018, when the game is $10 on sale and everyone has nuclear reactors in their computers (I mean, I assume, anyways) then your sheer strength of hardware will probably overpower the shoddiness of this port, and you will get a wonderful video game for your troubles! For those of us in October 2015, though... Yeah. We're screwed.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Edited after more playtime.Buying AAA titles on launch day is like picking up the soap in a prison shower, gentlemen - sometimes you get lucky, and other times you kinda just screwed yourself. - 30 FPS cap (yes there's an .ini fix, but come on m8)- strong motion blur that can't be turned off (in my case, the .ini fix causes a fatal crash)- lack of sensitivity sliders- lack of most post-process options- slim graphics options (e.g. textures are either 'Normal' or 'Low', AA is 'On' or 'Off')- unskippable intro movies (come on m8)For those wanting to use the .ini fixes as a stopgap, the issue is that raising the FPS cap to 60 causes strange stuttering with an i7-4790k, GTX 970, 16 GB RAM when traveling. Nvidia GameWorks on or off doesn't seem to affect my performance. There's bad pop-in, so it looks like it's poor optimization. Makes me wonder if that's why they put in the 30 FPS cap, and why many of the reviews were console copies. If you want to stay at 30 FPS, the motion blur at that lower FPS gave me motion sickness. In my case the .ini tweak for that results in crashes. Poo on you, Warner Brothers.I've played roughly 4 hours now with the 60 FPS tweak and it makes the game playable. For the most part it's a good game (the Batmobile isn't the best), but the technical problems and lack of PC options are really frustrating. Frame hitching and odd dips in frame rate can ruin the fluidity of the combat and driving portions, and personally it irritates during cutscenes.It's a poor PC port .ini fix or not. As it stands, can't recommend it to anyone on PC. Wait for a patch (or two) and see if they address these issues.In a perfect world, AAA publishers wouldn't be dropping soap in the shower in the first place, but I asked for it when I reached down to pick it up.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												It is frustrating that i waited years (been with the arkham games from the start) for the conclusion to my favorite gaming franchise, only to later find out i had to force myself to play it in slideshow speeds. My build as of the time was an MSI GTX 970 4G Gaming, i5 3550 @3.3ghz and 8gb DDR3 1333mhz. The game would underutilise my GPU heavily, based on MSI Afterburner statistics. It definitely is the worst optimization i've experienced on a PC game, and i did begin the game the second it launched. Even with gameworks disabled, and tweaks by other users didn't help the game. It was possible to run the game at a locked 30fps, but 5-10 minutes in or so, you'd drop frames drastically to like 5fps. My assumption was that because the game offers no loading screens (aside from launching the game in the first place) it relied heavily on a good hard drive speed. This was why there were so many delays in the first place on consoles, and why the game was originally capped at 30fps on PC. It was because the game was designed to utilise your hard drive speed to sustain 30fps. IronGalaxy (who worked on the PC version) didn't bother to improve the hard drive streaming issues, and it's the reason why anyone's GPU could easily be under-utilised, even if you unlocked the frame rate cap. I waited patiently for the game to be patched, which took a few months. Performance definitely improved after the patch, but i still had poor performance. No way of sustaining 60fps on a well capable 970. I complained about the performance with a negative review and said we consumers were deserving of refunds. Good thing i was allowed to get a refund later, even if i put 20 or so hours into the game at the time. I forced myself to play the game at launch simply because i wanted to complete the story before anyone spoilt it, so it was a bit of a trap for me as i didn't think i would be eligable for a refund. I later upgraded my computer with 12gb of ram, and an SSD. I partially did this upgrade with Ark: Survival Evolved in mind, as that game also relies heavily on your drive speed and ram amount. I eventually decided to buy Arkham Knight again. I installed it on my SSD this time. The performance definitely improved, thanks to the fast drive speed. I do get drops to the 50s at times, but it's a CPU bottleneck that you can't blame the game for, and it only happens when gliding around the city. Graphical options are 'mehh', barely a difference between low and high settings in performance if you have the VRAM. Also suffers from a lack of actual options to tune you graphics. Ambient Occlusion options and other Anti-Aliasing methods would have been welcome. You can still modify the graphics settings in depth if you access the ini files. The default Anti-Aliasing method has to be the worst i've seen in a game. It's apparently a form of SMAA which surprises me, as it just seems like a blur filter. The aliasing remains horrible in the game unless you downsample from 4k. MSAA options would've definitely been nice, but all i've been able to do is force Reshade SMAA for a better anti aliasing setting than the default option. It's good way of tackling some of the aliasing without much of a hit to performance. I also use Reshade to inject the game with my own Ambient Occlusion settings (I recommend SSGI). The game is also capped at 90fps as your highest option, though you can unlock this cap in the ini files. The game is solid underneath. Arkham City is still my favourite of the franchise, which surprised me as i expected the gameplay improvements Arkham Knight would offer to make it hard to go back. Arkham City certainly made Arkham Asylum feel a bit lacking after you played City, though both are still phenomenal games. What Arkham Knight ultimately suffered from, was the batmobile. The story is decent in my opinon, but the batmobile especially towards the end of the game feels like the biggest chore i've ever been forced into in a game. I understand that Rocksteady wanted to add a new gameplay option to keep the game fresh, but tank battles ultimately led to a lack of actual hand to hand boss fights in the game. It should've remained optional, and perhaps only as a driving mechanic too. There's no way you can expect all fans of the Arkham games to appreciate the batmobile, and i only notice about 1 in 5 people who are fans of the franchise actually like the batmobile. It's more likely you hate it rather than like it. I still however find fun in the game, This is because of mods and challenge mode in specific, which is why i've been able to dedicate so many hours into the game. As of 1st July 2016, the game is on sale and it's a steal for the price if your rig can handle it. It still remains a game that offers one of the higher end experiences that gaming can buy right now.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												First thing I did, was turn off V-sync and do a performance test, with a GTX 980, i7 4930k @ 3.4GHz, 16GB RAM. The game has a minimum FPS of 70 and a nice stable average of about 110. Playing on a 144hz monitor I was happy with this, went to play the game and surprise surprise it's locked to 30 FPS.I played for a while anyway as it was bearable, the gameplay I got through was nice, there are some nice little twists already and the Batmobile is not too shabby.There are about 5 minutes of unskippable logos on start up, which is very frustrating when trying to change settings which require a restart.I changed an ini file to unlock the FPS, and added a launch option to stop the logos from showing (-nologo). If this had worked, I would be recommending this game right now because for all intents and purposes it's great so far. But what happened instead, is that it crashed on launch, claiming that it couldn't find the main executable file. I checked my game files and they were all there. So I went to verify the integrity of the game cache and it ♥♥♥♥ing DELETED THE ENTIRE GAME! So that's a day wasted downloading it again, because at 33GB it takes me a fair while to download it. Having it on the discontinued DVD doesn't help, because it only contains about 1/5th of the files needed.I have to repeat, if you have changed any of the files for the game, do not verify the integrity of the game cache, because for some bizarre reason it will delete the entire game.And why have a performance benchmark test and just lock the ♥♥♥♥ing game to 30 FPS, what♥♥♥♥♥♥is this?

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I am really, really disappointed with the performance of this game. Forced 30fps framerate cap? No SLI profile at launch? No graphic options to disable motion blur? Right now this game is playing horrendously on powerful hardware. Not OK. It's obvious the PC version of this game got very little love by the dev team. For a AAA game, this completely unacceptable. The new nVidia driver even states that there are SLI optimizations. This is an outright lie. I forced alternate frame rendering in the control panel only to have FPS drops that made the game virtually unplayable. I've since disabled SLI and am using the second GPU for PhysX only. Playing with everything maxed out at 2560 x 1440, the framerate ranges from 15-55 fps, and it is all over the place. The game itself seems like it would be great if the performance wasn't giving me a headache from stuttering and everything else.Thanks, Obama.UPDATE: I feel like I need to add that the game is amazing fun. After many, many .ini file tweaks and nVidia tweaks, I have the game playing at a (fairly) stable 30-60fps. Obviously this large gap is still indicitive of a very poorly optimized, unfinished game, but I am at least able to play it. For those seeing the reviews on Steam and staying far away, I can recommend staying updated on patches and at least playing the game if Rocksteady ever manages to give the game any PC-version love.It's the worst port of the best game of the year right now.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Before I get to why you shouldn't purchase this game AT THIS MOMENT, I want to take a second to let you know that deep down, past the shoddy pc port, there is a truly magnificent game worthy as the (supposedly) final installment in the Akrham franchise. The core game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. Now to why you shouldn't buy the PC version AT THIS MOMENT. The PC port is absolute♥♥♥♥♥ The game is currently a broken mess for both AMD and Nvidia users. Unless you have a super overkill rig that can brute force through the super poor optimization this game has, you are most likely going to find a host of technical issues ranging from an unstable framerate, all the way to horrible texture streaming. Here are the core components of my rig: i7-4770k @ 4.0 ghz16gb DDR3 Corsair Vengeance @ 1866 mhzEVGA GTX 970 4gbThis is well passed the recommended specs for Arkham Knight and I should be able to run this game at Max settings with atleast 60fps with the exception of a few intense situations. As it currently stands the game fluctuates between 20 to 120 fps. The Batmobile is the worst offender and you will often experience stuttering and framerate tanks during the Batmobile sequences. Texture streaming is also a huge issue. The only things in the game that stay consistently textured properly is batman and the batmobile. Everything else tends to have very poor texture streaming resulting in objects that clearly are mean't to clean up texture-wise as you get close to them, but don't for several minutes, or not at all. I found this most noticable on catwoman's suit (which usually never get's her HD textures streamed) and the various door's in the Riddler's hideout.You will also experience a host of bugs and glitches as well as random stuttering that at times looks like the game froze.Overall, do not buy this game at launch its a broken mess but once these issues get cleaned up you are in for an amazing game.EDIT # 1: Welp, I just encountered my first progress-blocking bug which prevents me from collecting a riddler trophy so I can't 100% complete the game for the full ending. I had to watch the full ending on Youtube because of that. Thanks Warner Bros, you completely ruined this experience.

I wouldn't be surprised if I learned that they spent most of their time getting the DLC working instead of improving the base game.This is coming from a massive fan of the previous Arkham games. I'm utterly disappointed, and everyone involved in the making of this port should feel ashamed of themselves.

number of helpful: 31 of 50 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												Batman: Arkham Knight is (ostensibly) the final chapter in Rocksteady’s Batman: Arkham X series. In it, Batman faces off against Scarecrow, who is seeking revenge for Batman throwing him to Killer Croc in the first game, and the titular Arkham Knight, whose identity you can guess without even playing the game if you are familiar with the comics, and whose identity becomes obvious somewhere in the middle of the game even if you’re not.This game continues on in the tradition of Arkham City and Arkham Origins in that you play Batman in an open-world city. The map is even bigger this time around, and you are given the Batmobile to drive around in.The Batmobile is the big new feature of this game, and is very similar to the one seen in the Dark Knight trilogy of movies. It can turn into a tank and move around in any direction while in tank mode. This is essential for fighting the army of tank drones, autonomous vehicles which attack you and the city throughout the game.Alas, while these sections are okay, they suffer from one major problem: it doesn’t feel very Batman-y. Given that these games are about feeling like Batman, this is something of an issue.Alas, the rest of the game has little meaningful innovation. The fights in this game are bigger than ever, with a fight in the Batmobile against 60 drones, and fights against large numbers of goons appearing at various points in the game, as well as even more complex predator encounters, where you sneak around and pick off armed guards, including medics who can revive their allies, people who you can’t see through walls with detective vision, and huge goons with miniguns. The biggest innovation in the predator sequences is the so-called fear takedown, where you can take down a whole group of goons in sequence from hiding without them being able to shoot you while doing so.Alas, this isn’t very innovative, and the predator sequences and the fighting with goons sequences don’t feel very fresh or new. And while that’s okay to some extent, the lack of really interesting new enemies is kind of discouraging.Added onto this are the boss fights, or rather, the lack thereof. This game is very obsessed with the Batmobile, and unfortunately, a lot of the new boss fights are Batmobile centric. And indeed, the main boss of the game is the Arkham Knight, who you fight over and over again in various guises. This isn’t so bad – the fights are actually all unique – but they’re big on flash and not so big on substance. Cool fights – like the Mister Freeze fight from the second game – aren’t really on the menu here, and while some of the fights are okay, and sneaking around blowing up tanks in the Batmobile is kind of neat in its own way, in the end, it feels a bit repetitive at times after a while.The other villains are by and large much less interesting, sadly. Two-Face and Penguin make an appearance, but they’re just reskinned mooks, and are taken out in the same way. Deathstroke shows up again but is in a tank which is mostly a rehash of a previous fight in the game, Man-Bat is not really a boss at all, and while Firefly is a different take on the fight, it doesn’t feel terribly boss-like and is more of a racing sequence. Indeed, apart from the titular Arkham Knight, the only real boss-feeling enemy in the game is the Riddler, who pilots a gigantic mecha to take you out after you solve all of his riddles… again. This is actually a somewhat interesting fight, in part because it makes use of the switching mechanic which shows up in a few fights where you fight as two characters in the same fight, switching from one to another as you do team attacks, or just when you feel like it.Unfortunately, the Scarecrow himself doesn’t show up in any meaningful capacity as an enemy – gone are the cool sequences from Arkham Asylum, replaced by and large with cut scenes. There are a couple of neat sequences, particularly towards the end of the game, but ultimately the game doesn’t do a whole lot with Scarecrow.And indeed, this leaks over into the story as well – Scarecrow and the Arkham Knight are both pretty generic and uninteresting, and the game as a whole is a mostly bland revenge plot with one real twist which is kind of neat and involves the (deceased) Joker. Indeed, the Joker is again the highlight of this game, which is kind of sad because he’s, well, dead the whole game. On the whole, the plot isn’t terribly interesting or exciting, and it feels very much like you’re just bludgeoning your way through, rather than taking control of the situation in the way that it felt like you were doing in Arkham Asylum.The game as a whole isn’t very tight. I 100%ed the game and took about 70 hours doing it according to my Steam play time, though I suspect it was less than that and I just left the game running for a while a few times while alt-tabbed out. And unfortunately, this game felt long, and not in a good way – the game doesn’t have a whole lot of interesting tricks to it. Instead, there’s just a lot of content, but it is all the same content – drone fights, brawls, and predator encounters, and frankly, only a few of them are really memorable. There are over a dozen bombs you need to defuse while fighting waves of drones, but these fights are all very samey. There’s a neat sequence where you need to sneak around and take out “cobra tanks”, which are only vulnerable from behind… and then you end up doing it five times or so. The fights with goons quickly wear thin and don’t offer much new, and the predator encounters basically all feel very similar, with little meaningful variation. Sure, ostensibly the later ones are more difficult, but I never felt very threatened and they basically felt pretty rote, with only the invisible to x-ray detective vision enemies really mixing things up at all.There are tons of side quests, but they ultimately almost all feel samey, and only the DLC ones really felt like they did anything interesting. The DLC ones felt much more interesting, offering more divergent experiences, such as dealing with the Mad Hatter putting you in a pop-up book (which was, while basically a bunch of mook fights, at least visually interesting), going through a downed zeppelin prison ship, and racing through frozen waters to save Mr. Freeze. These are all much more memorable than the main-game sidequests, which were pretty repetitive and more or less followed the formula of “go to location and fight a bunch of mooks 3-15 times.” There wasn’t much in the way of interesting story to them, and they felt pretty superficial.Likewise, the Riddler has left something like 240 trophies around the game, plus dozens of destructible objects. Most of these just feel like they’re there – just a trophy lying around somewhere for Batman to pick up. Very few felt like actual riddles, and while there were some vaguely interesting puzzles, and the Riddler was actually kind of fun in his pretentious way, there were just an enormous number of them and collecting them felt like a bit of a drag. It might have been better if there had JUST been the Riddles, or if there had been something clever about the whole thing in a problem solving kind of way… but alas.And really, this is the case with pretty much everything in the game. There’s a huge amount to do here, but a lot of it is just the same thing, over and over. It is an open world game with a huge area, but the dungeon type areas – the places where you go inside and fight through a place – are actually pretty small and are few and far between. Why spend so much time on a huge open world when you could instead create interesting environments for Batman to navigate? Is it really fun flying around over the city, or driving through the city in the Batmobile, when there’s nothing terribly interesting to do in most of it?This is a game which is bloated. It isn't bad, but it is a treading-water sequel - more of the same. Lots more.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												I've played City, Origins, and now Knight, and of those three I can say this is the best game in the series. I haven't played the original Arkham Asylum, but I believe most regard City as better, so I can safely say that Arkham Knight is at least as good as Arkham City, if not better.YMMV, but the PC issues seem to be fixed for me. I have an i5-6400 and a GTX 970 and could play everything on max bar some of the physx stuff like the smoke effects, with 60fps, min 45fps at times in the batmobile. I dipped below 45 very rarely to the point where it was perfectly acceptable. While it is an unfortunate blight that the PC port had such severe issues for so long, if you haven't gotten the game yet consider yourself lucky that you get to have a fresh experience how it should be played.Overall it is everything that Arkham City was but better, great story that really delves into the psyche of Batman's character, very fun gameplay (while some find the batmobile fights a bore, I think they're exciting and not "un-Batman-like", nothing is lethal!), and a healthy mix of stellar side quests. Some are alright, never was a fan of the Riddler's stuff, and the Firefly missions were a bit lame, but everything else was pretty interesting and not too overbearing. I recommend having a healthy balance of the side mission and the main story missions, as if you want to access the games true ending you have to complete most of them (you can do everything except the Riddler pretty much, it's really not too bad).There is some more secret stuff story wise that you can only unlock if you complete everything, aka including all of the Riddler's painstakingly tedious "riddles", but you can just look it up on Youtube once you're done, it's nothing major and I'm sure most did that :)10/10, if you liked any of the other games, you'll love this one. 33 hours to ~95% completion. Get it.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Arkham Knight as of today's patch is still way too inferior to the console versions. Hold off purchasing until WB Games gives firm assurances that the remaining problems will be resolved. We're talking micro-stuttering, missing textures and graphic effects. collision detection, cheap on/off AA, severe performance drops in at least two areas of the game, one during a story-critical segment that makes it impossible to tell what is going on. Today's patch appears to have only added DLC support, not fixes which are much-needed. WB and Rocksteady are being very opaque over their plans for the future, or even if they are going to make the game run as it should on PC. The memory leak on Windows 10 is still there. The ambient rain effects bug caused by loading an existing save is still there. Ambient occulusion has a habit of not always appearing. SLI and Crossfire has still not been fixed and neither nVidia or AMD have released any driver updates for them. With there being no noticeable improvement since the September patch, it makes no sense why WB and Rocksteady would consider this to be fit for re-release but for the DLC finally being ready. UPDATE: I've started a new game to check some things out and will update this review soon.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Summary of current issues, then thoughts on the game itself.At present - June 23, 2015 - Arkham Knight has a humongous amount of technical issues affecting the game. One of the primary ones is that the game shipped with a 30 FPS cap built into it. No matter what hardware you have, it doesn't go beyond 30 FPS by default. You can change this by editing your (Drive Letter Here):\Steam\SteamApps\common\Batman Arkham Knight\BMGame\Config.ini file by looking for the MaxFPS setting and changing the value to whatever you want. You can also turn off stuff like motion blur and the like from there, too. Though your mileage will vary in terms of how successful you will be with changing any of these settings. But this 30 FPS cap is literally just the start of the issues with this game. I've asked around, and I can't find a reasonable level of settings, normal and up, at 1080p that will make this game run consistently at 60 FPS. I have an Nvidia GTX 970, a nice i5 processor, plenty of RAM, and an SSD. I'm sure this is a technical challenge of a game to make, but I am certain my system should be turning out a better performance in this game than this. In the higher-up city level of Gotham, the frame rate jumps all over the place. Some of the jumps are just annoying, and some are far more noticeable, with lots and lots of stuttering. On ground level, I haven't really had too much of an issue with that, surprisingly. Combat has been relatively smooth so far. But the Batmobile is a whole other story. The framerate is literally out of control when it comes to the Batmobile. It drops from a smooth 60 FPS down to what appears to be low/mid-20's, only to shoot back up to the mid-40's, all within a second! Moving the camera around to re-angle the Batmobile is a surefire way to tank the FPS almost instantly. Firing the riot control equipment from it often results in a microsecond sharp FPS drop. Many effects seem to be missing or extremely poorly implemented. Ambient occlusion just doesn't seem to be in the game at all. Something is very wrong with the way the game produces rain effects. The PlayStation 4 version of the game has working wet water effects, and provides a clear picture that this can't be what it was meant to look like. There doesn't appear to be any option to change the antialiasing solution the game includes, and it isn't very good at any detail level. Shadows are far too sharp and look very canned. I tried the game with the smoke and paper effects turned on. This might not be entirely the fault of Iron Galaxy's poor port here, as other games utilizing Nvidia-exclusive effects also have a performance cost to use them, too. However, very predictably, if you turn on the Nvidia-exclusive features, you take a massive hit in performance - which is already a pretty tapped-out thing in this game. The quality of the textures is overall very poor. I've seen some in the game that look to be placeholder textures. You don't even have to get The game is also using Denuvo DRM, and this has a negative performance impact as well. It is certainly not neglible. For non-technical issues, the game has an appalling amount of downloadable content, almost all of which is presently retailer-exclusive. As in, each retailer got something different in exchange for preorders. Warner Bros. totally boned over people who got this game as an Nvidia promotion by switching out the keys from ones that included Harley Quinn DLC to keys that don't have it. It's such a meaningless thing to do, and it is a total jackass move from start to finish. When not considering these technical issues, I actually like the game itself, and it's sad that it is necessary to overshadow what is likely a fantastic game by issues like this. The plot starts off extremely strong. I think the concept of mostly-unified villians against Batman united under Scarecrow is a legitimately interesting one. Scarecrow lets the developers do things and take risks they would otherwise be unable to due to the nature of the character - as seen in the first Arkham game. Combat is extremely iterative, but still very fun. There have been a few new enemy attack patterns that have been included to mix up combat even more, and Batman has new weapons to utilize against them. If you've played previous Arkham games, you know what to expect, and it's still very good, fluid, and fast. Enemies still don't really work together, and that's sort of a letdown. It feels like that would produce a lot of good opportunites to vary up combat and give you more of an incentive to utilize your weapons.Gotham is an absolutely massive environment. By far the largest environment in any Arkham game ever, and it isn't even close. This lends itself very well to the mission structure of the game, in ways that hasn't really been possible in Arkham City and even Arkham Origins. There's a lot more missions that you can do in Arkham Knight than in prior games, leveraging the massive world here. There's also varying types. You'll still have thug encounters, but you'll also have specific parameters, challenge missions, and Batmobile missions. You seem to level up much quicker than before, and it's a good thing. You'll gain experience and eventually skill points when you reach a new level. Waynetech upgrades are much more plentiful this time, as you'll upgrade combat moves, personal attributes, Batmobile attributes, and gadgets. There are still tons of puzzles to solve, secrets, things to find, and so much more. It really could be a fantastic game, if only this terrible port gets out of its own way.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Edit: November 4th 2015 - still runs like trash!Playing at 1080P on Low settings will cause you to run out of VRAM on a 2GB card so you have to run at 900P! (Can't get a decent stable framerate with a GTX 950 at all)The Batmobile driving sections for me are where the most issues are. (I was following Gordon who was driving a police car and the game dropped to around 15 FPS) The frame rate goes up and down and up and down and will probably make you motion sick.The rain is still borked and AA settings is very poorly implemented and not up to the task. I had to install the game on a SSD to get it to boot properly as it was taking several mins to start from my 1TB HDD (Common issue since last patch) I've got 16GB Ram and it makes no difference to performance despite developer claims that 12GB or more helps on Windows 10. (I also have a swap file as well) If you have a GTX 970 or 980t Ti you can probably play this as you have the GPU power and VRAM to throw at it. (Don't expect amazing framerates however)If you have a 2GB card I would say forget it and save your money or buy it on a Console instead. (There is a good game here, although the Batmobile is over used to the point of tedium, the combat and story are good and have evolved from the original games) I can't recommend the PC version to anybody with all the unresolved performance issues. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------My original launch review below.Currently runs like hot garbage on a GTX 750 Ti, Nvidia's humble mainstream 1080P card is crippled by this game, barely utilises all 4 cores of my overclocked 860k and floods the VRAM of my 750 Ti. Framerate falls off of a cliff when you get in the Batmobile.  Needs a patch or two before it functions properly. Graphics Options are limited, 30 FPS frame cap cripples performance.Edit 1: I got a playable framerate other than a tiny drop once at 1366 x 768, however the batmobile sections still make my eyes bleed from framerate tanking.The fighting in this game is much better than the previous games as Batman has a greater moveset from the off. I will be more positive once there is performace issues patch.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Whilst the game on my inital impressions looks fun at it's current state it is unplayable due to poor optimizations Pros: - Voice acting seems nice- Story seems engaging- Looks beautiful with nice partical effects - Combat is really fun and button mashing feels great- cool collectables and costumes Cons:- Horrendous optimization which include:- Random FPS dips making the gameplay and general flow of the action terrible and removes immersion  - The game by default is capped at 30 fps (this can be changed in an ini file). Anything above said fps leads to stability issues and 30 fps is just unacceptable    - SLI & Crossfire scaling is not , at present, where it needs to be, rendering some secondary cards useless - The batmobile is used a bit to much for my liking, It is pushed abit to much but some people may enjoy more than me.The crux of this me not recommending this game is due to poor optimization . The consensus in the gaming community is that even on the highest end of systems (gtx titans) this game is running at unacceptable framerates . It makes more sense as to why this game was soo cheap on certain websites and that review codes for the pc version where not made widely available. Rocksteady outsourced the pc development to another company and this has resulted in a bad version of the game making it to store. They have aknowledged this and are said to be working on this and hopefully will result in better performance down the line.Patches resulting in better performance in time is par-for-the-course in pc gaming and should be accepted that things will get better as driver support improves and the game is patch but, it is not acceptable to launch a game in this state and expect people not be angry. That is why i will, at this time, not recommend this game, Wait a while for performance improvments or buy it on console.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												So there are currently tons of issues with the game. I can only write this based off of my time with the game thus far. My current setup is an i5 4690k, MSI GTX 970 Sli, and 32GB Ram. Currently this game doesn't support any sort of sli gpu scaling, so the best option for anyone running sli is to disable sli and use your second gpu as a dedicated physx card. Doing this as well as editing the .ini file for 144 max frames, I'm still getting framerates from the high 110's to as low as 45fps with everything maxed out and the Gameworks options turned on. The game does tend to stay around 70-80fps for the most part though. I'm also using a Gsync monitor, which does help with the variable framerates and frame drops. So for me the experience has been pretty decent. The game is really fun a few hours in, and it really does look amazing. Keep in mind that nearly everyone is having major issues with the game running on very capable hardware. The game definitely needs some major patching to get to the great game that is hidden beneath all these bugs. I really hope Rocksteady get on it, and give people the game that they purchased. That being said, I can't in good conscious recommend the game in it's current state. Maybe in the future when a lot of the issues are ironed out my thoughts will change. But it's luck of the draw right now. If they get the game working as intended I would highly recommend it to pretty much anyone, but until then it's a pass.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												It *pains* me to write this review because based on the little I was able to enjoy of Arkham Knight, I understand why so many people are saying it's one of the best games they've ever played. What was already just shy of perfect in Arkham City has been refined and tweaked seamlessly, making the gliding, combat and exploration an absolute joy. Slicker than an oiled up ♥♥♥♥♥ at a fishing derby. Contrary to a lot of people's opinions on the batmobile, I love how it handles. It's a blast to plough through the streets of Gotham and see thugs run and cower in its wake. The first hour of the game's story also dwarfs that of City's or Asylum's by a long shot and in spite of the fact that it is nearly impossible to avoid spoilers online, the less you know about what happens, the better. Whenever I can play the game to completion, I know I'm in for a wild ride. Unfortunately, this bungled botch job of a port utterly ruins any fun you'll have. I would prefer to remain optimistic that the Day One patch will sort a lot of these issues out, but I've also been neck deep in the launch disaster of Mortal Kombat X, which I foolishly spent $100 dollars on. While the issues I personally have experienced with Arkham Knight are *nothing* compared to the mass of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t High Voltage is responsible for, many other people have it much worse, even on better rigs than mine too. Perpetual black screens, the city not being rendered in hell, some people can't even start the ♥♥♥♥ing game! Even when I fixed the capped at 30 FPS problem, tweaked the texture options, enabled MSAA and disabled the NVIDIA Gameworks settings, (which are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t by the way) my game would randomly just die after running well enough for me to enjoy myself and think I'd figured out a way around the issues.The fact of the matter is, releasing a port like this is unacceptable. Bungling the launch of such a high profile game is inexcusable and deliberately withholding PC review codes to avoid a PR disaster is practically criminal. There is NO excuse for this, especially not from a studio that's released two of my favorite games of all time...but, the sad fact of AAA gaming these days is you can't trust anyone. It doesn't matter what they've released, how great the footage looks in commercials or gameplay vids, what you might want or hope the game is like, chances are something horrible awaits you. I dread the releases of Fallout 4 and Metal Gear Solid V, should they choose to follow in Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X's example. For now, save your money. If Rocksteady can fix things in two weeks, I will edit this review to properly discuss the actual *game*. If not, I'll get my money back and see if the Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition is worth a damn...I swear, these bungled ports are the work of The Joker.**EDIT** At this time, Rocksteady has proven their utter contempt for the PC gaming community and I've requested a refund. I advise everyone who hasn't already to do so, because until the inevitable Game Of The Year edition comes out, you're in for the same ride as MKX. Good luck to anyone who sticks this out, yer gonna need it.


YouTube™ Video: Batman: Arkham Knight – PC vs. PS4 vs. Xbox One Graphics Comparison [60fps][FullHD] 

			Views: 548,751		

			Visit our sponsor: http://www.one.de/shop/index.php We are on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/candylandGS Batman: Arkham Knight kaufen (Germany only): http://amzn.to/1K8pYsl We compare Batman...		

**ADDITIONAL EDIT** So, year's almost over, Arkham Knight's back on Steam now and it's *still* not fixed. ♥♥♥♥ me, am I ever glad I jumped ship when I did. Selling the game for $10 less and offering refunds isn't going to fix anything WB. You ♥♥♥♥ed up. Admit it - admit that you're lying, deceiving, useless, money grubbing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and be done with it.In the time since I wrote my initial review I've also had the opportunity to play the game on a friend's PS4 and surprise surprise, it's not great. It's not a *bad* game but after that first hour I was incapable of passing the story quality nosedives, the acting gets hammier than a pig farm and 80% (not even kidding) of the main gameplay becomes Batman: Tank Warfare. Want to swoop down off of rooftops in the larger areas of Gotham to beat up bad guys? TOO BAD, drones will insta-kill you. Biggest disappointment of 2015, hands down. It'd be funny if it weren't so pathetic.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												There are plenty of reviews up about the performance of Arkham Knight.That being said, there are patches to address these issues, and while it's sad that a high-calibur game had enough issues to warrant pulling sales, I want to talk to people who may be thinking of getting the game after the sales hold is released. I've heard talks of a 'Game of the Year' edition may be made at some point. While this is hilarious given that the game can't be bought on the PC, this is sure to be confusing for people who don't have a console and are looking at picking up the game.For context, I have a good system with the game installed on an SSD. An SSD seemed to eliminate almost all of the performance issues for me. So, I was able to play through at release and it was relatively smooth. That being said, I can see a difference in the game after the patches.I have enjoyed all of the Batman Arkham series so far and was eagerly anticipating the finale. The graphics in Arkham Knight are amazing and there are moments of pure awesome Batman-ness in this game (for example, Fear Takedowns will make your jaw drop every time). All of the iconic Batman moments are in this game; but is that enough?I feel this game doesn't play to it's strengths. They've made predator mode very powerful, but only rarely do you get to unleash the full power on thugs. The story moments that are supposed to be strong aren't and the points that aren't supposed to be strong are. The Batmobile is a ton of fun to drive around, but they rarely make good use of it. When I say that about the Batmobile, I want to be clear: there are 2 'different' vehicles; the Batmobile (drives around really fast), and the Tankmobile (manuver around and shoot stuff).If you don't like the Tankmobile, you will not like this game. It is like 90% of the game, and while fun for the first few fights, every fight is essentially the same + more tanks than last fight. There are 2 major Batman villians known for their hand-to-hand prowesss... that you fight while they are in a tank! WHY?A friend put it to me like this "I just want to play as Batman. Let me punch some people, sneak up on some guys and drive around. If I wanted to play a tank simulator game, that's what I would have gotten"I can understand that Rocksteady really wanted to have the Batmobile in the game and they likely came up with the Tankmobile and all the enemy tanks as a way to justify it, but there is way too much tank fighting in the game. When a mod is released (I'm certain it will be) that drastically cuts down the number of tanks and/or tank fights... I will seriously re-evaluate this game as if that was the way it was meant to be released.I do highly recommend to make use of the optional Batmobile toggle button via the menu.For me, Predator mode was awesome... I just wish there was more of it or it was longer. The Bank heists were awesome and I'd love for there to have been more. The past games had some good 'detective-y' bits that were fun and different, This seems to have been thrown in as an after thought via 1 side mission. There's ways this could have helped the game: There's a side mission where you rescue firefighters from thugs. Only, they seem to be randomly distributed throughout the city and end up being very difficult to find after you've gotten a few. Some detective work to lead you there would have fit right in.There's 2 mission types that use the real (non-tank) batmobile: commanders patrol the city in APCs, which you have to chase down and a mission that basically has you race/chase a villian. There really isn't that many of these missions and they certainly are fun. Would really like for there to have been more. Something along the lines of "Batman! we just found out things are going to explode... on the other side of the city! How can we get there in time?!" would have worked just fine. There's a challenge map that has you race to a location, battle a hand full of tanks, then race to a new location and repeat a few times... I quite like this, despite what I said about the tank fighting. You're not overwhelmed with tanks; you're more concerned with doing it efficiently.Combat is kind of hard to breakdown. It's the same basic formula that has been so great over the years (with enough new things to keep it interesting). Getting into a fight with the average joes on the street corner really isn't fair at all. You just demolish them. However, there are prepared/armored/armed guys that hang out in very large groups. It kinda seems like just being awesome with the combat system isn't enough, you have to find a good opening into the fight to really make sure you survive; but the game goes out of it's way to make sure that you don't get to make those good openings. I've also heard that it's quite daunting to have so many moves and enemies that you have to attack in particular ways. Then again, there are the team-ups with other heros that are a blast, but you aren't facing the tougher thugs, so it's not like you really need their help.Summary:If you're on the fence about this game, I'd recommend watching some videos of the tank battles and see if that appeals to you. There are a lot of good console reviews praising the tank fights as fun, so that may be something for you.If you've played the other Arkham games and just want to 'complete the story', you'll end up playing at some point anyhow.For everyone else, I'd just say get Arkham Origins or City instead. That is way more Batman-like than Arkham: World of Tanks. Maybe when the price dropsOh, and don't even bother with the DLC. The 'Story DLC' is simply 3 or so rooms chained together. Can be done in 1/2 an hour... very much not worth the $.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Batman Arkham Knight is the final installment of the Batman Arkham series. It takes place in a deserted Gotham city with all of the criminals loose. Scarecrow is at large throughout the game with the Arkham Knight. Scarecrow plans to fill Gothams atomosphere with his deadly fear toxin. It is up to Batman to stop him. I loved this game. Rocksteady really hit a grand slam with this. It has an even bigger grand scale than what it was in Arkham City. There is so much to do in this game that it will last you for hours on end. The story and all of the side missions are fantastic of course. All of the performances for this game were flawless with Kevin Conroy and John Noble. The Batmobile is also very badass and it is really joyful driving around gotham in it. But I still found myself flying on rooftops instead of driving the batmobile. The fighting in this game is better than every as well and they did a good job with creating the different sorts of enemies like the medic. One thing that slightly annoyed me about this game was the obstacles that you had to use the Bat-Tank to get passed them. But overall, this game met the hype, even surpassed it. But I am giving this game a thumbs down currently until Rocksteady fixes the PC port. I tolerated all of the issues but as of now this game is better to play on the PS4 and Xbox One. 8/10+ Performances.+ Insane combat.+ All of the side missions.- Bat-tank objectives.- Crappy port (not counting this against the score).

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												I got this game for free after buying my 2nd 970, and I would much rather had a cash-back rebate for the cost of the game. If you want a detailed review other than "The PC port sucks, don't buy" and want an actual review of both the game and performance, read on. On the "Bad PC Port" side: Bugs, glitches and performance problems galore. To begin with: Half of the options in the menu don't even give you information as to what you're turning on or off, or to what level you are turning things up or down. Option choices in the Graphic's menu looks like a game from 2003. Anti-Aliasing? On or Off. Textures? Low or Normal. Shadows/Level of Deatil? Low/Med/High. That's it, those 4 things are your graphic options. The only others are 4 Nvidia Gameworks options that can just be switched On or Off and that's only if you're running an Nvidia card; AMD guys get completely left out. There is no real "setting", it's either on or off. There's also no FOV adjustment or any sort of finer adjustments that are commonplace even in Indie games. Running with a 4790k @ 4.86Ghz, overclocked G1 970s in SLI, 16Gb of 2133Mhz GSkill RAM, and installed on a 550 Write/520 Read Sandisk Extreme Pro SSD on what I assume to be "Ultra" settings, the game runs like a stop-motion amateur film more often than not, and when it's not stuttering, there are graphic issues or *constant* crashes. Most of the time the Batmobile is on screen there are FPS issues. Which unfortunately ends up being a real pain as the Batmobile IS the game. Many sections are fast-paced chases or require you to maintain certain distances; something very hard to do when it's stuttering like King George VI. Even pre-rendered video has stuttering which is beyond unacceptable. Optimization is so poor that on the built in "Benchmarking" feature my setup can barley keep an average 60-70FPS running standard 1080p with everything "on". And with the actual game itself hard-capped at 30FPS, it struggles to maintain that meager framerate. Although you can edit an INI file to make the game cap at whatever framerate you want, it's been stated by the Devs themselves they don't recommend doing so. There are several graphical bugs, clipping and pathing issues, texture issues, pop-in textures, poor textures, occasional draw distance issues, lighting issues with seizure-inducing random lights randomly appearing at certain camera angles, as well as several instances of crashing straight to desktop. Get used to seeing "Has stopped responding."As for gameplay, my negative opinion doesn't revolve solely around the "It's a horrible PC port" complaint. I would of disliked the game even without the several performance issues. The whole Batmobile thing ruined the game for me, as they just shove it in your face way too much. When you are 100 feet underground and there are perfectly placed roads and platforms to maneuver your Batmobile around, you get pulled right out of the game. The previous games in the series were also about stealth and the awesome combat system. The Batwing and Batmobile are not stealthy. They are used for getting from Point A to Point B; occasionally a secondary purpose of getting Batman out of a tight scrape or literal Deus Ex Machina. This completely spits in the face of the previous games. Clonking around in a wannabe Ironman metal suit isn't stealthy, driving through a city destroying cars, walls, buildings, or anything you run into while firing a minigun, a cannon, and missiles isn't stealthly. Building the whole game around GTA: Gotham ruined what could of been an amazing game. The Batmobile is tied to nearly everything in the game, from bosses, to minibosses, to exploring, to sidequests. Especially Riddler. Anything Riddler will involve the Batmobile. Even if you enjoy the Batmobile, it very quickly becomes tedious after the 8th Cut & Paste tank battle. If you want to further a plot line, prepare to have to use the freakin car. "Evening the Odds" was a fun little gimmick, and the Batmobile could of worked if the entire game wasn't built around the damn thing, and tank battles didn't happen every 10 minutes just 'because'. The unique Arkham combat system is also ruined by it. Random fights around Gotham are worthless, award no XP, and you find yourself either completely ignoring enemies or going on a GTA5 rampage with your Tankmobile. Those two choices get old very quick. NPCs will run away from you in terror any time the Batmobile is near you. Random fights around Gotham are worthless as experience is only given from combat that happens during the main story or sidequests. The gameplay has also been dumbed down way too far. There are no heart monitors, using remote controlled batarangs to disable them or any sort of strategy. Just charge in, use easy-mode "Fear Takedown," and you can literally take on half an army in the "Predator" sections of the game without varying up your moves at all.Gadgets are extremely underused, new gadgets aren't used anywhere to their full potential, and old gadgets from previous games are thrown in without consequence or reason. One gadget isn't even given to you as a necessity for furthering the game, it's "found" simply to give variation to Riddler trophies and end-game content. Again, everything revolves around the car. Even if you ditch the car and go without it, you won't get far without needing it to progress or having to use it to not die to a horde of tanks. What new gadgets that are introduced would be fun to use if Stealth was still something you considered in this game. I found myself just charging head-first into all battles instead of planning out attacks and using stealth like in previous games. The only time any sort of skill or planning is needed is for Challenges; and that's another issue. There are so few Challenges in this game compared to previous titles. But watch them spoon feed us VR combat challenges in paid DLC. Boss battles are very lackluster. One "Boss Battle" involving a well known and loved villian is another run-of-the-mill tank battle you've seen 4 dozen times. The climax? A 5 second cutscene showing you both jumping out of your tanks, and a single punch to the face. Ta-Da! Then a cutscene of shoving someone into your Bat-Carseat. And get used to that routiune. Much of what made previous games in the series fun is just completely nullified. There are a few sparse Pros sprinkled around thankfully. The combat system is upgraded from games past, and seems more fluid, although the AI seems to be a little dumber and rarely attack in large groups of 3-4 and prefer to attack you one at a time like Lemmings, even on hard. You aren't forced to counter everytime your Spider(Bat)sense goes off, and can instead dictate the flow of combat yourself moreso than ever which is nice. The grappling and flying system is much improved, although it's wasted as you'll just end up needing your car once you get to where you're going. And the game has a compelling story, although the game spoils itself about half-way through which was a letdown. Also on the story front, it's sadly a very short game. If you completely bypass any non-essential sidequests or missions, I'd estimate this game could be completed in less than 15 hours. I'm just over 50 hours and am 98.3% complete, the only thing remaining are a few Riddler trophies. So don't expect tons and tons of gameplay hours with this. To end everything, the Pros in no way outweigh the cons. And when a game looks better and runs better on a $350 console than it does on high-end $2500+ PCs, there's something seriously, seriously wrong.**Edited as I progressed further, encountered more bugs, glitches, and issues with gameplay. Also, a decent amount of my actual in-game timer is from leaving the game alt-tabbed or falling asleep a few times. And even with some of my time not even being in-game play, ~50 hours of gametime will net you 100% completion and then some. But there's no real reason to even consider a NG+

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												*******************************NO SPOILERS*********************************Probably the best Batman game ever made. I want to start off by saying that I didn't really care for Batman before playing the first Arkham game, and ever since I've fallen in love with the voice actors of the main characters, especially Mark Hamill as the Joker.This game takes place after Arkham City, with a new cast of main villains, namely The Arkham Knight, Scarecrow and another familliar face in the Batman series which I won't name (No Spoil). There's also many returning classics who play minor roles, such as the Penguin, Two-Face, Riddler, Catwoman, Poison Ivy, etc.)Arkham Knight has, by far, the biggest explorable map of all Arkham games, hence the introduction of the Batmobile to get around faster and complete many of the speed challenges. The storyline is on par with other Arkham games, with a quite predictable ending (even though some of the plot twists are quite good). The characters are well portrayed, the combat mechanics are better than ever, some of the puzzles will force you to think and the optionnal content is very good. I would recommend this to anyone who has the hardware to run it. The game had alot of optimization problems at the start, but at this point I think it's safe to say that most have been patched, and the game hidden behind that crappy launch is actually one of the best Batman experiences out there.

												Second release: So nothing has changed. The games is still unoptimized mess (well, compared to what we had for the first 3 months it is amazing). The only good thing they did is actually promising every single Arkham Game and TF2 items for those who kept this abomination, except that a ton of people already had other Arkham games, since there is no point of buying this one, if you haven't played previous installments.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME UNLESS IT IS 90% OFF!NEW: Well, the fixed a lot of problems so now I can play at 60 fps (still not stable), with low textures and shadows (otherwise fps is around 30 fps). Do I recommend this game? No, and I never will. There is a thing called YouTube, go there if you want to see how the story ends. Don't EVER buy it, just to show developers that people are smarter than they think, so they won't be able to release a broken product just to fix it later. Go buy The Phantom Pain that is perfect in every way, or go buy Mad Max, that works perfectly at stable 60 fps on max settings and is fun to play. Stay away from this game even though they fixed it. It is the worst Batman game out of Arkham series (including Origins), and not because, but thanks to one of the worst launch ever. Because it wasn't working players where looking critically at the entire game, not just optimization, and oh boy it is bad. While the main story is a lot of fun (except for Arkham Knight, because this character was awful), but every other aspect is far from good. Every single side-quest is boring and univentive, the Batmobile is pushed down your throat until you scream "STOP!"DON'T buy this game.OLD: I was able to play it at 30 FPS (not stable) with GTX 960, FX-8320 and 8 Gb RAM... on lowest possible settings (and really low resolution) until it crashed 30 mins later. Saying that this is the worst possible port of a AAA title is not saying enough. I really hope that every single person in Iron Galaxy and WB Interactive Entertainment who had something to do with PC version will get fired and will never be able to work in his entire life, dying alone and broke. This is just insulting. I was going to pre-order Mad Max, but now I will think twice before even buying it. ♥♥♥♥ you WB and ♥♥♥♥ everyone at Iron Galaxy, for ♥♥♥♥ing up Batman for the second time for PC.
