number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												After many hours spent in Gotham I can say this: Arkham Knight has succeeded.It may have cost Warner and Rocksteady an amount of time to fix what was broken, but lets face it, mistakes happen, apologies have been made and free DLC was given to compensate.Although the game has its flaws, the overall experience as the Batman is satisfying. The combat still stands, with some new shiny gadgets and a new Batsuit. There were some point during game when I thought that some gadgets from previous games would have been a warm welcome. When I was faced with some breakable walls, I wanted the improved Batclaw for example. Instead I had to fly trough it, which let to some frustration when my speed wasn't fast enough for the third time.The Story is a direct sequel to Arkham City, I will not spoil any major plot points here, but if you are really spoiler sensitive skip to the next paragraph. **MILD SPOILERS AHEAD** The story begins around Halloween and this time Scarecrow takes the lead together with his new angry army general The Arkham Knight. Scarecrow really takes all the credits when it comes to charismatic villains, while the Arkham Knight mostly sounds like a spoiled child.I found a lot of enjoyment in all the little side stories, but overall I was disappointed in some resolutions at the end of the chains. Especially if you invested 15 hours to defeat the Knight and the real battle isn't really face to face.The second story I was disappointed about was Deathstroke, I really expected a Arkham Origins epicness, but after all the taunts the story arch felt flat.Overall the conclusion of the Story (or at least the Scarecrow story) was satisfying and imo, better than Asylum (where are talking about the ending).If you are a gamer who decides to buy a game depending on the length, than this game is worth it. The amount of side objectives is immense, the main story takes about 15-20 hours, and along the way there are many extra missions you can take up like saving firemen crew, stop bank heists, chase villains and of course the infamous riddles.These riddles are not always as fresh and new as they felt in Asylum, and I think Rocksteady over did it a little.Although some are very clever created, a lot of them feel as extra fluff to keep you going, especially as you need them all to get the real ending. YOU READ IT RIGHT, you need ALL THE RIDDLER TROPHIES to get the real good ending.With 243 trophies on the counter, it takes a enormous grind to complete.Of course you can always watch the ending online if it suits you, but if you are like me, you want to earn it by doing it.If all the Riddler challenges and trophies were interesting enough it would be less of a chore, but they aren't, at least not all of them. 150 would have been a better mark.This game introduces you to the full advanced Batmobile. Although I really like to drive around and felt all powerful in this handsome Wayne toy. The shine wears off after hours of gameplay. It has to fit in the story, fit in the game. But to many times it felt as if the game has been built around the Batmobile and thus makes it "so convenient." You use it for: Boss battles, challenges, Riddler trophy locations, reaching areas etc . It's like everyone knew Batman was gonna bring his car, so they prepared for it, which feels odd. In the end, it is so overused that the real boss battles from Asylum, City and Origins have no place here, because the Batmobile saves the day every time.Conclusion, Although the city is deserted again and the story tries to sum up a reason for it to happen, it kinda feels lame. It would have been such an enjoyment to finally be the hero for Gotham's civilians, but again we are stuck with thugs only.In the end the game really delivers on fan service, almost every iconic Batman character has to come pass, all the little stories within Gotham are well executed. I think it's sad that some characters haven't got more screen time this time around. The gameplay is solid, but the Batmobile is overused. The pacing could have been a bit better with a bit less of the trophy hunt. The story delivers, the graphics are outstanding and the soundtrack makes the experience complete.7.5/10

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Disclaimer: I got this game for free through a Nvidia Newegg promotion along with The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt for purchasing a GTX 970 graphics card. ---PerformanceHaving played previous titles of this franchise in the past I was excited to try this one out however much to my chagrin it was (and at the time of this review) poorly optimized. I have a relatively decent system and I can ultra or near ultra basically any game on the market today @ 60fps. This game was locked to 30fps and while using the Batmobile the game would spontaneously drop below 20 fps with microhitching and shuttering around every corner.  Make no mistake this game will put tremendous stress on the drive it is installed on.While defragging my games drive I found three seperate installation directories of this game; 2 of which had apparently became corrupted and had been redownloaded by Steam since it could not detect the directory. It took almost half a day to remove this corrupted data and out of fear of permanet damage coupled by the sad performance of the game I decided to ultimately uninstall. On September 3rd 2015 Warner Bros released a patch for this game that was supposed to significantly improve the game stability. Based on the immense negative public outcry that has been rekindled because of this long anticipated patch I will not be revisiting the game as it appears nothing has changed.GameplayIf you are new to the Batman Arkham games it should be noted that combat is generally satisfying. You have access to many hi-tech gadgets and toys that you would expect a billionaire playboy crime fighter to have, as well as the martial prowess of the infamous Batman. You combine these unique advantages to take out criminal scum across Gotham City for the first time ever fully displayed in this franchise. You are not limited to a specific area such as Arkham City or Arkham Asylum and are free to explore within a set game paced progression based on the main story which has you track down a mysterious figure known only as the "Arkham Knight".  Even though Batman is incredibly strong, his enemies are numerous and in this title they can be exceptionally dangerous. Instead of fighting thuggish brutes you are now in the crosshairs of private military contractors trained to hunt and kill you. They are outfitted with good gear and trained in ways to defeat your tactics. The Fear mechanic has returned but is not as prevalent as in previous games and because of this they will be less likely to expose their vulnerbilities or break formation while attacking them.  You have to be careful and plan out your attacks from the shadows if you hope to actually win on the harder difficulties as enemies will not give up and one simple mistake can turn a "wild goose hunt" into a fully fledged fire fight. The Batmobile as previously mentioned is included heavily within this game. Given the size of Gotham City and the various missions designed to incorporate it's inclusion into the game, you will spend a good amount of time cruising around the city blowing stuff up, running over bad guy cars, and tasing them senseless with your electrified bumper (of great justice). Unlike previous Batmobiles though, this one comes equipped with a cannon - making it essentially a tank - and the NPCs will never let you forget this fact.Stealth is a key componet of any Batman game and graphical/performance issues aside this title keeps in line with tradition on this front. Being able to take your enemy out one by one is still my favorite way of dispatching packs, especially when you hear their dialouge change from "LETS DO THIS HAHA!" to "We're all f*****" several discovered bodies later. Nothing significantly new was added and as far as I can tell they did not remove anything from the other games. One of my peeves with enemies in this game comes from the lack of identifiying new enemy types or annoucing that they now are a threat. In previous games when a new enemy type appears you would be introduced to what they can do and more importantly how to stop them. In this game, you have to be observant and look at your enemies in detective mode to see what they are carrying, as well what armor/clothing they have on. Certain special enemies such as the medic can revive up to 3 unconscious baddies while stun stick guys do crazy melee damage and are better off taken out with batwings. Final thoughtsI will not go further into explaining the story so that nothing is spoiled, however I did enjoy what I played and was happy to see certain characters make an appearance. Overall this game is really good but is a terrible PC port. If you are a fan of the series or of Batman I would suggest picking up a copy of this on your favorite console and giving it a solid playthrough as the PC version of this game was not handled right and suffers from botched development.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Even in spite of everything it took to get this game working, it's still not very good. It gave me two main impressions: 1) it's more of the same of the past 3 Arkham games and 2) the Batmobile is so over-represented in the missions that I'd rather have just played either of the Transformers: Cybertron games instead. On top of that, getting the 100% ending is pretty weak sauce - you're better off not wasting your time with the Riddler puzzles, as they get super repetitive and boring between finding them and then solving them quickly thereafter. YouTube is a much more viable option to see the additional 4-5 min of footage. Overall, I'd say appreciate that Iron Galaxy totally botched this port of the game for those who got full refunds already - they saved you money and time in the long run. edit: the other fun fact is that there were at least two lies made during the advertisement of the game regarding plot elements that sorely disappointed throughout.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Unfortunately, AK is a terrible, terrible port. - Performance seems to range from poor to random (I was gettting essentially 30 FPS, went to sleep, tried to play again and getting half)- The Nvidia effects are causing crashes as well as enormous performance drops- The game has a huge memory leak- VRAM usage is ridiculous - it basically eats up all the memory your card has even if it's not necessary- It stutters like hell- It takes nearly 10 seconds to fully load in some textures off my Samsung 840 Evo SSD, other users are reporting textures simply never fully loading- The game is capped at 30 FPS, you can remove the cap but it'll introduce instability and performance drops- There are very few graphics options, meaning the game has pretty much 0 scalability- No toggles for post-processing options like motion blur, chromatic aberration, depth of field, film grain or bloom- Motion blur is a big cause of huge FPS drops and stuttering- Verifying the game's integrity on Steam will cause the game to corrupt and delete itself- Performance is even worse on AMD cardsThe game itself seems to be quite good, but this is the worst PC port I've played since AC: Unity. And that's saying something. Iron Galaxy Studios appear to be behind the PC port - so I don't know how much blame Rocksteady or WB deserve. Regardless, this is a complete mess and a disgrace to gaming. Consoles are apparently having issues too, although nowhere near as many as us PC gamers. Add in the fact that people who got the game by buying a new Nvidia card were suddenly refused access to the pre-order DLC hours before the game unlocked and the fact that WB didn't send out any PC copies to be reviewed, and we've got one of the worst PC ports coupled with some of the worst business practices from the history of gaming. This is an insult to gamers, fans of Batman, and the hard work that's gone into the franchise.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												                I liked this game a lot (this is quite clear from the fact that I continued to play it in the current state), but the terrible quality of the port cannot be ignored and the publisher has to be condemned for outsourcing the PC version to a small studio of twelve people for a game with a price tag of 50 euros (55?! Plus DLCs). It shows a lack of respect for the PC market and its customers and they probably would have gotten away and sold millions (just like Watch Dogs did) if there wasn’t the option for refunds. Let this be a lesson to any publisher that tries to screw up the PC gamers, as we are vocal and we made ourselves heard, through refunds and overwhelmingly negative scores that are not necessarily justifiable to the game’s quality but reflect our frustration towards this treachery.But is the problematic port making Batman: Arkham Knight a bad game? Nowhere near close to that. It is a true and true action game, without selectable dialogues or moral choices just for the sake of it as this is not a role playing but rather a very interactive experience as Batman following his rules and his unchangeable story. The story is flawlessly written and plays out in an unpredictable way putting an end to a six years long series that has done to superheroes video games what the Dark Knight series has done with superheroes movies (Can I get a Green Lantern series like these ones?!).                I can’t say that the game is worth buying now as its technical state is still a mess and playing at 30fps with heavily forced in motion blur is tiring. But in a few weeks or months when most of the problems are fixed it might be a title that should not be missed by fans of the genre and Batman alike.Pros:+ Excellent story+ Great world design+ Good graphics and physics+ High quality voice acting+ Lots of villains and heroes from the Batman universe+ Addictive gameplay+ Batmobile+ 40+ hours of gameplay+ Puzzles+ Completist’s heavenCons:- Horrible performance problems- Locked at 30fps (even if it's unlocked from .ini it is still unstable)- Lacks important graphics features and options- Multifunctional keys- Secondary missions can be repetitive- No serious boss fights- Batmobile is overusedRead the full review at:http://thegameslashers.blogspot.ro/2015/07/batman-arkham-knight-review.html

content:
Posted: February 27
												1. I have no problems with framerates nor crashes2. I have no major complaints with the batmobile.3. I've played AA, AC, AO.I'll try to keep spoilers to a minimal.AK, ah the end to a series that introduced me to Batman and just how awesome he is. Before I touched AA, I've always thought Batman to belong to the 'boring superheroes' group. After playing AA though, all that changed. I googled every characters that I encountered in the game, villians/heroes/sidekicks alike. Slowly immersing myself in Gotham, learning as much as I can in order to relieve the true experience in the game, and slowly liking it more and more. What really impressed me was AA's freeflow battles when I first took part in one. It was a first for me to experience such battles and boy was it fun!! So simple, yet so effective, some things are fixed, yet gives you the illusion that you are in control; ingenious, for lack of a better word. And I was glad things felt the same in AO and AC as well.Battle SystemAs for AK - Hits and misses, it's still freeflow, but things seems to have loosen up abit, as seen with the new introduction of rooftop hybrid-predator battles, as well as the controls not feeling as tight. I've made a couple of mistakes I'd never make in the previous three. But still satisfiying when you get no damage.Also, what is up with the distance batman and team can cover? I can punch a man here and leap 10km away (exaggerated, but srsly) to kick another, I didn't know batman crossed over and took lessons from Spider-man, damn, kinda makes the magic go away during the first 1 or 2 battles I partook. It wasn't this unrealistic in previous titles, afaik.They seem to have loosen up the grappling as well, you can pretty much grapple anything you can see right now, yep even things you never really wanted to grappled, lel. WORKS WONDERS when you are playing some of the hybrid-predator scenarios on rooftops /sMissions / Side MissionsLet me just say most side missions including the DLCs were well thought out and extremely detailed, the heart and thoughts that were put into these were pretty much amazing, majority of dialogues that were around were unique and there were tons of pressing A (Xbox controller) whenever I was in GCPD. Seeing the cells fill up everytime I go back was defintely satisfying too. HOWEVER when it came down to anything militia related, Good god they are the most annoying bunch I've ever seen, including Scarecrow and AK himself. It really gets tedious towards the end.Empty, meaningless threats - 'Muwahahahaha u will neber defeat me Batman!!' *throws 62 more checkpoints, 80 guard towers, 20 land mines and 32 Cobra drones.'Militia commenting that 'haha batman thinks he can win', when I've already twarted 3 semi-major events including defeating your stupid edgey commander!Look Scarecrow, AK, in case you don't know, I'm already 85% in the game and have already destroyed 6,000 checkpoints, approximately 3,200 guard towers, 5 land mines and 80 cobra drones and an almost complete genocide of your militia army, I'd need 200 GCPDs to accomodate all of them, AND YET YOU ARE STILL RAMBLING ON AND ON ON THAT STUPID SCREEN OF YOURS SAYING HOW YOU WILL DEFEAT ME WITH THE SAME OLD THINGS??? Those fear gas of yours should be relabeled as dumb gas.Now you may think I may be exaggerating a little, but as a completionist, I've 100% all riddler's challenges in AA, AO and AC and I'm already 82% in AK and intend to 100% to get the ultimate ending. So I don't use the word 'tedious' lightly.And just FYI, Riddler's mission aren't tedious. As a matter of fact, it is the star of all side missions in Arkham Series, it's so varied, and you always look forward to progressing, just to see riddler's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off face and hear him scream. Ladies and gentlemen, that is how you make a seemingly tedious progression not tedious - innovation, surprise, mix it up. Imagine all riddler's trophy sitting around only with no puzzles whatsoever, that is how all mlitia related side quests are.It's annoying everytime I have to go through it, and I have to say this is the first time I felt this annoyed in an Arkham series.Abilities,Gadgets4 letters - OP AF.Yes I get that Batman is supposed to be OP, especially since he is already established in AK. But srsly when you are in a game this long, with what I've mentioned above, all these isn't really helping. Back when I played AA, you can never help but feel that Batman IS there, just not quite since you need to level up to unlock abilities to progress, get that trophy, or simply kick people's♥♥♥♥♥in a more satisfying way. and you worked hard and progress for it.Well in AK It's 'here all these is for you' bruce wayne's parents died here's the deed and ten gazillion dollars style, now go kick some♥♥♥♥♥ Yep very fun inititally when you can already glide so high and travel so far, pull off all the abilities mapped to your controller in such complex ways, sometimes I don't even know what button I'm supposed to pressed.But when you have a game this long, you really need something to look forward too, and apart from comestical upgrades and abilities that you REALLY DO NOT NEED to complete the game, this really does make the game boring during the later parts. Oh look, drones - here a disruptorOh look, devices that can detect you in detective mode - here a disruptorOh look, devices that jams your detective mode - here a disruptorOh look, MINES!!!! - here.....-.-StoryAs much as my overly exasperating mish mash of words on how the overall interaction of the militias, Scarecrow and AK have been, the story is amazing, period. I look forward to progressing everytime I complete one part, but being the perfectionist I am, I have to go through all the side missions as much as I can before progressing, which really kinda gives me a love hate relationship for this game.And Joker, THANK GOD FOR JOKER I LOVE YOU MR J!!!!!!!!!!To sum it up, the story is like watching Blizzard's cinematics, you just can't stop! One of the main reasons why I will complete this game. Props to the writer, you guys have always been the best. BatmobileAn interesting addition to the game, I like it, however I think the main reasons why people are complaining is the controls, wow it really worked my wrists and it does get frustrating sometimes. Should they continue in insurgency, I hope they tighten the controls, it would be lovely. And do get rid of battle mode or at least please don't send 62 useless drones to my locations, NEWSFLASH I am THE Batman and this is my Batmobile, pls gtfo, thanks.Race courses by Riddler, damn well thought out as well, worth a mention.GraphicsTons of complaints back then, main reason why AK has a mixed overall review right now, but this plays smoothly for me, most things on normal, no crashes, Everything is Gotham, beautifully Gotham.The addition of Nvidia Gameworks is really impressive as well, especially lights shaft, interative fog/smoke and interactive papers, unfortunately my system is not a beast and I have to turn it off else there will be stuttering here and there, but it is a positive addition to the game if your system is capable of running it. Overall, I'll still give it a thumbs up for the effort you can see that was put into this game, however all newly implemented features require polishing, and for the militais, you sometimes can't help but feel the developers got lazy somewhere along the line.An explosive start to a seemingly smithering late game, worth a buy still as long as it's on sale.

												Worst PC port I've played in years. Runs like hot garbage on SLI GTX 980 Ti's. Literally howHas terrible post-processing effects you cannot disable even in a .ini like chromatic aberration and film grain.Comes locked at 30 FPS by default.No HBAO+, ambient occlusion, etc. Textures aren't that great despite using way too much VRAM.In-game anti-aliasing option is pathetic, just an "Off/On" toggle that enables a terrible form of FXAA. The Gameworks effects look pretty good, excellent smoke effects, but that's about the only positive thing I have to say about this game's visuals.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Where the hell do I even begin with this damn game....This is actually my secondreview. Though initially I gave it a positive review, claiming that, even though it didn't run very well, it was still a very solid game on the basis of its gameplay and story, and we shouldn't be so quick to judge it, considering they were hard at work on a patch to address the numerous issues that this god-awful port faced.That was five months ago. Five ♥♥♥♥ing months. And we just got the patch a few days ago. Since that patch, the game won't even start in fullscreen for many players, and those who can get the damn game running report that it's practically unchanged from the recent "Patch"--the only thing that seems to have been added is the DLC that console players have been enjoying over the past half-year.Yes. The story is great. Yes. The gameplay is fun. But I can't recommend this damn game to anyone on any ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ platform on the simple basis that CLEARLY, they don't give a damn about the people who're buying their product. Clearly they don't give a damn about selling an actual quality product. Oh, and it runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥ That's another nail in the coffin.Update: There have been a few updates to the game since I rewrote this review, and I am less than excited to say that the biggest post-"big update" flaw, that is, the game won't start in fullscreen for just about anyone, is still plaguing the game. You can, of course, run it in borderless window mode, but you shouldn't ♥♥♥♥ing have to.Update 2: I've long since lost count of the months, and I've long since given up hope of actually getting to play the new DLC, because the game STILL won't open in fullscreen. This hasn't stopped them from releasing more and more DLC, of course.Bottom line: I give up. The game doesn't work, and it never will work. It's sad, because I really want to love this game. Mechanically, it's one of the best games I've ever played. Graphically, it's more than beautiful, it's stunning. And the story? Apart from the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t "reveal" of the Arkham Knight's "secret" identity(Yes, you really did guess it right the first time you saw him), it's easily among the best comic book adaptations I've ever seen in any media. Even the AK's "reveal" is excused by his incredible motivation, and his stunning backstory.But you won't get the chance to experience it, even if you do buy it.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												This game is broken.  Even after a few patches, the game still runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥  But having beaten this on a PS4 copy, which I borrowed, I can say the game isn't really worth your time even if it was fixed.  Even if you can play the game with your $10,000 PC you won't find much fun in cruising in the Batmobile for 10 plus hours of a 15 hour game.  The best part about the Arkham games was the combat, but with the Batmobile, forget about ever fighting anyone.  Instead if you aren't made to drive through an obstacle course, you have to shoot endless waves of tanks.  If you spend some time out in the streets fighting thugs you will be disappointed everytime they run away cause the Batmobile gets close.  I spent a lot of time running down empty tunnels before arriving at a dead end.  To get through I needed the Batmobile, but the Batmobile wouldn't just appear because I suppose there was a puzzle I needed to solve about 10 minutes the other way, but I could just easily grapple over whatever contraption they had "designed".This game literally takes the best part of the entire series and makes it the fourth thing you do. TLDR; Too much Batmobile.  Very little combat.  One, or two predator sequences.  Good story, but a chore to get through.  The challenge maps are the core Arkham experience, but without the story there really was no point in doing them.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Despite having apparently brought in Rocksteady to work their magic, all the patch notes are basically "added support for new DLC". It's never gonna be fixed.As for the game itself, the campaign is a pretty meaty one that more often than not has 3-5 side missions also vying for your attention at the same time. I thought the story was quite solid overall (with a couple really stupid moments and I called the two biggest twists LONG before they played out), and I think the combat's gotten a bit easier, for better or for worse. The biggest complaints I have start to set in after beating the game and going for 100%: despite that I had a lot of fun with the Batmobile, the game is horribly overreliant on it yet doesn't use it to its full potential (I'm pretty sure you use the winch all of ONE time to scale a building). Almost all the boss battles are overwrought Batmobile combat sequences, some are outright carbon copies of one another, and some aren't boss battles at all.And then if you want to see the true ending you need to get 100%, which gets tiring very quickly. Do all the ground-based outposts, do all the highrise outposts, take out all the flying drones, foil the bank robberies, rescue the firemen, and face a few hundred waves of drone tanks in the Batmobile to defuse all the landmines. Chasing down the APCs and Firefly were by far the most entertaining parts because they were actually somewhat challenging. 32 hours in, and NOW I can start worrying about all 340 of the Riddler's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trinkets.Despite all my complaints, the campaign holds its own quite well and is a pretty satisfying conclusion to the series; the shortcomings mostly present themselves in the side missions and postgame. Don't worry yourself over the Harley Quinn DLC, though -- it lasts all of 15 minutes and is barely worth the time spent on it.

number of helpful: 68 of 122 people (56%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Batman: Arkham KnightHaving owned this game for about a year I can tell you I am supremely disappointed by this title and Rocksteady. I have waited until July 2016 to release my opinion on this game. Batman: Arkham Knight isn't a bad game per se, it just falls short in some crucial spots like game performance, which has impacted my review.Positives:+ Nice graphics, good lighting and rain effects.+ The concept of combat remains solid, with lots of different attacks. It's fun, albeit difficult to combo.+ Lots of unique gadgets to use, some that make a return from previous iterations of Batman and others are entirely new.+Very intriguing characters and a great story.+ Riddler trophies and mini puzzles are quite enjoyable.Negatives:- This point is entirely dedicated to the batmobile which is over-used throughout the game, becoming extremely tedious. Endless drone, cobra and APC hunting in side quests with extra tanks thrown in during the main story, make batmobile involvement beyond excessive.- Combat hotkeys are badly implemented into the game and they are unnecessarily complex...There's a crouch toggle and then a 'hold down' crouch button which makes no sense.To hide in grates I need to use the "hold down' crouch + middle mouse, but I never use 'hold down' crouch usually, since it's outdated and pointless with a toggle crouch. So I'm basically using one key for a very particular action. The game is not streamlined at all. It's the same story for combos in fights. I don't use WASD for movement, I changed this to the arrow keys - but I still need to press the 1,2,3,4 keys to execute combos, which are half way across the keyboard. - Big technical issues at launch, which I let slide as I waited for patches to correct the problems. 6 months passed and the game still didn't run efficiently. With a Nvidia Geforce GTX 970, 8 GB of RAM and an i7 CPU, I expect Batman: Arkham Knight to work smoothly on a relatively high setting, but minor and severe FPS drops occur during batmobile pursuits and in certain areas of the game world to this day. This is a killer for the experience and very irritating.Overall score: 7/10 Disclaimer: I've scored this game 7 because the content is fantastic, it really is. It'd be a 9/10 if it simply worked. But it doesn't, so it takes a hard hit of 2 points. It's still playable, but it should be better than what it is performance wise.

number of helpful: 18 of 28 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												The Batman series has taken me along for the ride. I should probably explain upfront the elephant in the room; the thing that everyone needs to know and yet somehow no one seems to be talking about.In between Arkham City and Arkham Knight, the game was handed to an Ipad Factory developer and Warner Bros.-owned Warner Montreal. Warner Montreal has never made a blockbuster to save their life, so basically what that team did was copy Arkham City almost exactly, and try to bring back a few old faces from the Batman comic. They failed spectacularly. Arkham Origins was a complete flop.     The reason for this decision was simple. Rocksteady is a great developer, and Warner Inc is greedy. Rocksteady said, after Arkham City: "We're not really happy with our engine. You need to give us a few years to improve our code." Not able to compel Rocksteady into action, they redeployed Rocksteady's secondary assets to Montreal. The problem with this is it stymied development of Arkham Knight, causing the game's PC release to be glitchy and unfinished when it finally arrived. TLDR: A lot of these negative reviews reflect poorly on the publisher, not on the game. Arkham Knight is the natural progression of the Arkham series. If you haven't played the other games, you won't understand the story of this one. If I wasn't a Batman fan, I would probably be confused with the time skip even after playing the previous games. It was rather jarring after seeing Oracle in a supporting role in City, and then being bumped up to a major recurring character in Knight. A lot of the story was left out and I think it might have been more evocative to see what happened with the supporting cast. Oh well. Functionally, I like this game. It feels very very smooth. When you call the batmobile, it's like the game intelligently decides how to cinematically drop Batman's model into the cockpit. If you're in the air, the car will drive beneath you and try to land you seamlessly in your seat. On the ground? The car will drive past you and the Batman model will take a quick hop in the air. Want to get out quickly? The model will eject and the car will drift to a halt. It's very well done. A lot of effort went into asthetics. Combat is pretty nice. Improvements were made on the counter system. Now trying to fit your strikes in with blocks isn't such a big deal.  I was disappointed with a lack of innovative level up incentives. The ability to use one specific gadet while flying costs 4 tech points? Also, some of the upgrades didn't unlock in normal mode until you were way past used to dealing with certain annoying enemies. All of the gripes I have with Knight are with production choices. Scarecrow's voice actor ISN'T SCARY. He sounds too much like Hugo strange. Hearing his voiceovers as I'm driving around makes me want to yawn. Jonathan Crane is supposed to be a spindly little doctor with a sadistic streak. Where is that character? Production turned him into a generic-o-matic villain. The character is flat and not fun. On the flip side, there is a certain surprise actor who does an amazing job, as always, and the production team did a great job of standing him up. I wish they had spent a little more time on Scarecrow.Where is Jervish Tetch? The mad hatter is my favorite villain. All I get is a little sidenote in the evidence locker? shame. All in all? 8/10. It's a great game. It certainly has my vote for GotY

number of helpful: 18 of 28 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												So I liked all the Arkham games, including this one. In terms of gameplay, this is not a great departure from the last three games. You are Batman and you alternate between jumping from rooftop to rooftop beating up random dudes and then having fisticuffs with crowds of jerks. Like Arkham City and Origins, it's still an open world sandbox game wherein Batman fights to protect a city that seems to be populated exclusively with dudes who are lining up to rob a bank or knock over a jewelry store. Seriously, besides one building of cops, a couple of firefighters and Batman's assorted sidekicks, the entire city is just a pack of dip♥♥♥♥♥. It makes you sort of wonder why saving it is even worth it in the first place. Anyhow, that aside, the main innovation is you have the Batmobile, which is a tank thingie that's fun enough to use. Nothing groundbreaking, but it's not like the Batmobile segments aren't fun or whatnot. The story meanwhile is pretty strong, although due to the comic book origins of the series it pulls a lot of punches. I think this is supposed to be the last of the Arkham games, so you'd think that the creators would be more willing to kill characters. I mean, it's not like if you kill them in this game they're deleted from the comic book forever guys. But in spite of that, there are some incredibly good scenes and I was very interested from start to finish. Some plot twists are  presented a bit too obviously (the identity of the Arkham Knight is painfully obvious for about three hours), but most of it  still comes together pretty solidly. Until you get to the ending. Or well, I should say "Until you see what the ending involves". Because in order to actually see what happens at the end you've got to collect every single mother♥♥♥♥ing Riddler trophy. All 250 or so of them. I don't understand Rocksteady's obsession with those ♥♥♥♥ing things. Is it just a petulant idea that if you go through all this trouble making a big sandbox city that you ought to put♥♥♥♥♥♥around to make sure the player goes around appreciating all of it? Ugh.I ended up watching the ending on Youtube. It was alright. But the fact that the game locked it behind tedious collection quests is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Still, beyond that it's a good game. I'll probably play some of the DLC.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I've played the other batman games on their release dates and it was no where near as horrifying as this. Thank God for Steam refunds. I will be asking for my money back. Now before you rip into me yes I played a little bit and only a little bit and no I do not think this is... this is not Rocksteady. Seriously wtf happened? So before you rip on me let me tell you why I will be doing this and why you should not buy this game! I apologize ahead of time for my language and a lot of it being beeped by Steam filter but I am extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ here.Anyways I booted up the game got really excited! Then I went to the graphics options and... what? This is the most bare bones options I have ever seen. I mean sure you got the special effects for Nvidia but... no changes in AA? No motion blur off? No Triple Vertical Sync?! Yikes... I had a little expectations but this was way way below them. I mean really low.Moving on to the game. Ok so I start it up voice acting sounds odd... on Jim Gordan. Is that just effects? Whatever. Music and rest of the voices are awesome. Visuals HOLY ♥♥♥♥! THIS IS AMAZING Oh whats this? Locked at 30 FPS??? Ah it's just a cut scene it'll fix itself after. Get to the cop scene "Uhhh.... it's still 30 FPS...." that right there made my heart sink. Jesus I was disappointed. Holy crap 60 dollars down the drain I was thinking at this point. I kept hoping for better. I said "No this is Rocksteady... they have never disappointed."♥♥♥♥ was I wrong. Holy ♥♥♥♥ was I ever ♥♥♥♥ing wrong. What the ♥♥♥♥ did I purchase here? This is not ♥♥♥♥ing Rocksteady quality. I glided over to Jim Gordon in what seemed to be... erratic FPS from 30 to 10 to 30 again to 35 (??? how? it's capped at 30.) then it goes to 30 again. I'm over here gritting my teeth saying what the ♥♥♥♥... over and over. This makes me start to think WB Games Montreal had their hands in this! Ok I land and start talking to Gordon. This is the point where I threw my headphones down. My 250 dollar audio techa headphones to the ground... and said "NO ♥♥♥♥ THIS ♥♥♥♥! NO! ♥♥♥♥ NO!" Gordon's voice sounds like it was recorded in a ♥♥♥♥ing shoe box or by some amateur! WHAT?! NO WAY! NO WAY IN HELL! I am an audiophile and I noticed this ♥♥♥♥ quick comparing Batman's voice and Gordon's voice! LORD! THIS GAME IS NOT WORTH 20 DOLLARS! ♥♥♥♥! THE STEAM SUMMER SALE IS OVER AND NOW I HAVE THIS 60 DOLLAR CREDIT FOR NOTHING?! ARGH!Take this from a huge PC Gamer / Audiophile. I am not that picky. I played games like Hyperdimension Neptunia. That game is not exactly what you call PC optimized but they tried and it's a pretty good job. The visuals are not fantastic either. I expect that though from a small publisher trying to do a big game like that with a lot of Japanese voice acting and a low fan base in America. My point is I wouldn't have these expectations if it was coming from a company with little money. A company like WB who publishes a game like Shadow of Mordor then publishes this? HAH! NO! THIS IS NOT WORTH ANYMORE THAN 20 DOLLARS OR LESS! THIS IS CRAP!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												Alright so after waiting for 4 months for this game to be fixed I finally gave up since Rocksteady failed to fix it and it seems like there's not gonna be any more further patches (at least I haven't heard of any) I decided to finally get my hands on the final chapter of one of my favorite videogame series of all time. This review is 100% spoiler-free.Before we get to the review itself I gotta say what has already been said by thousands of people: this is unforgivable how bad this pc port is. Yes my pc is far from top notch but it's definitely above average (i5 2500, gtx 960) and even if it's not capable of maxing this game out, it should at least let me play on medium settings without any problems but instead it dips down to 40ies and still freezes in 720p/all low/everything turned off, let alone 1080p medium that I've mentioned. This is unacceptable and there's nothing that can justify such attitude towards pc gamers and fans of batman arkham series. But in the end I feel like we should put all the bias and emotions aside and review the actual game, not the performance, so here it is:Visually batman arkham knight is stunning and lucky guys who could max it out had their opportunities to enjoy amazing graphics. The city is indeed huge but surprisingly it doesn't feel empty at all. There are bad guys hanging out around every corner, cars, drones, tanks, helicopters, AR challenges, 15 side missions, activities are all over the place, you won't get bored, take my word for it. Oh and have I mentioned the most controversial addition to the series? - The batmobile! I think you either hate it or love it to honest. Not gonna lie you will spend a lot of time in it and if you dislike it then most likely it will ruin your experience a little bit. I personally loved it and how smarly it is utilized in the game: you don't only use it as a transport or a weapon but also you use it to solve riddler challenges and campaign puzzles and it may sound simple but again trust me you better see how amazing it's implemented in the campaign. The batmobile of course looks cool, handles amazingly while driving and as a tank it's really fun to use as well. It's definitely something fresh and new and improves the gameplay which has already been great since... forever. Speaking of the gameplay: it's as good as it gets, better than ever before. Batman's movement during combats and in predator rooms is so refined, so slick and smooth that I doubt it can be put into words. In combat batman became even faster and more creative, he uses walls to get a momentum for his leg punch (which looks absolutely fantastic btw), and he uses environment to perform finishing moves. His enemies became stronger, they require more devices, awareness and strategy from a player - mashing one button is not gonna cut it. They've added medics that can revive knocked out thugs, ninjas who dodge your straight attacks and then magically try to stab you from behind when they're out of your sight and big dudes now have shields! Predator encounters which I personally didn't like as much as the combat became so good I wish there were more: now you don't need to be directly behind your enemy to get a silent takedown, you don't need to jump off the ledge or any surface if you're above the enemy to get that silent takedown either! And yes that sounds like a small thing but trust me it becomes a lot more convenient and less frustrating. Batman can now break through any glass to get a takedown from both above and below, he can also break through glass to get to the vantage point too, and grappling from the floor vents all the way up to the vantage point through the vent shaft is my absolute favorite thing to do in the predator rooms. Have I even mentioned this new FEAR TAKEDOWN that allows you to dive down into a group of enemies and eliminate up to 5 of them in a row even if they stand relatively far to each other? And I'm so overwhelmed by emotions while writing this review that I completely forgot to mention about your partners that help you fight bad guys. Fighting back to back with catwoman, robin and nightwing was a lot of fun and "duel team takedowns" were satifsying as hell!So far it seems like I'm talking about a game of the century here, right? So at this point I wanna move on to the story and that's where things start to get a little mixed up and where my first gripes with the game appear. The story itself is amazing, it's so well-written and interesting that it literally doesn't give you a second to catch a breath, it makes you wanna play from the beginning up until the very end. What's the problem then? This game is called "Arkham knight", he is the main villian along with the scarecrow and he had to be someone whose revelation would blow our minds out and that's where this game makes a pretty big misstep, because his identity becomes pretty obvious way before the actual revelation encounter and it takes away a lot of tension and interest. It's not something that completely ruins it, but this should've been done better and there's no denying it. Next thing I was very unsatisfied with was the boss battles... the absence of the boss battles to be precise. I mean yes there were some weak boss battles throughout the main campaing but they were nowhere near the level they should've been as for THE FINAL EPIC CONCLUSION OF A FIGHTING GAME. I was expecting a galore of very difficult bosses, but unfortunately it never happened. After all an amazing story that kept me excited somehow made it up for the lack of boss fights and a terrible main villain revelation. The ending. I had to think about it for a while because I had to analyze it myself and I came to the conclusion that it was very fitting, satisfying and done right. It's dramatic and badass at the same time and I felt like what happened - had to happen so bravo to Rocksteady for a proper finale to this epic series.So that basically brings me to the final verdict. Despite a few important shortcomings that could potentially ruin this game completely I still feel like the overall experience was outstanding, so I give Batman: Arkham Knight a 9/10.This could've easily been a game of the year, a game of the generation or even a game of the decade contender if it wasn't for the mentioned cons and an awful pc port which drove a lot of pc gamers insane.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Batman™: Arkham Knight brings the award-winning Arkham trilogy from Rocksteady Studios to its epic conclusion. Developed exclusively for New-Gen platforms, Batman: Arkham Knight introduces Rocksteady's uniquely designed version of the Batmobile. The highly anticipated addition of this legendary vehicle, combined with the acclaimed gameplay of the Arkham series, offers gamers the ultimate and complete Batman experience as they tear through the streets and soar across the skyline of the entirety of Gotham City. In this explosive finale, Batman faces the ultimate threat against the city that he is sworn to protect, as Scarecrow returns to unite the super criminals of Gotham and destroy the Batman forever.Product Features:“Be The Batman” – Live the complete Batman experience as the Dark Knight enters the concluding chapter of Rocksteady’s Arkham trilogy. Players will become The World’s Greatest Detective like never before with the introduction of the Batmobile and enhancements to signature features such as FreeFlow Combat, stealth, forensics and navigation. Introducing the Batmobile – The Batmobile is brought to life with a completely new and original design featuring a distinct visual appearance and a full range of on-board high-tech gadgetry. Designed to be fully drivable throughout the game world and capable of transformation from high speed pursuit mode to military grade battle mode, this legendary vehicle sits at the heart of the game’s design and allows players to tear through the streets at incredible speeds in pursuit of Gotham City’s most dangerous villains. This iconic vehicle also augments Batman’s abilities in every respect, from navigation and forensics to combat and puzzle solving creating a genuine and seamless sense of the union of man and machine. The Epic Conclusion to Rocksteady’s Arkham Trilogy – Batman: Arkham Knight brings all-out war to Gotham City. The hit-and-run skirmishes of Batman: Arkham Asylum, which escalated into the devastating conspiracy against the inmates in Batman: Arkham City, culminates in the ultimate showdown for the future of Gotham. At the mercy of Scarecrow, the fate of the city hangs in the balance as he is joined by the Arkham Knight, a completely new and original character in the Batman universe, as well as a huge roster of other infamous villains including Harley Quinn, The Penguin, Two-Face and the Riddler. Explore the entirety of Gotham City – For the first time, players have the opportunity to explore all of Gotham City in a completely open and free-roaming game world. More than five times that of Batman: Arkham City, Gotham City has been brought to life with the same level of intimate, hand-crafted attention to detail for which the Arkham games are known. Most Wanted Side Missions – Players can fully immerse themselves in the chaos that is erupting in the streets of Gotham. Encounters with high-profile criminal masterminds are guaranteed while also offering gamers the opportunity to focus on and takedown individual villains or pursue the core narrative path. New Combat and Gadget Features – Gamers have at their disposal more combat moves and high-tech gadgetry than ever before. The new ‘gadgets while gliding’ ability allows Batman to deploy gadgets such as batarangs, the grapnel gun or the line launcher mid-glide while Batman’s utility belt is once again upgraded to include all new gadgets that expand his range of forensic investigation, stealth incursion and combat skills.

												I can not begin to describe what an abysmal port this game was to PC. In its current state I simply can not recommend it to anyone and here is why:My system specsAMD-FX 9590 4.70 GHz 8 core processor16 GB Ram2 Nvidia 760 GTX video cardsMy computer should be eating the current Arkham Night recommended system requirements for breakfast yet I get CTD, hitching, LOWER FPS in SLI than I do in single card....this game is just a mess. In 2015 a game running on the 2004 Unreal Engine with these kinds of faults is absolutely unacceptable. DO NOT buy this game until Rocksteady Studios pushes a ptach to fix it and notable reviewers give it a once over.UPDATE: 02 September 2015 - Game still has not had a major patch pushed to fix all the launch issues. 2 months and change after launch they have had to oush a patch and we got a very minor updated to stability.Do yourself and everyone a favor. DO NOT purchase this game, and kick Rocksteady right in the balls aka wallet. They are not deserving of the profit they would make. Tons of DLC being developed and distributed on consoles instead of focusing on fixing the PC issues.UPDATE: 05 October 2015 - Upgraded video card to a 980Ti (not just for AK). A major patch was pushed last month which addressed some more commonly complained about issues like higher graphics settings, Antisotropic filtering levels, uncapping the FPS etc. The game runs better but still nowhere near where it should. SLI is still unsupported, and I even with my beast of a setup still get CTD every now and again. Hopefully by the end of the month Rocksteady will have all the major bugs ironed out. Once the game is finally patched to completion pick it up on a Game Key site. Don't buy it for $59.99

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												---------------------------------------------SPOİLERS----------------------------------------------This game has very bad sides. 1.BATMOBILE: Way too much Batmobile  especially ACE Chemicals mission. You have to use your friendly Batmobile to do EVERYTHING.2.DRONE TANKS: I wish we could destroy those drones without using the Batmobile.(I know we can do it with upgraded Disruptor but thats not what I meant, I mean with a EMP bomb or something)3.AK IDENTITY: Everyone knew that the Arkham Knight IS Jason Todd from the day that Arkham Knight  character announced.He should be Eli Strange, Prometheus or Anarky. Especially Eli Strange(come to finish his father job and get revenge from Batman), that would be AMAZING. And they could make an "Under The Red Hood" kinda DLC now that the Jason is not AK(as in my wish).  4.AK HQ: Based on AK name, I was expecting an secret base on Arkham Island or Arkham City but Arkham Knight HQ is an abandoned shopping mall. seriously what the hell?! 5.PLAYABLE CHARACTER LAZINESS: They gave Azrael the same moves as Batman and they got a reason because "Azrael has watched and learned Batman's technique to become his succesor" no because they are lazy as hell.They removed moves and gadgets from every character . Especially gadgets, Catwoman has no Thief Vision.6.AR CHALLANGES: Those stupid AR Challanges are NOT challange maps. 7.COMBAT EXPERTS: I was expecting more from Combat Experts. They have only one unique attack where they jump onto a wall or nearby ally and then leap to strike batman. expect from that they are Ninjalike enemies. I couldn't see and Hand-to-Hand attack like we see in the ACE Chemicals Infiltration Trailer.8. MILITIA EQUIPMENT: Guys with Jammer Pack was really making game harder but we get to see them one or two times maybe., and the guys with Thermal Imaging Headsets is no longer here. Seriously, two of Batman's strongest tactics is hiding at the vantage points and escape using smoke, how AK never tought that?9.LEVEL DESINGS: I want to have two ways of getting into certain places. One way is batmobile way, the  Second one is traditional. Not only it gives me a choice but also makes me wanna replay the game.10.SIDE MISSIONS:  Hush side mission was very dissapointing. Back at AC Hush side mission was  A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. Firefly side mission was bad too, just 3 batmobile chases. Back at AO Firefly boss was unique and very brilliant. 11.CHARACTER DESINGS:Some character desings were same as Origins (black mask, deathstroke, firefly(nearly)). 12. CHALLANGE MAPS: .They are releasing challange maps as DLC's that's annoying. 13.DLC: DLC's (expect Batgirl) like 10 minute challange map campaings and they didn't  take care of their stories. 14.RIDDLER : They were "succint" back at AC there was 440 piece and most of them was very easy.I think they sould made race tracks like conundrum in AC. I mean like when you solve 40 of them you unlock first race track, when you solve 80 of them you unlock second race track, that would be harder. After doing race tracks you just don't want  to collect all of riddler throphies for a stupid robot battle. 15.COMBAT: Combat has no such big changes. I like "pick up enemy, critical beatdown, batclaw super stun, charged super stun, aerial jugle" moves but like I said there was no such big changes. 16.TAKEDOWNS: Fear takedown was good but made game easier. Environmental takedowns was pretty good.17.EVIDENCE SCANNER:  Evidence scanner that when we were using to save Barbara Gordon was same as the AO's evidence scanner. (I am NOT talking about the one we  used at "perfect crime" that is deep tissue scanner) And we get to use it only once. 18.GADGETS: I think the REC Gun and Freeza Grenades lost their usage. explosive gel's Quick-Fire usage is the as Origin's detanator. A predator gadget known as Sonic Batarang is not here anymore! We only use Line Launcher for 2 or 3 times. Remoto Hacking Device and Disruptor was pretty good.19.BOSS FIGHTS: There was no Boss Fights just Batmobile tank battles. I waited for an legendary boss fight that we will do with Deathstroke and AK. They were just tank battles. 20.DIALOGUES AND ENDİNG: Back at AC we were hearing pretty good and funny dialogues. Game has lost this feature. Yes we are hearing dialogues in AK but they are NOT good.atmosphere is not a AC or AA. I love the parts that Joker talking with Batman(in Bat's brain). This really is the only pretty good thing that shows us the game's psycholocigal side. I finished all of the Arkham Games and I was  a fan of Batman comics before all 4 games release I can certainly say this game is the  worst portrait of Batman in last 40 years. I mean look at the ending. The man who knows 127 martial arts, crime fighter for 10 years, capable of take out 5 gunned man less than 5 seconds, worlds greatest detective, has genius level intelligence go surrender without a plan. Gordon is capable police officer. come on! He is only one gunned. No bombs, no guards, no tanks. He isn't even holds that gun at hand or point that gun to no-one's head. just get behind him Gordon and strike. They all act like (even Batman himself) they want Batman  unmasked and gassed.21. STORY HOLES:  From the very first trailer of Arkham Knight thought was all of Batman's villians  get together  to destroy Batman once and for all. But they all do different things. Two-Face has attacked the banks . Harley tried to save her ''Joker''s. We only saw Penguin suplying guns to The Arkham Knight. Others didn't helped Scarecrow or each other. Another thought is Scarecow don't want to kill Batman, he wants to destroy his soul. Then why did he send 45-60 tanks to Batman at some points of the Game  . At the GCPD assault 62 tanks came to destroy us(they were really wanted to kill Batman. If Scarecrow  don't want to kill then shouldn't be Scarecrow Game Over Scenes. They are like ''I didn't want to dead but oh well, I think I will say something). If that tanks weren't just drones, If they were manned tanks, As everyone knew, Batman couldn't do anything. And there is time problems.  Scarecrow could attack GCPD when Batman at ACE Chemicals or at the Panessa Studios taking on Harley. When Batman busy I mean.  But no he waited Batman to come GCPD.  And we come the biggest hole. Scarecrow has captured Batman with using Robin and Gordon but why didn't he used Barbara to capture Batman I mean the same way he did to Robin and Jim. You know before Cloudburst exploded. He can just capture Batman and reveal his name then exlode cloudburst. this would happen before jason's arrival so Jason could kill Batman(instead of saving him) I know that Scarecrow wants to destroy Batman's soul. He can do it by killing Barbara in front of Batman's eyes  and trapping Gotham under  fear .Batman couldn't do anything, but watching his friends and Gotham die. This would destroy Batman. And no one could save Batman because his friends can't even save themselves  Nightwing kidnapped by Penguin, Barbara Robin and Gordon kidnapped by Scarecrow, Jason kidnapped and Tortured by Joker, Catwoman captured by Two-Face and Riddler, even Batman himself got kidnapped by Harley. in Arkham Series they made Bat-Family (expect Batman) weak especially Nightwing.Even Harley was able to defeat Nightwing. This is very annoying.  Another thing is why didn't AK place cobra tanks at main gates of ACE Chemicals. Batman couldn't even enter the facility( Oh well, maybe Batman could enter the facility but without his Batmobile he couldn't do anything. With all this things, I can say story is NOT well-considered.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												i7 4770k, 290x, 8gig ram for reference. No real issues running any other major AAA titles released this year.I'm roughly 40% completion of the game, 21 hours of play. I just can't justify putting anymore time into this game until the performance issues are truly fixed. Until then, I can comfortably say this is one of the absolute worst PC ports I've ever played, and can in no way recommend anybody pay any amount of money for this game on PC.Before the most recent patch on the 28th of October, I was able to run the game on medium settings around 30fps. Indoors I would rarely have framerate issues, but outside in the city it was miserable with lock ups, freezes and dropping to 5-10fps for 10s at a time, most prominently while driving the Batmobile.After the patch, I get 40-60 in the city but the stuttering happens much more often. The game no longer completely locks up on me, but fluctuations from ~50fps to ~20 make the game seem even worse. The Batmobile is completely useless, it's like watching a movie from the 1920s. TL;DR: DO NOT BUY. DO NOT SUPPORT THE SALE OF THIS GAME ON PC. IF YOU BUY THIS GAME, GOOD CHANCE IT WILL RUN LIKE♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												I Can't Arkham White Knight This One.I have benchmarked this game on three different graphics cards and both consoles for more than 30 hours.  I've recorded and published at least 5-6 hours of video.  This game does not run well, period.A lot of people will say that it "plays fine for them", but then a lot of people are happy with 30fps.  Heck, a lot of people are happy with 30fps and Vsync off, meaning they are happy to play with screen tearing and a low, unstable frame rate.  I am not one of those people.  I didn't stray from console gaming to play games that perform poorly.  And this game performs poorly.Fact:  The PC port lacks graphical features the PS4 has.Fact:  The game shipped with a 30fps cap.People are claiming they can get the game to run at "medium" settings.  Folks, the game doesn't have "medium" settings.  It has "low" and "normal" for textures.  No "high".  No "ultra".  No "very high".  There is no "medium settings" preset for them to choose, and only three of the options settings even offers a "medium".  The others only have TWO choices, each.Missing settings:Ambient OcclusionChoise of AntiAliasingAnisotropic FilteringDepth of FieldMotion BlurFrame Rate selectionThose are things that are completely missing.  What's left is a couple of "on/off" toggles and two or three choices that feature a "high, medium, and low".People who claim to play the game on "medium" are just making up the definition of what "medium" means.I tell you this to save you the frustration of learning the hard way.The game has more features, and in SOME ways, looks better on PS4, but the PS4 version isn't that great, either.  Overall, it feels a little muddy, the motion blur on PS4 is worse, and the frame rate seems even lower over there.  So don't believe the whole "the PS4 version is so great" spiel.  The people who are saying that are basing it on the fact that the PS4 version does have some better looking textures and more of the promised Nvidia GameWorks effects.  (which sounds weird, I know)The performance of this game is distractingly bad, but it is not unplayable.  Heck, there were a couple moments where I treated it like a console game and almost had fun, despite its broken feeling.  This game is not terribly brilliant, right now, on any platform; and I say that as someone who has spent a good deal of time testing it on all three.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												The primary issue is, obviously, the terrible optimization. Even after the patches, the game was unplayable on my system and required a 270 Euros upgrade.The other issues come from a strictly game design standpoint. There is too much reliance on the Batmobile. Over half of the game is wasted on either shooting tank drones or solving puzzles with the Batmobile. Free-Flow and Predator not only have taken a backseat, they also suffer on their own. Free flow breaks combos far more often than in City (though considerably less than in Origins) and the sheer variety of enemy types can turn combat into a cluster♥♥♥♥. Predator mode fares somewhat better, but the uninspired level design undercuts the flow of constant movement that made Predator work in previous installments.If the draw for you is the fully-featured Gotham City, you'll be disappointed at how little there is to do in it. Outside of "liberating" the various areas (via taking down enemy outposts), it's a huge sandbox filled with criminals and empty boxes. As for the story, it's heavily derivative of Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, the twists are woefully predictable and the characters are unsympathetic and internally inconsistent with the rest of the series.If you enjoyed the previous games, you may want to have a look at this one eventually (during a sale, the Season Pass is a must as it offers the only classic Batman bits in this product), but otherwise steer clear.5/10 would trade my driving license for a bat-bong.

I have never heard of any game with that requirement. In conclusion the gameplay itself is great but due to the framerate problems I am having I wouldnt recommend this game at all. Im going to say either wait until things are fixed or just dont buy it at all.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Awful PC port, with not only a poor implementation but also a sloppy interface that shows a lack of interest for the PC version alltogether:- Lack of a lot of options in the menus, only generic ones being available, which is unacceptable for a 2015 PC game;- Mouse Sensitivity is set to 30 (!!!) by default and there is NO OPTION to alter it in any of the game menus;- Motion Blur is HORRIBLE and there is no option to disable it in any of the game menus; additionally, if you do what any PC gamer does and go to the .ini files to force disable it, the game crashes, so no way to get rid of a very bad looking and poorly implemented effect;- There are VERY frequest FPS drops, which can easily be seen in the benchmark too even when you get a high average framerate; these break immersion continuously and make it impossible to enjoy the game experience;- Problems with resolution settings, when first booting the game it was set to a low resolution; changing it increased the size of the game inside a window which remained the same size! (like what the hell man?!? I could only see the top left quarter of the image now); this required a restart of the game to work.Sadly, due to issues like the above, you can't really enjoy and review the actual game, so I hope they have some serious patching skills, otherwise this game will be an undeserved skidmark on what was so far a very cool series.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I've wanted so much to actually enjoy Rocksteady's sendoff to the Arkham series, but there isn't much love waiting for anyone that is purchasing this.  You might hear the odd exceptions where people have performance that is just nominal, but I get massive RAM usage and massive VRAM usage while playing a game with a framerate cap of 30fps by default.  That isn't just absurd, that's absolutely unacceptable.  This comes after finding out the team assigned to port this game were given 8 weeks total.  8 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ weeks isn't time to do anything of this scope, and it is truly telling of just how little care or concern is given to consumers that just happen to game on a PC.  So while this game might be the true end of a series that has had hype and acclaim since its 2009 debut, it isn't something I'd recommend at this point.It is an honest shame, but our money means just as much as someone on PS4 or Xbone, so I don't really understand why it is we should get a subpar product for the same price.Edit:  It seems that our dollar means just as much as any other dollar, seeing as how WB has revoked sales of the game until it is up to spec.  Unprecedented given the size and marketing behind this particular production, but still a fantastic sign that everyone's displeasure is being recognized.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Knight's gameplay is wonderful, and the combat and moves list has been greatly improved.  Batman's moves list is filled with so many great new additions which include new variations of old moves and animations. In addition, the Batmobile is nothing short of brilliance.  Despite these good marks, Arkham Knight is filled with technical issues that will most likely cause you to stop playing, and make you wait for the "upcoming" patch. As others have echoed, the Batmobile is incredibly fun to use.  The controls are slick, and nearly perfect.  You feel this sense of empowerment when you jump into the batmobile.  And like any other sandbox type of games, you may spend a considerable amount of time riding in the batmobile to travel from one place to another.  Your mileage may vary. From another perspective, this may become another Gearbox/SEGA launch fiasco.http://www.kitguru.net/gaming/development/matthew-wilson/arkham-knight-pc-port-was-outsourced-to-a-console-studio/To summarize the article:Batman Arkham Knight was outsourced to a studio called Iron Galaxy.  This studio has been known to be the "radio shack" of studios that does porting to PC.  This also explains why PC reviews did not go up before launch.  They knew there were major issues with the game, yet they pushed it out in this state anyway.This is a bad sign.  If Warner Bros doesn't order Iron Galaxy to patch the game, we may never see a patch that may remedy most of the issues.  And, considering Iron Galaxy PC porting team consists of only 12 people, I don't have much hope.  Technical hiccups that you should know about:Right off the bat, Batman Arkham Knight is locked at 30fps.  You can unlock it by going into the ini file in Batman AK steam folder - BMgame -> BMengine and make the changes you want.  Make sure that you go into BMSystemSettings and change the maxframerate to match the maxframerate in BMengine file.Okay, cool, the game can now run at 60fps.  Half the time it may run at 50-60fps.  As soon as you perform a bat dive, or propel Batman up to the nearest building, the performance will dip into what I would call "crawl" stage.  Sometimes it will hover around 15-20fps.  Sometimes, less.  Since you are performing so many actions in this game, you will be spending most of your time going through these framerate issues. There are many texture pop-ups that take several seconds to minutes to load.  This seems to be very uncharacteristic for the Unreal Engine. There were times when the textures did not pop up until after a scene was done.  It seems to be a glaring issue that occurs throughout many parts of the game.The transition from Steam overlay to Steam is bugged.  You can take screenshots in game, and later upload them, but they do not show up on the "Activity" page.  In addition, my review of Arkham Knight does not show up in my review page section.  User reviews are also not showing up on the activity page.Lastly, the post-processing effect graphics setting needs to be disabled manually in the configuration file, and some effects cannot be turned off at all.  I believe that Rocksteady used these filters for art style purposes. There are really low-based textures, and heavy use of ugly filters.  If you try to disable the motion blur, distortion, and/or depth of field in the ini file, it may crash your game.  So far, disabling post-processing motion blur seems to be the only form of post-processing effect in the ini file that doesn't crash the game. You are welcome to try.  Also, there is a very limited graphics option menu.  Very limited.  If you were wondering, and needed to compare PC rigs.  My specs:i5-2500K  (4.5GHz)GTX 970 SC ACX 2.08GB of RAMBatman: Arkham Knight Game Ready drivers (old drivers were cleaned using Driver Fusion, and I followed it up with a manual clean - cleaning the registry and folders)It is a fairly decent gaming PC.  Right now, Arkham Knight just isn't in the state that it needs to be in, and fingers crossed for a big update.  I don't think a small update will help matters.Final thoughts:Again, Batman: Arkham Knight features great gameplay with the same old Rocksteady formula.  There seems to be a really good game underneath all the performance issues, limited graphics options, and forced visual effects like post-processing. I will definitely change my review to a recommended review if Iron Galaxy Studios and Warner Bros make the necessary fixes that this game needs badly.  I can't imagine a studio would want to waste a great game to technical issues that could be patched.  It is feasible, and doable.  After all, Rocksteady did work extremely hard on Arkham Knight, but it is a shame that Warner Bros outsourced the PC port job to a third-party company with very little experience and competency.Not recommended due to major performance issues in current state.Note:  Will update and/or change the review if a patch fixes major issues.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												UPDATE: I was 96% through the game and it glitched me through the floor so now I can't finish the game. Yay!Alright so I've been play this game for a few hours and saw both good and bad things in this game. Unfortunately as most of you know there is one issue that completely ruins the game and it's the horrible optimization. But I'll get to that later. First let's talk about the good:-The combat feels great especially with fear takedowns to take out multiple enemies like a badass-Gotham City is massive and gorgeous to look at.-The Batmobile, while can be clunky at times, is a fast way to get around Gotham-The character design looks awesome.Now onto the bad which really overshadows the good:-Optimization (I'll rant more about that later)-I feel like the Batmobile feature is a little too forced onto the player. Almost all of the Riddler challenges are focused on the Batmobile itself-I can't tell if it's just me going crazy or if they made the gliding horribly slow. I guess in order to make the player use the Batmobile more they made gliding more sluggish. It might just be the dropping framerate.-30 FPS cap. That is a sin. But it doesn't matter since you will be dropping to 6 frames constantly.-The lack of effects options. On top of being poorly optimized the game has constant motion blur and particle effects that go nonstop. This causes the game to run worse whenever you're outside in the rain.About the optimization:Never have I seen a game so badly ported over to PC. I have a GeForce GTX 960 and at the very least I should be able to maintain a solid framerate. Even with everything set to the lowest settings, the framerate is all over the place. This is especially noticable whenever driving the Batmobile or gliding in the rain. The optimization completely ruins the game and keeps you from wanting to explore the city. You just want to get from point A to point B to hopefully get to an area where the game can run normally again. It's really sad for huge fans of the series like myself who wanted to enjoy the final game in the trilogy. Unfotunately the optimization ruins the game completely. I would recommend getting this game on console or wait until Rocksteady makes a fix. Until then stay away and save your money for something else.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												WHATEVER YOU DO, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC.So I just played the game at midnight and wow....it's horrible on PC. It is full of stuttering issues, sound issues, and crashes constantly. If you are going to pick up the game, get it on PS4 or Xbox One.The game is capped at 30p, although, you can get rid of this in an INI file. HOWEVER, the framerate is still horrible in a lot of places and if you remove this cap, a lot of textures will take a very long time to load and will look downright archaic. When you get into the batmobile and move around the city, you'll be going down into the 10s when it comes to framerate. Sure, the GameWorks effects look BEAUTIFUL but the game plays like garbage.UPDATE: I've recently discovered that a lot of effects in the console versions (such as ambient occlusion) are completely missing from the PC port.UPDATE 2: Warner Bros. has come forward and said they are looking into the issue and, in the meantime, are taking the game out of sale.My rig:FX-8350GTX 970 4GB8GB of RAMPlayed at 1080p then 900p to see if maybe it was because my machine wasn't good enough. No, it's the game that isn't good enough.Sorry guys :c I wanted to play this game so bad too, but it's just frustrating..

												Quite possibly the biggest disappointment in my lifetime (25yrs), not only was the game completely broke on release, the game has been "re-released" with the most shocking display of disregard for the customer.Onto the actual review of the game.Graphics = Excellent, the graphics give the game atmosphere and really give the impression of being in Gotham.Gameplay = Good, the melee combat system has been refined and makes every punch and kick have a real impact. The worst part of the game is the driving combat (really anything involving the batmobile is terrible)The best part of what make Rocksteady's game arguably was the sneaking and that seems to have been scaled back and not expanded on like the rest of the game.Overall A mediocre cash-in AAA game from Warner-Bros that clearly could have done with another 6-12 months of development.I will never buy another game from Warner Bros and will hope that Rocksteady can learn from this and never repeat it.4/10 MEDIOCRE sequel, killed in my opinion by the release meltdown
