content:
Posted: April 22
												There are two things it does right: combat improvements and the narrative presentation. There are just so many things at your disposal when it comes to free-flow combat, and yes, odd stuff happens still, but the tight rhythmic gameplay is just better with enemy variety as well as gadgets you can use during the combat (plus, some levels have you fight along side your sidekicks and these sections are really sweet). It balances out the flow of the combat, intensity as well as strategy. As for the narrative presentation, Arkham series has always been a knock-out when it comes to fusing gameplay with cutscenes, and Arkham Knight does it best here.The problem is, the story itself is lackluster. The wholly unsatisfying ending aside, the main story fails to incorporate various characters and the world, and instead sidelines potentially very interesting villains away from the main story. Arkham Knight himself is an interesting character, yet, really, I don't think anyone who has read the comics (or like me who hasn't but knows some stuff from them) found it a revelation. Scarecrow's character seems to be a bit different, more like Hugo Strange with an obsession for fear gas. Not to mention that Riddler challenges are tied to the true ending to the game, they wasted Deathstroke on a stupid Batmobile section? And yes. Batmobile. Batmobile is made well. The control on that thing is marvelous. But there are way too many Batmobile sections. If they were varied or require methodical approach like some of on-foot sections, I wouldn't complain: except they aren't. Most of Batmobile sections are incredibly one dimensional. You attack all the drones almost exactly the same way, meaning you approach almost all Batmobile combat sections exactly the same way. Some of Batmobile puzzles are good, but seeing how most of them are associated with Riddler, you get tired of them.And that's what the game feels like: tiring. This is basically Arkham City with Batmobile. A lot of the level design is still the same (and they are still good), and that's not a bad thing seeing how Origin basically is like that and it's fun to play. But it has stupid needless stuff sprinkled throughout, plus the Batmobile. Playing all the filler stuff, I can't help but feel like I'm playing an Ubisoft open world game with better core gameplay mechanics. They even have bloody towers all over the place you have to tackle. Except I somehow found Syndicate worth getting 100%; this I just couldn't.Oh and if you don't have a PC with more RAM than 12GB, don't even bother playing it on PC. I have i7-6700HQ, GTX 1070 and 8GB RAM, and the game still stutters like crazy when moving fast through Gotham in Batmobile or flying.

number of helpful: 17 of 27 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												TL:DR I have to hand it to them, even with all the♥♥♥♥♥♥they got, they put in the work to fix it as much as possible. It actually runs now and while it is not perfect in terms of optimisation it has improved greatly.Pros:+PHOTO MODE: I love screenshots and Warner Bros games like to use this awesome mechanic now and its great. Every game should include a mode like this. Shooting incredible screenshots, showing off the details in the game is a great way to self promote your game now brb as i have hundreds to upload onto my steam account.+Fantastic Story: A great end to the Rocksteady trilogy with great characters and plot points. Batman has amazing development as the story progresses+Detailed and dense city: Arkham city was fantastic in recrating a criminal filled gotham but this game does it even better adding so much more detail+Combat: Freeflow combat is always fantastic and they improved on it even more, adding new ways to brutally break every bone in someones body but still be Batman+Stealth: Greater difficulty is added to the stealth with new enemy variants like someone who can detect and find out your position if you use Detective mode for too long, People with reflective camo who hide from detective mode. Enemies start to Batman proof the area if they suspect youre doing something, setting a thermal charge to set the whole grate system on fire if they catch you down there is very tense when you have to grappel up and out of the grate before the fire gets to youCons:-Arkham Knight wasnt really a big surprise: The writing done to reveal who the arkham knight was felt a bit lazy to me and shovelled in. *Spoilers ahead*  even if you werent clued in on who all the Robins were, Jason Todd is never really mentioned too much in any of the other games but gets a huge exposition slot about how he "died" in this game. Anybody who has seen a film or played a game with a twist before could have guessed it and i would have much preferred if the enemy was just Red Hood and not Red Hood with a bat mask on. -Batmobile Segments: the batmobile is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, it handles well and makes you feel like the batman... but the overdone, repetitive drone segments where all you do is click MMB to explode unmanned drones every 30 minutes in the story gets very old very fast-Optimisation is not perfect: My specs are fairly high (980 4GB, 16GB RAM, i7 4790k) and i still get some frame drops in the batmobile, i am on all high setting besides Gameworks Fog and Paper Debris. from what i have heard, frame issues are due to these gameworks settings but also 16GB ram or a SSD is reccomended for this game because it still has streaming issues so beware of that before you purchase however steam refunds are always there if performance is not satisfactory for you-DLC: i loved the extra chapters where you play as other characters because they included very neat dialogue or story progression and or minute details that i enjoyed (Harley Quinn's version of detective mode with all the crazy writing on the wall including things about MR J and such) but they were very short. i have yet to play A matter of family yet though and hear that has more content than those chapters. Suits and skins are kinda cool and you can use them without having to beat the game first, with the exception of some of the more elaborate batmobile skins because they are not fit to use the battlemode like the base batmobile.Overall on sale, this game is fantastic and a great end to the trilogy if you have a mid to high system to run it. Even without a sale it is at a reduced price due to the horrible launch and the wait that we have had to endure. Thank you steam for including a recent review section so people can also see that this game has improved greatly over time and is now worth the time that people who really wanted to put into this game but were turned off due to bad performance.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												I have been playing computer games since 197X.  It's safe to say, I am not easily impressed anymore. It takes a lot to get me excited about, well, anything really.Furthermore, what I learned well over a decade ago is NEVER. BUY. PRESALE. EVER.And as most of you are probably aware by now, the PC port of Batman: Arkham Knight is probably the ultimate current example of why you NEVER. BUY. PRESALE.  EVER.ALWAYS wait for reviews.Fortunately if you're like me, kept it on your Wishlist, checked back on the reviews from time to time, and you waited until all the bugs had been worked out before purchasing this game, then you know that Batman: Arkham Knight is also the ultimate current example of the Best Action Game Ever Made and also Why The PC Remains The Ultimate Gaming Platform. Remember, I'm OOFG (Original Old Fart Gamer) so I don't throw out words like 'Best' and 'Ultimate' easily.  But if you loved Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, then I can't see why you wouldn't pee your pants over this one.  It's amazing.  There aren't enough glowing superlatives to describe my joy playing this game on the PC.  I didn't purchase this game until September 2016, which means I waited a LONG time after the release date to give this game a chance.  Based on others' horrible early experiences, I am very glad I waited, but based on the sheer joy of playing this game the past several days, I am very glad I didn't wait forever.Have no fear, this game truly is the great extension to the Arkham City story, characters, world, and gameplay that you hoped it would be.  Just like Arkham City was a brilliant follow-up and expansion of the Arkham Asylum universe, Arkham Knight really does do the justice to Arkham City that we all waited so long for, and had our doubts about after the godawful Arkham Origins.And also have no fear about the PC port.  I just got a new Maingear rig with the Dell Curved 34" monitor and am running a GTX 1070 at 3440x1440.  Max settings.  Smooth as butter (58 fps avg, no hitching, although I always turn v-sync OFF).  While a system with lower specs may not be able to run this smoothly, it does indicate that Rocksteady has the port running the way they originally intended.  There are some games throughout history that represent a major leap forward and slightly older machines just can't do it justice, forcing PC gamers to begrudgingly upgrade just so they can truly enjoy that historic game.  Wing Commander was one of those games (gotta get VGA gfx now).  As was Wing Commander 2 (gotta get a CD-ROM now).  The original Tomb Raider (gotta get a 3D adapter now).  Half-Life 2, etc etc etc.  And yes, dare I say, Arkham Knight might just be worth dropping some coin on upgrades.  It does really depend on how much you enjoyed Asylum and City and how much you want another game like that but bigger & better.  Origins almost turned me off forever, but man I am glad I didn't give up on the series.  I would recommend buying the Premium version.  At $49.99 it is still $10 less than most A-list titles, but you get all of the DLC side missions and they really are the best of all the side missions so you'll be glad you have them.  They also tie up some loose ends from Arkham City, such as what happened to Hush.Some people don't like the Batmobile.  I don't know what's wrong with them.  They must really be looking for something to not like.TL:DR:  F.U.  BUY THE GAME (IF YOU'VE GOT THE REC SPECS)

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Arkham knight is my second favorite entry in the arkham series, just behind city, it features the epic conclusion to rocksteady's trilogy and some truly incredible story moments. The batmobile is an awesome vehicle, but it is overused like any great mechanic, the stealth for the batmobile in particular is what stands out as frustrating, but every other mechanic is perfected in this final installment. The fluidity of the combat, and the swiftness of the stealth. Batman has also never looked better, at launch the port was very incomplete, but now it runs quite well. Hopefully companies learn to put more effort in their pc ports, but only time will tell. At 30$ this game is a steal and I highly recommend it. TL; DRPros:+all of the gameplay+stellar voice acting+plethora of easter eggs for diehard fans+really detailed and beautiful world+updated graphics engine+improved port greatly since launch+replay value w/ side missions, riddler trophies, more challenges etc.Cons:-Overused batmobile at end of the story-batmobile stealth-lack of boss fights-occasional glitches Overall this is probably my favorite game of last year and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the previous entries in the arkham franchise especially if you want to see the conclusion of what happens after arkham city. Highly Recommended.9/10

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												In this review, I am going to avoid the hyperbole that seems to run rampant with many of the other reviews but I should make it clear that this review is for the game now that it has been largely patched up. When it was first launched, Arkham Knight was a hot mess with severe performance problems pretty much across the board. The problems were so bad that the game was pulled from steam for quite a long time. I suspect that a great many of the particularly bad reviews were written during this time so they should perhaps be looked at with some scrutiny nowadays.  As it stands right now, Arkham Knight runs very well on my system (AMD 8350 Black edition, EVGA GTX 970 SSC, and 8Gb of RAM, 1920x1080) with a very smooth framerate and good overall stability (have yet to experience a crash). There are times where the framerate drops a little bit but nothing that meaningfully impacts gameplay in any significant way. It is worth noting that my experiece with this title at launch was very different, I had a much smaller monitor back then and got significantly lower performance. Whatever patches they have applied since then have improved things greatly and pretty much fixed the game entirely.  Moving away from performance, lets talk about the gameplay. Arkham Knight is probably the most refined Arkham title in the series. The fighting feels smooth and with the subtle rhythm elements that were (sadly) not really present in Arkham Origins. There are some new gadgets that mix things up as well as new enemy types. It certainly feels like a Arkham game usually does but enough has been refined that it does not feel worn out or boring.  The Batmobile is a major addition and it does tend to get more time than it really should (especially the Riddler puzzles that involve it). You will find that you spend a lot more time in the drivers seat fighting tanks and driving on absurd Riddler race tracks than you really will want to. As far as the car itself goes. I like the design, it has a very Tumbler'esque vibe to it while still fitting the more comic book style Arkham setting.  Overall, while the car is cool, there is entirely too much of it in the game.  The Graphics are a pretty big improvement over other Arkham titles. When you crank up the settings, it looks very striking with excellent lighting effects and detailed textures. It still has that somewhat muddy look that other Arkham games have but it does look very nice and holds up well to today's graphic standards.   On the subject of graphics, one welcome change is the inclusion of more realistic body types for NPC's and even Batman himself (with some suits). The older Arkham games seemed to only have one body type for male characters where they looked huge, like they were taking horse steriods. This one tones that down significantly and is much better for it.  Sound has always been one of the strengths of the series and this one is no different. Voice acting is rock solid with a fantastic cast and good dialogue overall. Some of the sound effects have become a bit too familier but it is not so bad as to be game breaking at this point.  The story is probably the weaker aspect of this title. It has some really good elements but it stumbles a lot. You will find that the main villains are not terribly interesting and the only thing really pushng you forward is the dynamic going on between Batman and his "inner voice" (can't say much more without potentially spoiling things). It is not a terrible story and it is not really bad enough to hurt the experience a whole heck of a lot but it does suffer from trying to fit too many differnet elements together somewhat awkwardly.   One welcome change is the general absense of Harley Quinn. I know she is a fan favorite but she really got played out by the time Arkham City was released. It is good to see that they moved away from her in this title as she would not have fit very well in the main plot.  Overall, Arkham Knight is a pretty solid entry in the series and a good refinement of the existing formula. It had a rough launch and will still suffer from the reputation it got during that time but as a whole, it is a good game that now runs and works much better than the sadly abandoned Arkham Origins.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												(Review written 9/29/2015)It's been over 3 months since launch, I have the season pass and all I have to show for it is a skin, and we have no estimated release date on a fixed version.  To top it all off, I'm stuck on a roof in new game plus due to a logic error in the design and no one seems to be addressing that issue (Google "Arkham Knight stuck on roof Founder's Island"; I'm not alone).The good: I beat the game and 100%'ed it, then started NG+ and would have beaten that were it not for the game-ending bug.  The story was good and they added new gameplay mechanics to stop us from falling into auto-pilot from previous installments.  For as much hate as they got, I really liked the "tank" sequences (except for one... "boss fight" that was ruined by the tank experience).  The team-ups with various Bat-family allies was pretty cool and there were a lot of really neat moments alluding to (or recreating) classic moments in Batman lore.  I genuinely enjoyed it.The bad: The game's broken.  I have a GTX980 and 24GB ram and blah blah blah who cares.  It's a bumpin' system over here, you get the picture.  The framerate was wanting even considering these factors, and it plummetted during somewhat common occurrences such as powersliding the Batmobile.  When I was playing it, there was a weird bug where the lowest resolution textures would load.  They tried to fix this in late August--you know, two months after launch--but this patch, while a good first step, introduced some other issues.  I have this weird one where some building textures fail to render at all and appear as this weird, out-of-place, bright, confetti pattern.  I joked to my girlfriend that maybe this was some kind of surprise Crazy Quilt DLC, but I was stuck on a roof, so I couldn't investigate.There are no challenge maps.  Sure, there  are AR challenges, but you don't have the choice of characters you did in Arkham City (or even Arkham Origins) and there aren't nearly enough.  This severely limits the game's value.  There is no DLC for the PC version currently, meaning if you paid for the season pass (like I did), you paid $40 (or in my case, $30 -- thanks, Steam sales!) for a Batman Beyond skin or something.They said that they'd fix the game in the coming weeks.  Well, it's 3 months later and we have nothing.  The last status update was 26 days ago.  Even if they release a miracle patch that fixes everything, is this the kind of developer/publisher you want to support?  Avoid.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												You must have the Best CPU in the market and SLI TitanX's to run this game smoothly I guess. I was very optimistic that Rocksteady can deliver a great PC game with their last Batman Game, but unfortunately they truly don't care about the PC platform.Gameplay is pretty much the same as Origins, just the added batmobile that drops a lot of frames when driving.I'll probably wait a week for a performance patch, if they can't deliver then a refund is justified. They should have optimized the game before release, not after.If you are on the fence about this game, DO NOT BUY this if you have less than i7 4790k and GTX 980 and want a 60FPS experience. If you are contented with a stuttery 23-30FPS on their recommended system specification with FPS unlocked to 60, then I guess you will enjoy the game. (FPS is locked @ 30FPS by default)My Rig:FX 8350 4GhzGTX TitanXSamsung SSD 256 840 Pro12GB Ram-I can run most optimized games like Witcher 3, Dying Light, GTAV, etc. at 1440p at a constant 60 FPS with ultra settings (hairworks off).Batman Arkham Knight however gives me a stuttery 23-30 FPS at the lowset setting @ 1080p, with FPS unlocked to 60 in the BmSystemSettings.ini file.I think they are a contender for the worst PC release this year.And yes, PC games minimum FPS should be 60FPS at the lowest setting with a decent rig.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												First, the good. Batman looks great, darker and grittier than ever, and the new combat mechanics such as environmental takedowns and using melee weapons make you feel more like Batman than ever before. The batmobile is a great new gameplay mechanic.That's it. Now to the bad... aka the rest of the game.This is the worst optimized pc port/excuse for a "big budget game" i have ever played. When the PS4 gets better graphics and performance than PC and the framerate is capped at 30, you can see just how lazy a job Rocksteady did, especially by hiring Iron Galaxy Studios. Unbelievably bad performance, and even the PS4 got a patch before PC. A good majority of the game's textures are just unfinished. The only character who looks remotely polished is Batman, and even still there are no rain effects comparable to PS4. It is clearly not a question of the power of PC over PS4, but one of simple laziness on the part of the devs. It's 2015, Rocksteady, get with it. Wish I could recommend, as Arkham is one of my favorite game series of all time, but until some serious overhalls happen, it's a no from me.My specs:AMD A8-6600k 3.9GHz Quad Core8 GB RAMRadeon R9 280 3 GB GDDR5(Believe this is above the "min" specs)Performance:With all settings low or off, can't even hold 30fps @ 1080pMaxxed out settings, actually not much worse, at about 25ish. Looking up at sky gives me a smooth 55 though, so at least I can take a break from the headache of actually playing by stargazing.Batmobile is worse offender, with frames dipping into low 10s.From other reviews I've seen, doesn't really seem to matter what hardware you have, the PC version is just absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ My gut reaction is to say "Thanks DICE" but looks like theres a new dog in town. "Thanks Rocksteady"

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Having enjoyed the combat and overall gameplay of the previous games. I got this with my GPU as a free game, so I can't complain it is wasted money at all. but this game was ported so poorly, this is mostly due to WB outsourcing the PC port to a 3rd party porting team. They did a horrible job , so I don't blame Rocksteady, and I'm pretty sure they are as pissedd as most of their consumers on how WB handled this. This is a perfect example of publishers ruining good games because they want more money and to save time. As a currently learning concept artist and hoping to be part of a design team in the future, I feel as if this will push me away from my career, I don't want my teams work  to  go to waste because of some corrupt and spoiled company  wanting to get out it as fast they can and be able to haul in the cash. Overall. having seen gameplay on console and playing very little on the PC myself due to FPS issues and bugs. the game overall was pretty nice. however. I cannot give the game a good review currently, solely because of how it runs. This will change, if rocksteady ever decides to update their game and fix the problems. with a promised august date , and that now it is halfway through august, I won't get my hopes up.

												Even though i absolutely love this game, it saddens me to not be able to recommend it to you. I didn't have any problems with it, but there are hardly ANY graphical settings to be found here. There is also a 30 FPS CAP IN A GAME MADE IN 2015. THIS SHOULD NOT HAPPEN. The story itself is dissapointing because the Arkham Knight is easy to predict and gives you too many hints. The REAL ending requires you to get 100% completion in the game. Shame you have to dig into the .ini file to fix any graphical hiccups you may have. If you try to turn off motion blur, the game crashes at startup. Don't buy if you have an AMD graphics card. If you have the computer to beat the extremely beefy system requirements, wait to buy this until it gets patched. Shame on Iron Gaming, Rocksteady, and Nvidia. This is an example of "If you're gonna do a job, do it right."

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												The worst game I played this year and I'm not even talking about the performance issues. [Played on release, some small details might be inaccurate by this point.]The Good:Joker BanterThe OK:Man-Bat exists.Batmobile gameplay *CAN* be more fun than on-foot tedium at times.The Bad:Everything elseThe story is just poorly recycled(and poorly written a lot of times) classic Batman stories cobbled together. Arkham Knight is exactly who you think he is.Have you ever jokingly wondered what a Batman game designed by modern Ubisoft would feel like? Well wonder no more, Arkham Knight is exactly that. Infact you could say this game is the Assassin's Creed 3 of Arkham titles.It even includes the CLASSIC Ubi towers you can climb to - destroy and road checkpoints to do the same. Hurray fillers.Three islands that carry the feeling of being fillers. Sidequests are unmarked, which sounds good on paper but it's an exercise in frustration - now you must go to each island and glide around like an idiot around the city at different levels(can be located in - air, top, mid, underground) in Detective Mode to find the next part of each sidemission while listening to sounds to find relevant conversation to locate said side missions.You can ease that a bit by destroying Arkham Knight's flying drones, which allows GCPD choppers to fly again and they help looking for side missions... if you're lucky and have detective mode on to tell which direction the sound is coming from and names of Island areas. Except doing certain story missions triggers the drones to come back, now you get to fly around all 3 island all over again to destroy drones.You get the same repetitive missions to do on each island. Some of them involve the Batmobile and destroying ## amount of tanks for each mission.Batmobile/Tank stealth sections are a thing. You get to quietly drive behind tanks and shoot them, then run away, it can be fun sometimes but I'm undecided on that.Remember Deathstroke from Arkham Origins? Remember the boss battle with him? Arguable the most intense bossbattle in the Arkham franchise, one of those extremely rare instances of QTEs done right. For some reason, in Knight, Deathstroke drives a tank now and that's how the boss battle with him plays out. You fight. In Tanks.Speaking of which, aside from things like the Boss battle described above which involve TANKS, they're gone. Knight has maybe 1 or 2 boss battles, one of them is Riddler. I cannot remember any others at this moment.Last but not the least, the 'true ending' - a small vague cutscene is locked behind 100% completion of the game, that includes collecting every riddler trophy.Maybe at one point this game had a soul, but it's past that point.

number of helpful: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												It's no secret that Bamham Knight has had issues on the PC, even to the point of resulting in Warner Bros removing the game from the Steam store for a few months. Having heard that even after returning to Steam the game was still pretty buggy, I was expecting the worst, but what I got was considerably different.In terms of the port quality, they seem to have patched it up pretty nicely. My specs (a GTX 970, an i5 3570k @ 4.4 GHz, and 16 GB of RAM) were able to max the game at a pretty consistent 70-80 fps, and the only bugs I encountered were two minor graphical glitches that were fixed by reloading the checkpoint. It has some nice features that a lot of PC ports leave out, like a borderless windowed option and the ability to instantly swap between keyboard and gamepad controls instead of having to change it in the settings. The game looks pretty gorgeous graphically, though in terms of animation it seems like they haven't bothered to make new dialogue animations since Arkham Asylum and Batman is still seemingly incapable of moving any part of his body except his mouth when he speaks. Maybe I just got lucky, since a lot of people still seem to be having trouble, but it ran almost perfectly for me.Unfortunately, I can't say the same praises for the game itself. You may be expecting this to be the game that finally brings the full Gotham experience, with actual people to rescue or at least see like in other superhero games, like Spiderman 2. Unfortunately, that isn't the case, and instead Rocksteady wrote in an extremely stupid excuse for Scarecrow to plan for the city to be evacuated at the start of the game, leaving the same gallery of thugs you spent three games pummeling already. As a whole, the game would feel like "Arkham City 2" instead of being a dramatic leap like going from Asylum to City, if it weren't for one damning fact: at some point, Rocksteady forgot that they were making a Batman game, and decided to try their hand at making a World of Tanks spinoff. This game introduces the Batmobile, which doubles as a tank, and they must be very proud of their brilliant idea because they never stop using it. Literally almost every mission in the game finds some way to shoehorn the batmobile into it, to the point that even the Riddler now seems to care more about his passion for NASCAR-themed death traps than actual riddles. It's not so much that the Batmobile segments are bad, it's just that if I wanted to play Tankman I'd play a game about tanks, not Batman: Arkham Knight. If you thought people had to be exaggerating when they say you spend the majority of the game in a tank like I assumed, think again.In terms of the parts where you aren't stuck in a tank, it's pretty much identical to the previous 3 games except less interesting. The free-flow combat system was an interesting mechanic in 2009, but the idea has been so played out by both the Batman series and other games copying them that the novelty has faded, leaving the fights just feel dated and tedious. The predator-style stealth that the series was originally known for is almost totally absent, with most of the encounters being more of the "jump headfirst into a large group of goons" variety. The various side missions from Arkham City return, but none of them are all that interesting, and in their efforts to include as many villains as they could they failed miserably at making sure any of them got more than 2 or 3 minutes of screentime. Most of the side missions are just busywork, constantly poking you in the arm and daring you to waste your time. Do you really care enough to find and rescue 20-or-so firefighters for no real reward? Can you honestly be bothered to find the Riddler's god knows how many stupid trophies for the fourth time? Probably not, but you'll have to if you want to see the game's two extremely underwhelming secret endings anyways.Ultimately, where the game fails the most is the story. The Arkham Knight himself is probably the most underwhelming villain I've ever seen in a game, and even ignoring his awful surfer bro voice all he ever really does is brag about knowing everything about you and then immediately start whining and throwing an almost Riddler-level crybaby tantrum whenever you start getting the upper hand, making him seem more like a spoiled child than a villain worth putting in the title. He just isn't an interesting character at all, especially considering you probably already knew who he is before you even read this review. It feels like the only reason he was included was so that Rocksteady could have something mysterious and new to bring in the people who aren't interested in the comics enough to appreciate a game where it's obvious that Scarecrow is the real main villain. The storyline itself just isn't all that interesting, and tends to jump between plot points in pretty nonsensical ways and dropping them out of nowhere just as quickly. Bamham Knight isn't awful, but it's certainly not a game I'd recommend paying full price for. It doesn't feel like a satisfying end for what started as a surprisingly good series at all, and just left me wondering if there was something I missed at some point. But at the same time, I'm a bit glad that the series is at least over now; I'd rather see the series die average than live long enough to become mediocre.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I've withheld my review on Arkham Knight til it came back up on the store so it will not be considered a pre-release review. First, let me say that I pre-purchased the Arkham Knight Premium Edition back at the start of June due to the being a longtime Arkham-series fan, and had actually had my hopes up that this would be as phenominal a game as it had been advertised in previews/trailers. When the game originally launched, I could barely play it, as it was so horribly unoptimized that I was one of the 90+% of people that had to use a community-discussion workaround to make it playable. After I did get it up and running, the framerates I got weren't the best, but the game was quite playable with some moderate frame drops in overly busy areas. I completed the main storyline and a good amount (but not all) of the side content, and was satisfied with the story. However, I knew this was not the game I paid for, and sat down to wait for Rocksteady and Warner Brothers to clean up the mess they let Iron Galaxy Games make of the pc version. Over 3 months later, the September patch came out, and at that point I couldn't even launch the game due to changes they'd made in the patch. This infuriated me, even moreso due to the fact that the pc DLCs had still been held back and the console players were still enjoying their games while the pc community was still in patch limbo.Another month later, just a few days ago, another patch is promised to be released... and what did we get? No major changes except that they allowed the cumulative DLC-backlog that the original game-owners were due to finally be recieved and played. All the bugs/glitches from September were still there, and I still couldn't even start the game. I was able to figure out my particular issue and get into the game again, but the damage was done. I'll play the DLC from what I'm still owed in the season pass, but I frankly don't have the heart to even bother replaying the game again. This whole 4-month (and soon to be half a year at this rate) fiasco just reeks of incompitence and flat out apathy on the part of the developers. The pc version of the game should NEVER have been outsourced to a 3rd party to complete. The fact that Warner Brothers re-released the game in this state and offered people who purchase it all the prior Arkham games is just a flat-out slap to the face, as it literally amounts to nothing, since people will have probably already had purchased most if not all of those games.In conclusion, I cannont recommend this game as it is at this current time. It's a shame that the conclusion to the Arkham series had to turn out like this; I enjoyed many of Rocksteady's games in the past, but now I'm leery of anything they produce in the furture for pc, as I don't know if it'll get outsourced again.

You've earned yourself an ever doubtful customer, looking sceptically at your products.I do NOT recommend this game until it's at least somewhat patched, optimized and hopefully a little polished for PC KBM gaming.Assigning KBM shortcuts and performance options should not be considered an satisfactory PC port: there is a lot of fine tuning missing that was always overlooked in the Batman franchise.EDIT: Several months later, end of october patches: still runs badly. number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												It is such a shame that they boned the PC release of this game so hard, because Rocksteady is a solid developer and this is a great addition to the Arkham series.  The symptoms of the terrible port still persist, although I would say that the game was about 80% okay for me. The biggest problem I had was that, in racing around Gotham in the Batmobile, the game is forced to load tonnes of textures incredibly quickly, and when it failed to do so fast enough it would freeze and think for about 10-15 seconds before resuming again. Because a lot of the driving requires very fast reflexes, this could at times cause considerable frustration, and unfortunately this happened almost entirely one the first island, which soured my initial opinion. Other than this though, there was really only the occasional noticable bug that didn't get ironed out as the QA manpower was diverted elsewhere during the release crisis. This game was rightly made an example of, as WB's despicable release deserved no forgiveness from consumers, however it's a shame that it had to screw over what is actually a really good game by a really good developer. Now, beyond all that, let me say that this is one of the best looking games ever made. I read a debate on this topic that argued between this game and Star Wars Battlefront, and while Battlefront is all style and no substance, Arkham Knight has more than enough substance to satiate those coming from Arkham City. It again ups the ante over its predecessors and delivers the entirety of Gotham for us to play around in, and while Arkham Origins ostensibly did the same, Rocksteady actually managed to fill the space with character. The sheer amount of time that must have been spent on the art of this game is absolutely mind-boggling. Almost every inch of the city feels specifically crafted rather than copy-pasted, and on top that there're dozens of unique indoor locations to boot. The NVIDIA enhancements are pretty stunning too – the way the rain plumes off of your cape as you leap into flight never gets old - although most of them will test your hardware.In regards to gameplay, it’s much the same as the previous games, with a few new gadgets here and there. I'd heard a lot of complaints about the amount of Batmobile in the game, and I personally can't really see where the negativity has come from. The Batmobile combat isn't the most elegant, but neither is the hand-to-hand combat. Although I quite enjoyed travelling around in it, it can also be abandoned for the majority of the game, and travelling on your own is a viable alternative when you level your skills up enough. In short, I didn't find it to be an unwelcome addition to the game.This is the fourth Arkham game though, and there are signs of the franchise tiring. The Riddler’s riddles felt lazier and many literally spelled out the answer in the riddle itself, many of the villains make their third or fourth appearances and really started to feel recycled, and the combat system seemed (at least at the beginning) even more self-guiding than before. Some of the tasks also seemed more like busy work than before, but that might be a related to the sheer amount of them they've used to fit the size of the city, as well as my own personal weariness of the 'open-world formula'.  In saying that, the story is genuinely intriguing and I can't seem to put the game down. I played 21 hours in the first 2 days at a time where I was getting burnt out really quickly with other games, and I’d often find myself saying ‘one more mission’ until it was 3 in the morning. TL;DR - This is a great sequel to Arkham City, and exposes the fact that, while they own the franchise, in developing Arkham Origins WB didn’t actually understand what made an Arkham game so good. AK continues to keep the core gameplay intact whilst expanding the scope of the game, however, I can't see them being able to expand any further from here on. I can’t see them creating a bigger game world, or doing much more with the established gameplay, or using the same characters again without it all seeming tired. I haven’t finished this yet, and perhaps the plot gives it away, but I hope they don’t keep bashing out endless games in this vein, because I don’t know if there’s much more of the well to draw from in this same way. If this is the swansong of the series, it’s a shame that the release was such a clusterf**k, and as a consequence has scarred the game permanently. If you can get it cheap in a good sale, like I did, I highly recommend it, but I wouldn’t pay full price, as despite the fact that it's a great game, it’s still broken in a number of ways.

number of helpful: 61 of 112 people (54%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Ok, I've bought this game after a year from release on summer sale. Devs told that game is mostly fixed.So why not, it is 50% off with all dlc. I've played for an hour just fine, but soon I started to get critical errors any time I glide, or ride batmobile more than 2 minutes (oh, you have to ride it more than 2 minutes). There is no fix, no workaround, and it seems there will be no new patches from devs, I've bought a BROKEN game. It is not laggy or buggy, this things you can workaround somehow, no,  it is BROKEN.And from community i see there are a lot of guys with the same issue, and it is mostly for AMD  cards like mine (r290).So if you want to buy this game, and you have AMD card, think twice. This game can run like the wind for you, or play you like a damn fiddle! You cant predict or be sure.UPDATE_________________________________________________________________After hours of testing different community fixes, I found solution.1) Forget about crimson drivers. I do not know if the game cannot befriend with crimson drivers, or drivers with the game. Or maybe crimson drivers do not even include Batman fixes.Use latest catalyst drivers (15.11)2) Try Batman Tweak Tool (you can find it in Guides), it really helps to optimize game settings and performance.3) Use super resolution (but I do not think this step is mandatory)Now I finally can play the game without crashes, shuttering and fps drops. But my review will stay negative, because it is not my job to sit hours and try fix the game, that already should be tested.I wand to pay the money and play the game with my brain dead..

												So I got this free with my brand spanking new EVGA GTX 980 Ti SC, which I've overclocked on top of the base overclock. This is in a system that has 16gb of ram and an i7 3770k. I've unlocked the framerate, turned off all nvidia features apart from lightshafts, and my fps just tanks to 30 and below every time I want to drive the batmobile, or glide as batman. it's a joke. It's a shame because, from what I have played, Arkham Knight is an astounding game. It's a mark above Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, but I cannot recommend it because it simply runs like dogshit. Hell, the console versions run better, and even worse, the PS4 version LOOKS better. The PC version has ZERO ambient occlusion. Nothing. It's gone. Also, don't even try to go into the .ini to turn off motion blur, because the game will most likely crash on startup. We're in the year 2015, and turning off motion blur causes the game to crash. Let that sink in people.Definitely do NOT buy this game until it gets patched, and when it does, I will update my review.I wish I could get a refund, and I got it for free.

												The Batman Arkham series has been one of my favourite gaming saeries ever. After playing through them on my PS3 and then again on PC, they blew me away everytime. Now with this port of Arkham Knight I am the most disappointed I have ever been with a game. Warner Brothers GAmes has specifically gimped the game so that it runs 'on par with the console experience.' It has no ambient occlusion, lackluster textures, no rain textures on Batman (which PS$ has), and worst of all a frame rate cap at 30 frames. I love everything else about this game. Seeing Batman knock somebody out with  a backwards headbutt was fantastic. The Batmobile does shoeget annoying during the tank parts. Do not buy this game, it manages to actaully look and run worse than the console versions.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Batman Arkham Knight hmmmmmmmm....... Where do I begin.I am now 5 hours into the game and am enjoying it. The fact that I had to spend an hour of my time fixing a Stutter So bad that I couldnt make my way around the title screen (this is a known error with laptop Nvidia cards) I eventually managed to make the game windowed which fixed my problem and actually made the game playable. I can excuse this mostly because its day 1 or 2 and its perfectly resonable to have a few problems. BUT that is not the end, after scrolling through millions of forums about all the diffrent problems with the pc port i have come to the though of WHAT HAS ROCKSTEADY BEEN DOING FOR 3.5 YEARS. They must have been crazy to think that capping the frame rate at 30 was ok in 2015. Even though there is an easy fix for this. It is also apparent that people with top of the line graphics cards are experiencing terrible frame drops, I understand that rocksteady wanted to make this game incredible FOR CONSOLE but its not OK to pass off the PC port to another company when we were expecting a ROCKSTEADY game. For the first hour or so my game ran fine (apart from the weird cape glitch from AO) then after that i started to experience random frame drops and SHOULD I MENTION THAT IM ON THE LOWEST SETTINGS. Also the fact that this game on its highest settings looks worse than the ps4 and Xbox one. It doesnt even look anything like the videos that we recieved in the upcoming months and you might say oh thats cause it was all console footage, Well NO it doesnt even look like what we were promised in the Nvidia gameworks videos which were on PC.few... thats my rant over.Look i really wanted to recommend this game I truley did. The story so far is cool and engaging, the gameplay is amazing, the fighting is even more fluid than before and driving the batmobile is amazing. but i just cant recomend this game right now at its current price and in the state it's in. wait a few patches or find it at a lower price if you really want it. I loved the other games and it truly hurts that I cant't recommend this game.

												I really wanted this game on release and it broke my heart to see all the troubles it had initially. Since it was on sale I picked it up, set a timer for 1 1/2 hours and played, hoping any troubles it had have now passed. As of this writing, I've played for 112 minutes and I'm not going to do a refund.My PC is not a large beast by any means but it can run things like Skyrim, Fallout 4 and the Witcher 3 with minimal issues. I can run Witcher 3 on medium better than I can AK on low. The game flat out tells me I am like 800 megs of VRAM short but the game runs. It drops frames and I hit slow downs sure, especially in the Batmobile but I havent had any game breaking crashes. The one issue I've been able to duplicate is if I stop after a session and start again later, I have to restart Steam entirely. Otherwise it just says "running" but nothing happens.I loved the other Batman games and I feel like I'm gonna enjoy this one too. Just make sure you have a beastly enough rig to tame it cuz this one is a monster.

												SHORT VERSION:Lie Down. Try Not To Cry. Cry A Lot.Another let down because of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port... the game is so poorly done that Warner Bros. suspended the sales of game on PC , says enough.LONG VERSION:Feels like Assassins Creed Unity all over again. Game has terrible fps drop downs no matter what spec u have , a 30 fps lock (which can be disabled in a ini file thank God) , almost no options to change in game...  seriously? Theres only like 5 things to change and then theres NVIDIA features which Im not even playing with due to whats happening with all of them OFF! It dosent matter if I run lowest or highest settings its all the same! The grain/blur filter which I personally hate in games cant be turn off. Game dosent even look that good anyways , to be honest it looks worst than console versions... has poor textures and ambiet occlusion comparing to PS4.Then there comes the dirty little trick they pulled off right before releasing the game ... the slimeballs... they changed the database of Batman games gotten from NVIDIA promo cards , so yeah if u have one of those they just ♥♥♥♥ed you up in the♥♥♥♥♥and took away Harley Quin DLC that u should get for preordering the game just before releasing it!How could they release this abomination? Were they drunk? On crack? Had a gun pointed on their heads? I do not know , what I know is it feels like an alpha game not a proper AAA finished product from the technicall side, they clearly must have known that and yet they released it anyways and they want you to pay for it 60 euro, maybe a walk of atonement like Game of Thrones style would be an appropriate punishment for what they did. If I had bought the game on steam I would go straight for a refund with no regrets telling them how broken this game is.You are really interested in Batman games? Just go play Arkham Asylum or Arkham City and wait for this pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥to get some proper patches , yet another game from Warner Bros. thats really unplayable on release just like MK X. I will never get a preorder game from them again.Hopefully they will fix it in the nearest future so I can change the feedback cause I do really want to play and enjoy this game just like the older titles.EDIT:Warner Bros. stated that they are suspending the sale of Batman Arkham Knight on PC till its fixed with an apology to all unhappy owners of the game... there is still hope this game will be as it should in the first place.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												After a long wait, the game seems to be fixed. I have a smooth 60 FPS and haven't experienced any crashes of glitches. For those of you wondering, I am running the game on a gtx 970 and a 4670k processor. More optimization has been added to the game to help out people with average to below average machines. I'm running the game with everything maxed out aside for the special "nvidia settings". I had recently owned the game before and the frames were jumping all over the place and had some pretty rough stuttering effects going on. Back then, I actually set the game to 30 FPS (most people consider this unacceptable) but I jump around from consoles to PC and honestly running the game on 30 FPS wasn't too bad for this title. So if you have a laptop/low-end PC, 30FPS was just fine. The Game itself is what you would expect from this franchise. Batmobile is a really nice touch, and the combat is always getting polished up. The DLC is really great. Now offers new challenges, bat suits, and batmobile skins. 1989 bat suit and batmobile, just awesome. I recommend the game to any batman fans and anyone whose still afraid of this game having problems should strongly consider giving it another chance.

												I really wanted this game on release and it broke my heart to see all the troubles it had initially. Since it was on sale I picked it up, set a timer for 1 1/2 hours and played, hoping any troubles it had have now passed. As of this writing, I've played for 112 minutes and I'm not going to do a refund.My PC is not a large beast by any means but it can run things like Skyrim, Fallout 4 and the Witcher 3 with minimal issues. I can run Witcher 3 on medium better than I can AK on low. The game flat out tells me I am like 800 megs of VRAM short but the game runs. It drops frames and I hit slow downs sure, especially in the Batmobile but I havent had any game breaking crashes. The one issue I've been able to duplicate is if I stop after a session and start again later, I have to restart Steam entirely. Otherwise it just says "running" but nothing happens.I loved the other Batman games and I feel like I'm gonna enjoy this one too. Just make sure you have a beastly enough rig to tame it cuz this one is a monster.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Batman Arkham Knight is literally all over the place in terms of its content. Sometimes I think that it's a solid 9/10 game, but at other times it can be a 3/10 game. The first few hours of Arkham Knight are superb, they show off everything the game has to offer, and contain a stellar story. The ball was raised extremely high up at that point, but then you get to the rest of the game. Between the nonsensical and downright boring padding thats added on after the main story, (which by the way adds about 10 extra hours to the game) and the lackluster narrative, Arkham Knight takes that highly raised ball, and slams it through the poorly-textured floor in its final acts. Not to mention the performance which is all over the place with my GTX 970, sometimes I get a consistent 45+ FPS, while other times it can go as low as 15 FPS in the span of 5 minutes. There also just isn't much to do, after the story you have the option of New Game+ or playing one of the five challenge maps they have to offer, that's it. In the end, I don't see how a game that took 4 years to make, and had multiple studios working on it, could only muster about 18 hours of actual gameplay to offer to consumers. I wouldn't recommend buying this at full price, let alone on PC. If you have to play it, borrow it, or rent it, as its not worth 59.99+ just for 18 hours of gameplay. In the end, I give this game a 5.5/10 - Slightly Above Average.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												I hadn't played this game during the "unplayable" phase so I don't know how far it's come with all the patches but I'll say that running on my desktop, which is fairly substantial, it's not perfect. This pc is built for video editing which means that it's got fairly decent specs for gaming as well and 16 gig of ram. It runs every recent high end title that i've tried, like Alien Isolation, Rise of the Tomb Raider or Dying Light, absolutely perfectly and with beautiful graphics. I want to emphasise that I've never encountered a game that my pc has struggled with playing at the game's highest graphical settings before, so this issue is with the game and not an upgrading issue on my end. And while Arkham looks fantastic (although no better than many of the other games that run fine), it sometimes functions fine, and sometimes skips and lags an insane amount and unfortunately it's worse when the texture resolution and detail options are turned up.However, gameplay wise, it's brilliant. If you like Batman, you'll love it, if you like the other arkham games you'll love it. It's definitely worth getting, I just don't kknow if it's ever going to work as well as it should. The story is brilliant and the side missions are fun, the soundtrack, voice acting, etc.. all of that, just like the other Arkham games is top notch, it really is a great game.As for DLC, wouldn't really recommend it, the Season of Infamy pack has some side missions which are kind of fun but really short and definitely not worth the price. However, the 1989 batmobile skin is brilliant. It's cheap and if you're a fan of the 1989 Tim Burton Batman film, like me, then you get to go around Gotham dressed like the Michael Keaton Bat and driving the slickest Batmobile they ever put on screen.So i'd recommend getting it in a sale, I got it for £13 and that feels worth it but I think I'd feel a bit ripped off paying full price when, at this point, it still isn't entirely fixed.

												It's barely playable in its current state, it's graphically inferior to its console counterparts (It's missing ambient occlusion entirely as well as rain effects on Batman and the Batmobile, all of which are present in the PS4 and XB1 versions), it has a 30FPS cap which can be removed via the ini file but did little to keep at a high, stable framerate for my rig that is comfortably above the recommended specs, and after a few launches, it then refused to even launch again, instead presenting me with a mile long list of errors. This is not acceptable for such a high profile release, or any release for that matter, especially one where they have the gall for charge $60 for it.EDIT: This will be updated when the game is patched and functional, and while it was unacceptable to launch in this condition in the first place, I have to give credit to WB for suspending sales of the PC version while they fix it.

												It says I have only played 90 odd minutes well its closer to 5 hours (No net)Anyway where do I start? There really is no excuse for this.I have a conclusion but its almost like a conspiracy to make the PC version so poorly over the PS4 and X-Bone.Did they sabotage the PC version? Only an idiot would do that but I can't understand why a company with 2 really good Batman games would release this as there is no way they did not know the state of the game prior to release.Normal Textures? Seriously? I have a great PC and a 980Ti my game should not run like crap.Anywy I have ranted enough.Would I recommend this game? In its current state no... Wait 6 months till its hopefully fixed and there is a ton of DLC  and it is in the Christmas sale for under £10 ($15 if you are in the USA) Rocksteady this trilogy should have went out with a bang now it will be remembered for all the wrong reasons.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												COMPLETED DATE30-Dec-2016 SETUPWindows 10 64-Bit, MSI GT80-2QE Notebook, Logitech F710 GamepadRATING (rated as if released in 2016, expect lower score for some aspects)Optimization : AStorytelling : AGraphics : ASound : AControl : A Fun Factor : ABang For The Buck : Get it nowThis game ran smooth on my system with maximum graphic quality settings. Great storytelling and voice acting, but the main plot feel forced. I love the level designs including the Riddler's puzzles. The Riddler's puzzles are not as hard to pull as in Arkham City, but still satisfying to complete. The side-quests kind of boring because almost all of them either requires you to "collect" something or chase something. Driving Batmobile feels great but the tank battles although fun at first, becomes annoying later on. The city much bigger than in the previous games with great details but it feel unnatural because the citizen are only cops and bad guys (thugs and militia). The developer did take all the good things of the previous games and improve them. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												TL;DR - 9/10, RockSteady fixed the issues that plagued the PC release, another great Batman game! If you liked Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, GET IT! WARNING - MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD!!!=-=-=-=-=-=-=This is very much like Arkham City in design, but RockSteady has added a few wonderful things to the mix which keep it fresh and new. The new suit lets you get around the city more quickly and the new Fear takedowns are fun, but the real beauty in this game lies in the addition of...wait for it...... the BatMobile.*Disclamer: I am HORRIBLE at driving games. Utterly awful. Can't do it. Never could.If there is one area where this game ***could** have fallen apart, the BatMobile and driving around the city is it. The open world game Mad Max had time trial missions that were almost impossible to complete and that robbed me of some of the enjoyment of the game. However, RockSteady has avoided every possible pitfall that I could think of with driving around in Gotham and has made the addition of the BatMobile another exercise in fun. If *I* can finish the driving challenges in this game, ANYONE can. The car-to-tank mechanic allows for easy maneuvering around tight turns and narrow areas, and the coolness factor of the car and the tank cannot be overemphasized.Now for the negative: I did have to go to the controller for the driving time trials, as well as one of the side missions during the game. If, like me, you are a completionist when it comes to open-world games, you'll probably need a controller to get through everything.Am I nitpicking? Pretty sure I'm nitpicking. Yeah, I think I'm nitpicking.I've played through about 15% of the main storyline and some of the side missions, and I'm hooked. Great Riddler puzzles, lots of combat combos, all the good stuff you've come to expect from RockSteady's Batman games.PROS------- All the good stuff you've come to expect from the Batman series- Great new suit- BATMOBILE!!! BATMOBILE THAT CONVERTS INTO A BAT-TANK!!!- Did I mention the BatMobile?- Gotta love the BatMobile!!!- Did I mention that the BatMobile converts into a FREAKIN' TANK??!!?!!?- FREAKIN' BATMOBILE!!! THAT CONVERTS INTO A FREAKIN' BAT-TANK!!!CONS------- Some parts of the game work better with a controller than with a mouse/keyboard setup

												Batman: Arkham Knight is unplayable. The game literally sucked up a full 7.94 GB's of my 8 GB's of memory. So a definite memory leak is obviouls within the first 8 minutes of gameplay. My north bridge is over-clocked, so playing ANY other game is smooth.

number of helpful: 19 of 32 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												First the non recommendation is not due to the technical issues. The game is not the disaster it was at launch, but it still has some issues. This is the most underwhelming Arkham game in the the series. For Origins, I had lowered expectations, and it met most of them. The good bit: The graphics and detailing of characters is awesome, right down to the fabric patterns of Batsuit. The Voice acting and Music are great all throughout.And the rest: The story tries to be the concluding third act for Arkham version of Batman. Unfortunately, Scarecrow and Arkham Knight simply don’t have the caliber to be the “ultimate threat” Batman has ever faced. Anyone vaguely familiar with the Batman Mythos will be able to deduce Arkham Knight’s identity (No he is not an original creation). One of the most powerful element of batman’s story is used and squandered on Arkham Knight. Scarecrow does his fear thing, and the hallucination shtick is overused crutch to further the story. Most other Bat villains are relegated to Side missions. Gameplay sans Batmobile is the same as Arkham City, with changes being Incremental at best. Nothing really shake things up – the rythmic combat and stalk from height stealth section remains the same.And then there is the god damned Batmobile. An all purpose transportation/combat tank. Some genius decided to make it the spine of Arkham knight’s Gameplay. Every other missions requires the use of batmobile, and it wouldn’t have been an issue had it been fun. The Batmobile section is serviceable are best, but since they are overused so much, it soon becomes a chore. Tank battles soon devolve to taking on 30+ enemies. Batmobile handling is neither arcadey enough and neither gives the feedback and impression of weight that should come from driving a hulking armored tank at speed. Riddler’s Racing events are an amazingly painful experience. Which you have to do, including every other mundane thing to get the true ending.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												This is definitely the most ambitious Arkham Batman game to date, and it shows. Visually it's one of the best looking games of all time. It controls great, give you the tools to be the Batman, and for the first time ever you feel as if you can really roam about as the caped crusader all thanks of the inclusion of the batmobile. Sadly the game was not ported well to PC, and you need some of the beefiest tech to be able to run this game maxed out and with stable framerates. Even then you will experience stutter from time to time as assets load while you travel about. The game needs a lot of RAM, and even an SSD seems to be mandatory for it to be semi enjoyable. It's all a big shame, since this is as close as you can get to the ultimate Batman expereince, the game has tons of content (especially if have the season pass), but it never truly was finished to the standard we expected, meaning there are still bugs/glitches and performance issues to be had no matter what platform you play it on. On this basis alone I cannot it give it a thumbs up, but I wish I could! It is an extremely fun game, and if you can get it on a sale, and you have the system specs to power it properly, then you will still enjoy it, you will just have to swallow your pride and live with the performance issues.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												FYI, I played and completed this game back around when it was released.  I am a big fan of the Arkham franchise and loved Asylum, City, and even Origins.  Regarding Knight, I was one of the "lucky" ones for whom the game still ran reasonably well...either that or I have a high tolerance for sub-par performance.  Supposedly the game runs better after the patches, I can't be bothered to check since I am done and have moved on to greener pastures.  This game definitely gets a thumbs down out of principle.  WB / Rocksteady's behaviour in this matter has been a debacle and should not be rewarded despite their untimely efforts in remedying the matter.  Many people seem to advocate that they somehow deserve our thanks for patching the game and customers are acting entitled when asking for some kind of reparations.  This is certainly not the case.  While it is technically true that they owe their customers nothing beyond a working game, any company worth a damn when it comes to their customer service would do this and more in the interests of good public relations and customer retention.  The fact that they did nothing beyond patching demonstates a bare minimum regard for their customer base.  This, in conjunction with a $40 season pass that has been well-documented to be scant in it's offerings, is just sad and disappointing.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												To start off, let's discuss the most obvious bad things about this game. As we all know, Batman: Arkham Knight is expremely power-hungry. The game (for me) plays at a top 62 FPS but drops to about 40 when sprinting. When gliding, I get a 20 FPS drop. The game, at random times, will stutter and freeze, and occasionally my screen will go black, causing a driver failure. To my surprise, the game actually has never crashed on me. Now let's look at the good stuff. (Wait, what good stuff?!?! There isn't anything good about this game!!!1!!1!1!) Actually, if you ignoure the awful performance quality, the game isn't actually that bad. The level of detail in the game is extremely high. I can't even distinguish a single flat surface on any of the models. You at least have to give the guys credit for the modeling. The combat mechanics take some time getting used to, but are a piece of cake once you get the hang of it. The story is pretty well done, and the game overall has a good length in gameplay. I also like the fact that the game is open-world so you can exploure as you please. My overall rating for this game is a 3/10. [✓] High definition visuals[✓] Good Gameplay[X] Crappy performance.Other thoughts:Personally, I would wait to buy this game for the re-release to come out. Trust me, it's worth the wait.Update: For me, the recent patches have helped my game about 20% in performance. Not a lot, but enough for my satistfaction.

												Having been spoilt lately by quality AAA PC games from the likes of Rockstar and CDProjectRed, the initial release Arkham Knight comes as a real kick in the pants.My personal experience seems to have been on the mild side, but a 30fps cap, which when removed causes textures to look like they belong on a SNES, is wholly unacceptable.The gameplay is classic Arkham, with a number of neat additions. And blasting through Gotham in the Batmobile is a very satisfying experience, when the framerate doesn't tank into the ground.As much fun as the game is, just wait until it gets fixed.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												First of all, I didn't reccomend this game about the bad port (It's somewhat fixed so..). I'll compare this to the old games, yeah sure, this game has the best graphics, and the best map out of all 4 of the other batman games, the thing that failed though is the fact that there is basically no boss fight in this game, when I got to the part where I fought the chopper, I thought it's just a generic brute enemy that's gonna come out once in a while (like the titans in the Asylum) but no, I was in the middle of the fight and then I noticed that there was a health bar that kinda confirms it as a boss and I didn't see that chopper ever again, the Two Face, well I expected it at least like the one in the Arkham City where Catwoman fight Two Face, but Two Face was just another thug that wasn't any stronger than the other Thug. The Story is really crap and it was too repetitive and expected. And Finally....The Batmobile, I was waiting to have a joyride with it but then I realise it makes the game, The World of Tanks : Batman Edition. The other characters was a waste, I mean at least give me an option to use it on the free roam and the challenge map but no, they are just a one use only and they have less gadgets than before. I expected more Rocksteady, this was the last Arkham Game, the last time I blindly trust you Rocksteady and I won't ever buy your stupid DLCs!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I've played some bad ports in my time, this is right up there. When you load the game for the first time the first thing you will notice is the menus are capped at 30fps, strange I thought but I guess in game will be 60fps and beyond. The next thing I did was check the minimal amount of graphics options and ran the benchmark, first without the nvidia features on and was pleased to see the benchmark running at 60+fps, I then tried the various nvidia features to check for any dips in performance.Then I selected new game and realised it was capped at 30fps which makes no sense considering the benchmark is at 60+, so I was forced to exit the game and edit the ini file in config to get 60fps. Unfortunately it looks as if right now I'll have to play the game capped at 30fps anyway, with the fps uncapped the stutter is worse than anything i've seen, the framerate fluctuates anywhere from 35ish to 60 when gliding and divebombing, I couldn't believe I payed £60 for this including the season pass. This could be a worse port than AC Unity, I tested this on a single gtx 980 and SLI 980's, which made no difference to the framerate whatsoever.This game needs a mammoth patch.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
UpdateAs of June 23, 2015 the game is playable, but optimization issues still remain. I recommend holding off on purchasing the title for the moment, because the performance issues are quite severe, and you will not have an optimal experience. What made the game playable for me was after a complete verify cache failure, the entire game was redownloaded, and the newer files seem to fix a lot of the stability issues I previously had. I cannot say this with absolute certainty but in my case I believe the preload files were "unpatched" or not a good version. If you are having issues, preloaded the game, and haven't redownloaded the game, I suggest trying that.The previous texture issue I had was due to me disabling depth of field. It seems that this game uses DoF heavily, and without it, it's quite apparently how low resolution the textures are. I hope they update the textures so that I don't have to use DoF.With my specs there are frequent drops in framerate anywhere between 30-60 FPS. I'm currently using RTSS to limit framerate to a maximum of 60, and have unlocked the 30 FPS cap and changed it to a maximum of 60 FPS.I don't have a complete picture of the game yet so I will not comment on gameplay just yet.Original PostAs of June 22, 2015, the game is unplayable. I will update this recommendation as patches become available.My current specs are as follows:Intel Core i7 2600k 3.8 Ghz (Liquid Cooled)AMD R9 290 (4GB w/ latest recommended drivers for the game)8 GB RAMSamsung EVO 840 250 GB SSDWindows 8.1 64-bitIssues:Crashed with a bunch of error messages.System locked, and had to do a hard reset.Sound cutting in one particular part of the intro section.Verifying cache lead to complete redownload of the game.Crashes sometimes when accessing options menu in-game.Texture quality is extremely poor for maximum settings (could be that high res textures are not included in the initial release package).Possible memory leak, as memory usage and page file usage seems to be much higher than the norm.Other IssuesCapped 30 fps (can tweak via .ini files)No detailed Post Processing options (can tweak via .ini files) like motion blur, or Depth of field.No mouse sensitivity options.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
If your PC cannot run this game, you will know before your refund period runs out.This review is focusing mostly on the game itself and not on the issues that I was fortunate enough not to experience. Don't hate me!Now on with the review. I've graded each section with a letter grade if you just want to skim. And there's a TL;DR summary at the end. :)Performance Issues (Worked for me, but obviously not for everybody) - DSo you have all heard about the performance problems with this game. Yes; lots of people can't run this game on their computers, and I say that's a terrible shame, because I really enjoyed playing this game myself! This review is focusing on the quality of the game itself assuming your system can run it. Mine could, with only 1 or 2 environments where I noticed any significant lag, but not bad enough that I couldn't complete the game. Yes, shame on WB for how they handled this game, but this review is about my experiences with this game, not on how I feel about how WB should treat PC gamers. OK. We cool? Good.Story, Voice Acting, and Characters - A+Along with the other games in the series, this game delivers in a big way! The story is excellent. I think this game hasone of the best stories of all of the Arkham Games. And the voice acting and character development is excellent as always. This game drew me in early and kept me invested in the story through to the end. I even decided to 100% complete the game, which I rarely ever do with games. My one minor complaint with the story in this game was that the Arkham Knight's identity was too obvious, but it did fit the story pretty well, so it wasn't too much of an issue for me.Presentation (Graphics and Sound) - A+Presentationally, Gotham has never looked better! The environments are excellent, vibrant, and surprisingly well varied for a Batman game without losing the dark atmosphere surrounding the Dark Knight. The sound in this game, including the music and the sound effects, was truly exceptional. When you are blowing up militia tanks with the Batmobile, you can practically feel the impact of each blast. And taking down Gotham's criminals in hand-to-hand combat has never felt more real.Gameplay (Good, but not GREAT) - C+The only point where I was a little disappointed was with gameplay. It's not bad, but compared to Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, it wasn't anything special. The Batmobile was done very well, and I had no problems with its controls, but the developers used it way too often. The boss fights were the most disappointing thing in this game. There were a few shining points, for instance, the part when you defeat Scarecrow and the final battle with the Riddler, but there were some characters that deserved a much better boss battle. Without spoiling anything, I was extremely upset that Rocksteady made one character's boss battle a tank fight, which was far too easy and didn't fit the character at all. Also, while I liked the final fight with the Riddler, collecting ALL the Riddler trophies and solving all the riddles got tedious  once I had completed the rest of the game. I'd still recommend completing the story mode 100% (they give you an additional cutscene at the end that makes it worth it), but be prepared for a lot of frustration getting ALL of the riddles. Nevertheless, that made finally punching the Riddler in his stupid face so much more satisfying! I was also disappointed that I couldn't free play as Catwoman or any other this time around, but with the city designed for the Batmobile, I can understand why, so it wasn't too big of a deal. (But wouldn't it be awesome if Catwoman could hijack any car in free roam and turn the game into a GTA clone? Please someone make that mod. I would even buy it if you charged for it!)Was that too long? Here's a TL;DR version! - Overall Grade: BThis game is worth playing as part of the series. I'd definitely recommend at least playing Arkham City before this one, and Arkham Asylum is still my favorite game in the series, but this game is definitely worth playing if you loved the other Arkham games (and if you have a system that can run it, of course)! That being said, buy it on sale, because WB doesn't deserve full price for how they handled the PC launch and the subsequent patches. If your PC can't run it, get a refund and try the console version. I'm sure that if you can get this game to work for you, you'll be glad you didn't miss out on it, even though it does have a few flaws.About the DLCOne other note, I purchased some of the DLC for this game, but it was mostly pretty disappointing. I'd say "Season of Infamy" (4 Extra Most Wanted Villains) and "A Matter of Family" (Batgirl) are worth checking out, but the others are pretty lame (unless you want to mod the game so you can use the characters in free play).

I know I will probably get blasted by some fanboys but this is my opinion and I dare do be different than yours.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Don't know what to say about this game. First of all, my GTX 970 still(November 15 2015) does not maintain 60 FPS while driving or flying (without Physix) and there are still glitches(I stuck glued to a roof, enemies fall through textures). But the problem, I think is in the other department. I remember the time when I waited for 5 minutes for loading of a 1-room location in VtM: Bloodlines and I didn't care, because the game was awesome! I just ate or did my homework during these 5 minutes:). And I could have overcome all the inconveniences of Arkham Knight the same way. But for some reason we all pay so much attention to graphics and insane for early 2000s 60 FPS here, because, I think, the game itself is not that big of a deal and you mostly play it for the picture.It is the same Batman game we played two times already. The fighting is the same, story does not shock you as it was in some moments of Asylum game. In my opinion it is even a bit worse: villains don't have much time and instead of mystery behind them present mostly structurized lazy side mission apearances. For example, to catch one of them you only need to race him across the city and beat him up 3 or 4 times. Every time he appears the same way and fight ends the same way. It feels more like a race-side-activity markers on the map of GTA game instead of "legendary detective uses all his devices to find and apprehand a dangerous long time eneme in a dark chaotic city etc.". That is the difference between Christopher Nolan movie and a standard summer blockbuster. It does not mean the game is bad, but I guess I just raised my hopes too high about Rocksteady's talent. Or they just had to make another game according to the contract. Anyway I wish them good luck next time!
