content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I haven't asked for a refund, instead I played it not for a long time, but for as much as I played it back then the more interesting it got. All I can say it's that the story it's a really good one, captivating and the villans unleashing hell on the streets of Gotham, a hell far worse compared to the previous games from the series.Gotham it truly looks astonishing, never-ending rain reflecting all the distruction inside the city. I can for sure say that they really worked on creating this awesome Gotham with all the missions and investigations that you have to do, plus the engaging it results an awesome game with a lot of content and a moderate value of replay.You also get to drive around the batmobile, and here I get to say that this thing might feel a bit repetitive mainly because you need to use the batmobile where is not the case or when you might not want to use it but you need to use it and there is no way to get past an objective where you need to use batmobile without it and by this I mean,destroying a wall, pulling down something, EMP something and of course the chases which in my opinion are the only thing you need to use batmobile at. Villans have reasons to do what they do especially Scarecrow and these reasons and their actions can drastically change your opinion about them. Takedowns also got improved and you can now assits some unique combat moment, some brutal than the others.As I can notice, a lot of reviews has changed overtime and a lot of people now praises the game because of the optimisation it got since the release and I agree with them but also the game it's not in 100% condition of optimisation but it is in a far decent one compared to the initial release. I highly recommend this game to anyone that wants to buy it and are not sure if it's worth it although I have to say that this game it's not a dificult one so if you are seeking a bit challange you might want to stay away from it. Also I recommend it to people that had it before to retry it and enjoy it this time.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Dear Rocksteady,          Thank you for this horribly optimized poor excuse for a port, I appreciate being dicked around after waiting almost a year to play this game. It wouldn't be so bad if my computer barely met system requirements and it was me, the consumers fault. That being said, I think it should be considered that this is a bad game, Why you might ask? Because when you have a game, that people released and said "okay here you guys go it's ready" and you click the play button, giggling with anticipation, the next things you see, define that game. So that being said: Arkham Knight is the worst game that rocksteady has come out with ever, Ill take you through the first 15 minutes: The opening cut scenes where they implimented time travel, and the use of bullet time really took me out of the game, then the coffee shop segment where things are really supposed to engage the story, rocksteady tried to portray the cop as a "teleporter" bringing a new superhero into the franchise. However this hero that we find ourselves playing as, shows his greatest weakness which is other teleporters jumping on your face. Now let's get to the opening where we get to play as batman, Batman starts his campaign against crime, not assessing the fact that his equipment is faulty, im assuming it's a story error in which rocksteady meant to tell us that everytime batman looks in a direction his helmet camera gets blurry and doesn't work. This combined with the fact that the batmobile seems to keep trying to go with the newly implimented "time jumping" theme.  Basic combat is also a joke because they nerfed the batsuit in the early parts of the game to the point that when you attack something it affects the visuals that batman is seeing and forces you to wait as the system keeps trying to reboot midcombat, I don't know that the libertys that they were trying to take with this game involving a teleporting cop, time-travel and batman going into a fight with faulty equipment to even the odds but I have no motivation to find out, as the first 15 minutes of this game showed me how awful a developer can be.Side note: If this is some half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥attempt, to get people to convert to a console by releasing a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor PC port. Because Rocksteady decided to line their pockets with all that Sony/Mocrosoft payoff money, Everyone has already seen the gimmicky preorders, that each console and gamestore has to try to get everyone to buy early and from them {i.e.) redhood dlc, no batmobile edition), then they truly should take a look in the mirror and say to themselves "we are bad people".  Disclaimer: This being said, I know that they could be trying really hard, and alot of games at release have problems and minor bugs, Also most of the gaming community including myself, Know nothing of the innerworkings or politics that it truly takes to publish a game and release it. This all being said, You don't release an unfinished game. Unless you intend on us playing it from alpha on, to bugtest for you. This is how fanbases get destroyed.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Let's start this review by saying, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.Quite possibly the worst PC port i've seen in recent years, absolutely lackluster menu options of all categories, locked to 30 FPS unless you go tinker in the ini file and once you do, you'll regret itUnlocking the FPS seems fine but here are the problems i ran into changing other optionsTurning off Motion Blur : Will make your game instantly crashTurning off Depth of Field : Completely breaks Detective Mode (invisible units) and other parts of the game like no counter icons in combatHeavy graphical artifacting when looking at a specific part of the cityThe game is terribly optimized, i7-4790K @ 4.6GHz, GTX 980, 16GB @ 2400MHz and i've had sub 30 dips during Batmobile sectionsVery disappointed in Rocksteady, this port is lazy, lackluster and horrible and they totally knew that considering the lack of preview codes for the PC versionDo not encourage this, i wish i could get a refund but i didn't buy it on Steam

												I got Fallout 3(a game infamous for crashing win 7 or 8 PCs) last week and in 42 hours of playing it has given me less trouble then Arkham Knight has in 34 minutes of playing.I have a AMD Radeon HD 7600 Series and before installing the driver update (http://steamcommunity.com/games/208650/announcements/detail/207511695917042396) I had a FPS of about 15 to 20, after getting the update I had the same FPS and some of the worst graphics bugs I have ever seen.I am not mad Rocksteady, I'm furious, I have been waiting for more than a year and now it looks like I’m going to have to get a new PC, a PS4, or Xbox one to play it and while I’m sure the refund I’m going to get will help I can't afford that right now.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												My Rigi7 5930 4.4ghzSLI 980s32gigs DDR4 2800First launch=crash, then forced to fully re-install.Second Launch, notice framerate cap, change ini file.Third Launch, why am I only getting 40 -50 fps with dips every where, game and new drivers are supposed to be optomized. Turn off SLIFourth Launch=much better framerate, still dips, not optomized worth a damn, no where near enough graphics options, I shouldn't have to go into a ini file to change standard gaming graphics options, and even if you do that you risk the game constantly crashing. Memory leak for DAYS, 10gigs of memory used in 5 minutes?If I wanted to play this using console graphics I would have bought it for my PS4 instead of PC.Wait for patch before buying, or buy console version instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Sorry to make my first Steam review a negative one but I can't recommend this game at the moment. This a terrible PC version, it runs atrociously. I have a 760 gtx which is an older card but was able to run the Witcher 3 on a mix of high and ultra settings at 30 fps, this game will not run without serious microstutter and frame rate drops. The worst part is even the cutscenes look really bad, even worse than the main game as they stutter terribly and make it look like your playing the game off an old scratched cd.  There are almost no options in the graphics menu, the only choices you have are LOW and NORMAL. Thats it, no medium, no high, no ultra. 2 options for each catagory and about 5 catagories. This is simply unacceptable in 2015. You will notice I have almost no play time and its because it looks so sluggish I can't stand it. Unforunately for me I bought the game through a 3rd party website so I can't get a refund, so I have no choice but to hope it gets patched into a functional game. THis is really a shame becasue the game looks like it would be wonderful if not for the technical issues. Do NOT buy this until it gets fixed.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												My first attempt to play this game ended in a total system crash.My second attempt to play the game ended in a crash after being told I had to restart to apply graphics changes.My third attempt to play the game ended after 25 minutes when Windows warned me I was nearly out of memory (16GB total).For the extremely brief time I was able to play the game, I was treated to visuals straight out of history, with gracphis options equivalent to a game ten years old.  The 30fps lock was completely awful and made for one of the worst gaming experiences I've suffered through in a very long time.In its current state, this 'game' is nothing more than an excercise in futility and frustration, and you'd only be paying to beta test, assuming the developers decide to ever actually address any of these issues. I highly recommend staying away from this piece of garbage.  If the developers actually do decide to attempt to fix any of these issues,Edit 19Aug2015 - It's been over a month since any communication regarding a patch that was promised two months ago.  Nothing has changed, the game is more or less unplayable and should be avoided at all costs. 												Now first off the game itself, its mechanics, the story, the atmossphere, etc. seems to be amazing BUT I am seriously♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by this downright AWFUL port we got. I waited for this game for nearly 1 and a half year now and was so excited to play it on the midnight release. But as soon as I just went into the graphics options I said to myself: "Alright this is going to be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥port." I mean what the actual ♥♥♥♥? There are THREE graphics options THREE. Textures that strangely only go up to normal, level of detail and shadows. Then you got the V-Synch and FXAA switch, resolution and screen mode. That is the whole menu and this is just absolutley riddicoulous and a disgrace to all PC gamers in the year of 2015. And if that wasn't enough first they tease us with these 60fps Nvidia Gameworks trailers and then you tell me that I ♥♥♥♥ING have to deacitvate that stupid♥♥♥♥♥30fps lock by editing an .INI file. What the hell Rocksteady??? In addition the framerate is all over the place when you unlock the it. It is almost unplayable at times and there is this constant stutter and freezing while gliding and driving the Batmobil that makes it totally unenjoyable and takes away all the fun. (I am running an i7 4790k at 4Ghz, a GTX 970 and 16 gigs of RAM btw.) This is a prime example of a PC port done wrong in EVERY way. And if that♥♥♥♥♥♥doesn't get patched within the first week or so I am going to ask for a refund.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Update: It runs better now that it's re-released, but it still doesn't run well for an alarming number of people. Furthermore, WB's attempt to rectify the situation is beyond pathetic. If you're an Arkham fan who's be around since launch? Congrats. You get free copies of all the other Arkham games which you most definitely already own. Also, TF2 items. Eventually. Huzzah. Oh, and anyone who buys the game within a few weeks of the re-release gets the same. Final cherry on top of the crapcake? The launch patch was more concerned with getting support for the ridiculously priced DLC in the game so you could spend more money.Terrible form, WB. You just proved that you're worse than Ubisoft or EA. I still would not recommend spending any money on this turd, and I would be very hesistant to drop cash on other, better WB games like Mad Max or Shadow of Mordor. If you really have to play it, do what my buddy did and family share it from someone stupid enough to buy it.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I don't think I've ever played a game with such a sharp distinction between the game itself and its technical performance. As a game, Batman: Arkham Knight is one of the best I've played. The cinematic presentation and story are second to none. The combat and stealth are fast and fluid in ways that the previous games only dreamed of. Both have tremendous complexity that provides a ton of options for dealing with foes above and beyond anything else in the genre.Of course, the big new addition is the Batmobile and it did not disappoint me. I have heard that some people really don't like it, so your mileage may vary, but I personally have been loving it. The combat is fast and loud, and the solid driving is made incredibly satisfying by some of the vroomiest engine noises you'll ever hear.So, why can't I recommend this game? As far as I can tell, I get fairly good performance compared to most people, and it still runs like garbage half the time. I'm running a Radeon R9 270x. Not a top of the line card, certainly. It's a bit slower than the 960. However, that's an Nvidia card which should clear the minimum requirements just fine anyway. Of course, the developers just happened to mention a few hours before release that AMD cards had substantially higher minimum requirements than Nvidia ones but there's nothing shady about that. No sir.Ironically, the game seems to have serious trouble loading stuff in irrespective of card manufacturer. Moving quickly, either in the Batmobile or just gliding around fast, will cause stuttering. Don't think you're safe with a brand new, top of the line card, either. Reports from all over indicate that the game very well may run terribly even with cards that would run anything else just fine.The follow-up question is, of course: Does the game look good enough to warrant this? Not even close. It does look great, certainly, but "computer meltingly great"? No. Again, I've been fairly lucky to only get minor stuttering and relatively playable framerates, but there are still far too many moments that look a little too slideshow-esque to be comfortable. The game is incredible if you can get it to run, but there's absolutely no guarantee that it will actually run. On any system.As a finale note: the second this game gets patched into a working state, I will update this review. Batman: Arkham Knight has an amazing game buried deep down inside. There just happens to be no guarantee that you'll be able to play it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												My review: 


Batman™: Arkham Knight 
A Screenshot of Batman™: Arkham Knight
By: Roomate Rawr




So much potential, squandered by a bad port. First of all, as everyone knows, there are big performance issues. Frequent bad FPS drops make it hard to play at times. There is NO SENSITIVITY SLIDER, and the default sensitivity is really high, which actually made me feel sick after about 20 minutes. The core controls are very bad in my opinion, which takes away from the immersion. For instance: Run, Evade, Glide, Grapple, AND Interact are all bound to ONE key. So even if you re-bind it, there is no fixing this. You'll find yourself pressing Spacebar way too often, and it starts to feel like Spacebar Simulator 2015. Also, re-binding doesn't always work. Even if you rebind a key, you'll find that often your preferred key doesn't work for certain things, and you have to use the original one anyway. Also, a lot of the default controls are just really weird. Hold Left Ctrl and press the Scroll Wheel to perform a takedown, for instance. It just feels like an all-around lazy port. They made the game for console, ported it to PC, and just threw it out for purchase. If you don't have a console, just don't bother. Not until it's fixed, and I really hope it is.

												My PC exceeds the recommended system requirements.I will update this review later, once I've actually been able to play the game because so far, at the moment, the game wont even bloody start. The game starts tabbed out, and I can hear the sound running fine, then I tab in and it flickers and spazzes out like a donkey on acid. I also can't tab out of it again to close it, resulting in me having to resart my computer just to end the damn spazzfest. I then verified the game cache only to be told that ALL of the files for the game were missing, so now I have to download the whole bloody thing again, which took 6 hours to do the first time around. I freaking love Batman, and I love the Arkham games, but so far this PC port is pile of donkey turd.EDIT: After re-downloading the whole game, same problem. I've also noticed that it actually appears to be turning my screen on and off. Also the cache integrity thing is an actual problem that a lot of people have been having, so if you have this game DO NOT verify the integrity of the game cache as it will delete all of your game files. I have sent a ticket to  WB support demanding that they fix this completely unnaceptable mess of a port.EDIT: After finally getting back to my ticket  I was fed some rubbish by the WB support team claiming I did not meet the minimum requirements when my rig quite clearly exceeds the recommended requirements. They little advice that they offered was not useful in the slightest. I think I shall have to use Steam's refund system... *sigh*

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Got this game for "free" by purchasing a GTX 960 so I was able to actually play this game when it was delisted from the storefront. While I didn't have any performance issues, or at least none that left a lasting impression on my experience with the game I just can not recommend this game as a full price purchase. The story is engaging enough, and does feel like a complete end to Rocksteadys trilogy, but where it falls flat is the gameplay. Rocksteady trades out the interesting boss battles of Arkham City for tired drone battles and "boss" tank battles in the batmobile. The batmobile got way too much focus here, it's far more fun to glide around Gotham than it is to drive around it's (mainly) barren streets.Buy this when it's on sale for cheap if you truly feel you need some closure to Rocksteadys series but if not just replay the first two installments of this series.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												While for me the game is mostly playable since I have an i5 4690k and an overclocked GTX 980, the game only shows that I have 4009 mb of VRAM which is not true and to have all the settings maxed out at 1080p (GameWorks included) you need to have more than 4 GB of VRAMBesides that, what I have played  so far is a consistent 90 fps without any frame drops (I haven't played it since it re-released so I will edit if I encounter any problems) and I haven't seen any glitches so far but other people are reporting that they're having frame drops, even on an i5 4690k and a GTX 970. But without the glitches and frame drops the game on its own is great gameplay wise, is a bummer storywise. I won't spoil it for others but I will say that the Arkham Knight reveal is such a let down, the side missions are mostly boring but there is a couple I like, there's a side mission where you have to fight Firefly and the one where you learn about Azraels backstory is cool, but its still a let down. At least Catwoman offers you "Special Hugging Time" ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)So if I had to review this game honestly it would be a 6 out of 10, buy it when the Steam Winter Sale or Steam Summer Sale rolls around, but it's not worth $50. I got the game for free with my GTX 980.What a let down for the end of a great series.....

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This game isn't a masterpiece, but is is close to being one. This is had a lot of technical error upon its release; however, they have been resolved. Although, don't be shocked if you aren't able to run it at a stable fps if your gpu isn't at least as powerful as a 750ti. This is an exquisite game with impressive rain, smoke, and shadow effects. As long as you have a gtx 970 and an I5, you should be able to max it out. You might be able to get away with an I3, but I don't own one to test. Nonetheless, this game is a steal at its current price of only 30 dollars; I'd give the game a 7/10. I am removing 3 points for the sometimes clunky batmobile combat, Arkham Knight's character, and the fact that Gotham is abandoned once again.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
Let me preface this by saying that I'm not recommending the game in its current state. When roughly a third of players can get the game running in the first place and an even smaller subset can have it working pretty well, there's a massive problem. WB is attempting to fix the problem, but the fix certainly hasn't been quick and current players get nothing for their troubles.That being said, I'm one of the lucky few that's been able to play this game with very few hiccups. There's a pretty big memory leak somewhere on Founder's Island that causes me to have to restart every 20 minutes or so, but that's the main problem I've been dealing with. I can also only play the game on low graphics settings, which is ridiculous. I don't have the greatest rig in the world, but I expected to be able to play with higher settings. I'll note my specs at the end of this review for anyone curious if they can play.As far as the gameplay itself is concerned, I actually like it a lot. Many people have complained that you're spending most of your time in the Batmobile, but it's about 50/50 for me and I like it that way. It's a nice change from previous games without completely changing everything. The actual fighting is the same as I've seen in Asylum and City, which is a big plus in my book. There are some new enemy types to keep it interesting, but they're not really common until the later parts of the game.The story itself isn't super spectacular and was very predictable in parts, but that's what I've grown to expect from these games. Anyone with knowledge of the lore will figure out what's happening pretty quickly, but the game is still very accessible to someone who's never picked up a comic book. I was very happy to see that Robin and Nightwing had decent roles in this one as compared to the previous games, which was actually what led me to get the game in the first place. I would've liked to see more with them, but it was better than nothing. It was also nice to see a lot of lesser-used villains. I admit, I'm not the most up-to-date on my lore, so a lot of the villains were new to me. It was a nice change from seeing characters like the Mad Hatter.Overall, I'm pretty happy with this game. I would not have paid full price for it (I got it free with a new video card), but it's something I probably would've picked up eventually anyway. Now if only WB could pick up the pace and patch it so everyone can enjoy it.For the curious, my specs:GPU: GTX 970CPU: Intel Core i5-3570K @ 3.4 GHzMemory: 8 GBOS: Windows 7 Home PremiumGame resolution: 1920 x 1200FPS: Usually 25-40; some cutscenes are 60+

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Just started a new game on a fresh install of the "re-release" version of Batman: Arkham Knight. I thought everything was going pretty good, 60 fps with slight dips, couple of cutscenes ran at 30 fps but I had v-sync on. Turned off v-sync, pretty stable 60 fps while I'm gliding around and fighting baddies. You can only play Batman the way you want for so long though. The inevitable Batmobile introduction is the first mission of the game. The moment it appears on screen, as if the game mechanic itself is sucking up enough processing power to run an entire second instance of any of the other Arkham games, my fps drops to 30-40. Now the game wants me to follow some high speed police chase around tight corners and turns in the ♥♥♥♥♥iest controlled vehicle of all time while throwing you constant "slow motion" esque stuttering. Luckily the chase lasts only a minute before you can get out of the damn thing. I go knock out another baddie, interrogate a soldier, knock his♥♥♥♥♥out too and then go back to being Bats. But then I see it. The Batmobile in all it's performance draining glory. Just looking at the ♥♥♥♥ing thing drops my fps to a stutering 36-42 fps range. Walking to the left or right until the Batmobile is just off screen renews my 60 fps lock. Walking up to it again to appreciate it's muddy texture and weird blurring effect again drops my frame rate to stuttering mess. It's really quite something. Not since the first release of this game have I so quickly reached for Alt+F4.On the plus side, I have successfully launched the game a handful of times to re-configure settings and run the benchmark tool and it has not yet crashed on me which is a great improvement from the original release, which would only launch about 50% of the time.1920 x 1200 @ 60 Hz LockAll High Settings w/ Motion Blur and Chromatic Abberation OffNVIDIA Gameworks Interactive Paper and Debris and Enhanced Rain EnabledWindows 10 Pro 64-biti7 3930K @ 4.2 GHzGTX 970 @ 1475 MHz16 GB DDR3 RAM @ 1600 MHzCrucial BX100 500 GB SSD

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												First and foremost the publisher of this game did a terrible job communicating updates to SEVERE problems with the launch version of this game. I pre-ordered this game's digital deluxe version which included the season pass and some pre-order exclusive features. The game initially ran ok for me but then all of that changed with the 1st "UPDATE" WB released. This update fixed the same for some people and broke the game for many others. At this point in time they took the game off the store, disabled all DLC and pre-order content and released a statement every 30 days until finally releasing the DLC and a full "PATCH" last week. This patch didn't actually fix anything and the game is extremely broken. The now 4 month DLC was released finally but took less than 2 hours to complete it all. Hardly what I was expecting from a $30 season pass. WB has now finally admitted the game is broken and there are certain things they will never be able to fix. They are offering full refunds to anyone that has purchased the game. I just submitted for a full refund. Maybe in the future after this game has had a few more updates and it drops in price I'll give it another shot. Until then I'd avoid this game like the plague.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												At the time of release, I can't really recommend this game.The game is fps locked to 30 fps (can be unlocked from ini configuration file), but the bigotry towards pc gaming doesn't stop there. Graphics options are very limited including anti-aliasing only having the option to turn it on or off.No option to turn off motion blur (which I ♥♥♥♥ing hate in games in general) or depth of field. You can turn these off from the ini configuration file but that just causes my game to crash instantly when the game enters main menu on startup.And performance is a total mess at the moment (i7-4770k @ 4,3ghz + Titan X SLi @ 4k resolution gets me performance of 15-70fps depending on the sli usage). Also the most atrocious offender is Batmobile, I rarely get over 25fps when driving around in the city (usually around 15-25fps).Otherwise the game has felt great, but the performance issues are currently ruining the game for many players.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Ugly, broken, inconsistent, and unreliable. These are not the words I expected to use when describing Arkham Knight "the epic conclusion to the Arkham series". Never have I seen such a bad port of a game with so much potential. Rocksteady have royally screwed over their PC players and I've officially lost all faith in the developer. I can only hope that they fix Arkham Knight in the days to come, but I wouldn't be surprised if they didn't.At least we have Arkham Origins (definitely not something I ever thought I'd say).AFTER SEPTEMBER 3rd UPDATE:This patch has fixed technical issues for me, and I've managed to get a stable frame rate of 45-60fps on my 770. However the game is still poorly optimised. I shouldn't need 3GB of Vram to play with normal textures. Technical issues aside, this is an amazing game. Rocksteady have gone above and beyond to create a worthy sequel to their last Batman game, Arkham City. The scale of Gotham is now huge, with proper skycrapers and convenient "enhaneced" mobility across the city. Which basically means your grappel will throw you 100 metres into the air instead of 20 metres. That mobility also has the added feature of the Batmobile, which I regard as one of the coolest gameplay features in recent years. The Batmobile extends gameplay options beyond my expectations for the series. I've never had so much fun driving something. It's fast and easy to control with a seriously enjoyable tank mode for combat against new enemies.The story is spot on, as usual with the Arkham series. Full of plenty of Villains from previous games, and even some new ones. The twists and turns of Arkham Knight left me gripped and always wanting to know more. I found myself glued to the game for 3 hours straight (a serious amount of time for a single gaming session for me). Safe to say that the ending was shocking, and the best in the series yet.I also need to mention the incredible graphics. Although I've already stated the poor optimization, the game looks amazing. I've never seen more realistic rain effects, or even lighting for that matter. It captures a very specific atmosphere that only belongs in a Batman game. The sound design is also worth mentioning. Unlike the previous Arkham games, Arkham Knight has more robust sounds, and this really helps to bring the game to life. Which is great.Overall, I've really enjoyed this post patch Arkham Knight. It still has some minor optimisation issues, but is perfectly playable on a 2GB card. Now to conclude, the positives of this game are very strong, BUT I can't bring myself to forgive Rocksteady for the awful launch. We've received no form of compensation for playing the game 2 months after the official release. For that reason, my review will stay negative unless Rocksteady decide to have a change of heart.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I loved this game sooo much. The combat is the same as the last games (combos actually seem easier to pull off), the story is intriguing, the side missions add a lot of exploration to the game, and the graphics are somewhat nice. However, as everyone has said by now, there are too many bugs and issues with the PC version of the game. Driving in the Batmobile just ruins the frame rate, and when you get the game, it's locked at 30fps. With a little changing of the coding, the frame rate can run however high you desire, but that doesn't mean you'll be able to hit however high you set it. Absolutely awful optimization on Rocksteady's part. Also, don't even try running the game on an AMD card, it won't end well at all.Intel Core i7-4790kGeForce GTX 97016 GB RAM^That won't keep it at a constant frame rate...yeah. :(

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												I finally got around to playing through this game after picking it up on sale with all the DLC for around thirty bucks. I've been a big fan of the Arkham games since the first one. I was both excited and hesitant to try out this title, given the...issues that existed with the PC release when it first came out. Kind of scary that a game was so bad they stopped selling it for a while, right?So let's talk about mechanics.Well, fortunately it seems that they have fixed their technical issues. I didn't have a single crash during my thirty-seven hour playthrough of this title, and the biggest glitch I had was an enemy clipping into the ground when I interrogated them for Riddler's secrets. That's it. Everything else ran smoothly the entire time.The mechanics have remained more or less the same since the first game, with simple additions and simplifications. Strike, counter, gadget. The enemies are essentially the same, normal thugs, brutes, shields, guns, stun sticks. Now the normal guys can do a charge attack that can't be countered with a right click, which makes them slightly more interesting. You can still counter the charge with a quick batarang, but if they're coming from off-screen, they can get too close and mess up a good combo pretty easily. The main addition to this game, enemy-wise, is the medic. They can wander around the battlefield and pick up enemies you've already knocked out, which can make predator encounters a lot more irritating. They can also give enemies a shock-buff that zaps you if you try to hit an enemy with it. A neat enough addition to the enemy roster.The big thing in this game, obviously, is the addition of the Batmobile. And yes, it is awesome. You feel powerful driving around in a tank, blasting holes in everything, and taking down enemies. Dudes on foot can be dealt with by running into them (which shocks them instead of smooshing them, which can be entertaining to watch) or blasting with your gun, which becomes nonlethal when an enemy enters the crosshairs. The tank battles are also a lot of fun, with you zipping around the battlefield lining up shots on enemy drones, which come in a few different flavours. Missile launchers, helicopters, and enemy tanks that range from small and weak to big scary robots that can only be approached from behind. The Batmobile handles well, feels fun, and has its own gadgets and boss battles.The riddler trophies and mechanics are also generally the same. Stand on switch, throw batarangs at targets, but of course there are new challenges based on your new gadgets, and trophies which require the car to handle. There were a few times I was briefly stumped while trying to solve a trophy, including one embarassing time where I spent around fifteen minutes flying remote batarangs around looking for an electrical current before remembering that I had a gun that literally shoots electricity. Not my finest moment.So that's mechanics talk, let's delve briefly into the story now. I'll start out spoiler-free and jump into spoilery stuff at the very end.The big bads this time around are Scarecrow, who has gotten creepier since we last saw him in the first game, and the mysterious Arkham Knight. I say mysterious, but his identity is honestly pretty obvious. If you read the comics, or watch any of the animated films, you know who it is. Regardless, even knowing his identity he makes a decent enough villain and counter to you as Batman. The story itself was decent enough, with you traversing the city, fighting dudes, and trying to put a stop to a number of nefarious plans. Won't go into detail for now, to keep it spoiler-free.A number of other big enemies crop up now and then, either part of the main story or having their own crime spree in Gotham. Even more are added in DLC, which works very well. If you have the DLC, you just need to be a certain percentage of the way through the main story, and the extra villains will appear with their own self-contained stories. Ra's al Ghul, Killer Croc, Mad Hatter, Mr. Freeze, they all pop up briefly to be beaten up and/or helped. Plus the villains in the base game, including Penguin, Two-Face, Poison Ivy, Harley Quinn. Some big names were missing, like Bane and Deadshot, but ah well.The DLC's didn't really add all that much, just a few extra villain stories, and a few completely self-contained stories that are accessed directly through the starting menu. Not much content, mostly just extra-sized challenge maps with a small amount of story. They range from having only a few fights and/or predator encounters to having a solid half a dozen in Batgirl's story. Nothing big here, but I did enjoy playing as the various characters. Nightwing is as adorable and hilarious as always. No surprise there.Aight, spoiler time. Anything below is SPOILERS.So first off, the Arkham Knight is obviously Jason Todd, second and potentially most obnoxious of the Robins, though Damian Wayne puts up solid competition. It's hinted a few times throughout the story, but it's no big surprise. Most fans called it before the game came out, there was even a whole animated film about him coming back and fighting crime in a violent and murderous way. He was a good anti-Batman, though, as most of the villains are kind of old hat at this point.I think the big twist this time was the Joker stuff. Following the events of Arkham City, with Joker's death (no he apparently did not evade death, despite what many fan theories claimed after AC) and Batman being injected with the joker toxin. Turns out, even the vaunted Lazarus Pit was not enough to stop the disease, which infected Batman and a handful of others who managed to get the Joker's blood before or despite the warning and recall in AC when it was discovered. And this was my favourite part of the entire game. After getting blasted with Joker's fear gas in an early attempt to stop him, the virus manifests as your own personal Joker hallucination that sticks with you for the rest of the game. It is -awesome-. Having Mark Hamill in your head as your own personal Joker that only you can see and hear, to sass you for the rest of the story? I wasn't expecting any Joker at all in this game, and instead he's everywhere I look, full of one-liners and hilarious commentary. Absolutely fantastic.The other big story thing was Barbara Gordon's death. Psyyyych, in a twist that surprises nobody, she's not dead, it was just a fear gas hallucination. All in all, I think Barbara Gordon was my biggest issue with this game. Not her ersatz death or anything, no. My issue was that in this game she was romantically paired up with Tim Drake, even marrying him after the story events took place, referenced in the DLC. Tim Drake, Babs? Really? WAY TO BREAK NIGHTWING'S HEART.Aside from that, good game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I'm really glad I waited for a sale to buy this one. I played a lot of both Arkham Asylum and City on PS3 and was quite sad with the PC release of Arkham Knight. The game is playable now, getting a solid experience with a i5 4440/GTX 970, only with minor stuttering here and there when driving the batmobile, nothing as atrocious as the release state. So far I feel like the story is as good as previous Arkham games, but i feels like it's a lot darker, the storytelling so far is amazing and extremely immersive. The batmobile is a great new addition, although it might feel repetitive for some. The characters/enemies are better introduced and really feel like a real threat to Batman.It's not as innovative as the previous, the combat is basically the same, but the new gadgets and moves are incredible, the animations are top notch, which doesn't let it feel repetitive for those who played the previous games. Can't wait to see how the story will develop, Rocksteady really put they heart into it.TL:DR: Performance is extremely improved, not 30fps locked, great graphics costumization. incredible story and gameplay, really worth the sale price.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												Don't let the horrendous PC release ruin this game for you. Now as of June 2016 the game is largely fixed and runs and looks beautiful. There are still occasional popins on objects in the distance even with maximum draw distance, but this is not a problem only this game suffers from. The story is fantastic, Scarecrow is a fantastic main villain and the theming of how his fear toxin affect Batman and the psychological effects of it are thrilling. For those of you worried about the fact that the Joker isn't in this game, you won't miss him, trust me. The only hitch in the story is the main twist is pretty heavy handed if you haven't read the comics and completely non-existant if you have. Without spoiling anything I will just say, there are no original characters in the Arkham games, the Arkham Knight is no exception. However the implimentation of the story of the Arkham Knight in relation to the rest of the canon is still beautifully handled and still has plenty of excellent drama. We all just know who he is already. The gameplay is over-all even better than Arkham City with more gadgets to play with, better and faster traversal on foot and flying as the Batman. Gliding around all of Gotham is fantastic and the city is beautiful from all angles with plenty of visual and audio cues for you to clearly know where missions are without map markers cluttering everything, a massive bonus for immersion. The batmobile is a welcome adiition in all ways but one. . . the Riddler has taken an interesting new profession since the last two games. Instead of building puzzles that challenge the player mentally now he just builds horrible race tracks for the batmobile. This is the most inexcusable shoe-horning of a new mechanic I think I have ever seen and since Rocksteady did such an amazing job of implementing the Riddler in past games that makes it even more inexcusable. You will hate these missions, especially if you want to 100% this game. A positive thing they added was that the motivation for beating the Riddler is more apparent than just the player's own boredom or the gamey goal of 100%. But this excellent motivation does not take away from how bad the missions are so no free pass Rocksteady. These two problems are the only thing holding this game back from being the best in the whole series. It is an excellent conclusion to the trilogy and if you enjoyed Asylum and City, I highly urge you to pick up Knight especially at its new reduced price.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I am currently in the very large group of players that had bought this game 'after' release.   I didn't pre-order, but as i'd really enjoyed every other game in the series figured this one would be a sure bet winner in my game collection.   I was wrong.   The FPS cap, whilst the ini file tip was useful, did not improve the game enough to cure the stuttering and pauses, and what looked to me as though the game was not making use of the AMD gpu that i have installed which has 4gb of memory on board too.  No other game in my collection behaves like this, and i have many, so this game stands out by a mile as though it has been badly made.. its how it seems, just can't give it a thumbs up with so many negatives dragging it down.  I'll wait for a patch sure i will, but this does not change one simple fact.. that on average you can EXPECT a big proportion of gamers to have an AMD card, so to blindly ignore the manufacturer and just seemingly optimise for nvidia was a huge gamble that has brought this debacle to market.   I sincerly hope that the work by the software engineers turns this around because if it doesn't.. then this will be a customer lost.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												After an outcry of bad reviews, media and refunds. They realised they had to do something and couldn't get away with it, why? because they were losing money, not because they care. Firstly, before the game was out they said that people that bought a select GPU, GTX 970/980 etc, would get this game for free thanks to a promotional deal with Nvidia, as they often do for big upcoming titles, and that you would also get the pre-order bonus. Which they decided to change their minds on last second before the game was released "Oh you don't get this pre-order bonus now, you have to pay for it" not to mention that DLC, pre-order bonuses or anything of the like being announced/there before the main game is even released is ridiculous and is just content that could have been in the main game itself, but they realise it is something they can cut out and make money on. WB knew that the game was in a terrible state for PC months and months before the game was released, but once again, didn't care, it's the PC market. The PC PORT of the game was outsourced to Iron Galaxy Studios, a smaller game developer rather than the one that everyone thought was doing it, and was promoted as being the developer, Rocksteady. So the PC market got the worse end of the stick with a lack of attention.When the game first released, it was a huge mess, there were freezes, stuttering and all sorts of performance issues all over the place, I remember my game actually reaching up to 14GB of ram usage which is pretty ridiculous considering what the game is, and that was with an i7 4930k at 4.5Ghz and two Gtx 970's at 1.35Ghz, it was not about the computer not being able to handle the game, because it can handle a lot better than this, at some points it would be fine and I would be around or over 100 frames at 2560x1440p, even in fighting situations or running around, but then randomly it would decide it wants to run like crap, stutter, freeze and crash, or just play at below 30fps for no reason at all. Since the updates it has been a bit better, it doesn't use as much ram, around 6-8GB now most of the time, and the FPS drops seem to be mostly gone, and there is no more stuttering, freezing or crashing, but I am not getting as high as I use to. They made promises over and over that they would fix the game and admitted to what a mess it was after they started getting such bad reviews and losing money, they said they would fix SLI and continue to optimize the game, but after a while they said they "can't" fix everything and decided that they are not going to fix SLI because, well they don't care and it's not in their biggest interest money wise. Generally WB have behaved♥♥♥♥♥♥poor with this game, maybe if they didn't outsource to a smaller developer to handle the PC version of the game, most of these issues would not be a problem, but alas they are. On another note, I would say if you've played one WB game, then you can probably expect the others to be very similar. Batman, Mad Max, Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor all feel pretty much the same to me, just different skins. The controls are nearly identical, the enemies are pretty much the same with different skins, and it has the same mindless "side missions" 'collect this' 'collect that' 'do this' 'do that' over and over. Even the maps seems pretty darn similar.I might finish this game eventually just because I own it and got it for free, but would I recommend it to anyone for them to buy it? no. Not unless it was on a 60-75%+ sale, even then I would feel somewhat bitter about supporting WB.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Knight... Oh boy.I held back on the game for over a year because of the problems it had on PC. I really despise the fact that we get more and more butchered ports since the PC, although being more difficult and more expensive to program a game for, offers many possibilities that consoles don't and vice versa. A game should therefore be ported in a way that it utilizes these by porting it properly. Arkham Knight was not ported propery to PC, that can be said without a doubt. I don't think I have to go over what happened, let's just recap the state of the game since Rocksteady stopped patching it a long time ago.Yes, it is playable now, so that's a plus. Yes, it doesn't crash often (2-3 times a playthrough for me) but on the other hand the other two Arkham games NEVER crashed for me. No, the problems with the FPS drops and the texture loading were never fully resolved. The game looks amazing but especially in the Batmobile and even on the best PCs it is possible that you get FPS drops and textures sometimes pop into sharpness only as you're standing right next to them. This is on a modern gaming rig that can run the Witcher 3 on Ultra without issues, I don't want to imagine how the game acts when you don't have the surplus of processing power.So there I was, prepared to never buy this game simply to make a point that I will not pay 29,99€ for a game which Rocksteady already stopped patching a long time ago. I will especially not pay 49,99€ for the game plus its season pass as some of the DLCs are very short and don't offer much.Then another provider offered a Steam Key Sale and I got the Premium Edition of Arkham Knight for 19,99€The game concludes the story from the previous games in a brilliant and epic fashion. You again get the feeling that you are the Batman, but this time things are different. Gotham City was evacuated and it is basically civil war in the streets. The police can barely keep themselves alive as the streets are filled with thugs and Militia since this time one of your adversaries brings his own paramilitary with him. New enemies, new attacks and all in all almost no encounter puts you against less than ten people. So again your new gadgets are welcome as they give you new ways to deal with the overwhelming enemies. Batman gets a new suit, for example, which gives him the ability to take out three (five if upgraded) enemies in quick succession at the beginning of a fight, but because there are so many of them that never feels overpowered.Probably the biggest addition, however, is the Batmobile. You can now fly over the rooftops or drive on the ground in your very own tank. There are parts where you will have to use it to fight against other tanks or solve puzzles as well. Personally, I didn't think that that got repetitive but I can see how others might feel that way since these parts can go on for a while.It's open world again and some of the sidequests, especially the ones against the Militia are a bit too much. You will take out A LOT of militia roadblocks, towers and mines in this game. All in all, however, it provides a good mix and most of the sidequests offer something interesting. And I'm not even talking about the hundreds of Riddler trophies!Arkham Knight is more grim than the other Arkham games because of the story and the setting. This is the night the Batman died after all. Unlikely alliances, lost friends, very disturbing screw-ups with the main character's mind and the general feeling that for the first time you might not be able to stop the bad guys is what makes this game so unique. It just has a certain epicness that keeps you longing for more.So, again a great game for everyone on console and a must-have for Batman fans. On PC however, you better make sure you have some spare processing power. Even then it is really difficult to recommend it for 49,99€ (the Premium Edition, because let's be honest, although the DLCs are weak we still want to play them) since Rocksteady basically decided to abandon the patching of this game while still bringing out new DLC. When on a sale this game is worth every penny, though.

Posted: March 17, 2016
												Game ran like utter poop on launch, averaging at around 30 fps and frequent drops to 15 fps. I could live with the 30 fps as I once was a console peasant, but the drops killed the game for me and remained untouched until just recently (16. March 2016). And I am happy to inform everybody who happens to read this review that the game is actually performing very, very well on my setup now. I went from the 30 fps to now lay at around 60 fps (Locked to 60 fps max in settings) stable with a occational drop to 48-52 fps when♥♥♥♥♥♥is just going bat crazy. Also no crashes.The game on it own when not taking the technical issues into the mix, is really good. The story is engaging, the banter from the villans is geniounly funny and Joker is totally killing it,♥♥♥♥♥♥if I could have had my own personal joker inside my mind I would have loved it. The graphics and the presentation overall is very nice, soundmix is top notch too. I personally loved the Batmobile missions but the camera can be a little wonky on it. So yeah I recommend the game but be cautious as some people are still experiencing crashes and god awful performance.Oh and ♥♥♥♥ the Riddler and his stupid trophies.My setup (for those interested):AMD FX-8350Nvidia GeForce 98016 GB rametc etc

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												This game, while probably very good, is a slap in the face to every PC gamer out there.This came out as one of the worst, if not THE worst optimized-for-PC game ever 4 months ago. So bad, even, that they recalled the PC version until today, just so they could do what they should have done before releasing this travesty.Now, 4 months later, they re-release the game, promising sunshine and daisies, and this disaster of a port runs even WORSE than it did before the recall.Before the recall, I could actually play the game somewhat decently, after tweaking some config files. I was one of the few who could, miraculously. It still stuttered like a madman, textures would pop in and out randomly, and all that, but it was (borderline) playable.Now, however, the game refuses to start half the time. The other half, I have to tweak every graphical setting separately and reboot the game, praying it'll start up again. Otherwise, the game can and will crash. After setting up all the settings, the game looks absolutely horrendous, with practically every texture refusing to load in properly, and all I get instead, are blotted messes that have to pass for whatever it's supposed to be. Even on the highest settings, the textures simply refuse to load in properly. The game looks like a late PS2 title now. I'm not even kidding.Avoid this turd of a port AT ALL COSTS. Get the console version and enjoy the actual game.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9
												Batman Arkham Knight is the 4th and final title in the Batman Arkham franchise action-adventure series that follows Batman through Gotham. I had a lot of skepticism playing this game because all I read were bad reviews from every PC user bashing the game because of the horrible launch that had a plethora of glitches and technical issues with unoptimized performance problems. Locking FPS at 30, crashes, lack of rain shader/ambient occlusion/AA/antisotropic filtering etc etc. I've never myself experienced any of these issues albeit I did play this game a year and a half after it came to PC via port (Release date 6-23-15 vs my gameplay 3-13-17). I sport a pair of Nvidia 970 GTX Sli'd and I don't have a single issue playing the game.Graphics:The plus side of the high-spec card is that the graphics are amazing. It has a certain cinematic authenticity to it, a movie level gloss and immersion that takes you directly into the game and makes you feel like you're truly in Gotham. From the smallest dust particle to the sweeping bridges and skyscrapers, Gotham City truly feels alive. Every crack in the sidewalk, every fierce tattoo, each choppy wave, an craggy wrinkle tells a story that makes you want to know more. The people may not be as attractive as in previous installments, but they are more realistic, and they truly have character. The devs have introduced a photo mode, where you can pause the game and do a nearly 360-degree rotation to get just the perfect shot. Just use the Steam shortcut you set up (F12 default) to take screens, and it removes the ugly interface when you take the shot.Gameplay:They added the Batmobile! What a great addition to the series! Not only can you zoom around Gotham City like a boss, you can destroy half the city as you go! I had great fun running down criminals, blowing up cars, knocking down trees, fences, support pillars, you get the idea. It's basically a fast tank, and it acts like one. In addition to a new form of transportation, we have a great many quests, riddles, and fights to win using the Batmobile, which is not only a car, but a BATTLEmoblie! At the touch of a button we can transform it to a highly-maneuverable tank in order to destroy. We can even do Batmobile-assisted takedowns with Wayne's patented non-lethal rounds. "It's like being punched in the chest by an angry gorilla!"As far as manuverability the game itself feels so much more fluid, totally engaging and immersing you into the gameplay from being able to fly and grapple across the world. It feels so big yet so small at the same time, it's a huge map but everything is accessable easily and quickly.Combat:As usual for the series, combat starts off deceptively easy, then amps up in difficulty as you progress. We have the new Fear Multi-takedown ability, which enables you to take out up to six enemies within seconds, provided that you can come upon the group by surprise. There are also points in the story where you can play two characters at once, and during this time you can do multi-character takedowns, one of the more fun parts of the combat system.Story:When the game started, I felt that the side missions were much more engrossing than the main storyline. I went through the game knowing not only exactly who our mystery assailant was, but why we were being attacked. Absolutely positive right up to the moment of the unmasking, and then, everything changed. That which had been mildly interesting was suddenly fascinating. My mental shift was profound, as far as such things go, and it pulled me into the story in ways I had never considered. Although one aspect of the story I had totally nailed, there were several real surprises throughout, something which I really cherish. A good story is something that I truly appreciate, but you have a good story with great gameplay. They also do a great job of including the rest of the villianous roster to the game that they previously left out.Pros:+ Amazing level of detail, environmentally and graphically on characters+ Each character is unique with the exception of the occasional thug+ Fluid gameplay+ Hours of exploration and more riddler quests to keep you engaged to 100%, doesn't feel too tedious though you may want to use a guide or youtube+ Introduced Batmobile and all the glory that comes with it+ Interesting and engaging plotCons:- A little repetitive to get the 100% ending- A little frustrating to get certain challenges done, but then again, it is a CHALLENGETL;DR9/10Great graphics, good plot, good combat. I had 0 issues with graphics. Tedious to get 100% ending but definitely doable. I'd say it was the best of the 4 in the Arkham series imo.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												I'll preface this review by saying I never had any performance issues. I know this game released with severe optimization problems for a lot of people. My review comes from just playing the game with minimal bugs and glitches.I loved the Arkham series. Arkham Asylum was so cool that it is literally the only game I completed 100%. Arkham City my first play through was lackluster, but probably because I just invested so much time into Asylum and was burnt out. My second play of City was amazing and it is an amazing game.Arkham Knight is boring. I bought it on the PC and could barely put any time into it. I saw it go on sale for the PS4 and decided to pick it up again. I was once again faced with the same issues. A game that had no interesting concepts. The developers really focused on the bat mobile. It is not fun to use, interesting or that different. It's basically drive around in a city that's way too small for a giant vehicle or enter combat mode and shoot AI tanks over and over again until you're done. There's no strategy to it. You don't feel like you're accomplishing anything other than it being over.The story lacks as well. It's hard to find any motivation for Batman except he's Batman and he has to stop the criminals. I felt like I just didn't care. I was just punching some dudes, then the robot Arkham Knight shows up and then I have to track him down too. That's really the entire story. There's no tension. The game looks great and ran well for me. I'm sure at this point, the game is running fine for most people. The only thing this game accomplished is that it made me want to go back and play the last two games. This game has no soul.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												The gameplay is fun (even though I suck at it - that takes some doing), the visuals are gorgeous, the story is good.But the program itself remains unstable.  As I've progressed through the main story, I have more and more frequently encountered random crashes to my desktop - even though my frames-per-second remain steady, and no graphical anomalies occur.And if it's this bad on PC still, in December ... I shudder and weep to think how horrible it must have been at launch.Add to that the lackluster DLC - seriously, the much-lauded one with Harley Quinn is like, two areas to fight through.  No character development, no sandbox area to roam about in, just ... two areas, some goons to fight, then a boss fight.  ::yawn::  Red Hood's DLC was the same deal....I will not be quick to buy another WB-published PC game in the future.  I honestly regret having spent more than $20 or $30 USD on the game (Premium Edition, no less!).  I'm not even at 60%, and I'm already giving up on it due to all the crashes ...  ::sigh::

												DO.NOT.BUY!One of the worst games I have ever played - sorry I mean "played". Seriously I was so hyped about the game, that I actually updated my hardware... for nothing as it seems. C'mon that is an insult. To every PC gamer out there who is still considering buying these games after reading about the disaster:Please don't!

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Even ignoring the major PC flaws, this was an underwhelming Batman experience. Boss battles were non existent and replaced by garbage tank sequences, even the battle with Deathstroke. Yes, that Deathstroke, the one with incredible martial arts skills and superhuman strength, is instead replaced with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batmobile fight, a copypaste of the atrocious Arkham Knight battle. The lack of challenge maps is extremely disappointing, but don't worry, soon a feature of the game that has been in every other game in the series will be paid DLC! Even then, the 2 character DLC's are 20 minutes at best, and even though they are advertised as "Campaigns", what they mean is that they are a bunch of sequenced challenge maps (that you cannot pick and choose). The story is mediocre at best, most likely due to the absence of Paul Dini, who has been a staple of the series (and Batman for that matter). The side missions are maybe the worst I have ever seen in a video game. Besides the cool Professor Pyg quest, and the Man-Bat jumpscare, they can be summed up in 5 words. Go here, trigger event, repeat, with seemingly no difference between each stage. Hush is relegated to a quicktime event, and firefly's is so laughably copy pasted on each stage of the mission you'll swear you are doing the same thing over again which-hint-YOU ARE. Another mission, featuring Deacon Blackfire, doesn't even try to hide it's low quality. You literally fight a group of enemies, and a cutscene triggers. I'm not joking. That's the end of the quest. The easter eggs Rocksteady has lovingly put into the game is a nice touch, but I find myself playing Origins more than this, not just because of the horrible framerate drops. It saddens me to see such a fantastic franchise end with a fizzle, rather than a well deserved bang.UPDATED AS OF APRIL 23RD:I returned to this game after many months of it sitting uninstalled in my library, and decided to give it another shot. Nothing could fix the poor story, but Rocksteady has added character select and fixed many of the performance issues. The riddler challenges were fun and sometimes difficult, but more riddles would have been appreciated. As for the DLC, I also bought the season pass for cheap. The character story packs are nothing more than strung together challenge maps, but A Matter of Family was surprisingly good and about 2 hours long. The skins and batmobiles are always welcome and fun to use. I am keeping the review to a not recommend, but  if you can get it for cheap, its a good game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												First let me say that I have played every single arkham game and this one blows the rest of them out of the water! Sure it had a little bit of a rocky start but Rocksteady have been working vigorously to fix the multiple problems and have rewarded all of it's customers who didn't get a refund with ALL the prior titles for free. I mean how many of the Assassin's Creeds have had some graphical issues? And I don't see any of their customers receiving free games. Before Rocksteady came along all we had were Batman The Animated Series and various movie title games. This company revolutionised the super hero game and still no other company have been able to replicate the experience with any number of other characters at their disposal.You're in a sandbox world. Multiple missions, gadgets, and costumes. You have a weaponised car which can turn into a tank. You can glide so well it's almost like you're flying. The story is beautiful, the graphics are beautiful, and Rocksteady are still releasing new story dlc with different villians not included in the base game six months down the line!Don't believe what others tell you if you're a fan of comic books, sand box games, in depth story lines, racing round streets in a jet powered car, excellent combat and stealth. You'll love this game!

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												When Batman: Arkham Knight first released, I was hesitant after hearing so many problems being shared with the game that I didn't install the game for a long period of time. Come time to play, I only experienced minor lagging and after a few updates there were no more issues in the performance department. Nevertheless, the wait was worth it! Batman: Arkham Knight has everything you could have asked for with the colossal and dark Gotham City. The Batmobile is integral to the majority of the game but I'd say it struck the balance between gliding and driving just right (besides, those combat sequences in Battle Mode are a lot of fun and break up travel, and never unnecessarily). The Gotham City Police Department is the Batman's rock in this game where Commissioner James Gordon's character steps into the spotlight the most out of the rest of his appearances in the series. Nods to the previous titles involving certain villains are made and some new faces will come as a surprise. The beginning is eerie and the graphics throughout the game are the best I've seen in a superhero game. Batman: Arkham Knight dwells on the the theme of fear and shows us that fear in many ways isn't a weakness at all. It's the only thing that keeps us wary, not weary. In being aware, we're not really afraid at all, not even of who we are and what we've come to be. Batman: Arkham Knight may not be the best superhero game but there's no reason not to settle for being one of the greatest in a series of great superhero games.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												The problems with this game go far beyond the technical BUT since thats alread a dead horse...OBVIOUSLY SPOILERS!So yes this is review #2, something was bothering me after the game ended.  As a batman fan of old it was a deja’vu if you will, and no it wasn’t Under the hood or death in the family.  I had seen this story before, where mere mention of this person’s name makes bat-fans shiver in♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥chills as bat-nipples and bat-credit cards with bat butt-clenches in a neon black light lit Gotham city flood one’s mind.  AK has the same story to the sequel to Schumacher Batman and Robin. Batman Triumphant. THAT’S how uncreative the plot in this game is…well adding to the uncreatively of this game. Think I’m ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting? Google it.  The review will still be here.No? Ok FINE... its plot was going to be how batman is poisoned by scarecrow which causes him to see dead joker and a Harley who was looking revenge for the joker…sound familiar?  On top of the other issues both techinical and design pushed me from yes to no. The game is fun, well at first.  Hamill as the joker and Conroy as Batman is great and those two things I would say when the eventual “GOTY” edition comes out with all the DLCs and it’s a steam seasonal sale or franchise sale OR a 3rd party site is having it CHEAP then go for it but…leave your expectations low.See the problem is it’s “front-loaded”. What I mean by that is this, the combat is a bit more fluid as is grappling around the city, but then it becomes to get too much SSDD.  All the side missions are fun at first but they just end up being repeating the same things over and over be it rescuing fire fighters, chasing firefly, stopping two face, stopping weapon shipments, clearing militia stuff untill you hit 100%..every single one of them, IF they even bothered to put that much effort into it.It’s so bad that when the Arkham Knight is taken out of the equation he was barely in and Death Stroke is put in, it’s the same tank boss battle after the same “save Gotham from the militia that doesn’t even care or notice their boss ditched them”.  Two different characters with the same tank "boss battle".And those are the “deep” ones by comparison.  You then get hush and Deacon Blackfire.  Hush is “oh no something happened to Lucius fox. Push button. Watch small cut scene. ENTIRE most wanted finished.  Blackfire is so out of place it’s not even funny, it opens for me when batman was going to “confront” the scarecrow.  It made no sense and all it was, was, beat up these thugs you’ve spent the last 30+ hours beating up, push button entire most wanted line finished.  The AR challenges are more of the same♥♥♥♥♥♥you JUST did but for some leader board carrot on a stick.I was beginning to think that this was some meta game where the game was trying to drive you insane by repeating the same thing over and over expecting a different result, while the joker tries to break batman.   The only relief from monotony are the Riddler challenges, yet putting a real ending behind 100% and needing 243 was a cheap way to add “depth” and pad the length of this very shallow game.  Remember 2015 games have to be epic in length and have an “open” world.I wouldn’t think much of the side quests If the main quest was at least original or even interesting or didn’t end in the dumbest most annoyingly anti-climactic convoluted “wat?” ending.  For one it’s Batman Triumphant with the “Under the hood” red herring tossed in.  Secondly that climax..or lack of. So bad. So stupid and out of place.  I’d say it’s ME3 worthy.Let’s take the Arkham Knight, title antagonist, he’s an interesting one.  See if you’re a batman fan and who wouldn’t be playing a batman game?  You know who he is, it’s as much as a spoiler as rewatching ESB in 2015 and being shocked Vader is Luke’s daddy.  So he must be a shocker for people who aren’t familiar with the DCU or DCAU but just the Arkham Universe or DCMU..but wait.  Jason Todd is never mentioned or seen in the Arkham-verse till now so there’s no history with the player. Not that it matters, again the title antagonist is nothing more than the strong man from 80’s movies.  He’s Sven-Ole Thorsen of Ahnold movies, he’s odd job to Goldfinger, he’s the strong guy in indy movies, they even hit the trope of “Revenge ruins the bosses plans”.....ick…  So just more “These are batman things!!” fan serviceThen after about the 80% mark THE TITLE ANTAGONIST…disappears…out right is gone from the game no rhyme or reason only to pop back up in a “steroids made me deaf” moment.  Why? So they can shoe horn in another batvillian.  DeathStroke.  Ahh boss battles…I’ll get to that if I have room…if not what others said.Ok so yes the Scarecrow is the main villain, and you eventually have the final showdown.  Now this ending shows that who ever wrote this has zero understanding who batman is outside of swiping a failed sequel.Batman, aside from lacking any sort of detective skills or common sense in this game, the man so paranoid he has a contingency to take out his friends, it’s said he has a contingency plans for his contingency plans.  The Scarecrow has Robin and Gordon and the world’s most paranoid detective has…NOTHING.  NOT A DAMN THING! He literally just gives up to the scarecrow, then the game gets stupid.  The climax of the game is in batman’s head as you play as the joker to free batman from the jokers influence…for some reason.Guess killing the Joker wasn’t such a good idea huh?  Then batman is the biggest fan service quote it was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥chill inducing locks up the joker in his own head. So he’s still in there? I don’t know?  ME3 made more sense.   So crane who outted Bruce as bats injects Bruce with toxin 3 times but it has zero effect because…I don’t know? He did grunt a lot so I'll assume he farted it out? He's just suddenly immune to the toxin thats been plaguing him the ENTIRE game. He poisons scarecrow and punches him.  Now you know how Deathstroke, manbat, firefly, hush and penguin you at least got to push a button..NOPE the MAN ANATGONIST at the END OF THE GAME is defeated in a cut scene.  Then, it’s batman’s life work to make sure the city can survive without him, that Gotham doesn’t need a batman..it’s a central ♥♥♥♥ing theme to the character like the detective skills and contingency plans.  SO on his last night, the night he gives up he must think Gotham doesn’t need him anymore, so the 100% ending.  Gotham is no better than it was on that fateful night at crime alley and yes Gotham still needs a batman.  Batman’s sacrifice of just laying down and dying..for nothing.What ties this into a well tightly coiled cat turd, this is batman’s last night, the end of the arkham series.  “how the batman died” you would THINK they’re pull out all the stops which at this point is obvious they didn’t.  So you’d figure AT LEAST they’re pull from his the A-LIST rogues gallery..you know Bane, Grundy, Croc, Ra’s, Freeze, Black Mask, Clayface, Calendar Man, Dead Shot, Zsasz, Falcone family, Rupert Thorne♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥get obscure with Etrigan.Nope you get the most wanted to be seen and highly dangerous rogues with such a grand history with the dark knight such as…firefly, pyg, blackfire.  The 60’s TV show had a better line up of villians. They even got lazy with the fan service..that right there should say volumes about this game.I was bordering on yes and no with my first review leaning towards yes then in retrospect the laziness just snapped like the end of ususal suspects and right over to the no.  I’d say this game is a solid 5/10..not a bat fan and could give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about batman 7/10.Actually 3/10 just because WB:I’s further response to the PC port is deafening silence.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												The big one to end the Arkham trilogy, and boy, is it a cluttered mess of a PC port, it sufferes a lot ever since release as so much as to actually remove digital and physical copies of the PC version. I don't blame the PC port team, they were only a team of 17 with four weeks deadline. That's incredibly small for a game of this size, especially a AAA game that has a big budget as this. Poorly optimized with bad choices from left to right, this is a game almost comparable to the PC port of Mortal Kombat X, yep, still hate you, Mortal Kombat X. PROS- When playable,  a VERY good game, with a more weavey kind of combat, its a little enjoyable to see Batman zip across left and right like an annoying fly beating people up in the blink of an eye. Especially with the introduction of FEAR take downs, allowing you to surprise the enemy and render them unconcious while they are too busy PANICKING THE ♥♥♥♥ OUT. - Starts with more gadgets than before at the start of the game, a little sad some of the old gadgets didn't make it back, but I guess you gotta weed some of the fun toys out. - Lays out a very interesting plot hook at the very start, it wants you reel you in and invest you in the game. And boy, is the story good so far.- All of the voice actors are consistent through the entire trilogy, save for two characters. But that's pretty good still, considering this trilogy has been six years in the making.- The Batmobile is finally drivable! While I would like less focus on the Batmobile, its nice to finally be able to drive it after being teased in the 2009 Arkham Asylum. Its a speedster car that has a tank mode built in, and the upgrade route for it is interesting, although unfortunately all tied down to one type of resource bar.- Has loads of backup saves! Loads! More games need to have this, and I'm not talking about just the cloud save system.- Puzzles are well designed, the detective mode is expanded even more, putting the replay footage of Arkham Origins to good use for Batman to solve the mystery of the missing turnip.- The best looking version of the game, however...CONS- Poorly optimized for the PC release, you can only really play this on high end machines. The framerate cap is set to 30, and it takes noticable dips down to even the single digit range when using such things like the Batmobile, or even grappling to high places. Only high end PCs can handle it at this point, and that's only because its forcing it through with the power of money. - If you have good ears, you'll notice a certain character sounds familiar, but has a different face...causing me to find out the identity of the major antagonist quite early on. Its even spoiled in the character bio section! If you really want to preserve the surprise factor when the game reveals it to you, try to remain ignorant as best as you can.- Season pass is poorly done, parts of it is already being handed off to be done by a different development team, and that is a bad thing. The main game itself is good enough as it is, so unless you're REALLY into Batman and are okay with not the same level of polish, then by all means, go for it.- Whoever made all these Riddler trophies to collect to watch the true ending is a horrible person. They're sadistic.Long story short, this game is fantastic, its well polished, looks beautiful...but definitely not worth picking up until they fix it the PC port. It is definitely the best version of the three availible, its just needs to be fixed to be playable. And with a game this big of a budget? Boy, I hope you didn't pre-order this, because you got♥♥♥♥♥♥heaped at you for $60, WB Games is notorious for pushing out poorly optimized PC games time and time again.
