Disappointed	Frankly, I am disappointed with Arkham Knight, in comparison to City and Asylum, it does not reach expectations. Considering I AM a HUGE Batman fan, I'd expect Arkham Knight to exceed or be on par with City or Asylum, the story was decent and could still have been improved with some tweaks (Not spoiling anything). I'm going to delve into the pros and cons of the game. Pros:	-Decent Story-The BEST Batman/Joker Voice cast-The new fighting system (though I preffered AC's one)-The Open World is huge, leaving much room for exploration-Beautiful Graphics and a destructible environment (not recommended for those with a 2GB VRAM GPU as you    will face frame drops quite abit)-Ability to further upgrade the grapnel gun (WOO HOO)-Predator stuff is great as usual-New hacking mechanics Cons	-Overusage of the Batmobile, it gets boring most of the time-Tank battles (Heavy reliance on the Batmobile/Tank)-The Arkham Knight  Jason Todd... How original Rocksteady	-Deathstroke boss battle  A badass and he is A TANK BATTLE?!!?	-The writing is decent, but does not reach City or Asylum quality-The PC ♥♥♥♥♥torm that went down when it came out on PC-My GTX 760 2GB cannot run it without drops :( VERDICT:	How much would I rate it? 7.5/10Would I recommend this game? Yes I would, when it's on sale and if you have a good enough PCDo I like it? As a Batman Fan, I prefer City to this, but I think it would be a great game for the general consumer. It could have been improved in many ways thoughWhat are your thoughts? A great way to end the Arkham Trilogy, but it definitely did not blow my mind or anything like that JASON ♥♥♥♥ING TODD	 Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
"This, is how it happened. This is how the Batman died."Genre: Action Adventure, Open WorldYear of Release: 2015Developer: Rocksteady StudiosPresentationIt's no secret that Arkham Knight was nothing short of dumpster fire when it first launched on the PC. Months later after subsequent patching and fixes, does the game run any better? Well, yes, but not by much. The game still suffers from stuttering under certain settings and unless you have high-end hardware, this isn't going to be very playable for you. It's a shame considering the game looks exceptionally great, with detailed character models, lighting, and rain effects that surpass what was capable of its predecessors. Similarly, the sound in Arkham Knight is excellent, especially given the roar of the Batmobile, the sound of gunfire, the patter of Batman's cape as you glide through the wind, and the voice acting as well is superb, with Mark Hamill delivering one hell of a final performance as The Joker. The music is intense, brooding, and atmospheric (as it should be), as Nick Arundel and David Buckley return to compose for the Arkham series. Overall, in every department except for system performance, Arkham Knight delivers.StoryYou're the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman. After years of plotting, the supervillain Scarecrow unleashes a widespread attack on all of Gotham City. Millions of Gotham citizens are deported as the police and Batman prepare to do battle with an army of supervillains. However, they must also confront a mysterious new villain-- the Arkham Knight, a militia commander with a connection to Batman's past, if they are to take back Gotham once and for all. The much hyped concluding story to the Arkham Trilogy is the one that ultimately falls the flatest in the whole series. It's definitely got it's moments, and some very clever plot points (such as Batman having visions of Joker) make for some really out of the box encounters, but none of it makes up for the remainder of the story. It goes from one meaningless conversation with Alfred to one meaningless encounter with drones again and again until some kind of plot twist occurs that doesn't have the impact it should. At the very end, I found myself describing the story for Arkham Knight wtih two words I thought I'd never say about an Arkham game: boring and forgettable.WorldArkham Knight finally gives you a fully-realized Gotham City, littered with detail and complexity unlike any city you've explored in any video game. Much of the city is fully destructable, which may make for fun Batmobile rampages, but doesn't help the fact that the city feels lifeless and empty. Having civillians on the streets and people walking about would have certainly made this less so. Arkham Knight features the most side content in any Arkham game yet, but sadly its arrangment of side content has devolved into an Ubisoft open world style of activities. Each activity repeats itself a certain number of times before you've completed all of that activity. Rarely do these activities feature the type of meaningful engagements found in the side content of previous Arkham games, and as a result, end up feeling repetitive and pointless. Thankfully there is some fun stuff to do, such as milita checkpoints and riddler trophies, but the rest feels like a wasted opportunity.GameplayArkham Origins, a spinoff of the Arkham series that was fairly successful, proved how well-realized and fun the gameplay forumla for the Arkham series can be after multiple games. In Arkham Knight, nearly every aspect of the pre-exisiting gameplay has been improved; the free-flow combat is faster and features more moves and abilities to take down an even wider range of enemy types; stealth encounters feature more challenging enemy types and more ways to take down enemies; gliding is faster and more maneuverable than before; there are several new and different gadgets than previously featured; and the level design is just about as great as it was before, albeit lacking ample puzzle variety that would require you to use all of your gadgets more often. For the most part, all of these gameplay elements feel pretty solid.However, there is one new feature in Arkham Knight that hurts the focus on these great gameplay elements and ultimately brings down the game: the Batmobile. While the induction of Batman's greatest gadget seems like a brilliant idea on paper, the execution in-game is kinda iffy. It's very fun to drive around in and tear through the streets of Gotham, though gliding remains to be a more effective method of traversal (and its more fun). The Batmobile weapon systems seem cool at first, but are fairly limited and make drone combat encounters frustratingly simple and boring. What makes it even worse is that the game forces you to use the Batmobile so much throughout the campaign that it overshadows the more refined gameplay aspects of Arkham Knight. The only aspect of the Batmobile I genuinely enjoyed was it's use for puzzles, though some might find these somewhat forced as well. In the end, your miliage with the Batmobile will vary, though I certainly didn't enjoy it as much as the game probably wanted me to.  Conclusion Batman: Arkham Knight is the biggest and most badass entry into the Arkham saga to date. As highly antipcated as this game was for concluding the Batman story, it ends on a dissapointing note, despite some very clever moments throughout the story. Gotham City is packed with detail and filled with things to do, but neither of these eclipse the lifeless feeling of the city nor the meaningless nature of the side content. Combat, stealth, gliding, puzzles, and level design have all been excellently-refined, but lose the focus they deserve to the Batmobile, which unnecessarily forces more mediocre gameplay upon you. While Arkham Knight may be the Batman game we neither deserved nor needed, it's still filled with many moments of greatness and stands as a fairly decent open-world game.. assuming you're PC can run it. Final Rating: 7/10 PC Version: 6/10Worth it if bought at 50% or cheaper.

												Much as I was looking forward to this game, got a new card to be able to run this on even, I can't find a reason to play at the moment.  The combat and environments are beautiful, at a distance, up close it all falls apart.  Eight graphical options does not a competent option list make, frame drops at high speeds and a 30FPS lock?  Sorry, I'll be playing Witcher 3 until this is fixed.  This is Unity level BS.I will state I am on the good edge of this, I haven't crashed yet but the frame drops and performance problems make it hard for me to enjoy the story Rocksteady crafted.  Glad I held off buying the Season Pass but maybe Rocksteady should include that for people who pre-ordered the game as a way of saying sorry.  Maybe I'm just being greedy but this shouldn't be happening in 2015.  Especially not with a AAA title costing $60 with a $40 Season Pass.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												It works smoothly, in between many immersion breaking crashes. I'm currenly BEYOND♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off because I got about 50% of the way into the game before a bug prevented me from progressing. I tried restarting the game, I tried reverting a save, I seem to be the only one WITH the issue and now my save is ♥♥♥♥ed. I don't even want to play any more. If I was still elligible for a refund on this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'd take it, but now I'm just $70 down the hole with a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥I don't even want to bother replaying to get my save back.If you're still looking at getting this, a lot of the puzzle situations bank on you noticing something minute or somehow already knowing a game mechanic they haven't told you about. A lot of the reason I even made it through is that it starts giving you hints when you take awhile, and even then that's mostly for the game mechanic related stuff. My problem with this is that a lot of the time the game never asked me to do some of the things I needed to to solve the puzzle until right at that moment, and you pretty much have to wait around and feel stupid unless you know what the mechanics it has never had/let you use are. And even then, some of them dont have any helpful hints at all. In one instance I didn't see a small hole in the wall where a fan was in a heavily damaged hallway for a long time. I got lucky and noticed it just as I was getting almost annoyed enough to quit. It was not obvious, and the point of the puzzle wasn't really supposed to be to find that hole. If you're looking forward to the Batmobile, sometimes it's really fun and feels bad♥♥♥♥♥ Sometimes it controls like♥♥♥♥♥out of nowhere with no real explanation and it loves to wrestle the camera away from you while you drive.The combat is the games strongest point, and it puts a much heavier emphasis on use of your gadgets than the previous games. On the downside, you have to pause the game to switch gadgets through some UI that felt clunky IMO.Some of the writing annoys me as well, like (spoiler alert) having to esentially kill Ra's Al Ghul, or get his daughter who asked for your help killed. Killing him doesn't seem like the Batman thing to do, and not killing him seems to punish you anyway, narrative-wise. THAT BEING SAID, the story is generally really good, although I don't want to play through half the ♥♥♥♥ing game again to fix my save.Some of the game is a little TOO clunky to be excusable. There are too many sections where it's not entirely obvious what you're even supposed to do. I would wonder if I needed gadgets, or I had to go do something else, but it was generally just "even though you've followed the assassin's blood trail all the way here and it's entirely obvious whose it is, you need to go back and follow it again with your evidene scanner on" or, just as annoying, "you're not seeing how to progress because it's a grapple point at a weird angle above you that you have to be standing in an overlerly specific spot for before we'll let you use it, even WHEN you see it." And I'll just point this out again: the game still crashes pretty commonly. Not enough to totally impede gameplay, but it ruined my immersion and will to play this more than once. Twice the crashes were even bad enough that I had to restart my computer just to get it usable again. They aren't why I'm fed up, but they're also there and VERY annoying. Here's to hoping that, by some miracle, more of this gets fixed. I love Batman and generally, the Arkham series. I know I don't want to bother trying to start from scratch now, though.

Each activity repeats itself a certain number of times before you've completed all of that activity. Rarely do these activities feature the type of meaningful engagements found in the side content of previous Arkham games, and as a result, end up feeling repetitive and pointless. Thankfully there is some fun stuff to do, such as milita checkpoints and riddler trophies, but the rest feels like a wasted opportunity.GameplayArkham Origins, a spinoff of the Arkham series that was fairly successful, proved how well-realized and fun the gameplay forumla for the Arkham series can be after multiple games. What makes it even worse is that the game forces you to use the Batmobile so much throughout the campaign that it overshadows the more refined gameplay aspects of Arkham Knight. The only aspect of the Batmobile I genuinely enjoyed was it's use for puzzles, though some might find these somewhat forced as well. In the end, your miliage with the Batmobile will vary, though I certainly didn't enjoy it as much as the game probably wanted me to.  Conclusion Batman: Arkham Knight is the biggest and most badass entry into the Arkham saga to date. As highly antipcated as this game was for concluding the Batman story, it ends on a dissapointing note, despite some very clever moments throughout the story. Gotham City is packed with detail and filled with things to do, but neither of these eclipse the lifeless feeling of the city nor the meaningless nature of the side content. Combat, stealth, gliding, puzzles, and level design have all been excellently-refined, but lose the focus they deserve to the Batmobile, which unnecessarily forces more mediocre gameplay upon you. While Arkham Knight may be the Batman game we neither deserved nor needed, it's still filled with many moments of greatness and stands as a fairly decent open-world game.. assuming you're PC can run it. Final Rating: 7/10 PC Version: 6/10Worth it if bought at 50% or cheaper.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
NOTICE: This review will be updated in the future, pending updates and improvements to the game by the developer.I’ll keep this short and sweet.If you enjoyed the storylines in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, you’ll probably enjoy this game.  It concludes the basic storyline of the first two games, and ties Rocksteady’s trilogy back to WB Montreal’s Arkham Origins in some interesting ways. In all, you get a story that—on a speed run—will provide about 6-8 hours of entertainment, more like 18 if you take your time to enjoy all the side quests and see the sights. If, however, what you got enjoyment from was in playing the challenge mode. Spending hours perfecting combat challenges and mastering speedy predator take downs, or (in Arkham City) getting to play as your other favorite Batman characters?  Save your money. This game fails to live up to the legacy of its predecessors in all but story mode. If you’re going to get this game I **strongly** urge you to wait for a game of the year edition, and wait for it to be on sale, perhaps during next year’s steam summer sale.- - - FURTHER DETAILS - - -Challenge mode has become a watered down, streamlined after thought that is injected into story-mode itself. So far as I can tell, Batman is the only playable character. Gone are the joys of spending hours replaying again and again for top scores with your favorite characters.  The Harley Quinn DLC “challenge maps” (and presumably the future DLCs for Redhood and Batgirl) are just a mix of two combat and two predator maps that must be played Campaign style; they are not individually selectable like in the traditional challenge mode of the previous games.The game’s launch has been fraught with bugs, graphical failures, and design choices that have left many of the dedicated Arkham playerbase baffled. It’s gorgeous, it sounds wonderful, and the voice acting is still topnotch, but Arkham Knight is little more than a glorified, interactive episode of Batman: The Animated Series, and the story isn’t even as strong as the tales delivered by that wonderful show.My Recommendation: Go to youtube and watch someone’s Let’s Play Arkham Knight, don’t waste your money on what is, unfortunately, another Third Installment Failure in the world of gaming. Graphics: 8/10The game is flawless in its appearance, however, the optimization is poor and certain design choices (like the inability to turn off motion blur) have caused players frequent and frustrating frame rate drops.Sound: 10/10The soundtrack is as atmospheric and engaging as ever, and the voice acting cast continue to deliver phenomenal performances bringing your favorite Gotham characters to life.Entertainment Value: 7/10The combat has been revamped and revised, smoother, more elaborate, and more detailed than ever. It’s a joy to get into a riotous brawl with 30 or 40 goons; however, the use of in-combat gadgets has become more complicated than ever before, and the game puts far too much emphasis on the Tankmobile, forcing you to wonder whether this is actually batman or a hopeful rebirth for 3DO’s classic BattleTanks game. Replayability: 2/10 If you like the story you might feel compelled to play through it again to pick up on anything you missed the first time, but challenge mode that made Arkham City worthy of 100+ hours of dedicated time has been gutted and replaced with something pathetically pale in comparison.

												DO NOT BUY AT THIS TIME.I bought the game on release expecting it to be as good as their previous titles. I ran in to a few issues withing the first few minutes of playing. I have an Nvidia Surround setup with 3 monitors spanning a resolution of 3800x1024Cons:- Bad aspect ration during cut scenes- inconsistent  cut scene vs pre-rendered intro- Dialog lag during rendered cut scenes- Lag / low framerate during fight scenes- Horrible handling of Batmobile- ALMOST NO SETTINGS FOR GRAPHICS. Everything needs to be changed in the config file from what I have been reading.I will play again tonight and update this list. So far I am very dissapointed. Feels like this is a port instead of an optimized game for the PC Platform. This game may be worth buying at a later time once these issues are fixed. But right now my gameplay looks nothing like the screenshots.

Spending hours perfecting combat challenges and mastering speedy predator take downs, or (in Arkham City) getting to play as your other favorite Batman characters?  Save your money. This game fails to live up to the legacy of its predecessors in all but story mode. If you’re going to get this game I **strongly** urge you to wait for a game of the year edition, and wait for it to be on sale, perhaps during next year’s steam summer sale.- - - FURTHER DETAILS - - -Challenge mode has become a watered down, streamlined after thought that is injected into story-mode itself. So far as I can tell, Batman is the only playable character. Gone are the joys of spending hours replaying again and again for top scores with your favorite characters.  The Harley Quinn DLC “challenge maps” (and presumably the future DLCs for Redhood and Batgirl) are just a mix of two combat and two predator maps that must be played Campaign style; they are not individually selectable like in the traditional challenge mode of the previous games.The game’s launch has been fraught with bugs, graphical failures, and design choices that have left many of the dedicated Arkham playerbase baffled. It’s gorgeous, it sounds wonderful, and the voice acting is still topnotch, but Arkham Knight is little more than a glorified, interactive episode of Batman: The Animated Series, and the story isn’t even as strong as the tales delivered by that wonderful show.My Recommendation: Go to youtube and watch someone’s Let’s Play Arkham Knight, don’t waste your money on what is, unfortunately, another Third Installment Failure in the world of gaming. Graphics: 8/10The game is flawless in its appearance, however, the optimization is poor and certain design choices (like the inability to turn off motion blur) have caused players frequent and frustrating frame rate drops.Sound: 10/10The soundtrack is as atmospheric and engaging as ever, and the voice acting cast continue to deliver phenomenal performances bringing your favorite Gotham characters to life.Entertainment Value: 7/10The combat has been revamped and revised, smoother, more elaborate, and more detailed than ever. It’s a joy to get into a riotous brawl with 30 or 40 goons; however, the use of in-combat gadgets has become more complicated than ever before, and the game puts far too much emphasis on the Tankmobile, forcing you to wonder whether this is actually batman or a hopeful rebirth for 3DO’s classic BattleTanks game. Replayability: 2/10 If you like the story you might feel compelled to play through it again to pick up on anything you missed the first time, but challenge mode that made Arkham City worthy of 100+ hours of dedicated time has been gutted and replaced with something pathetically pale in comparison.

content:
Posted: February 12
Batman™: Arkham Knight Game ReviewBatman™: Arkham Knight brings the award-winning Arkham trilogy from Rocksteady Studios to its epic conclusion. Developed exclusively for New-Gen platforms, Batman: Arkham Knight introduces Rocksteady's uniquely designed version of the Batmobile. The highly anticipated addition of this legendary vehicle, combined with the acclaimed gameplay of the Arkham series, offers gamers the ultimate and complete Batman experience as they tear through the streets and soar across the skyline of the entirety of Gotham City. In this explosive finale, Batman faces the ultimate threat against the city that he is sworn to protect, as Scarecrow returns to unite the super criminals of Gotham and destroy the Batman forever. - Steam Store Page DescriptionThe game description describes this game perfectly. Since this is a review, i'm not inclined to say anything about more about the story than what the Steam Store Page description says, as that'd be a spoiler and you can find that out for yourself. In my personal opinion, the story is great although there are some flaws that you'll notice at least 1-2 hours into the story. This game is an 'Open World' game, which means you're placed into a large map with lots of different things to do and without a completely linear path for the storyline. While you're actually playing as Batman, the gameplay is absolutely fantastic, with the FreeFlow combat system even further improved for a simple but very satisfying combat gameplay. Roaming around Gotham City too is very fun as you glide across the entire city with the help of your grappling hook, or even drive around the city in the Batmobile to reach your destination. However, I must say that while the Batmobile is absolutely amazing to use, as others say - it is overused, unfortunately. If you're into billion dollar cars that can convert into a tank and destroy almost anything in its path - this game is definitely for you!In terms of the graphics, there's very little choice for the main graphical options, although the game looks great even on the lowest settings, and looks brilliant on maximum settings. There isn't any options for 'Ultra' or 'Very High / Extra High' on any graphics option, however with this game I personally feel like there doesn't need to be.Graphics Options (Standard)- Display Mode (Windowed / Fullscreen / Borderless Window)- Resolution (e.g. 1920 x 1080)- V-Sync (On / Off / Adaptive)- Max FPS (30 / 60 / 90 / .ini tweak if you know how)- Texture Resolution (Low / Normal / High)- Shadow Quality (Low / Normal / High)- Level of Detail (Low / Normal / High)- Motion Blur (On / Off)- Anti-Aliasing (On / Off)- Chromatic Aberration (On / Off)- Film Grain (On / Off)- Texture Filtering (Trilinear / 2x / 4x / 8x / 16x)Graphics Options (NVIDIA GameWorks Settings)- Interactive Smoke / Fog (On / Off)- Interactive Paper Debris (On / Off)- Enhanced Rain (On / Off)- Enhanced Light Shafts (On / Off)Alongside these options, on the right to the settings list there is a 'Video Memory Usage' meter that will show how much VRAM your graphics card is using. So long as the bar is in the green, you'll be able to use those settings and know that VRAM stutter isn't going to occur. Although this doesn't mean that you'll reach your FPS target and doesn't mean that you definitely won't stutter, it's just one of many measures that you can use to factor out issues.All in all, give this game ago as it doesn't cost all that much for the base game anymore and most of the DLC doesn't add 'worth your money' additional story content. One DLC that I would recommend buying if you have the money spare is the 'Season of Infamy: Most Wanted Expansion' DLC. Below is a link that'll direct you to the Steam Store Page for that DLC:


YouTube™ Video: driving to hell at the speed of batman 

			Views: 65		

			Watch live at http://www.twitch.tv/notsopwningsora		

I have a Steam Community guide dedicated to helping you improve performance in Batman™: Arkham Knight:


Batman: Arkham Knight Optimisation Guide 
A Guide for Batman™: Arkham Knight
By: Rimmer

			This Steam Community guide for Batman™: Arkham Knight is aimed at improving the performance for users experiencing lower framerates than preferred by users.		


The guide is currently unfinished and does generally just say "turn down your graphics settings", however the guide will be updated eventually to provide more tips.Definitely worth buying at it's current price and you CAN REFUND the game if there's any issues.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Within the Batman Arkham franchise this is the new lowest piont. The first tutorial mission is bugged. That should be enough to prove how less important the PC port is for the publisher. The Batmobile is funny, but is forced onto the player at nearly every point. Even Riddler quest, which used to be actual riddles in Arkham Asylum are now car races. Even within the main story line many levels can only be solved using the car, even so in Origin Batman already had the necessary tools to overcome most of the hurdles with his normal tools. It is quite apparent that the developers were out of ideas and just created some arbitrary obstacles for the player. The problem here is, that the car is terrible to control. Beside the car, the normal mouse+keyboard controls are extremly bad as well. The fights are ok, just like the other Batman games, but the detective mode and some mini games demand you move your mouse several meters to the right in order to proceed. YES, METERS, In order to fast-forward an security footage I had to move the lenght of my gamepad 12 times.Additionaly, the gameplay is simplified to the extrem. It is no longer possible to play Batman Arkham Knight, you are mostly watching it. Difficulties only origin by the terrible controls and the extrem infantilizing of the core gameplay aspects.Btw, I so far I didn't had any performance problems, but the graphic isn't better than the other Arkham games and way worse then Witcher3*Edit* I have to change something, this game isn't easy at all, in fact it is the hardest game I ever played. Not the beeing batman part of it, in fact that is terribly easy. defeat one guy silenty, than you can instant defeat 5 others. This means the sneaking part basicly doesnot exist. In the fighting parts they changed the quite smart autotargeting system in Batman 1-3 to a non working one, don't know why they just did. Realy hard are the Riddler races, the control of the care is so ♥♥♥♥ing terrible, if you make a mistake you have to finish the whole 2 minute course and can't restart, this leads to terrible frustration on my side and ultimativly to just deinstalling it.

mood,simple but fun story.So i bought arkham origins a while back to prepare for arkham knight!I freakin pre-ordered it and even got the ''premium'' edition.I couldn't wait,stayed up till 2 am for the game to unlock and play it.dropped it after 30 seconds and went angrily back to sleep.The benchmarks aren't locked yet,in-game you are capped at 30fps.I'm not picky but i've built a pc for this game and w3,W3 was kind of a dissapointment because of console parity.(believe it or not,i still love my xbox but i didn't waste money on my pc for nothing!I wanted a fantastic experience.THIS IS SIMPLY ANOTHER INCIDENT OF CONSOLE PARITY!I'm getting sick of this bull.why even make cross platform games if you're gonna chop the arm and leg of another contestant to make it as fast/great as the other.No logic whatsoever!I swear im switching to a ps4.WHAT IS THE POINT!PS4 not only has everything running perfectly and awesome effects,no texture pop-ins or slug people.Note im running a 4790k with a 980,on a SSD!The game looks like complete crap!And yes i know tweaking the .ini files will remove the cap but it's an obvious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ move of rocksteady.WHY is there a benchmark if there's a 30 fps a ton of console copies they'll fix them yes.GREAT!i LOVED the arkham series and rocksteady!HELL even a huge batman fan but rocksteady is scum!I'm not even blaming iron galaxy,poor guys were trying to number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I remember the look in his eyes. Those raving, inhuman eyes. And that laugh, that felt like disease writhing under my skin.And those words."The... punchline, Bats. Oh, wait till it hits you..."Until now, I'd hoped it was a ruse, the desperate dying words of a madman grasping to retain any kind of hold. I'd hoped the words had been hollow, that the joke was over.How could I have let myself hope?The rain is falling, it looks the way I dreamed rain would look. Falling gracefully, dancing playfully as it glances off my cape. And as it pours, so do the shafts of light, breaking through from the heavens and cascading with promise of illumination, but what's the use if it doesn't help you see?The rain, the light, all it does is muddy the sky, impair my vision. There's no clarity here, just a dying city and the echoes of a madman's laughter."You won't be able to see it coming, Bats."He was right. I can't see. Everything is doused in a blur that smothers all detail. I wonder if I've occidentally ingested some of the Scarcrow's toxin. I run a blood analysis and it comes back clean.But this isn't clean. This isn't clear. This city is fractured, everything moves in slow motion, and that laugh wraps itself around my bones."You shouldn't have hoped, Bats. You should know better than that."I knew, damn his eyes I knew.He always did have the last laugh.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												TLDR: Fun game, terrible optimization, hidden DRM, no AMD allowed, and AAA treating PC users as second-class citizens has gotten really old.Arkham Knight's gameplay itself is largely unchanged from Arkham City's. The new additions are fun more often than not (fear takedowns are cool, traversal's better than before, but the Batmobile's controls are sluggish and its "tank mode" just feels goofy), and the game thus far seems to be lacking the magical grapnel-proof surfaces of Arkham Origins. On any platform but the PC, it would probably be a solid buy if you were looking for more of what the Arkham series has provided.The game's design accomplishments, however, are overshadowed by some terrible technical failures. The framerate is locked at 30FPS, yet somehow manages to keep dipping below that even on newer Nvidia cards. Several small graphical effects are simply disabled on the PC version. Arkham Knight uses Nvidia's Gameworks, which means that AMD users can expect absolutely horrible performance until a few months' worth of patches are released. And WB apparently attached Denuvo DRM to the game without bothering to let anyone know. There's a reason why Steam has a mention on its store pages for third-party DRM, and bundling it without disclosure has utterly destroyed my consumer confidence with WB.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												In its current state, the game is all but unplayable. Despite meeting (exceeding) the recommended requirements, the performance is abysmal. Framerate slowdowns, stuttering, locking up on a single frame for 5-10 seconds are all very common and frequent. The Nvidia Gameready drivers do nothing to alleviate the issue.The graphical options are absurdly limited. Excluding the Nvidia Gameworks options (mostly useless), there are about a half dozen settings.Furthermore, the game purportedly has Denuvo "anti-tampering" software, essentially protection for DRM. This software (besides already being cracked) caused performance issues in numerous previous releases, including Dragon Age: Inquisition and Lords of the Fallen. Why Warner Brothers thought it was a good idea to cripple their biggest release of the year is beyond me.Yo dawg, we heard you like DRM so we put DRM on your DRM so you can screw over legitimate customers while you screw over legitimate customers.Other than that, the gameplay additions and plot are (as far as I could tell through the occasional slideshow) excellent. But it means nothing if the game is unplayable.Also, as a preorder customer, I did not receive the Harley Quinn DLC which is extremely disappointing as I will not be dropping forty bucks for a "season pass" that will likely largely consist of challenge levels, especially not if the performance issues aren't fixed post-haste.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												So, I'm going to write this review, hoping to give some honest thoughts. This review WILL be edited and changed as the game gets patched, but I'll keep some of my initial thoughts up too.Let me get this out of the way now. This game is unplayable for a large percentage of people. The graphics in it cause too many problems for too many people, from completely dropping to a frame a second at times. This game was NOT well optimized at all.I'm running a pretty good machine, though it's not the highest end by any means, it's certainly nothing to scoff at. 8 Core AMD processor, 8 GB ram, GTX680 Ti card, running from a HDD not SSD. I'd say 70% of the time, the game runs playable for me, 25% it's irritating, and 5% it's completely unacceptable. TO GET TO THIS POINT: All graphics settings are at the lowest, all effects, v sync, anti-aliasing, and more are all turned off, and I'm running it at 1280x800 resolution. That's all pretty unacceptable, considering every other game I run, I just set everything to maximum...That all being said, this game, even with everything turned off, looks stellar (when it's not dropping frames).As for the actual game itself! The story is really engaging and fun, I'm having a blast with it. New game mechanics are all working great for me, new gadgets are fun, and the Batmobile is such a delight to use. I'm really eager to see everything in this game, and I'll post a (spoiler free) in depth comment on the story and side missions when I've completed them.Current thoughts: Frustrated but enjoying it. 7/10.If they can fix the framedrops so it's more playable? likely a 9.5/10 (so far)TLDR: If you have a good machine AND don't mind playing this with graphics settings on bare minimum, I'd suggest giving it a go. If you can't get around those two issues, don't bother.Do I recommend this game? I'm not saying yes or no right now, but Steam is making me pick. For the majority of people? No, I can't recommend it. Yet.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This is pure TRASH level port.- Game framerate is capped at 30FPS.- Unlocking the framerate through .ini tweaks will result in a stuttery mess with framerate all over the place.- Missing Ambient Occlusion, some shaders are worse compared to consoles.- Missing High and Ultra Textures, only Normal quality textures are available.- Games Anisotropic Filtering is set to 4X instead of 16X like it should be.- People are reporting Memory Leaks.- Garbage level performance across the board, Nvidia, AMD, it doesn't matter what system you have, the game will run like♥♥♥♥♥♥- A metric♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of other issues that are too many to list, like missing Language packs and♥♥♥♥♥♥SLi/Crossfire support.- Developers being shady ♥♥♥♥s and changing the recommended system requirements a DAY before release and NOT divulging the fact that A DIFFERENT STUDIO was handling the PC port of the game.Overall a pure ♥♥♥♥ing disaster!Shame on you Rocksteady!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
 In this episode Batman faces his greatest villain yet, incompetent game developers! Rocksteady has already begun finger pointing that although Arkham Knight is their game and they are willing to slap their label on it, they shouldn't be blamed for the torturous PC experience.  Instead PC gamers should target their scorn towards their ambiguous PC development partner, which Rocksteady has so bravely withheld official disclosure of, although some have speculated the culprits to be Iron Galaxy Studios.  Speculation [www.eurogamer.net]Originally posted by CODA, Rocksteady Community Manager: "We are working closely with our external PC development partner to make sure these issues get resolved as quickly as possible."   Source [community.wbgames.com]Does this stink of the same mistakes made by Gearbox when they outsourced the majority of their Aliens Colonial Marines; whose to say?At the moment it is unclear where the blame for this travesty of gaming software lies.  However Rocksteady has made it clear that they should not feel the hate for their latest title.  After all, they didn't even make it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Ah, Batman, where to start?  I saw the beautiful little diner and the astonishing sight of people in a computer game just beginning their climb out of the Uncanny Valley, I looked upon the little details and the way the rain fell and I smiled at just how smoothly it was running.  Then it crashed.I started it again and, not having reached a checkpoint yet, went back in to that diner.  There was that waitress with the impressive facial animations, I read some some newspaper headlines and then it crashed.I started it again and went back to the diner and watched the television for a minute.  The detail was pretty amazing.  Then it crashed.I started it again and went back to that damned diner with that damned waitress and the damned newspaper headlines and all the rest of it and then it crashed.Then I tried to verify the integrity of the game cache using the tool Steam provides for doing that, it found more than four thousand corrupted files and deleted itself.In short; don't buy it unless you're really, really, weirdly in to games locking up and then deleting themselves with no warning and for no earthly reason.*Edited to fix spelling errors.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												After almost 5 months, has this game improved? Yes, but not by much. We finally have the graphics settings that we should've had in the first place, but the engine is still an unpolished mess. Stuttering is frequent and I can rarely get above 60 FPS even with shadows turned down at 1080p on a GTX 970, and despite all of Rocksteady's patches, the game has crashed multiple times on me for no reason on the latest version. Which doesn't make sense, considering the load on my GPU never goes above 70%, yet the game still drops frames for no reason. And what do we get for our troubles Rocksteady? Some TF2 items, a challenge pack, and the previous games that most of us already own? Come on, I expected better. Also, no multi-GPU support on a modern PC game is ridiculous.As for the game itself? The gameplay is good, the Batmobile is fun to use (although the number of drone sequence gets a bit repetetive towards the end), and story is also pretty good. Granted, it's not an original story and the Arkham Knight is exactly who you think it is if you're familiar with the Batman mythos, but it's still told in an enjoyable way with excellent voice acting.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Before I write my review, here's a summary of my current PC build, constructed only a month agoIntel i7 4790kNvidia GTX 980 (palit)8GB DDR 3 RamSSD hard driveWindows 8.1 (64-bit)I cannot currently recommend the game IF you're expecting a enhanced visual experience of the game based on your PC hardware. In preparation for Arkham Knight, I saved and scrimped and actually built my PC after the first official statement for minimum\recommended hardware requirements was released by Nvidia and Rocksteady. Like many PC gamers I wanted this version instead of PS4\XBox One as PC games usually have the benefit of enhanced graphics that can sometimes make for a more immersive experience, based on the game.Feeling rather confident, when I first ran the game, I turned the settings to 1920 x 1080 and put every setting available to the highest setting possible. Initially the excitement of a new Batman game, and the graphical update in the first few minutes actually allowed me to almost ignore the 30fps frame lock. But like several other consumers I had issues such as my screen freezing (but audio still going), and Batman moving so slow to hop into the Batmobile it looked like a scene from The Matrix, being paused, and then skipped! When I closed the game the first time, I also encountered errors, but fortunately my game files didn't delete themselves, unlike some other very unfortunate consumers. I'm using a wireless X Box 360 Chrome Series pad and i've had no issues with controls.Last night, I turned my settings down to 1680 x 1050, put other settings on Normal and turned every Gameworks setting off. And playing for another hour the experience was stable. This included multiple trips in the Batmobile. So in regards to continuing playing the game I could as of now, and probably will, but only because I don't want the story to be spoiled, by gamers online.Being an Rocksteady\Arkham series fan if you're able to play the game without any problems (the lucky few) it's shaping up to be a great conclusion to the Arkham series. The graphics are improved over Arkham City, there's new fighting animations and there's new gameplay mechanics that make you feel even more bada$$ as Batman. The reason why I can't recommend this is because the company has released information to consumers for the type of PC they need for a gaming experience that is good, and current problems with the game make the game very unplayable for some. If a higher end PC is having to downgrade graphical settings then it's truly unfortunate for consumers with mid-range PCs that should have no problems running the game. If this was in the 90's there'd be mobs of annoyed gamers outside of Electronics Botique demanding refunds, but alas the state of gaming means publishers\developers can release seemingly unfinished products and just send consumer patches down the line at a time that suits them.Personally, i'm very disappointed, and as this being my first AAA PC game downloaded on launch day I hope this isn't a trend. I received the base game for free via Nvidia, and therefore I won't neg it for the 30fps frame lock, the last minute change to recommended settings, or the removal of Harley Quinn DLC for Nvidia 9xx customers, however that is VERY BAD FORM. The company Rocksteady has given us some great gaming moments in the past and it's a shame this has happened. I don't believe they're entirely to blame for this however because based on their first Batman games they've put alot of effort into giving us a great interactive Batman experience.  My heart goes out to the people though with the recommended PC set ups who have put good money down for this game, and have received a somewhat broken product in return.In case you haven't recently read, the sales of Arkham Knight on Steam are being suspended, which hopefully means they'll be updating the game. More than likely as a Steam user you've got plenty of games to tide you over until this update happens, but if you're going to wait I suggest you avoid certain gaming sites and resist the temptation to watch on YouTube so the story isn't ruined for you.  I don't know if this review helps anyone make a decision, but it's just my opinion.Update: 64 hours in, i've now completed the game. I had some frame skip when using some weapons but apart from that, the game ran ok. The update will no only benefit me when using season pass stuff, or playing AR mission which I doubt i'll do. If your PC can play it, it is a great story to the Arkham series.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												So, I'm going to write this review, hoping to give some honest thoughts. This review WILL be edited and changed as the game gets patched, but I'll keep some of my initial thoughts up too.Let me get this out of the way now. This game is unplayable for a large percentage of people. The graphics in it cause too many problems for too many people, from completely dropping to a frame a second at times. This game was NOT well optimized at all.I'm running a pretty good machine, though it's not the highest end by any means, it's certainly nothing to scoff at. 8 Core AMD processor, 8 GB ram, GTX680 Ti card, running from a HDD not SSD. I'd say 70% of the time, the game runs playable for me, 25% it's irritating, and 5% it's completely unacceptable. TO GET TO THIS POINT: All graphics settings are at the lowest, all effects, v sync, anti-aliasing, and more are all turned off, and I'm running it at 1280x800 resolution. That's all pretty unacceptable, considering every other game I run, I just set everything to maximum...That all being said, this game, even with everything turned off, looks stellar (when it's not dropping frames).As for the actual game itself! The story is really engaging and fun, I'm having a blast with it. New game mechanics are all working great for me, new gadgets are fun, and the Batmobile is such a delight to use. I'm really eager to see everything in this game, and I'll post a (spoiler free) in depth comment on the story and side missions when I've completed them.Current thoughts: Frustrated but enjoying it. 7/10.If they can fix the framedrops so it's more playable? likely a 9.5/10 (so far)TLDR: If you have a good machine AND don't mind playing this with graphics settings on bare minimum, I'd suggest giving it a go. If you can't get around those two issues, don't bother.Do I recommend this game? I'm not saying yes or no right now, but Steam is making me pick. For the majority of people? No, I can't recommend it. Yet.

content:
Posted: February 12
Batman™: Arkham Knight Game ReviewBatman™: Arkham Knight brings the award-winning Arkham trilogy from Rocksteady Studios to its epic conclusion. Developed exclusively for New-Gen platforms, Batman: Arkham Knight introduces Rocksteady's uniquely designed version of the Batmobile. The highly anticipated addition of this legendary vehicle, combined with the acclaimed gameplay of the Arkham series, offers gamers the ultimate and complete Batman experience as they tear through the streets and soar across the skyline of the entirety of Gotham City. In this explosive finale, Batman faces the ultimate threat against the city that he is sworn to protect, as Scarecrow returns to unite the super criminals of Gotham and destroy the Batman forever. - Steam Store Page DescriptionThe game description describes this game perfectly. Since this is a review, i'm not inclined to say anything about more about the story than what the Steam Store Page description says, as that'd be a spoiler and you can find that out for yourself. In my personal opinion, the story is great although there are some flaws that you'll notice at least 1-2 hours into the story. This game is an 'Open World' game, which means you're placed into a large map with lots of different things to do and without a completely linear path for the storyline. While you're actually playing as Batman, the gameplay is absolutely fantastic, with the FreeFlow combat system even further improved for a simple but very satisfying combat gameplay. Roaming around Gotham City too is very fun as you glide across the entire city with the help of your grappling hook, or even drive around the city in the Batmobile to reach your destination. However, I must say that while the Batmobile is absolutely amazing to use, as others say - it is overused, unfortunately. If you're into billion dollar cars that can convert into a tank and destroy almost anything in its path - this game is definitely for you!In terms of the graphics, there's very little choice for the main graphical options, although the game looks great even on the lowest settings, and looks brilliant on maximum settings. There isn't any options for 'Ultra' or 'Very High / Extra High' on any graphics option, however with this game I personally feel like there doesn't need to be.Graphics Options (Standard)- Display Mode (Windowed / Fullscreen / Borderless Window)- Resolution (e.g. 1920 x 1080)- V-Sync (On / Off / Adaptive)- Max FPS (30 / 60 / 90 / .ini tweak if you know how)- Texture Resolution (Low / Normal / High)- Shadow Quality (Low / Normal / High)- Level of Detail (Low / Normal / High)- Motion Blur (On / Off)- Anti-Aliasing (On / Off)- Chromatic Aberration (On / Off)- Film Grain (On / Off)- Texture Filtering (Trilinear / 2x / 4x / 8x / 16x)Graphics Options (NVIDIA GameWorks Settings)- Interactive Smoke / Fog (On / Off)- Interactive Paper Debris (On / Off)- Enhanced Rain (On / Off)- Enhanced Light Shafts (On / Off)Alongside these options, on the right to the settings list there is a 'Video Memory Usage' meter that will show how much VRAM your graphics card is using. So long as the bar is in the green, you'll be able to use those settings and know that VRAM stutter isn't going to occur. Although this doesn't mean that you'll reach your FPS target and doesn't mean that you definitely won't stutter, it's just one of many measures that you can use to factor out issues.All in all, give this game ago as it doesn't cost all that much for the base game anymore and most of the DLC doesn't add 'worth your money' additional story content. One DLC that I would recommend buying if you have the money spare is the 'Season of Infamy: Most Wanted Expansion' DLC. Below is a link that'll direct you to the Steam Store Page for that DLC:


YouTube™ Video: SHOCKING interview with Batman: Arkham Knight Developer 

			Views: 142,384		

			Angry Hitler version here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CvfnbsLtQzI		

I have a Steam Community guide dedicated to helping you improve performance in Batman™: Arkham Knight:


Batman: Arkham Knight Optimisation Guide 
A Guide for Batman™: Arkham Knight
By: Rimmer

			This Steam Community guide for Batman™: Arkham Knight is aimed at improving the performance for users experiencing lower framerates than preferred by users.		


The guide is currently unfinished and does generally just say "turn down your graphics settings", however the guide will be updated eventually to provide more tips.Definitely worth buying at it's current price and you CAN REFUND the game if there's any issues.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												My PC specs: AMD FX6300 CPU - AMD r9 270x GPU - and the rest is just standard 8gb ram 1600mhz corsair and 1tb hdd and a ssd drive for windows. I do realise my PC compared to other people having these problems ain't quite as good but, let's compare my GPU with a PS4 GPU, PS4 (not 100% on this but I think I'm right...) it's equivalent is meant to be a 7850, my card excels that maybe not by miles but it's definely better since I'm able to run alot of games up to this games release such as witcher 3 crysis etc, on quite high settings. Now let's compare my CPU, if you check online im 100% sure it says the PS4 CPU was intended for laptop technology and only has 2.4ghz, mine although it doesn't make it amazing just because of the amount has 6! Let me just say that one more time 6 cores and a whole 1ghz more speed than that CPU. I was running far cry 3 when it was popular at the time at ULTRA max settings and it still holds it's own to this day, apart from multi tasking which it lacks on slightly my CPU craps on a PS4 CPU in every way. I'm still genna say this one more time before trolls start saying things like oh but your PC isn't even high end blah blah, I'M FULLY AWARE believe me. My purpose of this review is just the fact that a PS4 can run games like batman at higher res than me and probably the standard high setting on a pc maybe medium not quite sure, but my PC can't do that. I've even downscaled my res and turned all settings lowest I could without NVIDIA enhancements and still get terrible frames while driving the batmobile and even flying in the air. I've waited over a whole year for this game since it was announced and this is what they give to me? I mean I know consoles probably do out sell PC and it's more popular but ROCKSTEADY, yes, you ROCKSTEADY you designed and developed this game and can't port it to the PC properly for us. All the mainstream companies are doing it to us, apart from CDprojekt whatever they're called (witcher 3 developers). I just have no words.All that being said my actual opinion on the game is that the combat is the most satisfying experience I've ever had when you first get the suit sent to you and take out the room like batman should be able to and I really feel like I am batman in the game while doing this. I'm just majorly disappointed by this game and they can't say they don't care because we get sales from console anyways, this will hurt them because gaming nowadays its mostly about recommendations and trust and I dont recommend this game to people for PC right now. So as I'm writing this review now and not in a future time I'm genna have to say NO and thumbs down. Wait for a price drop and maybe think about trying out another game as ROCKSTEADY don't deserve full payment for this game and support with this kinda treatment to their fans!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												The annoying part about video games is that we cannot just focus on the content of the game itself. Instead we also have to concern ourselves with the technical aspects as well. If we were reviewing Arkham Knight purely on the content of the game it'd be rated rather highly -- in fact it is on consoles where there are fewer technical problems. However in video games we cannot ignore the technical aspects of the game -- the performance, responsiveness and port quality are all extremely relevant to the enjoyment of a game. To put it frankly and succinctly it's just not very good. I am running on a R9 280x with an old but still trustworthy Intel core i7 950 with 24gb of RAM on Windows 10. On foot I achieve around 60fps which on "normal" settings which is fine. However when it comes to driving around in the batmobile (which the game expects you to do several times) I can get dips as low as 35fps without any destruction or much happening. It's not just limited to me either which makes it all the more sad. When they announced that the September patch was just an interim I expected that a later patch would further address the performance issues. The interim patch was a good start to making this a good PC port. Instead with just that it's 4 months late and barely better than a crap port. Sure it has borderless options but that's pretty much it. Their SMAA implementation also has some weird things about it. http://i.imgur.com/2PAn0aR.jpg It's just not worth recommending in my opinion based on my performance. The "gift" they bestowed of the backlog of Batman Arkham games is worth very little to me as I was a fan of Batman Arkham series because of those games so I own them already (except blackgate which is crap). TF2 items don't interest me either bar selling them for Steambux. Sigh I just want to play games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												OK, this is bad......at least for me, and apparently many others too. 3.4, GTX 970 4, 16 gigs, Win 7 64. I'm having stuttering that makes this literally unplayable. 2 seconds of single digit framerates, it'll then pause (and I'm not exaggerating--for 4-5 seconds), then resume. Then 3 seconds later, another 2 second freeze. The graphics are not even near the trailer, in fact I don't think this really looks all that far removed from City at its best. There's barely any graphical customization options. Aside from rain, gameworks is greyed out. Texture highest setting is "normal". Framerate capped at 30 that only an .ini tweak will fix.W.T.F.??This is either a) the laziest or b) most incompetent PC effort that I've ever seen. The Witcher 3 (which I thought was bad in its technical issues) is a dream in comparison. I'm requesting a refund and getting the PS4 game. Rocksteady will get none of my money for the PC version until it's actualy, y'know.....functional. That said, I've no problem with the game itself. I LOVE the 'mobile in all respects, even the combat, but I seem to be alone on this. From what I've played it was pure Batman Rocksteady bliss, but after I left the a certain area (about 30 minutes in) the game became nigh unplayable. I have to say I'm quite disappointed Rocksteady would allow it to be released like this. I used to think of them as one to take pride in polish, now I don't know how to feel.Developers need to held accountable for believing they can release games like this and get away with it. You cannot release software in this state. Inexcusable.

The worst problem though are the glitches... holy shiiit this game is glitched.  At least few times I experienced enemies walking in mid air and Batman getting behind textures after using grappling device. Like come on...If they could repair that and break constant repetitiveness from side quests. We would've gotten an spirit ancestor of Arkham City. Final impression after ending the main story is that its a very good game... Only a very good game. No ofense but some main characters seems to be half baked. Nevertheless I recommend it since Arkham Knight gets better with each hour spent, and you will likely remember it because of the Batmobile and story scenes, sweet memories :)

There is just so much to do. This is an amazing game and i would recommend it to anyone anytime. The best of the series so far,

												I can honestly say I have little to no problems playing this game. However, that is only because my graphics card is a 970 (as many others have). content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												theres alot to like about this game but in its current state, theres alot more things to loathe. its really unfortunate that such a broken mess was knowingly♥♥♥♥♥♥out to customers as I was one of the many fans, eagerly anticipating this game ever since it was announced. ready to place it atop my favorite games of all time, only to have to endure numerous issues incessantly impeding my enjoyment of the game. luckily for me, ive been able to find a few ways to work around the worst bugs and BS, and my computer confirguration has allowed me to skirt some of the sheer unplayability issues being reported by others, but I cant say that Im truly able to enjoy the game the way that it SHOULD be played. i definitely appreciate the design elements of gotham city and I certainly cant overlook the attention to detail that was put into the countless easter eggs and references to the batman lore and the wider dc universe. I can have some fun here & there, but I still cant help but feel slighted, almost bamboozled, by the way everyone involved: the developer, the publisher, hell, even nvidia tried to pull the wool over everyone's eyes with videos just prior to release showing gameplay footage with gameworks, claiming solid 60fps. Then WB trying to cover its♥♥♥♥♥at release quietly changing required specs & saying that 720p at 30fps was really all that the pc users could hope to achieve when they had actually known all along that the performance on pc was just atrocious. spent $75 on the game alone just to make SURE that I had it on release day only to be severely disappointed and theres no amount of their PR lies or BS apologies that will change the fact that they just didnt give a♥♥♥♥♥♥enough to not set consumers up for a huge slap in the face.  bottom lines, quarterly reports & profits; thats all that mattered and its totally marred an otherwise good game, turning it into a terrible experience. Ill never preorder again, never buy another Rocksteady or WB game and if I even see that Iron Galaxy worked on it, then Ill just chuck it in the fire. itll play better there. Almost two months later, theres still no fix. Im starting to think that there'll never be one. It sucks that I cant seperate that experience from the quality of the game, but I just cant. If not for my willingness to make some tweaks, getting totally lucky & discovering some work-arounds just to get it to play, having to adjust my core speeds and go as far as to overclock my graphics card, I wouldnt even have gotten the chance to play this thing. (for reference, I dont have to do any of those things to get GTA V to play at 1080p, 60fps) I didnt want to return it when everyone was getting refunds, because I wanted to PLAY this game! But now and possibly forever, regardless of how good it may be in the future, this game will be like baseball players during the "Steroids Era;" itll get an asterisk in my mind. It wont go in my personal gaming "Hall of Fame" and Ill always look back and think, "maybe that was a good game, but DAMNIT, it was SO ♥♥♥♥♥♥!" And what do we have to look forward to? Being charged for challange maps that they took out of the game when ALL three previous titles had them included? A batmobile & skin that cant even be used IN the game? or maybe "story" missions that have no story and last all of 10mins like the redhood, or 15 mins like the harley one, or maybe around 30-40mins like the batgirl one? WOAH. yeah, i see where that $40 season pass really comes in handy! no. its not the game itself as much as the PEOPLE helping others to the expand the games enjoyability, the people that the developers and publisher forgot to think about or truthfully just didnt give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about, thatll end up making this game into something better. And then its not the "game" as they made it. So the game you buy, is not worth it, but the game you make it into, well thats up to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												There are a lot of negative reviews for this game so let me explain a few things.Firstly, let me say I preordered this game because I know Rocksteady puts out a quality product. This game itself is quality. The port is not. RS outsourced the PC port to what is believed to be a team of 12 programmers who have a terrible track record, and I will not defend this.The optimization issues are sad really. Sure, past Arkham games have had issues at launch, but nowhere near this bad. On a 760 and 3770 I have everything on low and at 720p to get a somewhat consistent 60fps, and while the game still looks good it's hard knowing I should be able to do 60 on at least medium at 1080p. Others have severe stuttering. This needs fixing. If you're near the min specs, avoid this game like the plague until patches have been issues.Besides the aformentoned issues, this is a batman Arkham game through and through. I love that this game somehow feels more fluid than the past 2 games, and the flight is just as amazing as ever. The world is massive and beautiful. People seem to think there was some watch_dogs style graphical downgrade, however if there was I really don't care. On higher settings, this game is truly a next gen title (Right now you won't be able to play on these settings unless you have a card from the future but). One questionable thing I may add is that Commisioner Gordon sounds like Batman. Idk what happened there.And now the Batmobile. I shook my head when I heard they were adding this, but I'm pleasantly surprised by my enjoyment. The combat leaves something to be desired, but the actual driving itself feels really good, as the weighty feel to it makes it fun to drive. However. my major gripe thus far has to do with the Riddler intro mission and how it uses the Batmobile and sets up its use in later Riddler missions. I feel the Riddler wouldn't make use of the Batmobile but whatever.In summation, great game, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ launch. If you're a fan of the Arkham games like me and need to finish the trilogy, get it as long as you don't mind lowering the graphical settings and getting some performance issues. Otherwise avoid this like the plague until Rocksteady does somethingEDIT: Editing to say I requested a refund and I say stay away from this game until major patching and a discountEDIT 2: I got a refund and bought through a key site for a heavy discount. It disheartems me that I want to play so bad but I will refrain from playing any more until a patch drops. Also MARK IS BACK!

content:

												oh man where do I start.I'm late I'd say, I got an xbox with a copy of Arkham City and I couldn't stop playing. Also don't forget the tag team superhero stuff that's also pretty sick.Anyway if you want to get this, get it, seriously it is amazing!

Posted: June 24, 2015
												UPDATE: After the September 3rd patch, there has been a noticeable improvement in performance. The game has added many graphics options that were not previously available, as well as a bar indicating how much VRAM will be used based on your settings. However... there are still some unexplainable problems. While the game tells me that it will run better with motion blur disabled, I get a 5-10 dip in FPS with motion blur disabled. Thats right, the game runs better WITH motion blur. Why? I dont understand. /Update.There is a masterpiece of a game hidden within all the frame rate issues and bugs. I can't recommend the game to ANYONE in this state. It's pathetic, honestly. Patches better roll out SOON.We're almost 48 hours post launch and there hasn't even been word of when a patch will be deployed. I can run the game shakily at around 30 fps right now. I am recieving the "console experience" (Their words, not mine.) My rig is FAR more powerful then the current generation of consoles. Here are my specs.Processor: i7-4770kVideo Card: R9 280x (3 GB VRAM)RAM: 16 gbAlso, Running off of an SSD.DONT BUY THIS GAME UNTIL THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥HAS BEEN FIXED. As to Rockstady/Iron Galaxy/ whoever is responsible for this mess, please dont my most hyped game of 2015 (yes, even moreso then Fallout 4) end on such a tragically pathetic note. I may not be able to refund the game, but I can still refund the season pass.

content:
Posted: February 19
												To fix the FPS drops you have to go to \steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Knight\BMGame\Config and open up BmSystemsettings.ini using notepad and do the following things Change bAllowD3D9MSAA=False to bAllowD3D9MSAA=True Change AllowD3D10=False to AllowD3D10=True Change TextureResolution=1 to TextureResolution=2 Disable Bloom by setting Bloom=False Disable Reflections by setting Reflections=False Set AllowOpenGL=True Save and exitIt's a great game, they have fixed most of the crashes/bugs/glitches and fps drops, but people might still get some fps drops while in certain areas or while you are driving the batmobile. Don't buy the season pass because it is useless, the DLC story missions are only about 30 minutes long each and its a waste of money, however the rest of the DLC are kind of nice, you have different skins which might look better than the original game one.The best DLC is the batmobile skin from the Batman v Superman movie, which looks so much better.*UPDATE*the story is only about 10 hours long, maybe even shorter since it took me a lot of time to finish some of the missions, but if you don't do the side missions or side story, then the game will probably be too short for you.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Definitely a mixed bag. When it works (as it mostly has on my machine), it's the apex of Rocksteady's design. Smart, fun, and varied throughout with a satisfying story, top-tier visuals, and refined gameplay.When it doesn't, it's a mess. Even after the post-release patch I actually suffer more problems now than I ever did at launch, with bugged achievements, frame-rate issues, and horrible audio-skipping on pre-rendered cutscenes.The season pass content should be avoided. Unless you're a sucker for challenge maps, all it really adds are a handful of 10-15 minute "story" missions and a ton of skins. A very high price for what is essentially filler/bonus content.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Where to begin? Batman: Arkham Knight is a game I have mixed feelings about as a PC gamer. The game itself is pretty cool but on the other side it lacks compared to the previous installments.Gameplay: I have spend three hours so far and got a decent grip on the game. It's similar to the previous Arkham games and the controls are more or less the same, they switched a couple of buttons which will confuse any player who played the past 3 games and it will require a bit of getting used to. Biggest change is the Batmobile entering the scene. It's awesome but at the same time it feels cheap to just race around wrecking chaos. The Arkhams series were always about being stealthy and that got tuned down a notch by introducing the Batmobile. All the old tricks are still there and new ones are added like the ''Multi Fear-Take down'' and ''environmental take downs''. It adds some diversity to the combat and it looks great. The Wayne Tech upgrades are back as usual and there is a wide variety to choose from. Batsuit, combat, predator, gadgets etc. There is a quite a bit of farming involved to max it out. Batmans favourite gadgets like the batarang, explosive gel, the line launcher and more are back as well. This time there is also the Batmobile remote which lets you remotely control the Batmobile! Challenges: For me, this is the #1 reason to buy any of the Arkham games. It's what I spend most time on and find the most fun. However, there doesn't seem to be anything else but AR (Augmented Reality) challenges at this point and no playable characters outside the mini-campaigns similar to the Robin mini-campaign in Arkham City. This is an ENORMOUS let down. I'm praying that it's coming with the season pass content but I find it ridiculous that this is not part of the game from the start. Seeing how 3 games had challenges I never thought they would pull a stunt like this. This is the major reason I'm going to give this game a negative review.Graphics & Performance: Batman: Arkham Knight is a good looking game. Unfortunately it's not optimized for PC's. This differs for person to person but in my experience it's a let down. The game is capped at 30 fps at default settings.... What? Why? How? It's 2015 and especially on PC this is outright embarassing. Luckily it can be changed in the INI file but still... It's weird that it isn't uncapped by default. I meet the minimum requirements and still the game has  erratic behaviour when it comes to performance. One moment I'm gliding over Gotham with 60 fps and 10 seconds later it drops massively to 0 fps making the game come to a complete stop before it goes up to 30-60 fps. The amount of settings in the video settings tab is low. There are a couple of settings you can turn on or off which include: Resolution, V-Sync, AA, Shadows, Level of Detail and Textures. Then there are 4 options for Nvidia Gameworks which even on a Nvidia card doesn't seem to work all that well.Because of this I went to the INI file to see if I could adjust things like Depth of Field or Motion Blur, settings which are present in every game to date which you can turn on or off in the video settings. After turning these settings off I had a staggering 100+ fps and I was happy, however, seconds later the game crashed and it wouldn't boot anymore without a CTD. In other words, a very low amount of settings can be adjusted in the INI file which is a total let down for any PC game(r). It seems I have to suck this up and play with the erratic behaviour as a statement from Rocksteady kind of leans towards not polishing this game except for texture pop-ins and other minor issues.Final Verdict: This is the most awesome and at the same time the worst batman arkham game. Besides the performance issues, which are completely unnecessary imo, the lack of challenges is what makes me give this game a negative verdict. The game plays like it should, and the story seems decent but for me it already lacks. Should you buy it? If you have a rig that at least meet the recommended or ultra settings; go for it. Otherwise, be prepared to deal with stuttering and erratic performance. It's playable but that depends entirely on what is acceptable to you. This game is solid in gameplay but simply lacks compared to its predecessors.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This is one of the worst ports I have played.  30 fps cap which can be changed in the ini, but even if you remove it most people aren't able to get over 30. Nvidia and AMD cards both suffer from performance problems. Even newer cards like a 980ti are having problems on certain setups.Every setting I adjust seems to do absolutely nothing. Putting shadows to low removes a decent amount of stuttering, but it's still sitting at the same fps as before. The game seems to be using too much vram. If you set it to use 2GB of vram, it will still go above 2GB. It will try to do the same if you have 3 or 4GB, etc. Some users with 8GB of vram said it was attempting to use all of it as well.This port was also outsourced, just like the previous WB published title to be released on pc, Mortal Kombat X. This follows suit in having a horrible launch. This doesn't even count the non performance related bugs, like completed objective markers sometimes not disappearing and being stuck on your screen. And since the game autosaves, you either suck it up or start over.I didn't think anything could top AC Unity's launch. Refund if you bought it and are able. Stay away until many patches are released, if they ever actually fix these issues.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Batman™: Arkham KnightGPU: EVGA GTX 980 SC ACX 2.0 x2 (Two way SLI)CPU: i7 4790k Stock 4.0Ghz Turbo 4.4GhzRAM: 16GB Corasir Vengance Pro XMP 1866MhzMOBO: ASUS DELUXE Z97OS: Windows 7 Professional 64bitLATEST DRIVERS INSTALLEDHi Guys, just a quick Day 1 performance overview for Batman™: Arkham Knight on my system (above). Just some information for the community is all :)Firstly I ran the game on SLI both cards (NVIDIA RECOMMENDED) in the Control Panel at native 1080p with all settings on MAX buit with NO GameWorks settings on.My benchmark performance was:Average 76fpsMinimum 48fpsI then disabled SLI and ran the same bench on a single card...Average 104fpsMinimum 56fps. SLI is broken. there's no question.After doing this, I ran the single card bench at 1440p native...Average 70fps.I then proceeded to run some GameWorks options, so I turned on Rain - Lights - Paper and ran the benchmark at 1440p with my second GPU set as a dedicated PhysX driver. My average was 76fps. My second GPU got to 27% Usage (for the paper PhysX).I finally ran 2 more benchmarks. The first was all setting maxed out with Rain - Lights - Smoke ON and Paper OFF at 1440p with 1 Card rendering the game and 1 card rendering Smoke (PhysX). My results were:Average 64fpsMinimum 39fpsSecond benchmark was the same but at 1080p.My results were:Average 83fpsMinimum 60fpsResolution plays a huge part in FPS in games as I'd expect. SLI doesn't seem to work at all (Lose Performance when both cards active).NOTE: When I started the game and actually got to the free roam, every 20 feet or so I would stutter. More of a micro stutter. This may just be my system but the more information the better I guess :D.I do rate this as a 'NO' for now due to the lack in performance optimization. But as time goes on and the game gets more updates, this isn't my final decision.- Spongie

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												The Arkham series finishes on a rather sour note. Where to start? I've played each game in the Arkham series and Arkham city is by far the definitive one to play. Some things in City have been removed from Knight, notably challenge maps have been replaced with AR challenges, all of which are found in the single player story, as such, you can't play as any of the semi-playable characters for whichever challenge you choose, that includes the pre-order incentive characters. The game also doesn't seem to add much aside from the Batmobile addition, which in my opinion is absolutely abysmal. It controls very badly, and most challenges rely on the new Batmobile. When freeroaming in the story, you have trouble simply getting from A to B, because in between them are many vehicle based enemies. While this is fine in the way that it gets you something to do, it's cumbersome with all the back and forth running across Gotham you will do.Next, there's the map itself, "Gotham" seems like very little more map space than the previous games. Now quality over quantity should apply here, however all of the little things you have to do aren't very entertaining. All of the side quests based on various characters are fairly good, but some are still some pretty weak combat-fests, instead of anything interesting with the characters. Coming to characters, the story in itself is okay, some things are very reused, and some characters are really lacking in developement.The melee combat you know and love is still present, with very few things added to change it, which was probably a good move on Rocksteady's part considering everything else in the game. It's still satisfying, simple, and smooth. I do enjoy the melee combat, however it's too few and far between when playing through the story. Rocksteady REALLY wants you to play and love their new batmobile.All in all, I wouldn't recommend this game, maybe for a much  lower pricetag in the far future. If you want the definitive Batman experience, pick up Arkham City, and if you've beaten it and need a new Batman game, wait.
