content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I love the Batman Arkham series, I have always been a huge fan of them.  I was waiting for this game to come out on the edge of my seat. I want everyone to know that my poor review is has nothing to do with game play, as I really haven't played the game. It took me all day just to get it to work, in a window with poor quality. My laptop is more then able to handle this game, and it's run the others so beautifully. I got to the opening scene, the movie and because everything is so poor (and though I have to launch it through NVIDA, I can't use any of NVIDA's settings) the game play parts are so jumpy, and turning the camera view with the mouse makes me motion sick. I only have this problem with flight simulators, and never with any of the other games. To get it to work I had to go into the config files of the game, other people have giving step by step instructions on how to do it far better then I could even explain it and change the frame rate per second to 120, and set something else ot 0.0.  I then had to use NVIDA to launch it in a window, turn off all the NVIDA special stuff, set the graphics qualities to normal or lower... and reset the window size to the largest so I could even see what was going on. I think I am going to have to wait until they fix all this to even try to play it because it really does make me sick to my stomach after just a couple minutes of it jerking around.*UPDATE* I was able to get the camera to stop jerking around so much in the walking around, and the first hand to hand fight were you save a cop. Right after that it goes right into the car chase with the Batmobile... and I had to stop playing all together because I got car sick.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Disappointing.  That's the only word I can describe Batman Arkham Knight.  Being a fan of the Arkham series I was pretty much excited when Arkham Knight was announced that I pre ordered it in advance.  I even chose to buy this first over Grand Theft Auto V thinking that Rocksteady studios and Warner bros interactive would bring us the best Batman Arkham game ever considering their track record in the Arkham series and the fact that this is the final game of the trilogy.  But no, they have forsaken the PC gamers for the sake of the console version.  They hired a small 12 man game studio, Iron Galaxy, to make the pc port version who in turn made a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥job and Warner Brothers still released it as is. They could have postponed the PC version a few months late to fix and optimize the PC version but it looks like corporate greed got the best of them.  It goes to show they aren't sincere and doesn't care at all.  At the moment the game runs at 30 fps out of the box.  Sure you can tweak the .ini settings but it only shows how lazy Iron Galaxy was doing their job.  There's not much graphic setting options as well.  Hell, I've even seen texture comparisons between the PC and PS4 version over the internet and the PS4 version was much better hands down.  Unbelievable.Stuttering and fps drops are rampant in-game.  Although it's not that much noticeable in my system (I'm using a GTX 970 and I7 4790k) it does break immersion when it happens.  Even the cutscenes have stuttering from time to time. I shudder to think the experience of other gamers who has an older PC rig than I do.       Warner Bros interactive has lost me as a customer.  They are now up there together with EA and Ubisoft that I will try avoid as much as possible and will never pre order or buy from unless the game they made are optimized properly and has a lot of positive reviews. I will wait for a week to see if they will patch up and fix the optimization issues of Arkham Knight.  If not then it's time for a refund and buy Grand Theft Auto V instead.  At least Rockstar cares for their PC fans.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This is one of the worst ports I have played.  30 fps cap which can be changed in the ini, but even if you remove it most people aren't able to get over 30. Nvidia and AMD cards both suffer from performance problems. Even newer cards like a 980ti are having problems on certain setups.Every setting I adjust seems to do absolutely nothing. Putting shadows to low removes a decent amount of stuttering, but it's still sitting at the same fps as before. The game seems to be using too much vram. If you set it to use 2GB of vram, it will still go above 2GB. It will try to do the same if you have 3 or 4GB, etc. Some users with 8GB of vram said it was attempting to use all of it as well.This port was also outsourced, just like the previous WB published title to be released on pc, Mortal Kombat X. This follows suit in having a horrible launch. This doesn't even count the non performance related bugs, like completed objective markers sometimes not disappearing and being stuck on your screen. And since the game autosaves, you either suck it up or start over.I didn't think anything could top AC Unity's launch. Refund if you bought it and are able. Stay away until many patches are released, if they ever actually fix these issues.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Batman™: Arkham KnightGPU: EVGA GTX 980 SC ACX 2.0 x2 (Two way SLI)CPU: i7 4790k Stock 4.0Ghz Turbo 4.4GhzRAM: 16GB Corasir Vengance Pro XMP 1866MhzMOBO: ASUS DELUXE Z97OS: Windows 7 Professional 64bitLATEST DRIVERS INSTALLEDHi Guys, just a quick Day 1 performance overview for Batman™: Arkham Knight on my system (above). Just some information for the community is all :)Firstly I ran the game on SLI both cards (NVIDIA RECOMMENDED) in the Control Panel at native 1080p with all settings on MAX buit with NO GameWorks settings on.My benchmark performance was:Average 76fpsMinimum 48fpsI then disabled SLI and ran the same bench on a single card...Average 104fpsMinimum 56fps. SLI is broken. there's no question.After doing this, I ran the single card bench at 1440p native...Average 70fps.I then proceeded to run some GameWorks options, so I turned on Rain - Lights - Paper and ran the benchmark at 1440p with my second GPU set as a dedicated PhysX driver. My average was 76fps. My second GPU got to 27% Usage (for the paper PhysX).I finally ran 2 more benchmarks. The first was all setting maxed out with Rain - Lights - Smoke ON and Paper OFF at 1440p with 1 Card rendering the game and 1 card rendering Smoke (PhysX). My results were:Average 64fpsMinimum 39fpsSecond benchmark was the same but at 1080p.My results were:Average 83fpsMinimum 60fpsResolution plays a huge part in FPS in games as I'd expect. SLI doesn't seem to work at all (Lose Performance when both cards active).NOTE: When I started the game and actually got to the free roam, every 20 feet or so I would stutter. More of a micro stutter. This may just be my system but the more information the better I guess :D.I do rate this as a 'NO' for now due to the lack in performance optimization. But as time goes on and the game gets more updates, this isn't my final decision.- Spongie

												The Arkham series finishes on a rather sour note. Where to start? I've played each game in the Arkham series and Arkham city is by far the definitive one to play. Some things in City have been removed from Knight, notably challenge maps have been replaced with AR challenges, all of which are found in the single player story, as such, you can't play as any of the semi-playable characters for whichever challenge you choose, that includes the pre-order incentive characters. The game also doesn't seem to add much aside from the Batmobile addition, which in my opinion is absolutely abysmal. It controls very badly, and most challenges rely on the new Batmobile. When freeroaming in the story, you have trouble simply getting from A to B, because in between them are many vehicle based enemies. While this is fine in the way that it gets you something to do, it's cumbersome with all the back and forth running across Gotham you will do.Next, there's the map itself, "Gotham" seems like very little more map space than the previous games. Now quality over quantity should apply here, however all of the little things you have to do aren't very entertaining. All of the side quests based on various characters are fairly good, but some are still some pretty weak combat-fests, instead of anything interesting with the characters. Coming to characters, the story in itself is okay, some things are very reused, and some characters are really lacking in developement.The melee combat you know and love is still present, with very few things added to change it, which was probably a good move on Rocksteady's part considering everything else in the game. It's still satisfying, simple, and smooth. I do enjoy the melee combat, however it's too few and far between when playing through the story. Rocksteady REALLY wants you to play and love their new batmobile.All in all, I wouldn't recommend this game, maybe for a much  lower pricetag in the far future. If you want the definitive Batman experience, pick up Arkham City, and if you've beaten it and need a new Batman game, wait.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												While the actual gameplay is fun, the PC port is HORRIBLE. It is missing visual effects such as ambient occlusions and rain/water effects that are present in the PS4 version. It lacks SLI support and performs much worse with SLI enabled, you are better off using the 2nd card as a PhysX card with SLI disabled.  The frame rate is not very stable, especially poor performance when driving the batmobile. There are almost no options in the graphics settings, the ability to select high/ultra level textures is missing, you can't change anistropic filtering to 16x (it appears to only be 4x), there is no way to turn off annoying effects like the film grain or the especially horrible chromatic abberation that developers love nowadays, and the motion blur is overboard yet there is no way to disable it or tone it down.As for gameplay, I enjoy the fine tuning they did to the hand to hand combat but there is little guidance regarding all the changes and new abilities.  The batmobile is fun to drive around town, but the less than precise controls are annoying to use in the Riddler batmobile races/challenges. I did enjoy battling other vehicles at first, but it starts to feel repetitive as you progress in the game. Still,  I am having a good time playing the game in spite of these limitations and the horrible port job.  I'd recommend playing the PS4 version instead as the game is worth the time to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Despite me loving every other core Arkham game even Origins I cannot bring myself to recomend this one.The performance is obviously the most well publicised issue. Even after months of patching this game runs very poorly on some machines. I was one of the few lucky ones who had tolerable performance from the start but it was barely tolerable. The patches have improved things a lot for me and the game now runs at fairly steady 50fps, not perfect but a good improvement however there are plenty of people reporting little to no improvement on their systems.The story in Arkham Knight is quite possibly my favourite to date, going to some very interesting and surprising places even if the Arkham Knight's identity quickly becomes obvious to anyone even partially familiar with the batman mythos. It is a shame therefore that the surrounding game leaves so much to be desired. Combat is still the same great arkham formular with enough variation to keep things interesting but don't expect any great innovations. The batmobile on the other hand is brand new and quickly outstays its welcome. From its obtuse control scheme to the way it is hamfistedly inserted into every aspect of gameplay you quickly begin to loathe the frequent sections that require its use. I would often find myself examining at a puzzle or situation for several minutes before realising that, no I don't need to use any of batman's gadgets I just need to call the batmobile and make it shoot things. The game becomes less be the Batman and more be the remote controlled tank. This thing should have been left as a means of transport and nothing more.Playable characters have also been stripped back in the game. While previous games allowed for full control of catwoman (and Robin during a DLC) these characters are relegated to partners, allowed only allowed to be switched to during specific combat situations. Their movesets also seem to have been reduced from Arkham city. I found former combo moves and some gadgets missing from catwoman, nightwing and robin.Speaking of missing things the game has lost challenge mode, replacing it with the vastly inferior AR challenges many of which are character locked. While the brawl challenges feel pretty similar the predator challenges are hugely stripped down and are entirely character specific. Side missions are also fairly neglected with many villaneous favourites relegated to short, unsatisfying missions often ending in lackluster boss fights one of which is directly cloned from a main story mission as if to highlight the lack of effort in the sidequest design.Actually lack of effort seems to sum up a lot of this game, from the poor PC optimisation to the lackluster side missions. Only the main storyline feels like it had effort put in. That and their bizzare quest to shoehorn the batmobile into every gameplay mechanic.A huge disapointment.

This kills me as a huge fan of not just Arkham but all things batman. I was so ready to experience the game, but this may be the one I'll never get unless it gets some SERIOUS love from programmers who know what the heck they're doing.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Some people would say that the game is unplayable even now. I'm sad to hear that, but it works like a charm on my machine.Let's see why you should buy this game, shall we? PROS The combat is as good as it gets. If you like the combat from previous games, you are going to LOVE it in this one. The animations are really good and you can get more use of your gadgets.The story is fine so far. I haven't finished the game yet (waiting for new episodes of Gotham TV series because I like to play Arkham games after watching the show, I know I'm weird). It is nothing special, but it's OK.Graphics are great. I run it on the highest settings, and it looks gorgeous. The Batmobile is a (kinda) fun new addition to the game. CONS The infamous Batmobile is overused.I don't like the Riddler Trophies. I can understand why some people might like it, but I just don't . There are way too many of them, and you need to get them all in order to get the "real ending".Spoiler: The Joker does appear in this game, and I think he shouldn't.  CONSLUSION Arkham Knight is a great Batman game. It had a catastrophic launch, but it is definitely playable now. It's cheap, it's good. Get it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I've put together a new PC system after nearly a decade, just so I can play this game in all it's glory. Boy, I was wrong!Based on my experience with the previous titles (I even enjoyed the maligned "Origins"), this was my first pre-order. I know that many games have day-1 issues, but, come on, this is Rocksteady! My system specs areIntel Core i5 3.4 GHzGTX 970 4GB2x4GB 1600mhz Crucial Ballistix RAMInstalled on a Samsung SSD 840 EVO 250GBWell, from the intro, the video/game engine was a bit stuttery, but as soon as you confronted the "smoking guy" at the diner, the game crashed due to "low memory". OK, it can happen.As soon as the camera zoomed on Batman surveying the city, the camera movements were losing frames. The very impressive seamless change from cut-scene to game, as seen in trailers and promo, was erratic. I tried to deactivate various Gameworks features but the issues persisted. I changed the .ini file in order to have 60fps and it seems to work but there are small and big bugs, causing this to be far from the thrilling experience I expected it to be. It takes away all the joy I had about my new PC and the game. While I KNOW there will be fixes and updates (the uproar is too big to ignore), I am seriously considering a refund and buying the game later on a s sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												the game ran rather well on my rig (16gb ram, i7 core, nvidia 670 gpu) but I found the game to predictable, and in some repsects labored... you were forced to use the vehicle far more than was necessary. it was kind of cool at first but then when most every boss battle you were stuck using that instead of actual hand to hand combat (like they did in origins) it really bummed out the whole experience for me. dont even get me started on the riddler races or trophies... in previous games they were challenging and somewhat annoying sure, but you felt like you actually achieved something when you were done collecting them. on knight however I hated finding and getting each one. I seriously loathed finding them.  the game has a few sweet spots on their delivery and it has some decent challenges, however with this one... it almost feels like they took to many cool things that batman can do and tried to shove as much of it into the game as they possibly could to the point where things felt a little over done... the "keep it simple stupid" montra in my opinion should have been leaned on a bit more in the areas it wasnt and used less in the areas it was heavily incorporated.  anyways thats my opinion. do with it as you will.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Terrible Port, do NOT buy this game! Stutters galore, locked 30 FPS, Textures only go to normal, no Anti-Aliasing options other than "OFF/ON", no mouse sensitivity option...NO MOUSE SENSITIVITY OPTION? Are you kidding me?!Do not support this kind of junk from a so-called "AAA" developer who out-sources the PC Port to a 12 man team... This is not OK!EDITThere have been several patches now and most of what I said above is no longer relevant. I have now played the game for over 20 hours, and I must say it is pretty OK. Performance is much better now on my high-end system (i7 4790K and GTX 980), the game itself is pretty good if you enjoyed the other Arkham games, and the batmobile I did not hate as much as many people did, I suggest throwing some upgrades into it early on to make the long "tank" sections less frustrating and more enjoyable. The story in this game I thought was pretty bad honestly, there were a couple major surprises and themes which I did enjoy, but overall it was kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥♥to be honest. I'm not changing my negative recommendation due to bitterness over the game's release, but at this stage it is probably worth a buy especially if you can get it for $20 or less.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												After spending the day reading the forums about people having problems, I dreaded coming home to see if it would work for me. Uncapped my FPS, which is lame that I had to, and set all settings to the highest possible and 2560x1080 resolution. Launched and luckily for me the experience hasn't been so bad. FPS does drop to the teens while in the batmobile. around 30-60 FPS most of the time otherwise, with a couple skips here and there. Playable but at your own risk. May or may not work. CANNOT recommend the game even though it was free to me. Simply because PC gamers are just getting walked all over. Clearly an untested game. If it weren't free to me, I wouldn't have given them $5 for it. Shame on the devs rocksteady and whoever they sent it to be ported. Unaccetable to launch a game in 2015 without testing what you are sending out. So far, the entire day, the Devs have sent out the canned response, "We are aware and working on the issues." Screw you, you should have known about the problems before you launched the game. RANT OVER-Edit- my system specs for people who are interested. (and probably upset that their system that trumps mine is having more issues)FX-6350 4.19 GHZ Overclocked8GB 1866 RAMGTX-970 EVGA SSCPatriot SSD

												Terrible Port, do NOT buy this game! Stutters galore, locked 30 FPS, Textures only go to normal, no Anti-Aliasing options other than "OFF/ON", no mouse sensitivity option...NO MOUSE SENSITIVITY OPTION? Are you kidding me?!Do not support this kind of junk from a so-called "AAA" developer who out-sources the PC Port to a 12 man team... This is not OK!EDITThere have been several patches now and most of what I said above is no longer relevant. I have now played the game for over 20 hours, and I must say it is pretty OK. Performance is much better now on my high-end system (i7 4790K and GTX 980), the game itself is pretty good if you enjoyed the other Arkham games, and the batmobile I did not hate as much as many people did, I suggest throwing some upgrades into it early on to make the long "tank" sections less frustrating and more enjoyable. The story in this game I thought was pretty bad honestly, there were a couple major surprises and themes which I did enjoy, but overall it was kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥♥to be honest. I'm not changing my negative recommendation due to bitterness over the game's release, but at this stage it is probably worth a buy especially if you can get it for $20 or less.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Let’s start with the issue everyone is talking about. The performance of the game is absolutely atrocious and unacceptable. I have a GTX 980 and I’m getting a very wide range of FPS depending on the situation I'm in. I played the game with the highest settings with Game Works disabled and the 30 FPS cap put up to 60. While fighting the game usually has a steady 60 FPS dropping to 50 FPS once in a while. Using a Batmobile or gliding over Gotham I would usually get around 20-40 FPS. During my play through (which I still haven't fully finished due to multiple game breaking bugs that have set me back) I would get frequent frame drops to about 10 FPS. Now another issue with the game that has come to light is that the game looks worse than the PS4. Texture quality and the lack of AO on PC shows how badly this port was and is unacceptable. Overall on the performance side this is one of the worst in recent history. Warner Brothers decided to use the same company they outsourced the PC port for Batman Origins which was also a mess to some degree and it shows they didn’t learn anything when working on Batman: AK.Performance aside the game is fantastic. Gotham is massive and full of things to do. Side missions are no longer something you have to stumble on and are available on an easy mission select wheel. The amount gadgets available to you are about the same as Arkham City but seem to have more uses. For example the disruptor is a very useful item which in previous iterations of the game could simply disable enemy’s weapons. In AK you can do other things such as electrifying weapon caches or electrifying medics when using their ability to revive downed enemies.Combat in AK has been perfected, the fast paced fist to face beatings are even more fluid than before. The combat makes you feel invincible and a lot of times makes fights way to easy. Like the previous Arkham games as you continue down the story you acquire more gadgets and fight new enemies. This time round there is an even bigger selection of enemy’s to fight. The medic is one in particular that is more of a support for the enemy’s. The medic can revive downed enemies and also electrify them so that you can't touch them for a while. Stealth sections in the game make a return and give you a few more ways to handle the situation with new takedown moves and new types of vents. That and the new uses for a lot of the gadgets make the stealth section a bit more interesting and less frustrating.In Arkham Knight Batman can now use his Batmobile which wasn’t useable in the previous games. The look of the Batmobile is awesome and there are plenty of times during the game were you are reminded of that. The batmobile isn’t just used to get you from point A to B but can also be used to combat the many drone tanks that have taken over the streets of Gotham. The batmobile can change into a tank which controls very well and feels like it can pack a punch. The Batmobile feels very intricate and feels alive. Sadly the Batmobile gets very old very quickly and starts to feel more of a chore than something you want to do. This wouldn’t be an issue if the Batmobile wasn’t used frequently during the Main Story line. There are many sections of the story where the batmobile has to be used in combat and it really becomes a chore. One of the type of drones you have to fight is a drone tank that can only be destroyed from behind, this means you have to basically sneak up behind it in the Batmobile and wait for your weapon to lock on.  Overall the Batmobile is an awesome vehicle and definitely has a place in the game but you start to get the feeling quite quickly that they based too much of the game around it.The story for the Arkham Knight is fantastic and really helps drive the game forward. Many villains return from the previous games and those that don't are usually acknowledged and mentioned a few times during the game. Batman is once again tested to his limits against unimaginable odds. The voice acting is fantastic with a few changes to previous cast such as Jonathan Banks voicing James Gordan and John Nobile voicing Scarecrow.Overall Gameplay and Story are incredible but the performance hinders that to an unforgivable degree. I don't recommend you buy this game till Rocksteady and Iron Galexy (Made the PC port) fix a lot of the bugs and performance issues.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												-No Spoilers here-Batman: Arkham Knight is a hard game to recommend to anyone but a Batman fan. The Game itself in its current state is awful in terms of performance but locking the framerate to 30fps and setting everything to either off or Medium seems to fix any issues (Or follow what Rocksteady have said via the forums). The storyline is hit and miss aswell. I can't go into to much detail without spoiling a few things so I wont but don't expect the story to be all that good aswell as giving you a satisfying ending to what was a great series.The Batmobile is fun to drive around in and it feels like a tank which is good conisdering the enemies have many ways to combat you while driving around Gotham. Which brings me to the size, Gotham isn't as open as I'd of liked but its still pretty huge (Around double the size of Arkham City). Its filled with things to do and see, Criminals to apprehend as well as the usual trophies/riddles to complete.If I had to give this game a numbered score:Performance: 4/10Story: 6/10Gameplay: 8/10

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												It's absolutely astonishing that any developer would release a game in this condition. Prior to installing and playing the game I had convinced myself that the bulk of poor reviews were some sort of a smear campaign, or just a result of wildly high expectations. That just isn't the case. This game really is damn near unplayable in its current form. I could go over every issue I have experienced thus far, but then I would just end up parroting what everyone else has written, as the technical issues of this game appear to be affecting virtually everyone, with no hardware bias whatsoever. So I'll just say this.If you picked this up on Steam, request a refund. If you picked it up via a 3'rd party key site, request a refund. If you got your copy with the purchase of a graphics card and can't get a refund just uninstall the game. You'd be better of using that 38 gigs of space for storing multiple copies of the critically panned 1997 movie Batman and Robin, because unlike Batman: Arkham Knight, at least Batman and Robin runs at a solid 24 FPS no matter the hardware.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												It's not as memorable as Arkham City and it doesn't have the same atmosphere as Arkham Asylum, but in terms of graphics and gameplay, Arkham Knight is incredible.The PC version of this game will go down in history as one of the worst ports ever from a western publisher. Although it still has a few issues like the ridiculous VRAM usage, which ends up causing some pretty significant stuttering and slowdown, for 90% of the time the game performs absolutely fine and on top of that, it might be the best looking third person action game I've ever played. The textures, shadows and lighting in this game are all absolutely stunning. Now here's the thing with Arkham Knight on PC: You NEED at least 3GB of VRAM to be able to run  it at 1080p or higher. If not, the PS4 version is the way to go (Assuming you own a PS4 to begin with).I honestly think this is a fantastic game (100+ Hours on my PS4), and assuming you have the hardware to run it, the PC version, as of today, blows the PS4 version out the water.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												If you liked Arkham City, you'll like this game too. It still has loads of irritating Riddler content popping up everywhere but you don't have to do that stuff if you don't want to, just like in City. The combat and stealth are as fluid and fun as ever.Quick performance note as of March 17th, 2016: I'm running on an i5-3470 at 3.9 Ghz, GTX 970 @ 1350 Mhz, 16 GB of DDR3-1600 RAM, and I have the game installed on a Samsung 840 EVO SSD, running Windows 10.I'm running with a 60 fps cap and all of the regular settings turned on, but the Gameworks settings turned off. I get 60fps while walking or driving slowly, mostly 60 fps while flying with occasional dips to 57-58 fps, and about 50 fps while driving fast. I went ahead and turned motion blur on, and with that on I've found the drops to about 50 fps generally don't bother me and there's no micro-stuttering. The issues with motion blur that the game had on launch seem to have been resolved.As a test, I went ahead and removed half my RAM and ran it with just 8 GB. It immediately started stuttering. Over 8 seems to be a requirement for this game.That said, for me at least, performance is squarely in the "playable" category and so I can recommend trying the game as of now.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												Batman Arkham Knight Review:CEO: We are going to release a 2.5gb patch to our gameEmployee: And what will we improveCEO: Well we'll make it run worse than before and add literally nothing elseEmployee: I said improveCEO: Oh, sorry. I misheard. I thought you said "how are we gonna get MORE NEGATIVE REVIEWS ON STEAM".Performance:This game runs horribly. I used to run at low settings, 1080p, with AA and 8x Anisotropic filtering, and run at a solid 60fps. Now I run 900p with AA off and 2x Anisotropic, and the game runs at 40fps. Rocksteady need to sort out their PC port. They had to relaunch there game because of the port, and it went from bad at launch, better after an update, to worse than ever after a 2.5gb patch. Gameplay:The batmobile in the game seems a bit overused. It is used for a lot of puzzles, and gets a bit boring. The combat is as fun as ever, utilizing counters a lot. Rocksteady have added some new moves as well. The new gadgets such as the remote hacking device are fun and well utilized, and are actually very useful in many situations. For example, you can knockout a goon by turning on the escalator, or setting off an explosion. I do find it quite funny that once a goon is knocked out, you can shoot them as much as you like with your lethal cannons and guns on the batmobile. Of course they are not dead though, because that would make it too dark.Missions:There is a good variety of story missions in the game, and a lot of side missions as well. An example of variety in the story is  Scarecrow fills the city streets with fear toxin and you must travel around the city on the rooftops. The final mission of the game involves running around as joker destroying weeping angel like statues of batman.  At this point, I have finished the story, and it is a good length. It did not drag on like Saints row (my opinion as Saints row IV got very boring as I played the story), and is not too short like Mirrors Edge (an enjoyable game, but I was finished with the story within 3 hours). The side missions contain a lot of the regular batman villians, like Two Face and Penguin, and involve stopping their crime gangs for good. These are fun, and give you a lot of upgrade points, which like the other batman games, let you upgrade gadgets, and unlock new moves.Conclusion:Batman: Arkham Knight is a very fun game. The story is enjoyable, and even 29 hours in I am enjoying slowy completing all the quest lines. I just wish that Rocksteady would fix their PC port. It makes the game in some cases unplayable, and I will most likely be refunding the game when I get the oppurtunity.Performance score: 3 (at least it boots up)Gameplay score: 8 (excessive use of the batmobile)Missions score: Side missions: 9 (a lot of batmobile use, but feels satisfying to take down crime gangs and villians)                          Story missions: 9 (great ending, and lots of variety. Again, a lot of batmobile use)OVERALL SCORE: 6 (not reccomended on PC because of performance, but if you own a console, buy it on that peasant machine)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Product received for free
												They fixed it!  Thank heavens they fixed the PC port!  I had kinda lost interest in the Arkham series, due mostly to them moving to xbox one and ps4 (I had played the first 3 on the 360, but I don't feel like getting another console).  So when I heard that the game was fixed and a cousin bought me this game on my birthday, I fired it up and...  It was a bit laggy, but I updated my video card drivers, it ran...almost perfectly.  (GTX 770 4 GB for those wondering).All I can say is, I'm sorry.  I'm sorry Arkham series, I'm sorry I doubted you, I'm sorry I thought you were just a pretty trailer with no substance.  But the game is excellent, it's not perfect, but it is fantastic.  If you're a Batman fan and have played the others in the series, get this game now.  My only complaint (more nitpicks really) is that the Batmobile feels a bit forced in, I mean it makes sense, but it still feels a bit out of place in terms of controls anyway, in terms of the story it makes some sense, but it's controls are a bit odd.  Partially due to the fact that you use it as a tank as well as the vehicle you get around the city with (which I think you can still glide and grapple around the city faster than the batmobile still, but anyway).  The controls are not horrible or unbearable, it's just...different but kudos for trying.All in all, Arkham fans, get this game.

The issues with motion blur that the game had on launch seem to have been resolved.As a test, I went ahead and removed half my RAM and ran it with just 8 GB. It immediately started stuttering. Over 8 seems to be a requirement for this game.That said, for me at least, performance is squarely in the "playable" category and so I can recommend trying the game as of now.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												I have been waiting a couple of months after i purchased the game, hoping that the developers would have fixed the stack of bugs. They fixed some, but not nearly alot.The game runs better after the optimizations they have made, i can actually play normally now but i keep crashing frequently. It's frustrating that you crash out of hard parts and need to start over from your last checkpoint.The game crashed for more than a total of 50 times and i am not being funny there, that's the minimum amount, it can't possibly be less. There are also small bugs during flights, you suddenly freezing or standing still for example. Or falling through an interior or world texture.The game is great, the game is awesome. I love the game, i am a big fan of the batman series.Never made a game me so angry while playing it, it is too damn bugged. I literally broke a key from my keyboard. Gotta buy a new keyboard now and that costs me more money than i had paid for the game which i Pre-order'd.The game is a huge improvement from the previous Batman games. It's awesome that you get to use the batmobile now, you still solve riddles, crimes and keep doing the things you did in the previous batman games.The story is great, the graphics are great and so it the atmosphere. There are alot of easter eggs and funny things that you will find along the way while playing.I would recommend the game for Playstation or Xbox but NOT on PC. The game is great, but the experience had been ruined for me.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Obviously I played the PC version, but from what I hear the PS4 version runs fine, I dont know of the Xbone. As for PC it doesn't funtion properly on anything, sopposedly even worce on AMD.I managed to play just over an hour, after quitting the game to take a break, and disable motionblur from the ini files, the game no longer starts.First off, there is a 30FPS cap that can only be chaged my editing the ini files. While this is incredibly easy to do, it is in my opinnion unacceptable. Even after raising the cap to 60, I can barely maintain 32 FPS while driving the batmobile around. However I CAN get 60 FPS when I not in the batmobile, while not moving, on a rather tall roof. Apparently moving in the enviroment is incredibly tasking, makes doing challenges involving the batmobile a  fun challenge. With the low FPS I can't even seem to detect the target vehicles easily, I simply cant distinguish a moving target instantly, I cant even respond to everything the game shows me.I can't say for other issues, other than the game being broken it seems like something I could enjoy, animations, graphics, UI (save the map), controls. All that is arguably good, it is apparent even with the performance issues.I wanted to play some more, but the game has decided to chrash on startup without fail.Additional notes: Ran for a while with a i5 3570K @4.2Ghz, paired with a GTX 970 Gigabyte G1 (in a 4x PCI-e 3.0 slot if that matters, didn't seem to hurt other games) 16GB of RAM. Game installed on a 2x 500GB HDD RAID 0, read speeds ~300MBps according to crystal diskmark.From what I have observed trying to validate the games files deletes the game, and then proceeds to redownloading all ~33GB of it.EDIT: I would request a refund, but I got this game with my GPU, so steam cant help there as I never game them money for it. Maybe Nvidia will offer compensation, maybe not, they better, there is a ♥♥♥♥♥torm in the brewing for not only the game, but Nvidia and AMD alike.If you want a batman game get one of the predecessors of this game, they haven't had such issues.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Update after it was put back on Steam:So the "re-release" still has serious performance problems, especially if you're on Windows 10, where Rocksteady's solution is "just have 12 gigs of memory". To add insult to injury, by way of half-arsed apology they're handing out copies of the other Batman games, which you probably already own if you're playing the final episode. Poor show. Very poor show.Oh, and a bunch of reviews are now marked "early access" or "pre-release", which is just a damn lie. The game was released when those reviews were made, and it was a MESS. Update: I tried the DLC that they spent so much time pushing with pre-order begging. You'd have to try hard to make the Harley episode last longer than 10 minutes. I saw the Red Hood DLC on a friend's console, and that's the same. They're just the Campaign Challenges from previous Arkham games, but shorter and less satisfying. Very disappointing and quite insulting after the ridiculous advertising they put behind them.Original review:There's a decent game in there (The first half of the story is genuinely amazing, and while it peters out after that, the mechanics are solid enough to enjoy*), but the performance issues are terrible; I had textures that looked like they might be at home on a Playstation 2 game and still couldn't it to run smoothly, while Witcher 3 will quite happily run on the same setup with most of the options on high or better. I should be getting at least the same kind of quality as you see on, say, the XBox version, but it just isn't happening.I couldn't recommend this game until it has been properly optimised to run at a respectable frame rate. Even then, I'd hesitate; Performance is terrible across all hardware configurations, and that isn't some random bug that could be easily missed. Rocksteady and Warner Bros *knew* that performance was terrible, but they went ahead and released it at €50 anyway, or damn near €100 for the "premium" edition. That's a very deliberate action that shows they just don't care about PC releases.*Except the Batmobile. Now, maybe it genuinely handles like a drunken shopping trolley, or maybe it was down to the abysmal performance issues, but it just wasn't satisfying to drive anywhere. I stuck to flying about unless I was forced to use the car.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												After playing video game since the early 80's I can honestly say, this is the worst game release I have ever experienced HANDS DOWN!!! And I can say this with all honesty and little drama. In short, I can not reccommend this game at all. The quality and lack of concern mean it may never be resolved to a satisfactory standard. Nothing I have seen from WB is encouraging at all.WB knew this game was not ready for release and did it anyway. Along with Rocksteady's collusion, I may add. As a cold buisness decision. And sadly this was not the first time they have done something of this like before and certainly not since, as those of us who bought the game are aware.After a dysmal start, the reports are the patches 4 months after release are still not allowing the game to work properly, and the loyal customers who bought thus game along with season pass, have got nothing in goodwill but cold and frankly out of touch responses and gestures from Warner Brothers.Nothing from the pre release, to the re-release so far, has much in the way of accountability. Such to the extent that by mid summer nothing surpised me about how poor the next course of action (or lack of it) would be. I just knew something was awful was going to happen next, it was just hard to predict what. That longer this saga has gone on, the worse it has gotten. This is way past turd polishing now.WB have shown little interest resolving this, and making amends. Four months on and the game still does not work very well, and a token "Gift" to owners of the game of a copy of each of the Batman Arkham games most of us already have. And WB surely know it.Edit: Worth noting that many reviews have been listed as pre release, that have marked it down. They are in fact not pre release, but those who have bought the game at release in June 23 2015. So please be aware of this misconception.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Boring game. Ironically, my issues have nothing to do with the lousy PC port. After a couple minor settings changes, I can play the game at a reasonable clip. Part of what made the Arkham series so special, though, was the visceral hand-to-hand close quartered combat. With  well implemented mechanics, each battle was exciting and satisfying. Wether you liked the more stealthy challenges or taking out a mob with 'batarangs blazing', the previous Arkham titles drew you in to the action in ways few other games could. So I had to wonder what the hell they were thinking making the Batmobile the centerpiece of their latest effort? Maybe they thought they had taken the fighting mechanics about as far as they could? Who knows? But I have never been more frustrated by such awful driving mechanics. Tedious and  annoying I found my self gritting my teeth and clenching my fists as I plowed through the inane Batmobile 'missions', which you have to do to advance the story through nearly (what feels like) 60% of the game.Not even the interesting Batman/Joker schizophrenic illness or some cool new characters could save this mess. After 16 hours, I stopped caring. Congratulations Rocksteady, you've ruined a great series.Maybe your Batmobile can take its place among the other 'greats' like the 1971 Pinto, the 1957 Edsel Corsair or the 1987 Yugo. I'd ask for my money back, but I've played too long ... and 16 hours is way way too long.Lesson learned.

I don't know who this game is for, or where it merited an M rating.

The Arkham games are my favourite games of all time, so this has shaken my faith severely and negatively affected my playing experience.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												I've been wanting to review this game since it was first released in June, but I held back because of the game being pulled from the Steam store and the fact that it was still messy after it was released again. But I decided to review the game anyway, but I'm going to start off with one important thing.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC.Yes, although I'm giving this game a positive review, this review is based on the game just in general, not solely the PC version. Since I only played it on PC, there will be some bias here. However, I'm going to try and keep this review as generalized towards all console versions as possible. GraphicsThe heaviest blow compared to the other versions, Arkham Knight's graphics were indeed just "meh" compared to the other versions of the game. That being said, however, it's still a fairly pretty game. The rain looks pretty for me, and is used nicely. However, the overall feel I had with the game wasn't all that "dark" or "evil," but rather just bland. The atmosphere wasn't all that thrilling for the most part. But then again, PC bias could just be kicking in here.GameplayThe combat is the smoothest out of all of the Arkham games. It's fast-paced, intense, and very fluid. I had a blast beating up thugs and is one of the strongest points Arkham Knight has to offer. The Batmobile is the main part I would like to discuss about the gameplay. I wasn't AGAINST the Batmobile being in the game. Seeing how large Gotham City is, I wouldn't mind having some quick transportation to get from one place to another. It didn't disappoint for the most part in game. However, my main qualm with it all is the fact that the Batmobile was crammed into the game as much as possible. If you want to show off a new feature to a game, that's fine, but abusing it just ruins the experience. The tank form is especially annoying to me. You'll soon realize that 90% of the time, you're just destroying wave after wave of drone vehicles when you could just face the militia soldiers head-on. This leads to the "boss fights" to be incredibly disappointing. The side missions were also fairly interesting, but I wasn't entirely hooked to them. They were satisfactory, but nothing to write home about. In the end, the gameplay is definitely a mixed bag that's still above average.StoryThe story is definitely the best part to Arkham Knight. It was actually very entertaining and kept me on the edge of my seat. The scenes with the Joker were especially interesting. Sometimes, they might be really annoying, but I could still manage them. When the game reached the climax, I was actually genuinely WORRIED whether or not Batman would be able to survive the wrath of Scarecrow or not. The final mission was amazing and also mind-bending. Plus, the twists were very well played and added onto the very enjoyable main story. The one glaring flaw with the storyline in my eyes was the fact that the Arkham Knight's identity is fairly predictable if you're a Batman fan like myself. But, there wasn't many other people cut for the Arkham Knight role, so it was a reasonable choice. The side mission stories were somewhat decent, but it depends on which one you're doing. But, in the end, the main storyline is awesome and was an excellent way to end the Arkham series.AudioNot much to say here when it comes to music. When it comes to voice acting, it's a mixed bag. On one hand, you have people like Joker and Scarecrow, who were interesting and enjoyable to listen to. Batman, however, wasn't the best when it came to voice acting. He seemed very cheesy, and although that's what he's often known for, it didn't feel right in a game like this.ReplayabilityDespite Arkham Knight's large world full of different things to do, you more than likely won't get too much replayability out of the game. Aside from 100%ing it, you won't stick around for long unless you worship the game. There isn't really much else to say, as it depends on how much you enjoy the game.VerdictArkham Knight is definitely not the best Arkham game in the series. However, it isn't a horrible game. There was so much potential with the game that it isn't deserving of a GotY award in my eyes, but it's still a fairly enjoyable experience that you should be able to have some fun with the game.Graphics - 7.5/10Gameplay - 7.0/10Story - 9.0/10Audio - 7.5/10Replayability - 6.5/10.:7.9/10:.+Excellent way to finish off the series+Villain voice acting was very well done+Smooth and fluid combat+Main story was interesting from start to finish-Side missions were usually fairly boring-Batmobile was overused-Very disappointing boss battles-Graphics seemed bland

												There it is: Arkham Knight sucks! Somehow this game has some nice moments. But you´ll find them in Asylum and in City before. There´s been enough said and written about the crappy status at launch, now the game should run somehow. But the total game killer for me is the Batmobile. At first I liked it and the moment you first enter it feels great. - But a couple of hours later when you start to realize how strong this game is built around the Batmobile it´s just a big immersive killer for me. This overpowered tank (imho) has nothing to do with the Batman universe I know. - And please where the **** should The Riddler know the complete drive-and action abilities of the Batmobile so he can build his riddles around it... Please...So if you liked the first two so much as I do leave this game out of your libary. It is a huge disappointment in relation to it´s predecessors.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												With the overwhelming amount of negative reviews that address nothing about the game itself but rather its poor launch (which has since been patched and its performance vastly improved), I feel compelled to cast my vote in the “recommended” column as this is a tremendous finish to one of the best action/adventure videogame series ever. Arkham Knight is a Batman game for the new generation - everything fans love about the series returns amplified & refined in ways not possible on older platforms. The environment is denser, much of it interactive and teeming with detail, the already great beat 'em up combat system is added to & improved upon, enemy AI is noticeably better, the movement is more fluid & dynamic and enhances the ways in which you navigate the landscape, the weather & atmosphere change dramatically throughout the course of the game, the set pieces are remarkably grand in scale, sound design is stellar (including one of the best videogame soundtracks in recent memory), and Gotham - while slightly smaller overall - is more vibrant and fully conceived than ever.Arkham Knight doesn't have much going for it in terms of innovation; rather, it builds off the brilliant foundation the series began with in Arkham Asylum. As with its predecessors, you're tasked with main storyline missions and a dozen-odd side quests to undertake. This being the final chapter in the saga, it goes out with all cylinders firing. The dark surrealism from the previous games is still present, as is the sense of mystery & tension, the action-packed, free roaming-based variety of missions, and the extremely colorful cast of characters (I'd argue that Batman has the best villains of any superhero franchise). What Arkham Knight lacks in innovation it makes up for in refinement, excellent writing & execution, and the addition of the Batmobile, which gives players an incredible amount of new things to do. While grappling and gliding from building to building remains the fastest way to reach your destination (and is faster and more responsive than ever), I often found myself taking the Batmobile instead because driving it is amazingly fun. It defies physics in the best possible ways - you rarely drive into things and need to reverse because so much of the environment is interactive and the Batmobile just plows through almost anything in your way. It switches to combat mode at the touch of a button, instantly turning it into a tank that handles more like a levitating quadruped than a four-wheel vehicle. You'll find yourself catching details you may miss when gliding over them and wind up taking on an arbitrary task or ten before finally reaching your intended destination. The Batmobile is also creatively incorporated into environmental puzzles that are solved by remotely controlling it from a separate location.It's truly a shame that the initial PC release was so poorly optimized that it's tainted the game's reputation forever, as the subsequent fixes have solved many of those issues and left us with a very playable game. Naturally, performance varies from system to system - on my i7-5930k / GTX 1070 build, this runs at maximum graphics settings with the highest framerate (sadly, there is a framerate lock, but at least it goes up to 90FPS), and at worst, the framerate will dip on occasion, though never to the point where it's detrimental to the overall experience - but even on older or mid-range PCs, this has made vast strides from where it began. Arkham Knight lives up to the epic scope of of the Batman Arkham series and concludes it with honors. Apart from the main story missions, you have a lot side quests to cover (Riddler trophies & challenges, AR training & challenge missions that test your skills and wits in various gameplay scenarios, capture- and defend-the-base type missions, character-based subplots that offer insight into a handful of Gotham's supervillains), and while it may not quite live up to the near-perfect grandeur of Arkham City, Arkham Knight sits right alongside it in terms of quality and surpasses it in some areas. I had my doubts after Arkham Origins' many missteps and blunders, but this is a fitting end to the series that no fan should miss out on.(My nomination for "Villain Most In Need Of A Hug" in the 2016 Steam Awards)
